English more powerful than Hindus since latter were late at distribution of qualities. (Both defecating, but Hindu must wash, while Englishman uses paper.)
Why Egyptians are fond of asses.
Why Jews keep aloof from other peoples.
Distribution and differentiation of people miscellaneous.
Differentiation between "free" (saer) and "unfree" (daer).
Creation of animals.
Creation of animals by God.
Creation of animals by creator.
Culture hero creates useful animals.
All animals created in couples.
Animals created to serve man.
Creation of animals through transformation.
Animals from transformations after deluge or world calamity.
Creator sent for water: Meantime animals assume present forms.
Animals from various transformed objects.
Animals from transformed cloth.
Animals from bark thrown on ground.
Animals created from earth.
Buffaloes emerge from earth, the first man holding the tail of last one.
Animals from transformed man.
Animals from Pharaoh's drowned army. From the army crossing the Red Sea came the various animals.
Animals from men transformed for discourtesy to God (Jesus).
Seven whistlers are the souls of the Jews who crucified Christ.
Animals from transformed men according to favorite food. One man asks for flesh, one for blood, etc. They are changed to mice, cats, and bugs.
Animals from transformed survivors of shipwreck.
Animals from transformed ogre or giant.
Animals from different parts of body of slain giant. Giant person, cow, ox, etc.
Animals from transformed parts of the body (animal or human).
Animals from body of slain person.
Animals from severed fingers of woman.
Animals from transformed hair.
All living things from Jesus' spattered blood.
Animals from parts of body of deity or saint.
Animals from spittle of deity (saint).
Animals from body dirt of deity (hero).
Primordial animal mutilated to produce present form.
Creation of animals as punishment.
Creation of animals as punishment for beating forbidden drum.
Creation of animals to take revenge.
Creation of animals as punishment for incest.
Animals from frogs sent as one of Egypt's plagues.
Animals created through opposition of devil to god.
The devil's animals and God's. In the contest between God and the devil, certain animals are made by each.
Mouse created by Lucifer; cat by Michael to destroy mouse.
Devil's unsuccessful creation produces certain animals.
Devil produces animals only in God's name. He tries unsuccessfully without using God's name.
Dualism of animal creation.
Animals created while god Mahadeo quarrels with his wife.
Creation of animals from unusual primeval mating.
Animals from mating of sun and moon.
Animals born from primeval mating of snake and person.
Creation of animals other motifs.
Giant ox ancestor of all animals.
Animals vomited up by creator.
Animals emerge from tree.
Animals drop from clouds.
Creation of mammals.
Creation of felidae.
Creation of cat.
Cat from transformed eagle. Eagle mistakes stick of wood for fish and gets feet caught. Wind blows off feathers and makes hair.
Creation of cat: sneezed from lion's nostrils. Devil as mouse gnaws hole in bottom of ark. Noah asks lion's help. Lion sneezes and cat comes from lion's nostril and eats mouse.
Cat of divine origin; is really praying when he purrs.
Creation of tiger.
Creation of jaguar.
Creation of mustelidae.
Creation of otter.
Creation of sea otter.
Creation of marten.
Creation of canidae and other carnivora.
Creation of dog.
Dog created as watch-dog for Jesus. Jesus, left to watch the herd, creates the dog to drive off the wolf.
First lapdog in Ireland.
Creation of fox.
Creation of wolf.
Devil makes wolf; God gives him life.
Wolf from man transformed by magician.
Wolf as God's dog.
Creation of coyote and other canidae.
Creation of coyote.
Creation of jackal.
Creation of hyena.
Creation of bear.
Origin of seal.
Origin of walrus.
Creation of rodentia.
Creation of mouse.
Creation of mouse by devil in ark.
Mice engendered after flood from rottenness: no mice on ark.
Creation of rat.
Why we have rats: one escapes from slaughter of rats.
Creation of hare (rabbit).
Creation of mongoose.
Creation of porcupine.
Creation of primata.
Creation of monkey.
Monkeys from children hidden by Eve when God visited her.
Creation of monkeys: old woman thrown into fire. In unsuccessful imitation of Christ, the smith throws an old woman into the fire. She becomes a monkey.
Creation of monkey: lazy man.
Creation of ape.
Creation of baboon.
Creation of ungulata.
Creation of hog (pig).
God's urine used to make pig.
Origin of wild boar.
Origin of peccary.
Creation of hippopotamus.
Creation of camel.
Origin of deer.
First deer in Ireland introduced by Tuatha Di Danann.
Origin of reindeer.
Creation of moose (elk).
Creation of caribou.
Creation of cow.
First cattle in Ireland.
Creation of bison (buffalo).
Origin of wild and domestic buffalo.
Creation of horse.
Horse lives from time of Adam on.
Creation of white horse. Man takes skin of horse and substitutes a white bedspread.
Creation of ass.
Creation of ass: proud horse.
Creation of sheep.
First sheep in Ireland.
Creation of mountain sheep.
Creation of goat.
Creation of elephant.
Creation of ungulata miscellaneous.
Creation of tapir.
Creation of other mammals.
Creation of mole.
Creation of bat.
Creation of anteater.
Creation of armadillo.
Creation of birds.
Various birds from Pharaoh's drowned army.
God makes birds, devil reptiles.
The oldest bird.
Creation of passeriformes.
Creation of lark.
Creation of thrush (nightingale).
Creation of thrush.
Creation of nightingale.
Creation of robin.
Creation of swallow.
Creation of titmouse.
Creation of crow (raven).
Creation of jay.
Creation of magpie.
Creation of blackbird.
Creation of finch.
Creation of sparrow.
Creation of myna (bird).
Creation of faiconiformes.
Creation of vulture.
Creation of hawk.
Creation of kite.
Creation of charidriiformes.
Creation of plover (known as seven whistlers).
Origin of snipe.
Snipe from man admitted neither to heaven nor to hell.
Creation of sandpiper.
Creation of sandpiper: Pharaoh's cook calls drowned army to dinner.
Creation of gull.
Gull from transformed cat. A cat catches a strong fish with her claws. The fish carries the cat on its back to the sea, where the gull originates from the cat.
Gull a transformed ravished maiden. While he is sleeping, the maiden the hero has stolen is ravished by another man. The hero thereupon turns her into a gull.
Creation of quail.
Creation of pigeon.
Creation of sea pigeon.
Creation of dove.
Creation of coraciiformes.
Creation of the kingfisher.
Creation of hoopoe. Transformed shepherd.
Creation of woodpecker.
Woodpecker from devil's herdsman transformed. The devil strikes his herdsman so that he turns into a bird who continually calls after his beloved cow.
Creation of owl.
The owl is a baker's daughter who objected to the size of the dough put into the oven for Jesus when he appeared in her house as a beggar.
Creation of ciconiiformes.
Creation of bittern.
Bittern from Pilate transformed.
Bittern from transformed shepherd.
Creation of stork.
Creation of miscellaneous birds.
Creation of diver (bird).
Origin of swan.
Origin of swans from two fowls fed in Urd's well.
Creation of duck.
Creation of chicken.
Creation of crane.
Creation of cuckoo.
Cuckoo a transformed baker.
Creation of parrot.
Creation of peacock.
Creation of papiha.
Creation of insects.
Insects from body of slain monster. Usually the monster is burnt; sometimes the insects come from his head, sometimes from his body as it burns.
Insects from brains, blood, and bones of slain helpful animal.
Origin of insects from various experiences of saint.
The god Mahadeo turns wood chips into insects.

Origin of insects: released from sack. God places them in a sack and gives it to hare to carry to stream. He must not look in the sack. When he does so the insects escape. The hare laughs and this is the cause of his split lip.
Insects from devil's post-hole. Devil is given enough land to dig a post-hole. From this come all kinds of insects. To stop them a burning log is put in the hole. Insects therefore hate smoke.
Origin of insects: God throws sand on lazy shepherds.
Origin of insects: monstrous births from brother-sister incest.
Creation of hymenoptera.
Creation of ant.
Creation of ant by devil.
Creation of ant: avaricious man transformed.
Creation of bee.
Creation of honey-bees: transformed man.
Creation of bee to provide wax for candles in church.
First bees in Ireland.
God sends stinging bees to punish men.
Creation of hornet.
Creation of coleoptera.
Creation of beetle.
Beetle's special sacredness.
Creation of diptera.
Creation of fly.
Creation of fly: punishment for laziness.
Flies on the ark. Noah tries to keep them out. Devil says that either the flies go in or he does. Noah chooses the lesser of two evils. Later the devil slips in nevertheless.
Creation of flea.
Creation of flea: punishment for laziness.
Creation of flea: to give women work.
Origin of flea: from squirrel.
Creation of flea: God plagues the devil with fleas.
Creation of gnat.
Gnats created by devil to worry God.
Origin of gnats in Lapland.
Origin of mosquitoes.
Deity's wife creates mosquitoes to drive her husband out of jungle.
Mosquitoes created by goddess to make sleeping outside impossible to men.
Deity creates mosquitoes to irritate other gods.
Mosquitoes from bones of slain demon flung into the air.
Mosquitoes from ashes of bad woman.
Creation of lepidoptera.
Creation of butterfly.
Creation of hemiptera.
Creation of louse.
Louse created to give women work.
Creation of bugs.
Creation of maggots.
Creation of orthoptera.
Creation of cockroach.
Origin of cockroach in Finland.
Origin of locust.
Creation of cricket.
Creation of grasshopper.
Creation of miscellaneous insects.
Origin of spider.
Arachne transformed to spider: vies with goddess in spinning.
Origin of scorpion.
Origin of leaf-scorpion.
Origin of mantis.
Creation of fireflies.
Creation of lac insects.
Creation of fish.
Creation of particular fishes.
Creation of pike.
Creation of mullet.
Origin of olachen.
Creation of mackerel.
Origin of bonito.
Origin of salmon.
Origin of flounder.
Origin of flounder from Virgin Mary's half-eaten fish.
Origin of sole.
Origin of catfish.
Creation of eel.
Creation of prawns.
Origin of whale.
Origin of narwhal.
Creation of leviathan.
Creation of sharks: from a savage tribe.
Creation of reptiles.
Creation of snake (serpent).
Origin of horned serpent.
Snake from blood of slain monster. Medusa.
Snake preserved in ark: to stop hole with tail.
Snake created to suck poison from earth.
Snake from devil's slaver.
Adder harmful to holy person transformed to blindworm.
Creation of crocodile.
Creation of tortoise (turtle).
Creation of lizard.
Creation of chameleon.
Origin of salamander.
Origin of amphibia.
Origin of toad.
Origin of frog.
Origin of miscellaneous animal forms.
Origin of crustaceans.
Origin of crayfish.
Crayfish from devil's fleas shaken off in water.
Creation of crab.
Origin of lobster.
Origin of shrimp.
Origin of snail.
Origin of worm.
Origin of silkworm.
Origin of leech.
Origin of earth-worm.
Origin of cutworm.
Origin of multipede.
Cause of animal characteristics.
All qualities of animals appear with their creation.
Animal characteristics: change in ancient animal.
Animal characteristics: accidental action of ancient animal.
Lynx views country from mountainside: cause of his squint.
Rabbit laughs: cause of hare-lip.
Wolf falls out of nest: cause of straight back.
Why some whales die on land: first whale did so.
Shrew blows nose into snout. Sent after fire, he finds but a little which he tries to revive by hard blowing.
Spider carries large stone on head and drops it: hence spiders under stones.
Birds cling to sky in flood: cause of tail colors.
Lizard dips head in palm-oil: cause of red head.
Lizard swallows fish bone: hence head bobs up and down.
Tortoise left out in rain: hard shell develops.
How rattlesnake became harmful: earthworm feeds him chili pepper.
Buffalo helps tiger quench fire: white mark left on buffalo's neck where tiger held on while being ducked in water.
Stag defeated by snail vomits his gall-bladder.
Rat defecates on octopus's head: origin of tubercles on head.
Goddess scatters pubic hairs on fish: why he has so many bones.
Animal characteristics from great fear.
Frightened rabbit puts head in charred tree: hence black ears.
Frightened animals scatter: cause of present habitat of each.
Animal characteristics from squeezing or stretching ancient animal.
Ancient animal squeezed: hence small size.
Animal pressed: hence facial or bodily marks.
Wildcat's (Lynx's) face mashed in.
Tortoise pressed into earth: hence humpy back.
Baboon pressed on hot, flat rock: hence bald place on his back.
Why lobster is shallow: insulted cattle step on it.
Animals' size increased by stretching.
Animal characteristics changed by stretching.
Coyote's muzzle pulled out long.
Fox's tail pulled out long.
Mouse's nose pulled out long.
Animal characteristics from being struck.
Mole struck on head in attempt to steal fire: hence his flat head.
Fish struck by coconut: hence flat tail.
Animal characteristics from dropping ancient animal from air.
Swallow thrown on his tail: cause of split tail.
Ant thrown from heaven: hence narrow waist. God decides dispute between ant and spider in spider's favor.
Unicorn thrown from ark and drowned: hence no longer exists.
Crab thrown to ground: breaks into small pieces. Hence crabs are small.
Tortoise hurled on rock: half falls on land, half in water. Therefore amphibious.
Tortoise dropped by eagle: hence cracks in his shell.
Bat falls from high perch due to extreme heat of sun's rays, breaks bones, etc. Hence peculiar feet and nose.
Animal characteristics from throwing members at ancient animal.
Stick (leaf) thrown at animal's rump: hence tails.
Hare runs away at creation; almost loses tail. When, as the most timid of all beasts, he runs away, God throws a tail at him from a pile of tails.
Bowl placed on turtle's back: hence his shell.
Red fruit thrown at rail's (bird's) head: hence red lump on head.
Fox struck with churn-dash: hence white tail.
God throws diver's feet after him; hence his feet reach backward.
Animal characteristics: members bitten or cut off.
Bear fishes through ice with tail: hence lacks tail.
Devil pulls off goats' tails: hence lack tails.
Moon splits hare's lip with hatchet: hence hare-lip.
Bush-rat bites off tortoise's tail: hence tortoise's short tail.
Hawk's tail cut in two by sword as he is being transformed. Cause of his forked tail.
God as falcon has tail cut off: hence falcon's short tail.
Formerly animals have ears like elephant's: hare bites them off.
Appearance of animal from marking or painting.
Birds painted their present colors.
Chipmunk's back scratched: hence his stripes. As he is trying to escape, bear catches him with his claws and marks him permanently.
Marks on certain fish from fingerprints.
Marks on certain fish from St. Peter's fingerprints.
Marks on certain fish from devil's fingerprints.
Animal characteristics from burning or singeing.
Raven caught in smoke-hole: hence is black.
Animal scorches self while putting out fire in land of fire, woe and darkness.
Jackal carries sun in bag on back; burns his back black.
Animal who steals fire scorched: cause of his color.
Coyote burnt when hay is set afire: hence yellow patch behind his ears.
Robin steals fire, has breast scorched.
Raven singes feet on hot stones: why its wings clap when it flies.
Rabbit burns self under chin when he steals an ember.
Eel burned by torch: hence red eyes.
Other accidents to ancient animal.
Animal has color spilled on him: cause of his color.
Cow swallows book; cause of maniplies in stomach.
Only one serpent had sting: fed poison to the rest.
Animal characteristics as reward.
Hedgehog's skin reward for good deed.
Animal characteristics reward for pious act.
Animals blessed for honoring infant Jesus.
Animals blessed for good services at crucifixion.
Flies on Christ's body rewarded. They look like nails and prevent more nails being driven. They may eat at the king's table.
Blood from cross on robin redbreast: He helps Jesus; rewarded with red breast.
Blood of scourged Christ on certain spiders.
Swallows lift Christ's crown of thorns from his brow: why their nests are not destroyed.
Swallows put on mourning at crucifixion: have never taken it off.
Crossbill, attempting to draw thorn from the crown of thorns, twists bill in the attempt.
Markings on animals as recollections of Christ's life and sufferings.
Ant collects incense and myrrh for Christ: grows thin in middle.
Animal blessed for helping holy fugitive.
Ox helps patriarch who in joy kisses him on the lips: hence no hair on ox's lips.
Animal blessed for obedience to deity.
Bird coloring as reward for obedience to deity.
Dove returns to ark in obedience to Noah: receives sheen of raven.
Squirrel's markings and immunity from falling as reward by deity.
Why sheep walk with bowed heads: they have remained so after having bowed to God.
Sheep helpful to the Lord: get wool.
Deity rewards animal for bringing him water: cause of present characteristics.
Animal characteristics reward for hospitality.
Thrush's hospitality to peacock rewarded by being given motley coat of feathers.
Animal characteristics reward for helpfulness.
Cat helps man build house: may occupy chimney corner.
Bird carries deity (his daughter) home from land of skulls: given brilliant plumage.
Mouse gathers rice for man: may eat a little of his rice daily.
Pike helps Christ cross stream: made king of fishes.
Dog guards master's life and wealth: may eat before other animals.
Tortoise given hard shell when it ferries rice-goddess across stream.
Ravens show Adam how to bury dead: are born with white feathers.
Chameleon saves hero's life: may change color.
Animal characteristics as reward miscellaneous.
Dog rescues cow's teats from fire: origin of his black muzzle.
Dog lets devil into church to steal: rewarded with dog-skin.
Owl will not betray curate: therefore may live in steeple.
Fly steals fire from spider: may eat everywhere. Spider brings fire from hell. Fly steals it from him on the way.
Cuckoo delivers other birds from their cruel king: they agree to hatch out cuckoo's young.
Bird has red spot on its tail as reward for having moved woman's organ to its present position.
Animal characteristics as punishment.
Animal characteristics: punishment for impiety.
Animal characteristics: punishment for discourteous answer to God (saint).
Discourteous answer: why cow (horse) is always eating. When God (Peter) wants to use the cow (horse) the excuse is made that she (he) is eating. Curse: "May you always be eating!"
Discourteous answer: flounder's crooked mouth. When God asks him where he is going, instead of answering he turns to go toward God. His mouth becomes crooked.
Discourteous answer: why crab has eyes behind.
Discourteous answer: tortoise's shell. Zeus celebrates a wedding and invites the animals. Tortoise is late. Why? "I like my house." "May you bear your house always."
Animal characteristics: punishment for hostility at crucifixion.
Crane will not weep at crucifixion: must suffer thirst in August and break bills. Is the only bird who will not weep.
Swallows torment Christ on cross: lose voice.
Animal characteristics: punishment for working on holy day.
Cuckoo builds nest on Annunciation Day: has no nest.
Bees work on Sabbath: may not get honey from red clover.
Frog fails to honor infant Jesus: loses tail.
Spider vies with Virgin Mary in spinning: cursed.
Spider steals thread from Christ: has thread in back of body.
Animal harmful to holy person cursed.
Animal cursed for betraying holy fugitive.
Beetle cursed for betraying Holy Family on way to Egypt; beetle now has its eyes always on the ground.
Animal cursed for refusing to carry holy fugitive across stream.
Tortoise cursed for going under water while ferrying rice-goddess: people will be able to kill it with iron-made spears.
Toad refuses to weep over its dead children: dries up when dead. Cursed by Virgin Mary.
Fish in deluge deride God: are flattened with blow. They mock God for his powerlessness over them.
Crab beats deity's forbidden drum: eyes lift out of body.
Beetle demands return of gold from God: must hum. In his overweening pride he hits fence and ever afterward has hummed.
Buffaloes fail to come at god's leavetaking: now are killed by tigers.
Loris refuse to look at sun who comes out when they are dancing: hence never looks at sun.
Animal characteristics: punishment for immoderate request. Dissatisfied animal finds that when his request is granted he is worse off than before.
Camel asks for horns: punishment, short ears.
Bees pray for sting: punishment, first sting suicidal.

Beetle makes immoderate request; ant moderate: inverse awards. Creator hears wishes of animals. Beetle wants strong, noble appearance. Ant is modest. Beetle punished by being made to creep on ground. Ant is given own castle.
Griffin disdains to go on ark; drowned: hence extinct.
Animals ask for goddess's perfume: punishment, bad odor.
Birds who aspire to blackbird's coat punished.
Peacock given ugly feet so as to prevent too great arrogance.
Dog's embassy to Zeus chased forth; dogs seek ambassador: why dogs sniff each other under leg.
Ants ask God to give them wings: wind blows them away.
Raven attempts to imitate dove: punished with awkward gait.
Donkeys ask immediate reward from God: eat their own excrements.
Animal characteristics: punishment for laziness.
Animals refuse to help dig well (make road) and are punished.
Animals refuse to help dig well: may not drink from river or spring.
Snake refuses to help make road: dies on road.
Shrew refuses to help make road: dies on road.
Sloth refuses to help make road: may not look upon sun.
Dog will not help build house: must remain out of doors.
Too cold for hare (dog) to build house in winter, not necessary in summer: must go without house.
Owl as watchman goes to sleep: does not see by day. He is placed as watchman of wren who is imprisoned in a mousehole.
Grasshopper builds no house for winter; ant strikes him blind: therefore born blind.
Bird neglects to build nest: goes without.
Animal characteristics: punishment for disobedience.
Raven does not return to Noah: must suffer thirst and break bill.
Raven does not return to ark in obedience to Noah: black color is resulting punishment.
Animals eat deity's forbidden fruit: punished.
Lemur looks where forbidden: has big eyes.
Hare weeps for mother when forbidden: moon hits him and cleaves lip.
Animal characteristics caused by animal's lateness at distribution of qualities.
Animal characteristics: punishment for planning man's downfall.

What creature has sweetest blood: gnat's tongue torn out. Assembly to decide who has the sweetest blood so that it may be the food for the serpent. Gnat discovers that man has the sweetest blood. Rather than let him tell this secret, swallow tears out his tongue. Gnat can only buzz.
Animal characteristics: punishment for carrying devil into paradise.
Snake carries devil into paradise: loses feet.
Peacock has snake carry devil into paradise: cursed with ugly voice and feet.
Animal punished for not warning of devil's temptation in Eden.
Magpie tells man he is to die next day: no tongue and long tail. God pulls out his tongue and makes his tail long for doing this forbidden thing.
Animal punished for not heralding dawn.
Nit tries to bore through man's head: must remain at edge of hair.
Jay carries sulphur to devil in hell: must be quiet at noon.
Cat commanded to pray so as not to slay man: why cat purrs.
Animal characteristics punishment for meddling.
Animal reveals mistress's adultery: punished by master.
Animal characteristics: punishment for greed.
Rabbit (frog) eats seed-grain from fields: nose closed during sowing season.
Ring-dove eats man's grain: man may kill him. Similarly francolin and guinea fowl.
Fish eat other fish: guilty must swim deep.
Diver eats nests of small birds: must not nest away from water.
Animal characteristics from miscellaneous punishments.
Hare punished for perjury: eyes deep in head.
Fly punished for failing to answer question: is speechless, buzzes and associates with foul things.
Ass betrays deity's secret: hence his ugly bray.
Owl reveals deity's secret: power of speech removed.
Woodpecker punished for stinginess.
Animals punished for assaulting women.
Ass has cross on shoulders from being struck by Balaam.
Crocodile is punished for trying to attack man he is carrying: has only half tongue.
Animal punished for hardheadedness (frog toothless, mole sightless).
Why mouse is crushed whenever she crosses a road: elephant's curse.
Why elephant hurts himself when running through the grass: mouse's curse.
Animal characteristics: obtaining another's qualities.
Animal characteristics: borrowing and not returning. Animal borrows a member (or quality) from another and refuses to return it.
Stag's horns borrowed from dog.
Owl's wings borrowed from rat (or other animal).
Partridge's voice borrowed from tortoise.
Cuckoo borrows food from other birds.
Nightingale borrows blindworm's eye. Each has one eye. Nightingale borrow's blindworm's and will not return it.
Jay borrows cuckoo's skin.
Squirrel borrows coney's tail. When coney's tail is not returned, he goes in shame to live among rocks.
Boy borrows python's hands and feet: hence python lacks them.
Hornbill borrows tomtit's bill.
Beaver borrows muskrat's tail and never gives it back.
Monkey borrows tail from deer and refuses to return it.
Animal characteristics: obtaining for feast and not returning.
Animal characteristics: lending and refusing to receive back.
Spider hands box to ant and refuses to take it back: hence ants carry huge loads.
Animal characteristics: stolen from another animal.
Thrush steals woodcock's song.
Animal characteristics: exchange of qualities.
Buffalo and cow exchange hides: hence bad fitting hides.
Snake and turtle exchange head for fangs. Explains snake's fangs and snake-like head of turtle.
Rhinoceros exchanges his red hide for hippopotamus's black.
Dove and magpie exchange eggs dove's seven for magpie's two: why dove has two eggs.
Toad trades his tail for mole's eyes.
Beaver and muskrat exchange tails.
Animal characteristics: result of contest.
Cock and ptarmigan in contest: winner to live in town.
Man and tiger in contest: winner to live in town.
Lizard wins contest with toad: why snakes and lizards change their skins.
Animal characteristics from contest in carrying.
Ant carries load as heavy as himself. Defeats bear, raven (or other bird). Various explanations.
Animal characteristics determined by race.
Race of animals to see where each shall live.
Race of ox and horse: ox must labor. Horse wins and ox must serve as draft animal.
Race of culture hero with ostrich: ostrich loses beautiful feathers.
Flounder complains in race: crooked mouth. In race between fish he cries out in jealousy because herring is winning. He is punished with crooked mouth.
Animal characteristics from jumping contest.
Dog burned in jumping contest over fire: enmity between dog and hare.
Bird characteristics from flying contests.
Animal characteristics result of lawsuit.
Wool on his forehead awarded sheep in lawsuit. He is given the privilege of keeping it when the rest of his body is shorn.

Lizard loses lawsuit: must bob his head. Lizard and ant accused of theft of king's crow. Ant pours boiling water down lizard's throat. When case is tried, lizard cannot talk but only bobs head up and down. Adjudged guilty and condemned to bob his head eternally.
Animal characteristics from contest in watching.
Hare and man contest in watching for leaf to fall off tree. First one to succeed may eat other. Hare loses.
Animal characteristics from duel.
Why tiger does not attack wild boar until latter is old: result of duel.
Animal characteristics: as a result of quarrel.
Animal characteristics from transformation.
Animal characteristics from transformation of animal.
Shepherd transformed to bird still calls sheep: explanation of bird cries. Usually told of hoopoe and bittern.
Spider transformed for greediness: now occupies dark corners.
Catfish transformed from woman still carries women's tatoo marks.
Catfish transformed from children still carry marks of children's knife holder.
Woodpecker transformed from stingy woman: therefore stingy.
Weeping man turned into owl; still bewails sorrows.
Snipe messenger for warriors because he was a messenger when a man.
Animal characteristics from transformation of implement (or other object).
Horse originally had eyes on feet: put out and became eyelike marks.
Pegs driven into backs of baboons become tails.
Serpent steals from God's coat a stick for his back.
Animal characteristics from miscellaneous causes.
Animal characteristics learned from another animal.
Thrush teaches dove to build nest.
Sparrow taught to sing by lark but not sufficiently: where sparrow got voice.
Animal characteristics: imitation of other animal or object.
Animal cries: imitation of sounds.
Nightingale hears boy call oxen: learns her song.
Cricket hears water hiss on hot iron: learns his song.
Garden warbler hears smith beat iron: learns his song.
Lizard's tail imitated from snake's.  Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 20 No. 110, XXXIII 55 No. 110.
Animal habit a reminiscence of former experience.
Animal cries a lament for person lost when animal was transformed.
Animal cries a lament over animal's transformation.
Animal cries reminiscent of former life as man.
Animal cries recall ancient adventure. The ancient animal cries out in difficulty. The present animal has the same cry.
Green pigeon cheated out of its chick: is always mourning.
Animal's seeking attitude from ancient loss. The ancient animal loses something. Its descendants are forever seeking for the lost object. This explains the characteristic bearing of certain animals.
Hog loses pancake in mud: still seeks it.
Hawk (vulture) loses grandmother: still hovers and seeks her.

Bat, diver, and thornbush shipwrecked. Bat brought money, bush put on clothes, and diver brought leather. All shipwrecked. Diver is looking for his leather. Bush looks for his clothers and holds fast to all passers-by. Bat is abroad only at night to escape creditors.
Dolphins seek King Solomon's ring. He loses his magic ring in the sea. They are sent by God to get it. This is why they go up and down in the sea.
Dog loses his patent right; seeks it: why dogs look at one another under the tail.
Son accidentally kills father, who returns to life as cuckoo and tells people when to sow grain.
Enmity between animals from original quarrel.
Cat loses dog's certificate: enmity between cats and dogs. Dog is given a certificate of nobility. Through cat's carelessness it is lost.
Cat garbles message from man to tiger: enmity between man and tiger.
Quarrel of dog and cat about which was higher caste.
Squirrel steals dog's needle: enmity between them.
Why cat and dog fight: dog ate up cat's part in master's reward.
Present habitat of animals result of ancient quarrel.
Two animals learn songs together one successfully, the other unsuccessfully.
Origin of animal characteristics: animal persuaded into self-injury.
Animal persuaded to amputate limb: therefore lacks it.
Bustard persuaded to kill all but two children: has but two eggs.
Worm, thinking that world is coming to end, blinds self so as not to see calamity.
Elephant tricked into eating own testicles. Has them inside.
Coyote persuaded to break leg: therefore has thin right leg.
Jackal persuades hyena to jump and break foot. Latter has short left hind foot.
Animal characteristics established by deity.
God makes serpent ugly.
Creation interrupted since God must go to a fire.
Animal characteristics because creator had not enough time to finish what he began.
Creation of hog incomplete since God has to go to a fire: cause of hog's round snout.
Animal characteristics result of contest between God and devil.
Devil's animals devour God's.  God makes white fish, devil a pike to eat it up; God a worm, devil a frog to eat it, etc. (Cf. +A1751.)
Devil gives horse four eyes; God reduces them to two.
Devil's cows one-horned; God makes them two-horned.
God changes color (tails) of devil's cows. Devil makes all animals of same color (or all tailless). When God makes them of different colors (or with tails) devil no longer recognizes them.
Jesus causes animal characteristics.
Jesus drives evil spirits into hogs: hence short snouts.
Jesus drives evil spirits into hogs: hence "toes" on back of foreleg.
Animal characteristics obtained during deluge.
Animal characteristics: change for convenience.
Wild animals lose their ferocity through fear of Behemoth.

Faithful horse weeps for coming death of saint.
Faithful horse weeps tears of blood for master.
Faithful horse joins in keen at hero's death.
Faithful horse lays his head in lap of dead master's wife.
Faithful horse allows only its master to catch and ride it.
Faithful horse lies down in order that its mutilated master can mount it.
Faithful horse refuses to go before its master mounts it, even when already loaded with two chests with gold.
Faithful horse dies together with its master.
Faithful horse fights together with its master.
Faithful animals resuscitate master.
Faithful cattle fight at master's grave until they cast their horns.
Faithful cattle shed horns in grief for death of man.
Faithful cow refuses to move for grief at master's death.
Faithful cows lose milk at king's death.
Faithful lapdog dies when mistress dies.
Faithful dog helps open mistress' grave and dies on it.
Faithful lion follows man who saved him.
Acquisition of helpful animal.
Congenital helpful animal. Born at same time as master and (usually) by same magic means.
Helpful animal foster brother. Hero reared by animal's parents.
Helpful animals obtained by purchase or gift.
Helpful animals a gift.
Helpful animals obtained by exchange.
Helpful animal(s) bequeathed to hero.
Helpful animal purchased.
Helpful dogs obtained by purchase.
Helpful, strong horse caught.
Helpful animal an enchanted person.
Helpful animal reincarnation of parent. The dead mother appears to the heroine in the form of an animal.
Helpful animal reincarnation of murdered child.
Helpful animal brothers-in-law.
Animal helpful after being conquered.
Abused and pampered horses. Hero is ordered by ogre to feed and care for certain horse and to neglect other horse. Hero disobeys and feeds neglected horse. Latter is enchanted prince and helps hero.
Helpful bird hatched by hero. Hero holds eagle's egg in hand and hatches it. Young eagle becomes his helper.
Helpful animals transformed from other animals.
Helpful animal otherwise acquired.
Helpful animal sent by God (or a god).
Helpful animal acquired as reward for vigil.
Reward of helpful animal.
Helpful animal demands food.
Hero feeds own flesh to helpful animal. The hero is carried on the back of an eagle who demands food. The hero finally feeds parts of his own flesh.
Helpful birds demand food.
Animal bribed for help.
Animal bribed with food. (Sop to Cerberus.)
Death of helpful animal.
Helpful animal killed through misunderstanding.
Faithful falcon killed through misunderstanding. Tries to warn the king against drinking water poisoned by snake.
Faithful horse killed through misunderstanding. Tries to warn king against drinking water poisoned by snake.
Llewellyn and his dog. Dog has saved child from serpent. Father sees bloody mouth, thinks the dog has eaten the child, and kills the dog.
Woman slays faithful mongoose which has saved her child.
Faithful dog killed by overhasty master: thinks mistakenly he has returned home against orders.
Faithful parrot killed by mistake.
Too watchful dog killed.
Helpful animal killed by hero's enemy.
Man attempts to kill faithful serpent at wife's instigation. Loses everything.
Treacherous wife forces husband to kill helpful dog.
Life of helpful animal demanded as cure for feigned sickness.
Unsuccessful attempt by enemy to kill helpful animal.
Wife demands magic parrot who has accused her.
Faithful animal killed in battle.
A small animal (hare, bitch) gives timely warnings to the hero about the trap prepared by his enemy. Animal warning about trap killed.
Helpful cow to be killed because of refusal to help stepdaughter.
Helpful animal killed (threatened) by ungrateful hero.
Weapons made from bones of helpful horse.
Death of helpful animal miscellaneous.
Truth-telling dog killed so as to hide murder.
Treatment of helpful animals miscellaneous.
Helpful animal's injunctions disobeyed. Disaster follows.
Cat leaves house when report is made of death of one of his companions. His master has been told to say "Robert is dead". As soon as this is said, the cat leaves.
Large reward given for return of helpful animal.

Animals grateful for rescue from peril of death.
Animals grateful for rescue from pit.
Animal grateful for rescue from drowning.
Animal grateful for rescue from net.
Lion is freed from net by mouse. Mouse asks that his son marry lion's daughter. Request granted. The mouse is trampled to death by his bride.

Animal grateful for rescue from trap.
Animal grateful for rescue from fire.
Insect having fallen on back grateful for being turned over.

Medicine shown by animal. It heals another animal with a medicine (herb, water, etc.) and thus shows the man the remedy. Sometimes the medicine resuscitates the dead. (The animal is most frequently the serpent.
Remedy learned from overhearing animal meeting. The hero learns how to cure his own blindness and the sickness of the king (princess).
Animal fetches remedy for man.
Grateful fox fetches fox liver as remedy.
Bee fetches balm from heaven to restore hero's speech.
Snake gives man antidote for poison.
Resuscitation by animals.

Animals save person's life.
Animal warns of fatal danger.
Animal warns against poison.
Horse advises hero not to wash in water (as his false wife told him to) or his eyes will pop out.
Animal warns man against drinking.
Animal warns against accident.
Eagle saves man from falling wall. The grateful eagle swoops down and takes the man's hat, and thus gets him away from the wall that is about to fall.
Animals warn against attack.
Dogs warn against witch.
Cackling geese spread alarm.
Flea's bite alarms king. Robber tells flea of plan to rob king. During the robbery the flea bites and awakens the king.
Prince awakened by fly on his nose in time to save himself from enemy.
Dog warns of pursuit.
Owl warns other birds from limed net.
Animals warn wife of husband's danger.
Owl saves man from plunging over cliff. Flaps wings and arrests man's attention.
Birds warn of enemy's approach.
Animal saves man from death sentence.
Serpent shows condemned man how to save prince's life. Bites the prince and then shows the man the proper remedy (cf. +B512). By thus ingratiating himself the man is freed from false accusation.
Kite steals jewels and thus saves condemned man. Innocent man in possession of stolen jewels, is about to be apprehended. Kite carries off the jewels and saves him.
Woman slandered as adulteress is thrown into lion pit. Lions do not harm her.
Eagle carries off condemned child.
Circling cranes carry away girl.
Animal saves man from pursuer.
Spider-web over hole saves fugitive.
Whale fights monster pursuing saint.
Great clam fights hero's pursuer.
Animal overcomes man's adversary.

Helpful buffaloes tramp hero's enemies to death.

Helpful bird kills snake attacking master's wife and child.
Horse kills master's attacking enemies.
Shut in with elephants, blackbird orders ants to burrow themselves into the elephants' brains.
Grateful hawk attacks hero's enemies.
Helpful centipede kills ogre.

Helpful animals quench execution fire. Master is to be burned at stake.

Animal saves man from death by drowning.
Fish promises to spare man in coming flood.

Owl saves man from drowning: flaps wings to call attention to direction of land.

Noah's curse admits devil to ark. Devil persuades Noah's wife to stay out of ark till Noah shall call devil in. Noah at last loses patience and calls out, "The devil! Come in!" The devil comes in and turns himself into a mouse.

Miscellaneous transformation incidents.

Repeated transformation. Transformation into one form after another.

Men transformed to animals fight.
Fairies (gods?). transformed to animals fight.

Repeated transformations to deceive wives. A husband thus makes each of his many wives believe that he is always with her.
Periodic transformation. A person or thing is transformed at definite intervals.
Daily transformation.
One shape by day; another by night.
Animal by day; man by night.
Man by day; animal by night.
Tree by day; man by night.
Bush by day; woman by night.
Flower by day; girl by night.
Ugly by day; fair by night.
Size of object transformed at night.
Magic dog shrinks at night.
Sheep by day; dog by night.
Young man issues from conch-shell every evening.
Weekly transformation.
Transformation to werwolf every Friday night.
Transformation every ten days.
Yearly transformation.
Storks become men in Egypt in the winter.
Fairies become birds every other year.
Yearly transformation to person of different sex.
Transformation and disenchantment at will.
Power of self-transformation received from wood spirit.
Power of self-transformation received from demon.
Power of self-transformation received from a god.

Deity has power of self-transformation.
Size changed at will.
Person changes size at will.
Person changes appearance at will.
Animal's size changed at will.
Dogs large or small at will.
Size of object changed at will.
Compressible canoe. Can be made pocket size.
Compressible ship. Can be put into vest pocket.

Compressible hammer.
Cloth large or small at will.

Demons change size at will.
Creature born from egg changes size at will.
Boat transforms self at will of master.

Reasons for voluntary transformation.
Transformation to reach difficult place.
Lover as bird visits mistress.
Girl as bird visits lover.
Transformation to be able to woo maiden.
Transformation to gain access to enemy's camp (fortress).
Transformation to spy out enemy's camp.
Transformation in order to enter rival's stomach.
Transformation to travel to otherworld.
Transformation to escape difficult situation.
Transformation to escape from captivity.
Transformation to escape death.
Transformation to escape lover.
Pursued sweetheart becomes tree.
Transformation to escape ambush.
Transformation to escape notice.
Transformation to hide from ogress.
Transformation to escape ogress.
Transformation to elude pursuers.
Transformation so as to rescue.
Transformation to falcon in order to rescue condemned man at the gallows.
Man transformed to deer decoy for people at execution of saint's friend.
Transformation to travel fast.
Transformation to test heroes.
Transformation to be picked up (caught).
Transformation to fish to be caught.
Transformation to child or pet to be adopted.
Transformation to seek lost (or unknown) person.
Faithful brother transforms self to deer to seek sister.
Transformation to eagle so as to scour country for lovely woman as bride for king.
Transformation to defeat enemies.
Transformation to kill enemy.
Transformation of magic object to animal which kills enemy.
Demons assume human form to revenge brother's death.
Queen transforms herself to defeat god of death.
Transformation to frighten enemy.
Transformation to destroy enemy's property.
Transformation to ant in order to gnaw bow-strings of enemy.
Transformation to spy enemy's camp.
Transformation so as to protect hero from enemy.
Transformation to receive food.
Transformation to buffalo so as to eat grass.
Witch transforms self to animal (hare, pig) so as to suck cows.
Transformation to steal.
Transformation to be put in food-bag.
Transformation to flying horse so as to abduct king.
Transformation in order to steal fire.
Transformation to seduce.
Transformation to animal to seduce woman.
Transformation to husband's (lover's) form to seduce woman.
Transformation of sex to seduce.
Transformation to seduce man.
Transformation of animal to woman to seduce man.
God as mare seduces stallion.
Seven girls in guise of seven parrots come to boy who has spurned them.
Miscellaneous reasons for voluntary transformation.
Transformation to snakes at night in order to sleep.
Transformation to animals to fight.
Transformation to show displeasure.
Transformation to act as helpful animal.
Transformation to lion in order to guard palace.
Sea dragon in serpent's form to accompany hero.
Transformation to eagle to carry hero to safety.
Transformation to eagle in order to guard princess.
Transformation to obtain blessing.
Transformation to friar to instruct mankind.
Transformation: wife to mistress. Transformed wife substitutes for husband's mistress.
Transformation to test fidelity.
Transformation to another form to persuade man to go to battle.

Transformation to recover stolen goods.
Transformation to tramp to escape recognition.
Transformation in order to drive buffaloes to milking.

Transformation as punishment.
Transformation as revenge for repulsing amorous advances.
Transformation as punishment for denouncing saint.
Transformation for violation of vow.

Transformation to cure inconstant husband. He falls in love with another woman: his wife changes him to negro. He then falls in love with negress: wife changes him to ass. He then falls in love with she-ass. Finally restored to his original form.
Transformation as reward.
Transformation of woman by goddess to preserve chastity.
Transformation of enemy to be rid of him.
Transformation of rival in love (marriage) to be rid of him.
Transformation of stepchild to be rid of him.
Jealous co-wife transforms the other.
Transformation to save a person.
King of birds transforms his quails into sticks and pebbles so king and his hunters and hawks cannot kill them.
Magic flight.
Transformation flight. Fugitives transforms themselves in order to escape detection by the pursuer.
Fugitive transforms self to stone. Thrown to safety by pursuer.
Fugitive transformed by helper to escape detection.
Reversed transformation flight. Transformed pursuer.
Obstacle flight. Fugitives throw objects behind them which magically become obstacles in pursuer's path.
Magic objects as decoy for pursuer. Date palms are dropped which are transformed into animals which the pursuer stops to pick up.
Reversed obstacle flight. Magic obstacles raised in front of fugitive.
Magic flight with the help of a he-goat. Speaking he-goat saves the girl promised to the devil.
Sea turns to ice to permit flight.

Gradual transformation.
Partial transformation.
Partial transformation: person with animal head.
Partial transformation: person with animal hair.

Animals in human form retain animal food and habits.
Animal with human eyes.
Partial transformation color changed.
Magic mantle changes color hourly.
"Spirit of poetry" as hideous youth becomes beautiful.
Transformation by magician.
Transformers. Demigods who transform things at will so that they assume present form.
Transformation by witch (sorceress).
Transformation by troll.
Transformation by saint.
Transformation by god (goddess).
Transformation by evil spirits.
Transformation by fairy.
Transformation by offspring of fairy and mortal.
Transformation by angel (God).
Transformation by druid.
Transformation by helpful animals.
Transformation by magic animal.
Transformed animal refuses to touch meat of that animal.

Transformed mother suckles child.

City's inhabitants transformed to fish. Different classes to different colored fish.

Food left for transformed person.
Man transformed to woman has children.
Transformation during sleep.
Magic object can transform self.

Gods have power to transform themselves.
Additional transformation motifs.
Eyes of hero's buffalo friend turn into two powerful dogs that protect his wife.

Place disenchanted.

Disenchantment by removing (destroying) covering of enchanted person.
Disenchantment by removing skin (or covering).
Disenchantment by flaying.
Disenchantment by hiding skin (covering). When the enchanted person has temporarily removed the covering, it is stolen and the victim remains disenchanted until it is found.
Disenchantment by destroying skin (covering).
Disenchantment by holding temporarily disenchanted person.
Disenchantment from fruit (flower) by opening it.

Disenchantment of animal by admission to woman's bed.
Disenchantment by kiss.
Beauty and the beast. Disenchantment of animal by being kissed by woman (man).
Three redeeming kisses. (Die weisse Frau.) A woman can be disenchanted from animal form if man will kiss her three times, each time when she is in the form of a different terrifying animal.
Disenchantment from tree form by embrace of lover.
Disenchantment by enduring animal's embrace.
Girl disenchants animal husband by enduring his embraces without fear.
Son disenchants animal father by enduring his caresses without fear.
Disenchantment of monster when prince promises to marry the monster's mother. The prince imagines falsely that the mother is also a monster.
Disenchantment of monster when his mother acknowledges him as son.
Disenchantment of monster child when baptized.
Disenchantment by promise to marry.
Disenchantment by sexual intercourse. Man disenchants woman in form of a bear.
Disenchantment by feeding enchanted animals.

Disenchantment by accomplishment of tasks.
Disenchantment by sewing shirts for enchanted brothers.

Disenchantment by obeying directions received in a dream.

Disenchantment by serving transformed person.

Disenchantment by maintaining silence for a year or more.

Disenchantment possible under unique conditions. Only one combination of time place and person will serve. For many of these combinations see Hartland Science 240, 244, 248.

Disenchantment at end of seven years.
Disenchantment when superhuman task is finished. Enchanted person appears every seven years in human form and puts one stitch in a smock. When it is finished, she will be delivered.

Disenchantment at end of two hundred years.
Disenchantment at end of nine hundred years.
Disenchantment possible at the end of seven hundred years.

Disenchantment at midnight after owl hoots three times.
Disenchantment by only one person.

Forgotten fiancie reawakens husband 's memory by detaining lovers through magic. Heroine takes up residence near home of her forgetful husband. She is apparently going to permit a lover to sleep with her when she detains him by having him try to place some magic birds on their roost. They continue to fall down throughout the night. (Or the lover is left magically sticking to a calf's tail or other object.) The thwarted lover tells of his experience, and in this way the attention of the husband is gained.

Means of resuscitation learned.

Dead body incorruptible. Beard and fingernails continue to grow.
Resuscitation when murder is discovered.
Resuscitation after murderer is buried in the earth, wood laid over him, and a lighted lamp on its top.

Attempted resuscitation fails because of overanxiety.

Dead lover's malevolent return.
Dead sweetheart haunts faithless lover.
Dead sweetheart in the form of a white rabbit follows seducer.
Dead sweetheart appears to seducer every evening, even after he has married another woman.
Dead lover sets tasks. If girl does not perform them (or answer his questions) he will carry her off.
Dead lover haunts faithless sweetheart.
Dead lover returns to dance with fickle sweetheart at her wedding.

Fatal kiss from dead.
Spells to recall dead lover. Boiling dead man's head, bones, or carcass in a pot, or burning a piece of lover's clothing or cat in a hot oven.
Dead relative's malevolent return.
Dead spouse's malevolent return. Usually to protest with survivor because of evil ways.
Dead wife haunts husband on second marriage.
Dead wife returns to reprove husband's second wife.

Dead husband returns to protest wife's spending his money.
Dead wife torments husband who has let her die of neglect.

Mother haunts daughter.

Dead mother haunts daughter who marries against mother's will.
Dead mother returns to invoke curse on murderer-son.
Ghost of murdered child.
Ghost of abortion.
Dead brother's return.
Dead brother reproves sister's pride.
The dead daughter reproaches her mother for putting her dowery into coffin.
Dead relative's malevolent return miscellaneous.
"If I were not your next of kin.". Ghost tells man that otherwise he would tear him into pieces.
Return from dead to inflict punishment.
Return from dead to reveal murder.
Ghost tells name of murderer.
Ghost skeleton points lance at murderer.
Ghost light hovers over hiding place of body of murdered person.
Noise of chains leads to buried ghost.
Ghost returns to murderer, causes him to confess.
Return from the dead to slay wicked person.
Return from dead to slay own murderer.

Ghost kills man who interferes with ghostly activity.
Ghost returns to slay enemies.
Ghost punishes injury received in life.
Ghost returns to demand vengeance.

Ghost stampedes stolen cattle being driven past his ranch.
Return from dead to avenge death (murder).
Ghost an unjustly executed man. Real murderer found.
Return from dead to punish indignities to corpse, or ghost.
Ghost punishes person who mocks him.
Ghost returns to demand proper burial.
Dead man speaks demanding proper funeral rites.
Ghost returns because corpse was not properly burned.
Return from dead as punishment for trying to raise ghost.
Return from dead to punish theft of part of corpse.
Return from dead to punish theft of golden arm from grave.
Return from dead to punish theft of leg from grave.
Return from dead to punish theft of bone from grave.
Return from dead to punish theft of liver from man on gallows.
Return from dead to punish theft of skull.
Return from dead to punish theft of teeth.
Return from dead to punish kicking of skull.
Return from dead to punish disturber of grave.
Return from the dead to capture thief.

Return from dead to demand stolen property.
Return from dead to demand clothing stolen from grave.
Return from dead to demand ring stolen from corpse.
Return from dead to demand stolen children.
Return from the dead to warn thief that he will be punished.

Driver asks person at address about the rider, finds she has been dead for some time. Changeling. Fairy steals child from cradle and leaves fairy substitute. Changeling is usually mature and only seems to be a child.
Changeling deceived into betraying his age.
Changeling betrays his age when his wonder is excited. Usually pottage is boiled in an eggshell. The changeling: "I shall soon be a hundred years old but I never saw this done before!"
Changeling plays on pipe and thus betrays his maturity.
Changeling dances wild dance to music, betrays maturity.
Changeling addresses woman in verse and thus betrays maturity.
Changeling shows supernatural power to work and thus betrays maturity.
Changeling calculates his age by the age of the forest. "I have seen the forest grow up three times."
Threat to throw on fire causes changeling to cry out and betray his nature.
Whipping causes changeling to betray his nature.
Characteristics of changeling.
Changeling has abnormal features or growth. Limbs grow too rapidly, head is too big, or he is slow to learn to walk, or the like.
Changeling is always hungry, demands food all the time.
Changeling is sickly (often the fairy exchanged for a baby is an elderly, infirm member of the fairy clan whom the fairies are tired of caring for).

Disposing of a changeling.
Changeling thrown into water and thus banished.

Farmer is so bothered by brownie that he decides he must move to get rid of the annoyance. He piles all furniture on wagon and starts for new home, meets acquaintance who remarks: "I see you're flitting." Brownie sticks his head out of the churn on top of the load, answers: "Yes, we're flitting." Farmer goes back to former home.

Devil. (The Devil, Satan, The Bad Man, Old Nick, etc.)+1 Not clearly differentiated, especially in German tradition, from the stupid ogre.

The devil originates from God.
God creates the devil (Satan) from his own shadow.
Devil originates from God's spittle.
The devil originates from the spittle of an evil man.
God changes an angel into the devil, because he tried to imitate God in creating the world.
God creates the devil by striking a stone with his whip.
God discovers the devil.
God finds the devil sitting under a tree which was made by his throwing his staff into the water.

The devil is created without the special aid of God.
The devil is developed from man.
The devil is created out of a bubble.

Satan created out of hell fire.
The devil creates other devils.
The devil creates devils by casting water behind himself.
Devils are created from sparks produced by Satan's striking two stones together.
Five devils created by Adam create other devils in the same manner. Adam has created five devils by wetting five fingers with dew and shaking them behind him; God had commanded him to wet one finger.
Devils are created from sinful priests.

Two devils (male and female) extracted from corpse's belly.

Devil calls himself "Puss".
Devil is called "the black one".
Devil says his name is "Millearces" (thousand ways to lead men to sin).

Gaelic titles given to the devil:  the worthless one; the one whom I will not mention; yon one; the one big one; the one from the abyss; the mean mischievous one; the big sorrow; the son of cursing; the big grizzled one; the bad one; the bad spirit; Black Donald.

Satan fights Israel.
Satan attacks saints.
Devil inflames saint's injured eye.
The devil advises human beings.
Devil advises young girl not to go to a castle. Later, when she returns pregnant she says that the devil advised her to serve at the castle. He slaps her and tells her she is lying.
Devil exhorts youth to enjoy himself and not to think of God. When the youth has grown old the devil says, "It is now too late to think of God.

The devil advises a suspicious husband. The Ring of Hans Garvel. Appears in a dream and hands the husband a ring. " When you wear this ring you will be sure of your wife. " He awakens to understand the obscene implication.
Devil disguised as man tells of trip to heaven and hell. Heaven is full of wretches who weep, fast, and pray. Hell is full of wealth, power, and good living.

Devil spins and knits.
Devil plays fiddle at wedding. Causes bad luck (kills bridegroom).
Devil sings (dances) on grave.
Devil causes salamander to appear in glass of rum, drinks it.
Devil engages in drinking contest with man for purse of gold. Gold causes man to become miser.
Satan asks God to put man into his power (Job).
Satan makes wager with God about mortal's piety.
Satan prays to God.
Satan chants songs of praise to God.
Satan weeps.
Satan as blasphemer.
Pranks played by the devil.
Devil prevents moving of little stone by sitting on it.
Devil interrupts mass by pretended battle.
Devil steals knight's cloak.
Devil takes an unbaptized child out of the cradle and lays a wooden log in its place.

Devil leads and misguides people.
Trying all night to catch an animal (really devil).
Taking snuff with the devil.

Exchanging things with the devil. The cheat appears later.
The devil as tailor to a dandy. The dandy demands clothes sewed without thread. The devil disguised as a tailor makes them. In church the dandy's clothes fall to pieces, leaving him naked.

The devil's mother.
Devil's mother rides a goat.

Devil's grandmother is bleaching when it snows.

Marital experiences of the devil.
Devil wooes an innkeeper's daughter.
Devil marries a widow who maltreats him.
Devil marries old maid who proves to be a termagant and a miser.
Devil visits woman and founds a family.
Devil marries girl.
Girl married to a devil. Despairing of ever finding herself a husband, the old maid exclaims: "I would marry even the devil, were he to marry me. " The devil takes her at her word.
Devil marries disdainful girl; she escapes.
Devil marries girl whose rich mother refuses to let her marry common young men of community.
Devil wooes woman;  she discovers identity in time to escape with aid of minister who swallows candle after getting devil to promise she could live as long as the candle lasted.
Girl married to devil escapes with answers to his riddles.
Girl wooed by devil is saved by magic herb she wears.
Devil takes form of girl's lover and takes advantage of her. She meets lover on way home, learns what has happened, dies.
Devil in guise of woman woos man.
Man marries a she-devil He catches her as succubus and marries. Some years later his wife's brothers invite them to a feast (wedding) and he gets gifts or wife's dowry.
Devil's sexual relations with mortals.
Satan's sexual intercourse with Eve.
The stupid devil.
Devils do not know or understand thoughts of men.
Devil works backward. Begins building at top of house.
Devil tries to wall in too large a piece of ground in a night and fails.
The devil tries to learn a trade; he fails miserably at all but versemaking. He now loiters in alehouses, sings songs.
Simple-minded devil indicates how he can be driven away.
Devil's unfinished work cannot be completed by human hands. One stone missing in church, etc.
The devil destroys by night what is built by day.
Devil destroys Adam's work by night.
Devil builds bridge except for one stone. No one dares to add the final stone.

Devil haunts a house. Finally is exorcised.

Ruins of a palace haunted by Satan.

By the help of the Virgin Mary the devil may be escaped.

Devil cannot enter person who is thinking of God.

Devils driven away by hymn (psalm).
Demon cannot hurt holy man or woman.

Devils driven away by cross.

Devils put to flight by cross made of leaves.
Devil made to disappear by making sign of the cross.

Devil made visible by making sign of cross.

Devil disappears when offered host.

Devil is chased by holy water.
Devil leaves at mention of God's name.

Task for devil: making needles.

Identity tests. Recognition. Elaborate means are employed in folk-literature for the recognition of persons even though they have been separated a very short time. The various means used are detailed in the following discussion.
Recognition through common knowledge.
Recognition through story-telling. Telling of a story known to both persons concerned brings about recognition.
Recognition by telling life history.
Recognition at inn (hospital, etc.) where all must tell their life histories.
Recognition: life story painted on wall.
Recognition by life history sung.
Recognition by tracing ancestry.
Recognition by song (music). Person is recognized because the song is sung only by him or because he is the only one besides the listener who knows it.
Missing female poet discovered through test of poetic ability.
Recognition by verse of song.
Recognition by matching a couplet together.
Recognition by overheard conversation (usually with animals or objects). Person not daring to reveal self directly thus attracts attention and recognition.
Recognition by overheard conversation with animal.
Recognition by overheard conversation with horse.
Recognition by overheard conversation with dog.
Recognition by overheard conversation with cow.
Recognition by overheard conversation with objects.

Recognition by overheard conversation with bridge. Bridge which will trip up bridal party if king is not marrying an equal. Disguised princess praises bridge for its recognition of her equality with the king.
Recognition by overheard conversation with stone.
Recognition by overheard conversation with plant.
Recognition by overheard conversation with churchdoor.
Recognition by overheard conversation with cups (or other utensils).
Recognition by overheard conversation with flax. By comparing her fate with that of the flax the heroine is able to reveal herself.
Recognition by overheard conversation with stove.
Recognition from overheard conversation of two sons.
Recognition from overheard conversation with flower-woman.
Recognition by observing emotional reactions of another to object of common experience.
Recognition by seeing husband shed tears on sight of bird (main character in a former experience common to both husband and wife).
Recognition by tears at recital of own exploits.
Identity tested by account of common experiences.
Identity tested by demanding that person say again what he said on former occasion. (Impostor fails.)
Recognition by recalling common experiences.
Recognition by describing or producing object of common knowledge.
Recognition by brother king of lost brother brought about by model of their father's palace which lost brother builds of clay.
Recognition by wounds on lip and finger received at common adventure.
Recognition of brothers brought about by bouquet of flowers tied as father's gardener used to do.
Recognition by describing unique bed.
Recognition by reminders of what has been said.
Recognition by password.
Recognition through common knowledge miscellaneous.
Recognition by ability to identify property.
Recognition of reincarnated person by ability to identify former weapons.
Recognition by answer to conundrum (known only to two persons).
Recognition by resemblance.
Recognition through picture. Picture is publicly displayed and brings about recognition of lost person.
Recognition through image.
Recognition from dream.
Recognition through personal peculiarities
Recognition by unique ability.
Recognition by unique ability to dislodge sword. Sword is stuck in a stone or tree.
Recognition by unique ability to bend bow.
Recognition by unique ability to swing spear.
Only one man can lift small pot from ground.
Recognition by unique ability to cut (carve) tree, etc.
Recognition by unique ability to break iron apple with first stone cast.
Recognition by unique ability to perform magic act.
Recognition by ability to shed pearls for tears.
Only one man is able to read magic book.
Recognition by unique ability to shoot, swim, and drink.
Recognition by unique ability to handle easily a heavy stone.
Recognition by unique ability to play chess.
Recognition by unique ability to read inscription.
Only one man is able to pluck fruits from tree.
Bridegroom alone able to pluck flower from bride's grave.
Recognition by extraordinary prowess.
Recognition by unique manner of performing an act.
Recognition by unique manner of playing lute.
Recognition by unique manner of playing harp.
Recognition by unique manner of playing flute.
Recognition by unique cookery. Only one person could have prepared the food in this way.
Recognition by unique needle-work.
Recognition of false bride by inability to finish true bride's weaving.
Recognition by embroidery.
Recognition by unique manner of carving chips. These sent down stream for recognition.
Recognition by ogam carving on withe (rod, tree).
Recognition by manner of throwing cakes of different weights into faces of old uncles.
Recognition by exact fitting of clothes.
Slipper test. Identification by fitting of slipper.
Recognition by shoes with which the father had once beaten his son.
Garment fits only true king.
Crown fits only legitimate successor to throne.
Person's rank betrayed by habitual conversation.
Disguised king (noble) recognized by habitual speech.
Impostor of low origin recognized by habitual speech.
Tailor married to princess betrays trade by calling for needle and thread.
Peasant boy masking as prince betrays self by his answers.
Recognition of maidservant substitute bride by her habitual conversation.
Weaver married to princess betrays trade by talking in his sleep.
Weaver married to princess betrays his identity when he unconsciously waves his hands as though he were weaving and asks for his shuttle.
Substitution of low-caste boy for promised child detected when he prefers long road to short one through jungle (swimming instead of ferry, etc.)  India: *Thompson-Balys.
Slave recognized by his conversation, habits, and character.
Recognition of royalty by personal characteristics or traits.
Princess on the pea. Princess recognized by her inability to sleep on bed which has a pea under its dozen mattresses.
High-spitting the test of a chief.
Test of king (pope): his candle lights itself.
Flame issuing from mouth as sign of royalty.
Unknown prince shows his kingly qualities in dealing with his playmates.
Unknown prince reared by fisher spends money on princely tastes.
Prophecy for newborn princesses: the one who takes gold in the mouth will be married to a prince; the one who takes hawkweed, to a peasant.
Task: to ride horse whereby one becomes king.
Test of royalty: ability to sow, reap, and winnow rice in one day.
King recognized by unique ability to occupy certain seat (Siege perilous).
Chariot tilts under anyone who is not entitled to throne.
Chief in disguise carries bundle so large that rank is recognized.
Recognition by perfume.
Recognition of deity.
God recognized by his supernatural powers.
Milk gushes forth from cows when they sit under tree inhabited by deity.
Test of a god: when his image is bound it frees itself.
God in disguise recognized by tokens on his feet and hands.
Girl sleeping naked awakened: is she a goddess?. If mortal, she will cover herself; if a goddess, will not.
Cannibal recognized by cloud of dust raised.
Cannibal nature of woman recognized when she devours dead buffalo raw.
Demon recognized by corpse it occupies turning to worm when stake is driven through it.
Animal in human form recognized.
Fox (in man's form) cries out like a fox in his sleep.
Fox (in man's form) betrays identity when he procures fox-food for human wife.
Recognition through personal peculiarities miscellaneous.
Unique scent of their rice betrays abandoned children.
Recognition by bodily marks or physical attributes.
Recognition by scar.
Recognition by birthmark.
Recognition through branding.
Recognition through branding with hoof-marks.
Sacred animals branded by conjurer.
Recognition by tatoo.
Recognition by wound.
Recognition by hole burned in hand when woman removes glove.
Mutilation of children's bodies for identification.
Recognition by missing member.
Recognition of resuscitated person by missing member.
Recognition by broken tooth.
Recognition by missing finger.
Severed finger as sign of crime. Robber bridegroom thus detected.
Recognition of murdered person by severed fingernail.
Recognition by missing toe.
Recognition by description of woman with missing hands.
Recognition by artificial hands.
Tell-tale hand-mark. Clandestine lover is identified by paint marks left on his skin by his mistress.
Disguised mistress identified by chalk marks left on back by lover.
Clandestine lover identified by scratches left on face by lady.
Recognition by ornaments under skin.
Recognition of twins by golden chain under their skin.
Recognition of disenchanted person by ornaments under his skin.
Recognition by means of ring enclosed in wound.
Recognition by grain of gold under skin.
Recognition of transformed person (animal).
Recognition of man transformed to horse.
Recognition of person transformed to animal.
Person transformed to animal recognized by his eyes.
Person transformed to animal recognized by ability to read.
Horse recognizes kol transformed to look like his master and throws him off.
Marvelous horse identified by prince though in form of miserable worn-out one.
Recognition of other transformed persons.
Woman transformed to flower is recognized by the absence of dew on petals.
Recognition of disenchanted person by physical attributes.
Recognition of disenchanted person by thread in his teeth. As werwolf he has torn woman's apron and caught thread in teeth.
Werwolf killed and recognized by man's clothes under the wolf's skin or rosary on the neck.
Person disenchanted from animal "unable to hide his tail.
Person disenchanted from animal unable to eat after manner of men.
Marks of royalty.
Star on forehead as sign of royalty.
Moon on forehead and stars in palm of hand as sign of royalty.
Gold (silver) hairs as sign of royalty.
Golden body of boy as sign of royalty.
Pearls from hair as sign of royalty.
Roses from lips as sign of royalty. Princess laughs roses.
Cross between shoulders as sign of royalty (nobility).
Bright eyes as sign of royalty (nobility).
Luminous face as sign of royalty.
Gold tint as sign of royalty.
Child born with chain around neck: sign of royalty.
Girl born with costly jewels: sign of royalty.
Prince born with bow of gold and string of silver.
Tears of blood: sign of royalty.
Red teeth as sign of royalty.
Marvel as sign of royalty.
Tree bows before prince.
Water stands still before prince.
Frogs croak at prince's command.
Chariot horses spring at anyone who is not entitled to throne.
Two blocks of stone that move apart to allow passage of chariot of true king.
Stone screams under feet of legitimate king.
Arrows turn aside for prince (king).
Gold in stool as sign of royalty.
Identification by a hair.
Identification by hair found floating on water.
Identification by hair dropped by bird.
Recognition by hair found in a fish which has swallowed it.
Recognition by golden hair.
Identification by wolf's hair.
Recognition by missing hair.
Recognition of murderers by their short hair.
Recognition by feather.
Youth shoots raven and takes feather to raven's sister as token.
Identification by feather taken from hero when he was transformed to bird.
Recognition by physical attributes miscellaneous.
Troll's daughter after being cooked in kettle recognized by golden fingernail.
Identification of man by his little toe.
Recognition by voice.
Recognition by smile. Sultan frees prisoner when he recognizes him as a former aid.
Identification of man by his skull.
Recognition by large breasts that woman in bed is not husband's wife.
Recognition of monk by his large organ.
Identity established because one of man's teeth is blue.
Identification by tokens.
True redeemers to be recognized by tokens.
Clandestine lover recognized by tokens.
Hero lies by sleeping girl and leaves identification token with her.
Hero takes token from sleeping princess.
Clandestine visit of princess to hero betrayed by token.
Clandestine visit of lover to queen betrayed by token.
Identifying tokens sent with messenger.
Tokens sent to jailor as warrant of king's authority.
Marriage tokens identifying lover.
Tokens between lovers.
Ring sent from husband to wife as token that he has been baptized, and that she should also be.
Token sent as warning.
Token sent with youth to relatives, that they may take care of him.
Rescue tokens. Proof that hero has succeeded in rescue.
Tokens of exploits.
Branches broken from tree to prove journey.
Cup taken as proof that one has been present at feast.
Flail substantiates story of witnessing threshing in heaven.
Stolen ring as proof of daring theft.
Captive sends token of safety.
Inscribed name on article as token of ownership.
Saber with king's name inscribed on it.
Articles of clothing with name embroidered on them taken as tokens.
Ring with names inscribed on it.
Handkerchief with name on it.
Garlands (flowers) as token.
Recognition by tokens left as trail.
Identification by ornaments.
Recognition through precious metal.
Recognition through gold found in eagle's nest.
Recognition by gold wrapped in mantle.
Identification by producing three golden apples.
Identification by necklace.
Identification by jewel.
Recognition by smell of jewels worn about neck.
Identification by ring.
Recognition of wife's ring in friend's possession informs husband of her unfaithfulness.
Identification by ring baked in cake.
Identification by ring baked in bread.
Identification by ring dropped in pitcher of wine.
Identification by ring dropped in glass (cup) of wine.
Identification through broken ring.
Recognition through arm-ring.
Recognition by ring springing off finger.
Recognition by medallion (plaque).
Identification through ring concealed in garland.
Recognition through gold ring with owner's name engraved on it.
Recognition by earrings.
Recognition by bracelet.
Identification by amulet.
Identification by matching parts of divided token.
Identification by broken weapon. Point of weapon broken off. Later found to match rest of weapon.
Identification by matching weapon with wound.
Identification by indenture. Each of two persons keeps his half of a contract which has been torn in two. Fitting of the halves brings about recognition.
Identification by fitting together two pieces of parchment.
Pieces taken from flags serve to identify.
Parts of slain animals as token of slaying.
Dragon-tongue proof. Dragon slayer cuts out the tongues and uses them later to prove his identity as slayer.
False dragon-head proof. Impostor cuts off dragon heads (after tongues have been removed) and attempts to use them as proof of slaying the dragon.
Tongue as proof that man has been murdered.
Tongue of slain giant as proof of slaying.
Arm of monster kept as token of innocence of dog.
Head of monster as token (proof) of slaying.
Monster's beard as proof of visit.
Ears, fingers and noses of demons cut off as proof of killing them.
Recognition of tiger-slayer by tips of ears, nose, and tail of tiger.
Teeth and fingernails of slain cyclops taken as proof.
Beak and claws of slain monster as proof of slaying.
Abandoned son shows claws and tail of tiger to which his parents have exposed him.
Identification between lovers by matching claw and leg of dragon.
Sex organs of enemy as proof of slaying.
Identification by severed limbs.
Identification by severed hand.
Severed head as proof of killing.
Identification by cloth or clothing.
Identification by garment.
Identification by royal garments.
Identification by feather cloak.
Identification by scarf.
Identification by handkerchief.
Identification by glove.
Identification by veil.
Identification by girdle.
Identification by cut garment. Garment is cut and fragment taken as token.
Identification by shred of garment of rescued princess used as bandage for wound.
Identification by cloth or clothing miscellaneous.
A piece of cloth on one's back as a guarantee against his being eaten on the way.
Needle left in garment of husband by abducted wife as sign.
Identification by tokens miscellaneous.
Identification by cup.
Identification by weapons.
Identification by sword.
Identification by spear.
Identification by war-club.
Recognition by dart.
Identification by coat of arms.
Identification by axe. Recognition by axe which man bears.
Recognition by knife. Man who is werwolf recognized by knife which was carried away by the wolf.
Recognition by calabash. Slave recognizes calabash and knows that girl lives.
Recognition through books.
Leaf (chip) sent down stream as a warning to one below.
Recognition by trimmed leaf thrown from tree hiding place.
Milk poured into stream as signal.
Recognition by token mouth-harp left by bed.
Identification by magic hand.
Recognition by tobacco-pipe.
Circumstances of recognition.
Attention drawn and recognition follows.
Attention drawn by magic objects: recognition follows.
Attention drawn by playing marbles with remarkable jewel.
Attention drawn by gold and silver decorated mouse: as princess turns after it, suitor recognizes her.
Recognition by ability to perform marvels.
Attention drawn by helpful animal's theft of food from wedding table; recognition follows.
Recognition when parents come to son (priest, pope) to be confessed.
Recognition by cup in sack: alleged stolen goods. Cup is placed in the sack of Joseph's brethren, they are accused of theft; this gives occasion for recognition.
Attention attracted by hints dropped by heroine as menial: recognition follows.
Heroine in menial disguise discovered in her beautiful clothes: recognition follows.
Enchanted heroine seen temporarily disenchanted: recognition follows.
Recognition because of imperfection of disguise.
