Hero's power to transform girl to carnation brings about recognition.
Husband attracted by wife's power of healing: recognition follows.
Abandoned child joins parents in game: recognition follows.
Abandoned child recognized in game.
Combat of unknown brothers brings about recognition.
Hero is served at table by his unknown son: recognition of his wife follows.
Geese tell of beauty of their mistress and bring about recognition.
Disguised hero's golden hair discovered by spying princess.
Tears fall on person below and indicate presence of those above (on cliff, tree, etc.).
Recognition by tear falling from tree where girl has been abandoned.
Seller of trinkets tells of heroine's address of son as "tiger's son" and brings about recognition of true bride.
Recognition through accidental encounter.
Poor people given alms: one of them recognized.
Woman entertains every traveler in the hope of finding her husband.
Impoverished husband in service of wife recognized.
Abandoned wife recognized among workers.
Outcast wife (children) builds castle identical with king's, invites him, and is recognized.
Recognition of abandoned child when parent comes to him for relief from famine.
Abandoned queen invites all to forest, gives appropriate food to her persecutors, and is recognized.
King finds note with children in casket floated down river identifying them as his.
Recognition of transformed person among identical companions. Prearranged signals.
Recognition of person among identical companions.
Recognition of disguised princess by bee lighting on her.
Insect points out deity by settling where he is.
King selected by having a cricket light on his head.
Recognition of disguised princess by bull.
Recognition of own cow in herd of twenty thousand. Hornet helper.
Father recognizes son after having thrown him in oven.
Animal (object) indicates election of ruler.
King selected by elephant's bowing to him.
Elephant raises girl three times to be king's wife.
Bird indicates election of king (pope).
Horse indicates election of emperor.
Man before whom riderless car stops chosen king.
Man before whom oxen stop chosen king.
Stone of destiny (Lia Fbil). Roars out under rightful king.
Pope selected by chair moving toward candidate.
Animal will serve only certain man.
Horse will permit only certain man to ride him.
Disguised man recognized by dog.
Chieftain recognized by faithful swineherd.
Chieftain recognized by former captive.
Animal first to recognize his returned master.
Recognition by "force of nature". Unknown member of family immediately and magically recognized.
Recognition of son by gushing up of milk in mother's breasts.
Child mystically recognizes woman as his mother.
Sick prince's pulse beats violently when his loved one passes by.
Fire issues spontaneously from fireless hearth when man approaches.
Ghost of unknown child passes over heads of parents and bursts in a spray of blood.
Recognition by unmasking.
Beating brings about outcry and recognition.
Identification by nurse. Long-missing person identified by his childhood nurse.
Recognition by miraculous sight of seer (saint).
Hero spits twice at his wife as sign of recognition.
Recognition by servant: saves master from death.
Princess appears before crane (who had demanded her in marriage) and is recognized by him despite loathly disguise.
Recognition by supernatural manifestation.
Recognition of man acceptable to God: knife leaps into his hand.
Test of guilt or innocence.
Guilt or innocence of souls tested by bridge.
Criminal detected by having child hand knife to him.
Magic manifestation at execution proves innocence.
Sword magically changed to wood when executioner is to decapitate innocent person.
Gallows rope breaks when innocent person is hanged.
Grass refuses to grow: indication of innocence of man hanged there.
Ineradicable handprint as indication of innocence.
Indications of innocence.
Garden filled with flowers on innocent girl's approach.
Voice from heaven testifies to innocence of accused.
Church door opens magically, as proof of priest's innocence.
Decision made by contest.
Decision of victory by single combat between army leaders.
Decision by single combat or holmgang of who is to marry girl.
Holmgang to decide owner of gold.
Holmgang to decide who is to be king.
Trial by combat. Guilt or innocence established in judicial combat.
Vindication by champion. Usually noble lady or king accused.
Judicial combat interrupted by friends of loser.
Wrestling to test legitimacy of son.
Ordeals. Guilt or innocence thus established.
Ordeal by fire. Suspected person must pass through or jump over fire to determine guilt or innocence.
Ordeal by burning coal.
Ordeal: carrying live coals in robe or cloak without harm to garment or bearer.
Sanctity of person tested by survival in burning house.
Sanctity of books tested by throwing them into fire.
Ordeal by hot iron.
Ordeal: virgin to pull on hot iron and name men. Only with guilty will she and he be burnt.
Ordeal by red-hot iron applied by druids.
Ordeal by burning oil.
Ordeal by boiling water.
Ordeal by spitting. Extinguishing fire is proof of innocence.
Ordeal by water. Guilt or innocence shown by ability to swim.
Ordeal by water applied by druids.
Legitimacy of children tested by dipping them in river.
Ordeal by holy water. If simpleton closes his eyes to holy water he is possessed; if he laughs he is merely an idiot.
Guilt or innocence shown by effect of enchanted water.
Sanctity of books tested by throwing them into water.
Ordeal by poison.
Ordeal by crocodiles (snakes). Judgment depends on whether person is devoured or rejected by crocodiles.
Ordeal by kissing poisonous serpents.
Ordeal by rope-walking.
Ordeal: walking on ladder of knives.
Ordeal: walking on eggs.
Ordeal by balance. Defendant is weighed twice. He must be lighter second time.
Ordeal: carrying murdered man's blood. Must not spill it.
Ordeal by creeping under a sod partially detached from the earth without its falling down.
Ordeal by bread and cheese. Declaration: if I am not innocent may I choke on bread and cheese.
Ordeal: taking stone out of bucket. Color indicates guilt or innocence.
Ordeal: names of suspected persons are placed in chalice on altar: the one to whom the lot falls is guilty.
Scales test: weighing witch against Bible.
Ordeal: cock under pot crows when guilty person touches pot.
Ordeal by exposure.
Other tests of truth.
Worn-out shoes as proof of long journey.
Credential tests: proof that messenger comes from certain person.
Riding speckled horse as credential test.
Nature fruitless if false judgment is passed.
Person magically disfigured when he speaks falsely.
Casting lots as truth test.
Incantation which when recited over certain "lots" causes them to distinguish between guilt and innocence.
Test of death: to see whether person is dead or feigning.
Sham-dead person tested by hot lead poured on hand.
Sham dead tested by stinging insects down back.
Crocodile masking as dead obeys suggestion that he make flesh quiver.
Sham dead tested by pricking.
Test of death by putting burning wood in the mouth of fallen warriors.
Sham dead detected by batting eyes.
Test of truth by magic object.
Bocca della Verita. Person swearing oath places hand in mouth of image. If oath is false the hand is bitten off.
Oath of truth before magic lion. If oath is false perjurer is dismembered.
Stone of truth. When one stands on it he must utter truth.
Stone cannot be moved by one who speaks falsehood.
Magic stone detects perjury: sheds water.
Stone on which saint was born pours forth water when perjury is committed under it. "But if (the) oath be true, the stone remains in its proper nature."
Other magic object tests truth.
Tree tests perjury.

Thief detected by psalter and key. Closed Bible with key inside at magic text loosely held by diviner and client. Name of suspected thief on end of key. As verse is spoken, if name is that of thief, book and key will turn around.
Thief detected by sieve and shears. Sieve put on open shears and then grasped by two fingers so as to balance. Charm recited. If sieve trembles when name is called, that person is guilty.
Stick with money in it breaks and betrays thief who swears his innocence.
Oath taken before image. If oath is false the image turns around (or changes color).
Chain around neck tests truth. Tightens when wearer speaks falsehood.
Magic object cast on water sinks if person is guilty.
Magic object clings to hand of guilty person.
Magic spring detects perjury: disfigures perjurer.
Magic spring detects parricide and idolatry.
Well rises for sheep only for rightful owner.
False judgment by judge causes fruit to fall. Just judgment by judge causes fruit to be perfect.
Pig that can be boiled only after four true stories are told.
Truth-testing vessel.
Magic cup as test of truth and falsehood.
Calumniated princess' dead body fails to rot; accuser repudiated.
Act of truth. Person asserts a thing as true declaring: "If my words are true, may this or that happen."
Test: telling true stories.
Placing hand on genitals as test of truth.
Amount of blood in spittle as test of complete subjection. Incomplete till all is blood.
If oath is false, fruit will fall.
Oath taken on boy's head: boy to die if false.
Act of truth: boy falls dead though what has been said is the truth; when lie is told he is resuscitated.
Women swear falsely by their husbands and children, who immediately fall dead.
Act of truth: island sinks into sea, after hanging of man who has appealed to God to cause the phenomenon as indication of his innocence.
Act of truth: cursed church clock never runs correctly.
Oaths before gods as test of truth.
Test: which of twins is elder. Younger unthinkingly hands chopsticks to elder and thus betrays his junior rank.
Test of innocence: apple and gold offered. Innocent person takes apple.
Test of child's innocence: onyx stone and coal of fire offered.
Holiness of saint tested: asked to perform miracles.
Grade of holiness tested: one whose candle burns down first.
Gold in the Bible. A man professes to be a great Bible reader. King leaves a piece of money in the Bible. On his next visit it is still there.
Test of sin.
Exposure in boat as test of sin.
Footsteps in manure (dust) as proof that dead man has walked.
Tests connected with marriage.
Excessive demands to prevent marriage.
Task: to win ogress' daughter for a bride.
Suitor tests. A suitor is put to severe tests by his prospective bride or father-in-law.
Tests for hero, husband of supernatural (divine) wife.
Brother unwittingly qualifies as bridegroom of sister in test.
Inspection test for suitors. Suitors for princess's hand must present themselves for public inspection.
Physical and mental requirements for suitors.
Successful suitor to be without blotches.
Successful suitor must have gold teeth.
Suitors chosen with feet as only part seen.
Successful suitor must have whitest hands. Blacksmith qualifies because of frequent washing of hands.
Successful suitor must have the prettiest hands; not whitest, but dark with scars and gold rings.
Successful suitor must have cheeks like blood, skin like snow and hair like a raven.
Suitor test: correct wearing of clothes.
Suitor test: to be able to go through a wall.
Bridegroom-to-be has to have three pecks, three quarts of gold and an animal with a horn on his head pointing to the sky, and a large red hair.
Suitor test: obedience and humility before bride.
Princess will marry whoever will give her anything she wishes for a month.
Fairy will marry king only if he will either cut off son's head or give up fasting on eleventh day.
Suitor's sincerity tested.
Suitor's sincerity tested by reporting girl's death. All but one make excuses for not helping with funeral.
Suitor's sincerity tested by seven years' banishment.
Suitor test: to whom the princess turns. Rival suitors sleep with princess. The one she turns to is to have her. They vie in enticements.
Suitor test: to make the princess fall in love with him.
Suitor contest: bride offered to suitor giving the token of the greater love.
Suitor test: apple thrown indicates princess's choice. (Often golden apple.)
Orange (lemon) thrown to indicate princess's choice.
Flowers thrown to indicate princess's choice.
Ball (goblet) thrown indicates princess's choice.
Suitor test: garland thrown indicates girl's choice.
Expressing love by throwing little stones.
Long term of service imposed on suitor.
Seven years of service imposed on suitor.
Two years of silence imposed on suitor.
Gardener's son to marry princess if he remains in prison twelve years.
Test of suitor's love and endurance by constant postponing.
Suitor preferred who will pay enormous sum for bride.
Suitor test: hiding from princess. She has magic sight.
Suitor test: finding princess.
Suitor test: finding object hidden by princess.
Suitor test: to get to imprisoned princess in a year's time.
Suitor test: bringing leg that fits into dragon claw left by the beloved of the princess.
Suitor test: bringing maiden's lost shoe.
Suitor test: learning girl's name.
Suitor test: choosing princess from others identically clad.
Suitor test: choosing sweetheart's sedan chair from thirty others like it.
Suitor test: skill.
Suitor test: aptness in handicrafts.
Suitor test: constructing automatic peacock.
Suitor test: skill in archery.
Suitor test: eating a pomegranate without letting a single seed fall.
Suitor test: skill in hunt.
Suitor test: skill in fishing.
Suitor test: cleverness and learning.
Suitor test: power of endurance.
Suitor test: resisting intoxication after much drinking.
Suitor test: being swung by mustache without shedding tears.
Suitor test: enduring blow from spear.
Suitor test: standing naked in river through a winter night.
Suitor test: bathing in boiling water.
Princess to be married to man who withstands twelve years' fight.
Suitor contests: bride offered as prize.
Suitor contest: difficult riding.
Suitor contest: riding up glass mountain.
Suitor contest: riding to fourth story of tower.
Suitor contest: jumping horse over palace.
Suitor contest: riding up mast (spear).
Suitor test: jumping over high hedge.
Suitor contest: riding across pit.
Suitor contest: riding through fire.
Suitor contest: jumping river on horseback.
Suitor contest: jumping ditches and hedges of spears.
Contest in reaping: best reaper to get beautiful girl as wife.
Suitor contest: tournament.
Suitor contest: success in battle.
Suitor contest: bride offered to the one distinguishing himself most in battle. Girl loves both suitors equally.
Suitor contest: prize to one whose staff blooms. Told of Joseph in contest for Virgin Mary.
Suitor contest: shooting.
Suitors contest with bride's father in shooting.
Suitor contest: bending bow of woman's absent husband.
Suitor contest: race.
Loser in bride-race must die.
Race with princess for her hand.
Apple thrown in race with bride. Distracts girl's attention and as she stops to pick it up, suitor passes her. (Atalanta.)
Hero's confederate slows down princess with his breath. Extraordinary blower blows against her so that she is retarded and loses race.
Suitor contest: race with bride's father.
Suitor test: winning horse-race three times.
Suitor test: boat race.
Suitor contest: wrestling.
Suitor contest: wrestling with bride.
Princess wins wrestling match with suitor by revealing her breast. He looks and is beaten.
Suitor contest: aiming with missile.
Suitor contest: splitting antlers.
Suitor contest: trapping.
Suitor contest: carrying one hundred jugs of water from sea to castle in one day.
Princess given to the one confessing all his treachery.
Suitor contest: splitting block of wood.
Suitor contest: cheating.
Suitor contest: trial of strength.
Suitor contest: animal fight.
Suitor contest: cockfight.
Suitor contest: bullfight.
Suitor contest: throwing ball up to princess.
Suitor contest: throwing iron ball.
Suitor contest: eating one hundred carcasses at a sitting.
Suitor in contest with bride or member of her family.
Suitor in contest with bride.
Suitor test: duel with bride.
Suitor test: to defeat bride in game.
Suitor test: to defeat bride at dice.
Suitor test: to defeat bride in harping.
Suitor test: tournament with bride.
Shooting contest with bride-to-be.
Suitor contest with brother-in-law.
Suitor test: duel with father-in-law.
Groom and his army have to fight bride's army.
Girl demands suitor's life (or mutilation).
Lover has head cut off at girl's desire.
Suitor test: tribute of his severed hands.
Tasks assigned suitors. Bride as prize for accomplishment.
Bride helps suitor perform his tasks.
Otherworld mistress instructs hero how to perform tasks (imposed by her mother).
Bride's parents (supernatural) help suitor win in suitor contests.
Girl assigns tasks to her suitors.
Suitor task: to study philosophy for five years.
Suitor task: prince to learn a trade.
Devil as suitor assigned tasks.
Suitor tasks announced by inscription on statue.
Goddess assigns task to her mortal suitor.
Suitor task: avenging bride's father's death before marriage.
Suitor task: avenging bride's former fiance before marriage.
Suitor task: cutting open magic gourd.
Suitor task: killing ferocious animal.
Suitor task: to kill dragon to whom the princess is to be sacrificed.
Suitor task: killing lion guarding girl.
Suitor task: to slay thieving boar.
Suitor task: to kill treasure-guarding snake lying around the princess's chamber.
Task: hero's servant must kill giant pig.
Suitor task: killing tiger demons.
Suitor task: to kill other monsters.
Suitor task: to defeat enemies.
Suitor task: to bring enemy's head.
Suitor task: to overcome robbers.
Suitor task: to kill all earlier suitors.
Suitor task: to kill (defeat) unwelcome suitor.
Suitor task: to bring back food as a marriage present.
Suitor task: making weather calm.
Suitor task: controlling violent tide.
Suitors assigned quests.
Prospective father-in-law requires that suitor for his daughter's hand visit foreign country  (otherworld?). to learn feats of arms.
Suitor required to catch wild animals.
Suitor test: faithfulness.
Suitor test: keeping princess's secret.
Suitor test: making princess laugh. Sadfaced princess has never laughed.
Princess brought to laughter by people sticking together.
Princess brought to laughter by small animals.
Princess brought to laughter by foolish actions of hero.
Princess brought to laughter by indecent show made in quarrel with old woman at well.
Suitor test: outwitting princess.
Suitor test: forcing princess to say, "That is a lie."
Suitor test: bringing dumb princess to speak.
Princess to marry man who can make her speak to him in all watches of the night.
Dumb princess brought to speak by shepherd who insults her.
Silent princess gives right answer when talking monkey is given wrong one by suitor-prince.
Suitor test: entering princess's chamber.
Princess to marry man who can give her correct account of what happened in her bedchamber.
Suitor test: overcoming princess in strength.
Suitor test: lifting strong princess's giant weapon.
Suitor test: riding strong princess's horse.
Princess given to man who can heal her.
Maiden queen promises herself to the man who heals her husband and kills his bewitcher.
Suitor test: to consort with princess without sleeping. Suitors are given sleeping potion.
Suitor test: to live on small amount of food.
Suitor test: to live on as much food as can be piled on a leaf.
Suitor test: to make garden bloom in winter.
Suitor test: to plunge into a stream.
Suitor test: finding an extraordinary object.
Who will find the most marvelous thing?. Each finds some marvelous thing. It turns out, that to save the girl's life all the things must be used together.
Suitor test: finding a cow with silver horns.
Suitor test: finding a hog with silver bristles.
Suitor test: bringing marvelous tree.
Suitor test: obtaining flowers.
Suitor test: obtaining for bride a necklace like her mother's.  India: Thompson-Balys.
Suitor test: to get wedding dress so fine that it will go through ring.
Other suitor tests.
Suitor test: building causeway.
Suitor test: clearing land.
Bride test.
Ring (jewel) bride test. Hero will marry girl possessing certain ring or jewel.
Bride chosen from girls assembled at feast.
Deceased wife marriage test. Man will marry woman meeting certain specifications prescribed by his deceased wife.
Bride test: wearing deceased wife's clothes.
Bride test: wearing deceased wife's ring.
Bride test: size of feet.
Bride test: performance of tasks.
Bride contest: game.
Game of hide and seek with seven princesses to determine which is to be hero's wife.
Man marries girl bringing his clothes soonest.
Bride test: procuring food plants in shortest time.
Bride test: thrift.
Bride test: making dress from wasted flax.
Bride test: thrifty cutting of cheese. Three girls tested. First eats rind and all, second cuts away good cheese, third cuts away just enough.
Bride test: thrifty peeling of apple.
Bride test: thrifty scraping of bread tray.
Bride test: industry.
Bride test: key in flax reveals laziness. Suitor hides key in flax on spinning wheel. Finds it there next day.
Bride test: domestic skill.
Bride test: bread-making.
Bride test: bread-making dough under fingernails. After three weeks the girl still has dough under her fingernails.
Bride test: cooking griddle cakes.
Bride test: cloth-working.
Bride test: spinning girl cannot use spinning-wheel.
Bride test: weaving magic cloth, sewing magic shirt.
Bride test: sewing a shirt for bridegroom's father.
Bride test: skillful sweeping.
Bride test: cooking.
Bride test: ale brewing.
Bride test: cutting up a monster fish with scaly hide.
Bride test: kindness.
Suitor chooses kindly girl.
Bride test: kindness father-in-law disguised as beggar.
Wealthy (handsome) suitor disguised as beggar to test bride's kindness.
Prince disguised as a madman to test bride's character.
Bride test: greediness.
Bride test: obedience.
Bride test: to allow oneself to be beaten with shoe.
Bride test: constancy.
Bride's constancy tested by seven year's mourning over supposed dead lover.
Bride test: wisdom (cleverness).
Chastity test. Various means are employed to test a woman's (or man's) chastity.
Chastity test by magic objects or ordeals.
Magic object points out unchaste woman.
Magic stone as chastity test. At foot of bed: cannot be stepped on by unchaste woman.
Stone breaks when unchaste woman looks at it.
Magic tree as chastity test. Cannot be climbed by unchaste woman.
Magic plant as chastity test.
Magic drinking horn (cup) as chastity test.
Drinking bitter water as chastity test. Water will poison the unchaste.
Magic cup as chastity test: sticks to hands of adulterer.
Magic pin as chastity test. If it floats, woman is chaste.
Magic chair as chastity test. Unchaste woman cannot sit in it till bidden.
Mantle as chastity test. Will not fit unchaste woman.
Magic bridge as chastity test. Cannot be crossed by unchaste.
Magic statue as chastity test. Moves eyes in presence of unchaste woman.
Magic idol as chastity test. Turns black in presence of unchaste woman. Lights up in presence of chaste woman.
Magic bed and pillows as chastity test. Speak and reveal unchastity.
Magic spring as chastity test.
Unchaste woman dips arm into the water: skin boiled away.
Fountains as chastity tests. One fountain of clear water, other muddy.
Magic harp as chastity test. Plays out of tune at approach of unchaste girl.
Magic lamp as chastity test. Only virgin can light it.
Apple as chastity test. Fades if owner is not virgin.
Magic mirror as chastity index.
Catching salmon as proof of virginity.
Swan as chastity test.
Dust of Tabernacle as chastity test.
Chastity tested by ordeal.
Chastity ordeal: passing under magic rod. Unchaste woman bears twins.
Chastity ordeal: holding shaven and greased tail of bull.
Chastity ordeal: feather over door; if girl who enters blushes she is not a virgin.
Chastity ordeal: passing through fire.
Chastity ordeal: holding hot iron.
Chastity ordeal: oath on boiling oil.
Chastity ordeal: poisonous snake around girl's neck.
Chastity ordeal: drawing lover out of wall with single thread rope.
Chastity ordeal: jumping.
Chastity ordeal: jumping over magic thread.
Chastity ordeal: jumping over pit.
Special powers of chaste woman.
Special power of chaste woman: blowing out candle with one puff and relighting it with another.
Special power of chaste woman: making ball of water.
Special power of chaste woman: carrying water in sieve.
Special power of chaste woman: raising fallen elephant.
Chastity test: throwing certain number on dice.
If princess is chaste her weight will be only that of five flowers; if not, normal.
Tests for true lover.
Valley from which no false lover can escape until it has been entered by a true lover.
Tests for true husbands.
Crown exposes infidelity of husbands.
Tests for cuckolds.
Cuckold's knife cannot carve boar's head.
Horns grow on cuckold.
Chastity tests of holy men and monks.
Chastity index. Objects indicate faithfulness or unfaithfulness of separated lovers (husband or wife).
Clothing (cloth) as chastity index.
Shirt as chastity index. Remains white as long as woman (man) is true (Cf. +D1056.)
Handkerchief as chastity index. Will not soil as long as woman (man) is true.
Veil as chastity index. Flowers on veil fade on head of unchaste.
Flower as chastity index.
Rose as chastity index. Fading rose indicates unfaithfulness.
Three roses fall as sign of unfaithfulness.
Lily as chastity index.
Lotus flower as chastity index.
Blooming staff as chastity index.
Ornament as chastity index.
Ring as chastity index. Indicates faithfulness by color.
Fruit as chastity index.
Apple as chastity index: shines as long as woman is chaste.
Weapon as chastity index.
Sword as chastity index: will not spot while woman is faithful.
Chastity index miscellaneous.
Picture as chastity index: indicates by its color.
Painting on wife's stomach as chastity index.
Drinking-tube as chastity index: retains taste of another's lips.
Other indications of chastity.
Talking private parts betray unchastity.
Disguise to test bride's chastity.
Chastity test: king weighs princess against a flower.
Wife tests.
Test of wife's patience. Griselda. Children stolen and attendance at wedding to another demanded.
The clever wife in disguise wins a second wife for her husband.
Test of wife's endurance. Haughty princess married to beggar and must endure poverty and menial work.
Feigned death to test wife's faithfulness.
Feigned absence to test wife's faithfulness.
Other tests of wife's love or faithfulness.
Feigned illness to test wife's love. Husband feigns loss of genitalia.
Wife's faithfulness tested by proposal in another's name.
Test of wife's ability to keep secret.
Test of wife's ability to keep secret: the buried sheep's head. Husband tells her that he is burying head of murdered man. She is to keep secret. She tells. When head is dug up it is sheep's head.
Test of wife's obedience.
Test of wife's obedience: finger in hole. Disobedient wife puts her finger into the hole where her husband has fixed sharp nails.

Test of wife's obedience: the one command. Upon his wife's insistence that he test her by giving one command the husband tells her not to go into the oven while he is away. She does so and oven falls on her.
Test of wife's obedience: not to eat leeks. Although she does not like them, she immediately begins to want them.
Man leaving home warns wife not to wash face in puddle in dunghill. She does. He cannot understand why; she cannot explain.
Test of wife's obedience: decorating house.
Complacent wife agrees with all of husband's absurd statements.
Husband tests false wife by sleeping on her hair. Had always done so with true bride.
Wife tests miscellaneous motifs.
Widow prepared for suttee can lift by little finger heavy stone by temple.
Father tests. Test as to who is unknown father of child.
Infant picks out his unknown father.
Infant indicates his unknown father by handing him an apple.
Baby picks out his disguised father from a crowd by handing him a bow.
Infant picks out his unknown mother.
Animals compete as messenger to call father of new-born child. Their voices are tried.
Test of unknown father: gold on street. Princess has gold put on street leading to her. The man who rides over the gold-covered street without noticing is the father of her child.
Test of paternity. Child tested to see if it is child of certain father.
Test of paternity: adhesion of blood. Blood of real son will adhere to dead father's bones.
Test of paternity: shooting at father's corpse. Youngest of supposed sons refuses to shoot and is judged the only genuine son of dead emperor.
Other marriage tests.
Test of mother's and father's love for children.
In large family father unwilling but mother willing to sell children.
Test of faithfulness of husband and wife.
Husband refuses to murder his wife for high honors; wife agrees to murder husband.
Husband has a friend woo his wife: she is seduced.
Husband has friend woo his wife: wife is generous to certain point only. Husband makes her wear dress symbolic of her generosity blouse of coarse cloth; dress of gold brocade.
Husband has friend woo his wife: seduction narrowly averted by frightened husband's intervention.
Husband castrates himself to test wife's faithfulness.
Virility test for husband.
Maternity test: to produce a baby within a year.
Mother test.
Baby finds its mother, goes to her for suckling.
Mother test: milk goes long distance into child's mouth.
Old woman suckles all babies at son's circumcision to prove she has borne child.
Irish myth: *Cross, Chauvin VII 160, VIII 11ff.; West Indies: Flowers 459.
Sons tested for skill.
Test of wisdom.
Test of wisdom: wise man sends ruler magic gems. Ruler admires their beauty but neglects to inquire of their virtues.
Wise man answers questions of many with single speech.
Sons tested for wisdom; given same amount of money. What will they do with it?
Test of learning.
Test of religious learning.
Test of musical ability.
Song duel. Contest in singing.
Test of skill in handiwork.
Contest in lifelike painting.
Contest in lifelike painting: fly on saint's nose. Second artist in first artist's absence paints a fly on a saint's nose in a picture. On his return the first artist tries to drive away the fly.
Contest in lifelike painting: mare and curtain. First artist paints a mare so realistic as to deceive a stallion. Second paints a curtain which deceives the first artist.

Contest in lifelike painting: grapes and curtain. First artist paints a bunch of grapes so realistically that it attracts the birds. The second artist paints a curtain which deceives the first artist. He wins.
Barber's contest in shaving (without waking man).
Test of cleverness: uttering three wise words. Youths called on to do so display by their answers extraordinary powers of deduction.
Test of cleverness: uttering three truths.
Test of resourcefulness.
Test of resourcefulness: weighing elephant. Man puts him on boat; marks water-line; fills boat with stones until it sinks to same line; weighs stones.
Test of resourcefulness: finding how many people are in dark closed room. Fills room with evil smell; men call each other by name and disclose number.

Test of resourcefulness: carrying wolf, goat, and cabbage across stream. Man is to set across a stream, in a boat that will hold himself and only one other object, a wolf, a goat, and a cabbage. He must do this so that the wolf doesn't eat the goat, nor the goat the cabbage. Two solutions: (1) (a) take goat over, (b) take wolf over and goat back, (c) take cabbage over, (d) take goat over; (2) (a) take goat over, (b) take cabbage over and goat back, (c) take wolf over, (d) take goat over.
Test of resourcefulness: putting thread through coils of snail shell. Thread tied to ant who pulls it through.
Test of resourcefulness: to swing seventy girls until they are tired.
Test of resourcefulness: not to sit at the foot of couch. Servant gives prince a lemon to place on it indicating which is head and which foot of couch.
Test of resourcefulness: to eat food without untying cloth containing it; hole torn in cloth.
Test of resourcefulness: to get melon out of jar without breaking it. Melon is planted in jar made of unbaked clay. Jar is wrapped in a wet cloth so that it collapses.
Test of resourcefulness: to cook rice without fire (in hot sand).
Test of resourcefulness: to find relationships among three sticks: they are put in vessel of water; degree of sinking shows what part of tree each comes from.
Test of resourcefulness: to discover how old, respectively, three horses are. Youth drops water on each; one jumps fifteen paces only, another twenty, and the last bounds in air and gallops.
Wit combat. Test in repartee.
Princess offered to man who can defeat her in repartee.
Princess defeated in repartee by means of objects accidentally picked up. E. g., Hero: What red lips you have! Princess: There is fire inside. Hero: Then boil this egg (producing egg).

King defeated in repartee by boy, who thus wins girl. Boy: "Who would give a man a bath, feed him his rice, and then bring him the tamal-pan to chew?" King: "No one but a wife." Boy claims minister's daughter.
Princess offered to man who can defeat her in argument.
Test: making senseless remarks. King brought to say, "What is the sense in that?"
Contest in wishing.
Three brothers contest in wishing. Third wishes for all that the other brothers have wished for.
Wit combat among three sisters for additional dowry. Replies to husbands when their premarital pregnancy is noticed.
Contest in scolding as introduction to battle.
Literary contest won by deception: he who will be first silenced is the loser. When the false teacher answers in nonsense syllables, the true scholar is speechless and so loses contest.
Test: finding answer to certain question.
King propounds questions to his sons to determine successor.
Bride offered to man who can find answer to question.
Tests of cleverness or ability: miscellaneous.
Test: threading needle. Guest of convent is given choice of nuns. On the morrow he is given three opportunities to thread a needle. Success means reward, failure confiscation of his belongings.
Contest in making mouths water. Hero uses certain berry that always causes mouths of onlookers to water.
Chess game as test.
Tests of poetic ability.
Test: supplying missing half-stanza.
Contest in adding a verse which makes the first poet ridiculous.
Riddles proposed as tests of poetic ability.
Understanding poem as test.
Test: telling skillful lie.
Test: telling five lies which should so closely resemble the truth the tester will believe them himself.
Tests in guessing.
Princess offered to correct guesser.
Three caskets. Princess offered to man who chooses correctly from three caskets.
Choice of two sword sheaths (from one a gold shaft protrudes; from the other, a silver).
Suitor must prefer princess to treasures.
Test: to guess which of veiled sisters has golden hair.
Guessing with life as wager.
Guessing contest between kings.
Test: guessing trolls' names in order to save one's life.
Curse evaded by guessing names in magic writing.
Test: guessing unknown propounder's name.
Test: guessing unknown propounder's age.
Test: guessing unknown animal (plant).
Test: guessing origin of certain skin.
Test: guessing nature of certain skin louse-skin. Louse (flea) is fattened and its skin made into coat (drum, etc.)
Test: guessing nature of certain skin wolf-skin.
Test: guessing origin of animal lungs. Lungs of fattened lizard are further inflated.
Test: guessing nature of certain plant. Plant came from scrapings of princesses' bodies.
Test: identifying what type of rice is in sack.
Test: guessing nature of devil's possessions.
Test: guessing nature of devil's horse. Answer: he-goat.
Test: guessing nature of devil's cloth. Answer: goat-skin.
Test: guessing nature of devil's gold cup. Answer: cup of pitch.
Test: guessing nature of devil's roast meat. Answer: dead dog.
Test: guessing nature of devil's spoon. Answer: whale rib.
Test: guessing nature of devil's wine glass. Answer: horse's hoof.
Test: guessing nature of devil's plate. Answer: stone.
Test: guessing nature of devil's purse. Answer: whip.
Test: guessing person's thoughts.
"What am I thinking?". "That I am the priest." So answers youth masking as priest.
Test: guessing princess's birthmarks.
Question: "What is under my cloak?". Questioner has branch of blackthorn laden with berries under her cloak.
Guessing: whether more of a certain stone is above or below ground. A test set by heathen king for a saint.
Guessing sex of unborn child (or animal).
Test: to prophesy offspring of cow and mare.
Riddles. Only such riddles are treated in this work as appear in tales, ballads, myths, or the like.
Propounding of riddles.
Supernatural creatures propound riddles.
Queen propounds riddles.
Queen of Sheba propounds riddles to Solomon.
King propounds riddles.
Riddles sent to Solomon by King Hiram.
Saint as propounder of riddles.
Bridegroom propounds riddles at wedding feast.
Riddle propounded with penalty for failure.
Riddle propounded on pain of death.
Sphinx propounds riddle on pain of death.
Riddle propounded on pain of loss of property.
Fine for failure to solve riddle.
Riddle propounded on pain of loss of official position.
Death sentence escaped by propounding riddle king (judge) cannot solve *Type 927; *De Vries FFC LXXIII 314f.
Riddle assigned defendant in action. If he solves it he wins suit.
Escape from devil by answering his riddles.

Devil held off from person by answering his riddles. St. Andrew the Bishop, and the Devil. The Devil, in form of beautiful maiden visits a holy bishop. St. Andrew appears as a pilgrim, answers the questions through which the devil seeks to keep him at a distance and discomfits the devil.
Child in cradle guesses devil's riddle: all are saved.
Answers found in other world to riddles propounded on way.
Riddle contests.
King and rabbi exchange riddles.
Princess offered to man who can out-riddle her.
Man wins wife by instructing her how to answer her mother's riddles.
Woman gives self to solver of riddles.
Man marries girl who guesses his riddles.
Solvers of riddles.
Clever peasant girl asked riddles by king.
Clever peasant wife asks king riddles.
Conflict between peasant and nobleman decided so that each must answer riddles: peasant's daughter solves them.
Clever daughter construes enigmatic sayings.

Found mortar taken to king reveals peasant girl's wisdom. Peasant finds mortar in his field and against his daughter's advice takes it to the king, who demands the pestle as well. Peasant laments that he has not followed daughter's advice. King summons her.
King and abbot. King propounds three riddles to abbot to answer on pain of death. Herdsman disguises as abbot and answers questions.
Solomon and Marcolf. Witty questions and answers between youth and servant.
King Solomon as master riddle-solver.
King and clever youth. King asks questions; youth returns riddling answers.
King and clever minister. King propounds riddles and questions to his clever minister.
King and peasant vie in riddling questions and answers.

King and peasant: the plucked fowl. The king gives riddling questions to a peasant, who always interprets them right. The king says that he will send the peasant a fowl which he shall pluck. The king gives the same questions to his courtiers, who cannot interpret them. They pay the peasant good money for the answers. Peasant tells king that he has plucked the fowl.
Druid as solver of riddles.
Cleric as solver of riddles.
Clever prince interprets enigmatic statements.
Saint as solver of riddles.
Inscription on home of riddle-solver "I have no care."
Riddle propounded from chance experience. On way to riddle trial youth sees things that give him a clue for his riddles.
Happenings before feast give Samson clue for riddles.
Means of solving riddles.
Counterquestions. Riddles answered by a question that reduces the riddle to an absurdity.
Counterquestion: "What is difference between you and an ass?. What is difference between you and a cushion."

Reductio ad absurdum of riddle: stallions of Babylon. "Why is my mare restless when stallions of Babylon neigh?" Hero beats cat for having strangled a cock last night in Babylon (impossible distance away).
Answer to riddle found by trickery.
Riddle solved with aid of hidden informant.
Problem of why certain person cannot sleep solved by trickery.
Riddle solved by listening to propounder talk in his sleep.
Riddles solved with aid of propounder's wife.
Accidental discovery of answer to riddle.
Enigmatic statements. Apparently senseless remarks (or acts) interpreted figuratively prove wise.
Girl given enigmatic commands must do the opposite.
Three young men arrested tell who they are.
Arrested man tells who he is: before his father the great incline the head and give blood and money (barber).
Arrested man tells who he is: the hospitable fire of his father is sought (bean merchant).
Arrested man tells who he is: father throws himself into the ranks and holds them (weaver).
Arrested farmer tells who he is: one son is thief (priest), second beggar (teacher), and third murderer (doctor).
Riddling answers betray theft or adultery *BP I 198, II 361f.
Riddling answer betrays theft.

The full moon and the thirtieth of the month. Prince sends servant to clever girl with a round tart, thirty cakes, and a capon, and asks her if it is full moon and the thirtieth of the month and if the cock has crowed in the evening. She replies that it is not full moon, that it is the fifteenth of the month, and that the capon has gone to the mill; but that the prince should spare the pheasant for the partridge's sake. She thus shows him that the servant has stolen half the tart, half of the cakes, and the capon.
Riddling answers betray adultery.
Enigmatic statement betrays incest.
Woman's question to her husband disguised as woman, how many men she had in one night. This is properly understood as, how many helpers he had, and answered by lifting ten fingers.
Clever youth (maiden) answers king's inquiry in riddles.
King: What do you see?. Youth: One and a half men and a horse's head. (Himself, the legs of the king on horseback in the door, and the horse's head.)
King: Are you alone at home?. Youth: Not now; I see the half of two quadrupeds. (Two legs of the king and the forefeet of his horse.)
King: What is your father doing?. Youth: He is in the vineyard and is doing good and bad. (He prunes vines and sometimes cuts good and sometimes lets bad ones stay.)
King: What is your father doing?. Youth: Makes an evil greater. (Closes up a path; this causes another to be opened.)
King: What is your father doing?. Youth: Makes many out of few. (Sows grain.)
King: What is your father doing?. Youth: Makes better from good. (Hedges his field.)
King: What is your father doing?. Youth: Cuts wood which was burnt last year. (To pay old debts.)
King: What is your father doing?. Youth: He fences thorns with thorns. (Eggplant garden fenced with thorns.)
King: What is your brother doing?. Youth: He hunts; he throws away what he catches and what he does not catch he carries with him. (Hunts for lice on his body.)
King: What is your brother doing?. Youth: He runs back and forth. (Plows.)
King: What is your brother doing?. Youth: He sits between heaven and earth. (In a tree.)
King: What is your mother doing?. Youth: She does for another what the latter cannot do for her. (Lays out a corpse.)
King: What is your mother doing?. Youth: She shows the light of the world to one who has not yet seen it. (Assists at a birth.)
King: What is your mother doing?. Youth: She is baking the bread we ate last week. (To pay back borrowed bread.)
King: What is your mother doing?. Youth: She cuts off the heads of the well to cure the sick. (Kills chickens to feed her sick mother.)
King: What is your mother doing?. Youth: She drives away the hungry and compels the filled to eat. (Drives away the hungry hens and stuffs the geese.)
King: What are your mother and father doing?. Girl: Mother is separating earth (being a midwife), and father is mixing earth (at a funeral).
King: What is your mother doing?. Girl: She has gone to turn one into two (to split peas).
King: What is your sister doing?. Youth: She is mourning last year's laughter. (Nurses child, the fruit of last year's love affair.)
King: What are you doing?. Youth: I boil those which come and go. (Beans which keep rising and falling in water.)
King: Where shall I tie my horse?. Maiden: Between summer and winter. (Between wagon and sleigh.)
Maiden (to king): The house has neither eyes nor ears. (No child at window nor dog in yard to announce king's approach: he therefore finds her not dressed to receive him.)
Maiden (to king): Shall I feed you with loss or gain. (A slaughtered hen or milk.)
Girl to king: Should it (the flood) come I shall not come; should it not come, I shall come.
Other riddling answers.
Enigmatic conversation of king and peasant.

The four coins. (Focus.) King: What do you do with the four coins you earn? Peasant: First I eat (feed self); second I put out at interest (give my children); third I give back (pay debts); fourth I throw away (give my wife.)
King: Why did you not do it (marry so that sons could help you)?. Peasant: I did, but it was not God's will (I married three times but it was not God's will  to give me sons).
Riddling remarks of traveling companion interpreted by girl (man) at end of journey.

Man helps traveler and makes riddling remarks. Gives him food, shares his coat in rain, and carries him over stream. Reproaches him with traveling without mother, house, or bridge (nourishment, shelter, or horse).
Traveler says he is going to the city to see what has become of the seed he sowed in the street. (What has become of the girl he left in the city to await his return.)
Traveler says he is going to seek a hind that he saw in the woods ten years before. (A maiden.)
Traveler says he must look after his net to see if it has taken fish. (He has left his lady seven years before with a pledge of faithfulness. Net has taken fish lady has had lovers.)
One traveler to another: Let us carry each other and shorten the way. (Let us tell tales and amuse ourselves on the way.)
One traveler to another: That field (uncut) is already harvested. (Belongs to spendthrift who has already spent the money.)
One traveler to another (as they see corpse borne by): He is not entirely dead. (Has left good property.)
One traveler to another (when asked how he crossed an unbridged stream): I cross on an ashen bridge. (Found a ford with an ashen staff.)
One traveler to another: Is this cup valuable or not?. (Is your daughter married or not?)
Boy says that travelers should catch the mares (walking sticks that are in the jungle).
King gives enigmatic order to minister.
Enigmatic letter of king must be explained on pain of death.

King: Show me a ruby eight for a pice, nectar eight for a pice, and a faithless creature worth one-eighth of a pice. Minister: The lamp sells at eight for a pice and gives more light than any ruby; the water is the real nectar; and the dog is worthless and faithless lover because he follows anyone who feeds him.
Enigmatic counsels of a father. Taken literally bring trouble, but when properly interpreted are valuable.
Father-in-law gives daughter-in-law enigmatic permission to go home.
Father's counsel: walk not in sunshine from your house to your shop. (Attend to business, rising early and retiring late.)
Father's counsel: let pilav be your daily food. (Eat frugally.)
Father's counsel: marry a new wife every week. (Do not see your wife too much.)
Father's counsel: on wishing to drink wine go to the vat and drink it. (Stench in vat so great that desire for wine is turned to loathing.)
Father's counsel: if you want to gamble, then gamble with experienced gamblers. (If you see how wretched professional gamblers are you will not want to gamble.)
Father's counsel: dress up the trunks of trees, cover the road. (Plant the road with fruit trees and betel between the trees.)
Father's counsel: find treasure within a foot of the ground. (Sons dig everywhere and thus loosen soil of vineyard, which becomes fruitful.)

Father's counsel: the four wells. Three empty and one full (3 sons and father). Full one can fill the three empty but the three when full cannot fill the one when empty (sons when scattered will not support the father).
Father's counsel: dam up the outlets. (Keep expenditures down not outlets of rice-field as son-in-law thinks).
Father's counsel: don't stay too late with a concubine, nor tell her any secret.
Always eat bread with "honey". (Working diligently, your bread will be as sweet as honey.)
"Never greet anyone.". (Start your work the earliest, so that not you but others may greet you.)
"Always wear new shoes.". (Walk the fields bare-footed, wearing your shoes only when nearing the town.)
"Have a black look" (frown).
"Bite the ear" (do state affairs secretly).
"Take people by the locks" (use your influence to make people subservient to you).
"If you have to go to a prostitute, go early in the morning."
"When you go to the bazar, eat your morning meal first."
"A father should always check and never forgive; a mother should always forgive and never check."
"Do not plant a thorny tree."
Enigmatic advice: take only salt and water as food.
Extraordinary actions explained.
Man puts on shoes only when he wades river. (He cannot see what he is walking on.)
Man uses umbrella under trees. (To protect self from falling branches and bird droppings.)
Man cuts hooks for the revenge of his father (Hamlet).
Enigmatic statement made clear by experience.
"Love like Salt.". Girl compares her love for her father to salt. Experience teaches him the value of salt.
"Love like wind in hot sun.". Husband offended but later learns wife's meaning.
Poison in nectar: wife who betrays husband to his enemies.
Nectar in poison: mistress who saves her lover.
Dogs in human shape: friends who seduce man's wife.
Donkey ruling a kingdom: king condemning man unjustly.
Suitors receive enigmatic answers. Girls answer in single words, which, when arranged in certain order, show that they accept.
Inhospitality reproved enigmatically.
Enigmatic statement: roof has no eaves. (Else it would give the beggar shelter.)
Enigmatic statement: the tank (pond) does not belong to you. (Else you would have given the beggar fish to eat.)
Enigmatic statement: the flocks are only rocks and grass. (Else you would have given the beggar milk and curds.)
Enigmatic welcome of host. Sounds very inhospitable but properly interpreted makes guests welcome.
Symbolic invitation to continued liberality.
Enigmatic counsels of relatives (other than father).
Enigmatic counsels of a brother.

Enigmatic counsels of older brother. Gray younger brother asks well-preserved older brother for the secret of his good health. Answer: A measured mouth, a close purse, and a knot on the trouser's fly.
Other enigmatic statements.
Girl will not drink of water which had no father or mother  (i.e., stagnant).
Enigmatic statements of a sham mad man (Hamlet).
Clever flatterer: Sir, you are a full moon, and my sovereign is a new moon (the full moon will decline, but the new moon has but started on its growth).
Man asked to kill thousands, press hundreds beneath his arm, etc. (To shave his head, put some hairs under his arm, etc.) India: Thompson-Balys.
Enigmatic counsel: uproot old trees and plant new ones (dismiss old governors and appoint new).
Give coals orange color, let glimmer of gold appear like expanse of heaven, prepare two heads of darkness. (Request for chickens for breakfast.)
Symbolic interpretations.
Wise carving of the fowl. Clever person divides it symbolically: head to head of house, neck to wife, wings to daughters, legs to sons; keeps rest for himself.
Wise division of the goat (similar).
Symbolic meaning of numbers, letters, etc.
Symbolic meaning of numbers.
Symbolic meaning of numbers one to seven (ten, twelve). E.g. One: sun; two: Moses' tablets; three: three Maries; etc.
Symbolic interpretation of letters.
Symbolic interpretation of names.

Symbolic interpretation of playing cards. Soldier reproved for playing cards during church says that playing cards are his prayerbook and calendar. Ace: one God, one Faith, one Baptism; 2: old and new Testaments; 3: Trinity; 4: evangelists; 5: wise virgins; 6: days of creation; 7: sabbath; 8. Noah's family; 9: ungrateful lepers; 10: commandments; knave (jack): Judas; queen (of Sheba); king: God; 12 face cards: 12 months; etc.
Symbolic meaning of spiced and bitter tongue served at dinner.
Angel gives symbolic interpretation of value of work as well as of prayer. Works and prays where monk can see him.
Symbolic interpretation of sin. Priest drags heavy sack of sand behind him to show how men drag sin.
Discussion by symbols. Sign language.
Discussion between priest and Jew carried on by symbols. E.g., priest raises three fingers (Trinity); Jew raises arm (one God); etc.
Discussion between two poets (sages?). carried on in poetic obscure language.
Learned professor from one university examines by signs a professor at another university (actually shoemaker or miller or the like).
Princess declares her love through sign language: not understood.

Is town too full of anchorites?. Saint entering holy town is sent cup full to brim of milk by its worldly-minded fakirs that he may know the town can hold no more anchorites. Saint floats a flower on milk and returns cup.
Symbolic interpretation of official robes.
Symbolic interpretation of points on a bishop's hat.
Youth asks for branch of tree; promised root. (Branch = youngest daughter; root = eldest.)
Melons ripe and overripe analogous to girls ready for marriage.
Sign message sent by girl to enamored prince; interpreted by prince's friend.

Chief asks another for cutting of yams to complete his yam patch (daughter in marriage). Reply that seed yams for the year are shrivelled and old and it is too early for seedlings (his daughters are too young or too old).
Explanation of enigmatic phenomenon.
Explanation of phenomenon; a man who not only picks up wood but everything that lies in his path (a miser).
Explanation of phenomenon: large pond emptying itself into several smaller pools (man may spend without getting any return).
Symbolic interpretations of dreams.
Other symbolic interpretations.
Symbolic interpretation of chairs in heaven.
Symbolic interpretation of church and image therein.
Roots and branches of World-tree explained symbolically.
Symbolic interpretation of ineffectual thatching of house and building of fire in otherworld.
Symbolical interpretation of fight between one-legged bird and twelve-legged bird. One-legged bird symbolizes innocence; twelve-legged bird, guilt.
The unsolved problem: enigmatic ending of tale.

Skillful companions create woman: to whom does she belong?. Woodcarver carves a doll, tailor clothes her, gardener gives her speech (or the like). (Answer sometimes given: her father, her mother, or her husband).
Skillful companions resuscitate girl: to whom does she belong?
Girl rescued by skillful companions: to whom does she belong?
Hare and pig race across ditch. Each fails in his own way, pig behind hare. Which is winner?
Riddles of the superlative.
Riddle: what is the strongest?
What is the strongest?. A horse.
What is the strongest?. God.
What is strongest?. Earth.
What is strongest?. Woman.
What is strongest?. Truth.
What is mightiest?. Rain.
What is strongest?. Necessity.
What is strongest?. Wine.
What is strongest?. The king.
Riddle: what is the swiftest?
What is swiftest?. Thought.
What is swiftest?. The eye.
What is swiftest?. The sun.
Riddle: what is sweetest?
What is sweetest?. Sleep.
What is sweetest?. Peace in heaven.
What is sweetest?. Mother's breast.
What is sweetest?. One's own interest.
What is sweeter than sugar?. The princess's speech.
Riddle: what is the sweetest song?
What is the sweetest song?. Angel song.
Riddle: what is the sweetest sound?
What is the sweetest sound?. Bell-ringing.
What is the sweetest sound?. God's Word.
Riddle: what is the richest?
What is richest?. Autumn.
Riddle: what is the hardest?
What is hardest?. Parent's heart  (said by child being sacrificed).
What is the hardest?. Death.
Riddle: what is costliest?
What is costliest?. The earth.
Riddle: what is most beautiful?
What is most beautiful?. The spring.
What is most beautiful?. Earth.
Riddle: what is highest?
What is highest?. Sun, moon, and stars.
Riddle: what is deepest?
What is deepest?. The heart of man.
Riddle: what is longest?
What is longest?. The way through the world.
Riddle: what is the heaviest?
What is heaviest?. Lead.
Riddle: what is greenest?
What is greenest?. The Month of May.
Riddle: what is the most beloved?
What is most beloved?. Life.
What is most beloved?. Health.
Riddle: what is best?
What is best?. God.
What is best?. Water.
Riddle: what is brightest?
What is brightest?. The sun.
What is brightest?. Mother's eyes.
Riddle: what is softest?
What is softest?. The hand. (In order to lie soft one places his hand between the head and the pillow.)
What is softest?. Mother's bosom.
Riddle: what is the fattest?
What is the fattest?. The earth.
Riddles of the superlative miscellaneous.
Riddle: what is oldest?
What is oldest?. God.
Riddle: what four things are hardest to hold?
What four things are hardest to hold?. Wolf by eyebrows, bear by claws, snake by tail, hawk by beak.
Riddle: what are best and worst stones?
What are best and worst stones?. Best: altar, whetstone, millstone; worst: hailstone, stone in the eye, gallstone.
Riddle: what is the best fowl?
What is the best fowl?. The goose, since it makes the cabbage sweet and the bed soft.
Riddle: what is best religion Christian or Mohammedan?
What is best religion Christian or Mohammedan?. They are equally good:  as both eyes are equally dear to you, so are both religions to God.
Riddle: what kind of work occupies most men?
What kind of work occupies most men?. Healing, for every sick man practices this.
Riddle: what is greatest?
What is greatest?. Fame.
What is the greatest?. A sense of shame.
What is the greatest?. Charity.
What is the greatest villainy?. Stealing.
What is moistest?. The south wind.
Riddle: what is wisest?
What is wisest?. Time.
Riddle: what is most general?
What is most general?. Hope.
Riddle: what is most useful?
What is most useful?. Excellence.
Riddle: what is most shameful?
What is most shameful?. Cowardice.
Riddle: what is most pleasant?
What is most pleasant?. Love. (In spite of childbirth pains women continue becoming pregnant.)
Riddle: what is easiest?
What is easiest?. The natural.
Riddle: what is the hardest to skin?
What is the hardest to skin?. The male member.
Who are the best painters?. Women  (in the art of make-up).
Riddle: what is the best time to eat?. For the rich man, when he wishes; for the poor man, when he has something to eat.
What are the most accursed things?
What are the most accursed things?. A thriftless wife, a baldheaded daughter, a sour-faced daughter-in-law, a crooked axle, and a field which lies across the village road.
What is the most difficult to find and the most difficult to lose?. The truth.
Who are really irresistible?. Meat and drink.
Who are really meek?. Cows and daughters.
Which is best, domestic or ascetic life?. With good wife domestic life is best.
Which is the best of flowers?. Cotton.
What is the finest jewel?
What is most faithful thing in world?
What is most faithless thing in world?
Riddles of comparison.
Riddle: what is swifter than a bird, the wind or lightning?. The eye.
Riddle: what is dearer than gold?. Mother love.
Riddle: what is whiter than a swan?. An angel.
Riddle: what is sweeter than honey?
Riddle: what is softer than swan down?
Riddle: what is harder than stone?
Who is greater than God?. Man's purpose.
Riddles of distance.
Riddles of terrestrial distance.
Riddle: how far is it from one end of the earth to the other (east to west)?
How far is it from one end of the earth to the other?. A day's journey, since the sun makes it daily.
Riddle: how deep is the earth (or how far to lower world)?
How deep is the earth?. It is deep: my grandfather went into it (died) years ago and has not yet returned.
How deep is the earth?. My father went five years ago to measure it (died); when he returns I shall tell you the result.
Riddle: what is the center of the earth?
Where is the center of the earth?. Here; if you don't believe it, measure it yourself.
Where is the center of the earth?. Here, for the earth is round and any point can serve as center.
Riddle: how deep is the sea?
How deep is the sea?. A stone's throw.
How deep is the sea?. At first, knee-deep; further on, waist-deep, neck-deep; and beyond that over the head.
Riddles of heavenly distance.
Riddle: how far is it from earth to heaven?
How far is it from earth to heaven?. A day's journey, since Christ went to heaven in one day. (A half-day's journey, similar reason).
How far is it from earth to heaven?. A day's journey, since there is no inn to stop at on the way.
How far is it from earth to heaven?. So and so high, and if you don't believe it, measure it yourself.
How far is it from earth to heaven?. As far as you can see.
How far is it from earth to heaven?. As far as from heaven to earth.
How far is it from earth to heaven?. Not far; when it thunders there it can be heard here.
How far from earth to heaven?. A calf's (fox's) tail, if it were long enough.
How far from earth to heaven?. A leg's length, for it is written, Heaven is my throne and earth my footstool.
How far from earth to heaven?. One step, for they say, He stands with one foot in the grave and one in heaven.
How far from earth to heaven?. The devil knows for he has fallen this distance.
Riddle: how wide is heaven?
How wide is heaven?. So and so wide, and if you do not believe it, go measure it yourself.
How many exits from paradise?
Riddle: how far is it from happiness to misfortune?
How far is it from happiness to misfortune?. One day; yesterday I was herdsman and now I am abbot.
Riddles of weight and measure.
Riddles of weight.
Riddle: how much does the moon weigh?
How much does the moon weigh?. A pound, for it has four quarters.
How much does the moon weigh?. So and so much, and if you don't believe it go and weigh it yourself.
Riddle: how heavy is the earth?
How heavy is the earth?. Take away all the stones and I will weigh it.
Riddles of measure.
Riddle: how much water is in the sea?
How much water is in the sea?. Stop all the rivers and I will measure it.
How much water is in the sea?. So and so much, and if you don't believe it, go measure it yourself.
How much water is in the sea?. A tub-full if the tub is large enough.
How many measures of water are in the river?
Riddles of numbers.
Riddle: how many seconds in eternity?
How many seconds in eternity?. A bird carries a grain of sand from a mountain each century; when the whole mountain is gone, the first second of eternity has passed.
Riddle: how many stars in the heavens?
How many stars in the heavens?. As many as the grains of sand; if you don't believe it, count them yourself.
How many stars in the heaven?. Two million; if you don't believe it, count them yourself.
How many stars in the heavens?. As many as the hairs in the head; if you don't believe it, count them yourself.
How many stars in the heavens?. As many as the hairs in the goatskin (on a donkey).
How many stars in the heavens?. As many as the points on paper; if you don't believe it, count them yourself.
Riddle: how many hairs are in the head?
How many hairs are there in the head?. As many as are in the tail of my ass; if you don't believe it we will keep pulling out one hair from your beard and one from his tail.
Riddle: how many drops in the sea.
Riddle: how many leaves are on the tree?
How many leaves are on the tree?. As many as there are stems for.
How many leaves are on the tree?. So and so many; and if you don't believe it, go count them.
How many leaves are on the tree?. Counterquestion: how many stars in the sky?
Riddle: how many days have passed since the time of Adam?
How many days have passed since the time of Adam?. The seven days of the week.
Riddle of dates.
When were you born?. Its beginning is like its end, its top like its bottom (1691).
Are there more men or women in the world?
Riddles of value.
Riddle: how much am I (the king) worth?
How much am I (the king) worth?. Twenty-nine pieces of silver, for Christ was sold for thirty.
Riddle: how much is my beard (king's) worth?
How much is king's beard worth?. The months July, August, and September.
How much is king's beard worth?. A May rain (three rains in summer).
Riddle: how much is a golden plow (throne, crown, palace) worth?
How much is a golden plow (throne, crown, palace) worth?. A rain in May.
Riddle: how much does the sun earn for his daily work?
How much does the sun earn for his daily work?. A day's wages.
Riddle: how much is a certain crucifix worth?. Twenty-nine pieces of silver.
Metaphorical riddles.
Riddle of the year.
Riddle: tree with twelve branches, each with thirty leaves, black and white. Year, month, days and nights.
Riddle: tree with leaves white on one side and black on other. Year made up of nights and days.
Riddle: twelve cypresses with thirty boughs each. Years and months.
Riddle: palace consisting of 8760 stones; twelve trees, thirty branches, each with black and white cluster of grapes. Year, months, days, hours.
Riddle of the day and night.
Riddle: white brother, black sister: every morning brother kills sister; every evening sister kills brother; they never die. (Day and night.)
Riddle: black and white horses chasing each other. (Day and night.)
Riddle of the course of the sun.
Riddle: bird nests on top of one cypress in morning, on top of another in evening. (Bird is the sun.)
Riddle: who are the real travellers?. The son and the moon.
Riddle of king and courtiers.
Riddle: king in red; courtiers in white. (Sun and its rays.)
Riddle: king in white; courtiers in white. (Moon and stars.)
Riddle: king in red; courtiers in different colors. (Spring and flowers.)
Riddle: what is the mother who devours her children when they grow up?. (Ocean and rivers.)
Riddle white field, black seed. (Paper with writing.)
Riddle: two legs, three legs, four legs. (Man, three-legged stool dog.)
Riddle: four hang, four walk, two show the road, one wags behind. (Cow's teats, feet, eyes, tail.) (Other answers: cat, dog, horse, hog, etc.)
Riddle: six legs, four ears, two faces, etc. (Horse and rider.)
Riddle: bill white, horns on feet, knob on head (cock).
Riddle: who of fourfold beard is he, of azure foot and neck so ruddy?. Arrow.

Riddle of the Sphinx: what is it that goes on four legs in the morning, on two at midday, and on three in the evening. (Man, who crawls as a child, walks in middle life, and walks with a stick in old age.)
Riddle: two are better than three (two legs better than man with staff in old age).
Riddle: what is the creature that is of all countries, that is loved by all the world, and that has no equal?. (The sun.)
Riddle: the father not yet born, the son already at the top of the house. (Flame and smoke.)
Riddle: bird without feathers flies on tree without leaves. (Snow falls on bare tree.)
From wooden spring iron bucket makes stones from which water flows. (Metal stick picks stone from eye. If you rub lids with it, tears come.)
Allegorical riddles.
Riddle: what is that thou passest over with haste?. (The field of youth; the mountains of youth, etc.) Irish myth: Cross.
What house gives no hostages, cannot be burned, and cannot be harried?. (The fairy stronghold [sndh] of brugh na Boinne. )
Riddles of explanation.
Riddle: why is the hair gray before the beard?. (It is twenty years older.)
Riddle: why are there more days than nights?. (The moon turns some nights into days.)
Riddle: why are there more living than dead?. (There are some of the dead of whom we still speak.)
Riddle: why are there more women than men?. (Some women make women [i.e., weaklings] of their husbands.)
Riddles based on unusual circumstances.
Riddle: a fish was my father; a man was my mother. (Man eats magic fish and becomes pregnant; a girl is taken from his knee.)

Riddle of the unborn. I am unborn; my horse is unborn; I carry my mother on my hands. (A boy who has been taken from his dead mother's body digs up the body of his mother and makes gloves of her skin. He rides on a colt which has been taken from a dead mare's body.)
Riddle: seven tongues in a head. (A horse's head in which a bird's nest is found with seven birds in it.)
Relationship riddles arising from unusual marriages of relatives.
Riddle: what does God do?
What does God do?. He brings low the proud and exalts the lowly  (said by shepherd masking as bishop to king, who has exchanged places with him).
What does God do?. God is astonished that I sit on a horse and the king on an ass  (see +H797.1.)
Riddle: one killed none and yet killed twelve. (Horse is poisoned; raven eats of him and dies; twelve robbers eat raven and die.)

Riddle: deaths from sleepiness, anger, and greed. Elephant sleeps before snake's hole. Snake bites elephant and kills it. Jackal eats hole in elephant and is caught inside. Snake can't get out of its hole.
Riddle: from the eater came forth meat and from the strong sweetness. (Swarm of bees and honey in lion's carcass.)

Riddle of the murdered lover. With what thinks, I drink; what sees, I carry; with what eats I walk. (Queen has cup made from skull of her murdered lover; ring with one of his eyes; she carries two of his teeth in her boots.)
Riddle: drink this wine which a bird took to nest. (Stork took bunch of grapes to nest; boy makes wine from them.)
Formerly I was daughter, now I am mother; I have a son who was the husband of my mother. (Girl has nursed her imprisoned father through a crack in the prison wall.)
Riddles based on the Bible or legend.
Riddle: who first spun and when?. (Eve.)
Riddle: what were the clothes of Adam and Eve?. (Their hair.)
Riddle: who, having neither father nor mother, are dead?. (Adam and Eve.)
Riddle: who, having had father and mother, is not dead?. (Elias.)
Riddle: who, having had father and mother, is not dead like other mortals?. (Lot's wife.)
Riddle: who has had, here below, two names?. (Jacob-Israel.)
Riddle: what was the walking tomb with the living tenant?. (Jonah and the whale.)
Riddle: what is the land that has seen the sun only once?. (The bottom of the Red Sea during the passage of the Israelites.)
What is the land that has seen the sun only once?. (The land on which the waters were gathered after the creation.)
What is the tree that became flesh?. (Moses's staff.)
Riddle: what is that which has drunk water for its sustenance and eaten after its death?. (Moses's staff, which became a serpent.)
Riddle: the king is surrounded by his nobles; what is this like?. (The idol Bel surrounded by the priests of the god.)
Riddle: what did Christ do in his 30th year?. Answer: entered into his thirty-first.
Riddle: what does the king of the world of the Devas do?. Punishes the bad people.
What three not born of male and female ate and drank on earth?. (Angels who visited Abraham.)
Riddle: what house was full of dead?. (Philistines in the building demolished by Samson.)
What was not born, yet life was given to it?. (The golden calf.)
Other riddles.
Riddle: worth of the animal.
Riddle: what animal is good living but not dead?. (Ass.)
Riddle: what animal is good dead but not living?. (Hog.)
Riddle: what animal is good living and dead?. (Cow.)
Riddle: what animal is not good living or dead?. (Wolf.)
Riddle: animal qualities.
What animal which lives in sea-water will drown if taken out of it?. (Gnnm Abraein.)
What animal which lives in fire will burn if taken out of it?. (Tegillus, now called salamander.)
What animal has one voice living and seven voices dead?. (Ibis, from whose carcass musical instruments are made.)

Riddle: what are the two fixed, the two moving, the two joined, the two separated by jealousy, the two eternal enemies?. (Heaven and earth; sun and moon; night and day; soul and body; life and death.)
What two trees do not fade until they wither?. (Yew and holly.)
What goodness did man find on earth that God did not find?. (An overlord.)
Riddle: what are the two combatants without hands or feet or words?. (The bull and the buffalo.)
Riddle: what is that which is neither man nor jinn nor beast nor bird?. (Louse and ant.)
Riddle: what do crows do when they are five years old?. (They start their sixth year.)
Riddle: what six things are not worth doing?. (Sowing salt, mowing pebbles, drinking from an empty jug, making signs to a blind man, wooing at mealtime, playing a harp in a mill.)
Three stupid things for men to do (various answers).
Riddle: what is the difference between a poor man and a rich?. (Riches.)
Riddle: what is it that one buys who does not want it or use it?. (Coffin.)
Riddles with "none" as answer.
Riddle: how many dead mice go to a feast?. (None.)
Riddle: bottom and top of staff. Of the two ends which is the top and which the bottom?
Riddle: where is the root of the floor?. Below.
Riddles about flax.
Riddles about naphtha.
Tasks imposed. A person's prowess is tested by assigning him certain tasks (usually impossible or extremely difficult) to be performed either to escape punishment or to receive a valuable reward.
Tasks imposed on pain of death.
Tasks imposed on pain of death of relative (friend, hostage, etc. ).
Bird must bring orphan to king or bird will be killed.
Heads placed on stakes for failure in performance of task. Unsuccessful youths are beheaded and heads exposed. Hero sees them when he sets out to accomplish his task.
Task assigned the Gods.
Assignment of tasks in response to suggestion.
Tasks assigned at suggestion of jealous rivals.
Task (quest) assigned at suggestion of jealous co-wife.
Tasks assigned at suggestion of jealous brothers (sisters).
Tasks assigned by jealous parent.
Tasks assigned by jealous mother.
Task assigned at suggestion of jealous mother  (of prospective bride).
Task suggested by jealous co-wife of mother.
Tasks assigned at suggestion of jealous father.
Task assigned at suggestion of jealous father (of prospective bride).
Tasks assigned because of mother's foolish boasting. The mother foolishly boasts to the king that the daughter can perform an impossible task (often spinning).
Tasks assigned because of girl's (boy's) own foolish boast.
Tasks assigned because of man's boast.
Tasks imposed at suggestion of spouse (sweetheart).
Tasks imposed because of wife's foolish boast.
Malicious wife reports that her husband is a famous doctor: he is commanded to cure the princess.
Task imposed because of girl's foolish boast.
Tasks assigned at suggestion of wife and paramour.
Tasks assigned at own unwitting suggestion. Jason thus sent for the Golden Fleece.
Tasks assigned at suggestion contained in letter borne by the victim.
Assignment of tasks in response to suggestion miscellaneous.
Tasks assigned at suggestion of treacherous servants.
Task upon suggestion of barber.
Tasks assigned at suggestion of religious person.
Task assigned at suggestion of parrot.
Impossible task assigned by plaintiff as proof.
Task assigned at suggestion of treacherous soldier.
Tasks assigned at instigation of queen (disguised ogress).
Assigners of tasks.
King (father) assigns tasks to his unknown son.
Task set by king to sons to determine heir to kingdom.
Departing husband assigns his wife tasks.
Tasks assigned before man may rescue wife from spirit world.
Task assigned before wife may rescue husband from supernatural power.
Tasks assigned prisoner so that he may escape punishment.
Tasks assigned as ransom.
Tasks set by deity.
Tasks as trial of prowess of mortal by gods.
Task assigned by angel on God's order.
Tasks imposed as tribute.
Tasks imposed as fine.
Tasks assigned in order to get rid of hero.
Prince envious of hero's wife assigns hero tasks.
Husband assigns tasks for king who has stolen his wife.
Disagreeable tasks set hero to do so that he will disobey and be killed.
Tasks assigned to devil (ogre).
Princess sets hero tasks.
Princess throws handkerchief high in tree; asks hero to get it.
Maiden queen sets hero three dangerous tasks in order to disenchant her sisters.
Princess orders hero to bring her rings of another princess.
Quest assigned by scorned princess.
Queen of Sea sets hero tasks.
Relative assigns tasks.
Wife assigns husband tasks.
Sisters-in-law impose tasks.
Tasks assigned by stepmother.
Task imposed by elder brothers.
Witch assigns tasks.
Tasks assigned because of longings of pregnant woman.
Task assigned by dying child.
Fairy assigns tasks.
Other assigners of tasks.
Tasks assigned by druid.
Tests imposed on woman by prospective paramour.
Tasks set by cruel sisters-in-law to get tigress.
Giant assigns task.
Serpent-king assigns task.
Assignment of tasks miscellaneous.
Cumulative tasks: second assigned so that first can be done.
Tasks assigned as payment of gambling loss.
Tasks voluntarily undertaken.
Warriors go towards strong enemy as consequence of own boast.
Hero goes north to fight with trolls.
Task assigned from misunderstanding.
Task assigned from misunderstanding: search for prince named Sabr ("wait").
Task evaded by subterfuge.
Countertasks. When a task is assigned, the hero agrees to perform it as soon as the assigner performs a certain other task.
Reductio ad absurdum of task. When an impossible task is given, the hero responds with a countertask so absurd as to show the manifest absurdity of the original task.
Tasks performed through cleverness or intelligence.
Tasks performed by cleverness.
Tasks performed by close observation.
Task: sitting on eggs without breaking them; hero perceives trick.
Tasks performed by means of secrets overheard from tree.
Help in performing tasks.
Task performed with help of old person.
Tasks performed with help of old woman.
Task performed with help of little old men.
Tasks accomplished with help of grateful dead.
Tasks performed by captive spirits of the dead.
Tasks performed by helpful forest spirits.
Task performed by fairy.
Tasks performed with help of four demons in ring.
Task performed by dwarfs.
Task performed with help of supernatural wife.
Task performed with help of mistress.
Tasks performed by deity.
Task performed by deity in answer to prayer.
Tasks performed by aid of goddess.
Task performed by mysterious stranger.
Tasks performed with help of brother.
Animals help man perform task.
Pigeons cover the sun's rays with their outstretched wings and lengthen night to six months so that hero's task can be completed in one night.
Task performed with help of angel.
Tasks performed with help of saint.
Tasks performed with help of Brahmadaitya.
Task performed with help of druid.
Help in performance of tasks: invisible hands.
Task performed with aid of magic object.
Performance of tasks miscellaneous.
Unpromising hero last to try task (rescue from animal).
Impossible tasks.
Tasks contrary to laws of nature.
Task: construction from impossible kind of material.
Task: making a rope of sand.
Task: making a rope of sand; countertask: first showing the pattern.
Task: making a rope of chaff.
Task: making ship of stone.
Task: making a knot of spilled brandy.
Task: making an invisible knot with an egg.
Task: weaving a silk shirt from hair.
Task: weaving a silk shirt from hair; countertask: making a loom from shavings.
Task: taking a stick from the body. (Fingernail.)
Task: spinning gold.
Task: sewing a shirt of stone.
Task: sewing a shirt from flower petals.
Task: brewing ale from sweet milk.
Task: making a peacock of silk.
