Task: construction from impossible amount of material.
Task: weaving cloth from two threads.
Task: making many shirts  (clothing an army)  from one hank of flax  (wool).
Task: clothing an army from one hank of flax; countertask: making horseshoes for cavalry from one needle.
Task: weaving a shirt from a piece of thread; countertask: making a loom from a rod.
Task: making sails for ship from one bundle of linen; countertask: making spindle and loom from one stick of wood.
Task: making shirt from piece of linen three inches square.
Task: making shirt derived from a single flax-seed.
Task: weaving mantle from wool of a single sheep.
Task: making shawl-cloth one hundred cubits in length out of one cocoon of silk.
Task: feeding army from one measure of meal.
Task: making broth for army.
Task: making many kinds of food from one small bird.
Task: making ale derived from a single grain of corn.
Task: making boat from splinters of a spindle and shuttle.
Task: brewing impossible amount of ale from one grain of corn.
Task: bringing quantity of mosquito bones within month; countertask: furnishing scales with wind as beams and heat as pans.
Tasks contrary to the nature of objects.
Task: hatching boiled eggs.
Task: hatching boiled eggs; countertask: sowing cooked seeds and harvesting the crop.
Task: hatching eggs immediately; countertask: sowing seeds and bringing in crop next morning.
Task: carrying water in a sieve.
Task: carrying water in sieve; sieve filled with moss.
Task: carrying water in sieve; pious child able to do so.
Task: carrying water in leaky vessel.
Task: carrying water in leaky vessel; vessel repaired with clay or gum.
Task: carrying water in leaky vessel; frog sits in hole.
Hero sets wife to task of filling water-bottle with spout turned downward.
Impossible task: filling a grain-bin through the hole in the bottom.
Task: filling a bottomless water tube.
Task: filling pots having subterranean outlets.
Task: bringing berries (fruit, roses) in winter.
Task: bringing berries in winter. Reductio ad absurdum: father is sick from snake-bite (impossible in winter).
Task: procuring cuckoo to sing in winter.
Task: making withered flowers green.
Task: straightening a curly hair.
Task: making a dog's tail straight.

Task: showing picture of a voice.
Task: eating the moon.
Task: building castle suspended between heaven and earth.
Task: getting fruit from top of tall tree without cutting tree. (Cuts roots of tree.)

Task: recalling a dream someone else has had.
Task: filling a sack full of lies (truths).
Task: going to get nothing and bringing it back.

Task: bringing the foam of the ocean in a large piece of cloth.

Task: setting back sun.

Paradoxical tasks.
Task: coming neither on nor off the road. (Comes in the rut or the ditch at side of the road.)
Task: standing neither inside nor outside of gate. (Forefeet of horse inside, hind feet outside.)
Task: coming neither on horse nor on foot (riding nor walking).
Task: coming neither on horse nor on foot. (Comes on another animal.)
Task: coming neither on horse nor on foot. (Comes sitting on animal but with feet reaching ground.)
Task: coming neither on horse nor on foot. (Comes with one leg on animal's back, one on ground.)
Task: coming neither on horse nor on foot. (Coming drawn by an animal on net, trough, or sledge.)
Task: coming neither on horse nor on foot. (Walks on a stick horse.)
Task: coming neither on horse nor on foot. (Crawls on all fours.)
Task: coming neither naked nor clad.
Task: coming neither naked nor clad. (Comes wrapped in net or the like.)
Task: coming neither naked nor clad. (Comes clothed in own hair.)
Task: coming neither naked nor clad. (Comes with part of body clothed.)
Task: coming "neither in softness nor in hardness.". (Comes clad in garments of mountain down.)
Task: coming neither barefoot nor shod. (Comes with one shoe on, one off; or in soleless shoes.)
Task: coming neither with nor without a present (game). (Lets bird fly as the reaches it toward king.)
Task: coming neither by day nor by night. (Comes at twilight.)
Task: standing between summer and winter. (Stands between wagon and sleigh.)
Task: coming neither with nor without a companion. (Comes with an animal.)
Task: coming neither washed nor unwashed. (Comes partly washed.)
Task: coming neither hungry nor satiated. (Eats a thin soup, a leaf, a single grain, or the like.)
Task: coming laughing and crying at once. (Rubs eyes with a twig to simulate crying.)
Task: bringing best friend, worst enemy, best servant, greatest pleasure-giver. (Brings dog, wife, ass, little son respectively.)
Task: sweep the floor and do not sweep it.
Task: light fire but do not light it.
Task: making bed but do not make it.
Task: eat bread but bring it back whole. (Center of loaf eaten.)
Task: give sheep good care but do not let it fatten. (Sheep fed but kept near wolf where it is afraid and does not fatten.)
Task: filling glasses with water that has neither fallen from heaven nor sprung from the earth. (Uses horse's sweat.)
Task: furnish beef which is neither male nor female. Countertask: send for it when it is neither night nor day.

Task: bringing something ever-increasing  (ambition);  something ever-decreasing  (life);  something which neither increases nor decreases  (one's fated lot);  and something which both increases and decreases  (universe).
Task: building house neither on ground nor in sky.

Questions asked on way to other world.
Answers found in other world to questions propounded on the way.
Question (propounded on quest): Why has spring gone dry?. Answer: Animal to be removed from its water-vein.

Question (propounded on quest): Why does no one ever drink water of two certain wells?. Answer: In their last birth they had been two Brahman women and whenever they wanted to give alms they gave only to each other.
Question (propounded on quest): Why does not a certain tree flourish?. Answer: Gold is hidden under it (or a serpent is under its roots).
Question (propounded on quest): Why does no one desire to eat fruits of a certain tree?. Answer: Tree in its last birth had been a very learned man who gave his knowledge away.
Question (propounded on quest): Why do the live stock die?. (Various answers.)
Question (propounded on quest): How can the prince be cured?. Answer: He must remove stone which he has spit out in the church.
Question (propounded on quest): How can the princess be cured?. Answer: She must recover consecrated wafer which rat has stolen from her first communion.
Question (propounded on quest): How can snake be cured from blindness?. Answer: By giving away his gem.
Question (propounded on quest): How can the cripple be healed?. Answer: He must distribute his knowledge.
Question (on quest): How can the girl thus far avoided by suitors marry?. (Various answers.)
Question (on quest): Where is the lost key?. (Various answers.)
Question (on quest): Where is the lost princess?. (Various answers.)
Question (on quest): When will a ferryman be released from his duty?. Answer: When he is able to get out of the boat and leave the oar in another's hand.
Question (on quest): When will a certain water-animal be freed from an annoyance?. (Various answers).
Question (on quest): How can mice rid themselves of cats?. (Answer: tie on bell.)
Question (on quest): How can ants secure longer life?. (Answer: by doing without wings.)
Question (on quest): Where does Bras-de-Fer (Ver-sous-Terre) live?
Question (on quest): Have you see my prince?
Question (propounded on quest): Why can't the dragon king ascend to the sky?
Question (propounded on quest): Why can't the child talk or the dog bark?
Question (propounded on quest): Why is the cow so severely beaten every day by her calf?. Answer: in her last birth she had been the young of her present calf and had treated it the same way.
Question (propounded on quest): Is a poor shepherd known to God?. Answer: He had been a very generous god-fearing person in his last birth and God had not forgotten him.
Question (propounded on quest): When can certain structure be finished?. Answer: When king's daughter marries.
Question (propounded on quest): How can a man and woman be freed from their annoyance.
Question (propounded on quest): Why does kingdom go well by day and burn by night?
Quests for the unique.
Quest for the most beautiful of women.
Quest for the most beautiful bride.
Quest for bride as handsome as the hero.
Quest for faraway princess.
Hero visits all islands to see if he can find woman to rival wife's beauty.
Quest for the most beautiful bouquet.
Quest for the finest of chains.
Quest for the best of bread.
Quest for the best of meat.
Quest for the worst of meat.
Quest for best-cooked dish.
Quest for the finest of linen.
Quest for best-worked handkerchief.
Quest for the smallest of dogs.
Quest for the finest of horses.
Quest for the richest person.
King seeks one richer (more magnificent) than himself.
Quest for bride richest and poorest.
Quest for the greatest of fools.
Quest for three persons as stupid as his wife.
Quest for person who can withdraw sword.
Quest for the spring of the biggest of three rivers east of Gardariki.
Quest for the strongest.
Quest for ornament (jewel, etc.) to match one already at hand .
Liar escapes from devil: quest for greater liar.
Quests for the unique miscellaneous.
Quest for only person who can cure certain sickness.
Quest for best cap.
Quest for the most beautiful rug.
Quest for the most beautiful ring.
Quest for marvelous objects or animals.
Quest for magic objects.
Quest for things seen in dream.
Quest for marvelous water.
Quest for Water of Life (water which will resuscitate).
Quest for healing water.
Quest for the water of youth.
Quest for dancing water.
Quest for singing water.
Quest for marvelous pillar.
Quest for silver pillar covered with golden flowers.
Quest for marvelous remedy.
Quest for magic healing lantern.
Quest for draught of healing.
Quest for remarkable animal.
Quest for marvelous bird.
Quest for Bird of Truth.
Quest for three feathers of marvelous bird.
Quest for remarkable bird feathers.
Quest for golden bird.
Quest for jeweled golden cock.
Quest for golden peacock.
Quest for speaking bird. Makes all other birds sing with him.
Quest for fat of water blackbirds.
Quest for marvelous boar (pig).
Quest for purely white boar.
Quest for pig not farrowed.
Quest for pigs killed by night and revived by day.
Quest for marvelous cattle.
Quest for bald, white-headed cow.
Quest for cow with liver of tallow.
Quest for golden calf.
Quest for marvelous horse.
Quest for blue-eyed horse.
Quest for horse with peacock tail.
Quest for marvelous goat.
Quest for marvelous dog.
Quest for creature with a single horn mounting to heaven with single red hair on its head.
Quest for a large-headed worm.
Quest for sheep that is a hound by night and a sheep by day.
Quest for marvelous parts or possessions of animals.
Quest for golden fleece.
Quest for vulture's egg figured with golden letters.
Quest for Gorgon's head.
Quest for animal with golden chain.
Quest for magic pigskin.
Quest for oil of magic pig.
Quest for liver of thunder and heart of dragon.
Quest for honey from the royal bee-hive.
Quest for extraordinary plants (fruits, trees).
Quest for marvelous tree.
Quest for singing tree.
Quest for extraordinary plant.
Quest for plant of immortality.
Quest for magic tobacco.
Quest for extraordinary herb.
Quest for magic rice.
Quest for extraordinary fruit.
Quest for rejuvenating fruit.
Quest for marvelous fruit with princess inside.
Quest for marvelous apple.
Quest for magic apple.
Quest for dancing apple.
Quest for apple of life.
Quest for singing apple.
Quest for healing apple.
Quest for apples that are under the sea.
Quest for marvelous pear.
Quest for red pear.
Quest for berries from tree guarded by giants.
Quest for magic chestnut.
Quest for marvelous flower.
Quest for flower that sends forth its fragrance for hundred miles around.
Quest for flower of a tree inside the seventh of a series of forts.
Quest for gold flower.
Quest for wonderful but man-killing flower.
Quest for lotus flower.
Quest for sarai flower.
Quest for bakali flower.
Quest for jasmine flower.
Quest for branches of tree guarded by dragon.
Quest for the living harp.
Quest for gold mouth-harp.
Quest for magic cauldron.
Quest for sword of light.
Quest for Thunder Sword.
Quest for axe which sticks in beam outside a tower.
Quest for magic lantern.
Quest for magic iron rod.
Quest for magic wand.
Quest for castle of jewels.
Quest for ferule to fit staff.
Quest for magic spear (sword, etc.).
Quest for lost magic mirror.
Quest for stolen mirror.
Quest for comb.
Quest for marvelous gems.
Quest for covering that is kept in an emerald box by the well.
Quest for unpierced pearls.
Quest for magic stone.
Quest for magic ring.
Quest for Life Index.
Quest for marvelous cloth (garment).
Quest for garment of spider web.
Quest for beautiful saree for the queen.
Quest for silken turban on tree sixteen rivers and seven seas away.
Task: achieving kingship by bringing silk from bazaar.
Quest for roll of cotton driven by the wind.
Quest for marvelous objects or animals miscellaneous.
Quest for marvelous golden wood for knife handle.
Quest for golden spinning equipment.
Quest for great tank of Indra (god).
Quest for mountain of gold.
Quest for marvelous game-board.
Quest for dangerous animals.
Quest for lion's milk.
Cubs furnish lion's (tiger's, etc.) milk to hero.
Quest for tiger's milk.
Quest for bear's milk.
Quest for wolf's milk.
Quest for wild dog's milk.
Quest for hare's milk.
Quest for cheese made from milk of wild white buffaloes.
Quest for devastating animals.
Quest for devastating buffaloes.
Quest for wonderful but vicious horse.
Quest for demon-owned cows.
Miscellaneous quests.
Impossible quests.
Quest for the world's end.
Quest for place where sun comes up.
Quest for the bottom of the sea.
Quest for tears shed into the sea.
Quest for ornaments bride has worn in former birth.
Allegorical quests.
Quest: learning what death is.
Quest: learning what fear is.
Quest: learning what fear of Death is.
Quest: learning what anger is.
Quest for the anger of God. Man is so fortunate that people say that he has everything but the anger of God. He seeks it and finds it with much misfortune.
Quest for bag of truths (lies).
Quest for trouble.
Quest for happiness.
Quest for immortality.
Quest for wisdom.
Quest for luck.
Enigmatical quests.
Quest for glass of all waters. (Sea water.)
Quest for bouquet of all flowers. (Beehive.)
Quest for the hazelnuts of ay, ay, ay. (Brings hazelnuts with thorns so that the king cries "Ay, ay, ay" when he takes them.)
Quest for dusty cloth. (Barren woman assigns quest. Dusty cloth is one made dusty by the feet of a child.)
Paradoxical quests.
Quest for wood neither crooked nor straight. (Sawdust.)
Quest for king's joy and woe. (King tells of adventures in which his brothers are all killed. They were a joy to him but their death a woe.)
Quest for unknown person.
Quest for unknown parents.
Quest for unknown father.
Woman seeks unknown father of her child.
Quest for unknown, vanished beloved.
Child seeks unknown parent.
Son seeks unknown father.
Boy twitted with illegitimacy seeks unknown father.
Child seeks unknown mother.
Boy twitted with illegitimacy seeks unknown mother.
Quest for unknown woman.
Quest for bride.
Quest for bride for king (prince).
Quest for bride for king like picture he has seen.
Quest for bride for oneself.
Quest for unknown woman whose picture has aroused man's love.
Quest for girl hero has seen in dream.
Quest for dangerous maiden as bride.
Quest for bride for dwarf.
Quest for Glass Princess.
Quest for clever woman.
Quest for princess transformed into skein of silk.
Quest for woman exactly like another.
Quest for persecuted woman.
Quest for princess hidden by father.
Quest for queen of fairies.
Quest for son of sinless couple.
Hero seeks his equal.
Quest for unknown son.
Quest for unknown bridegroom who has certain name and is only son among seven children of father.
Quest for unknown objects or places.
Quest for unknown magic words. Hero seeks them on the heads of swallows, the necks of swans, the backs of geese, and the tongues of reindeer.
Quest for unknown story (epic).
Quest for unknown lines of poem.
Quest for unknown wonder.
Quest for unknown animal.
Quest for unknown puppy-hound.
Quest for lost persons.
Unspelling quest: journey to disenchant (free) captives.
Quest for stolen princess.
Quest for vanished daughter.
Quest for vanished wife (mistress).
Quest for vanished wife and son. Husband seeks wife and son in many countries.
Quest for vanished husband.
Quest for husband who has been reincarnated as cat.
Quest for vanished lover.
Quest for lost sister.
Quest for lost father.
Quest for lost grandfather.
Quest for lost brother(s).
Quest for lost (stolen) family.
Quest for lost prince (king).
Quest for lost uncles.
King in quest of his prime minister who has left him in anger.
Quest for lost object.
Quest for lost horn.
Quest for missing ring.
Quest for lost bird.
Quest for lost ecclesiastical rule.
Quest: answer to certain question.
Question: What is it women most desire. Answer: Sovereignty.
Quest for armor from a grave mound.
Quest for gold from a grave mound.
Quest to distant sage for advice.
Quest for person who has not known sorrow.
Heroes seek judgment as to which is greatest.
Quest for light-giving child.
Quest for enemies.
Quest for witch stepmother.
Quest for enemy's children.
Fear test. A person is put to various tests in the attempt to make him show fear.
Deity assumes frightful guises to frighten child.
Chief of dead assumes frightful guises to frighten visitors.
Ogress assumes frightful guises to frighten messengers.
Fear test: behaving as if enemy is coming in order to see who will flee and who will stay and fight.
Suitor tested by apparent threats to his person.
Fear test: serpent put in flour so that fearless youth kneads it into the dough.
Test: going without fear through a wilderness filled with all manner of beasts.
Fear test: staying in frightful place.
Fear test: staying in haunted house.
Fear test: staying in haunted house where corpse drops piecemeal down chimney. Dead man's members call out to hero, "Shall we fall, or shall we not?"
Fear test: staying in haunted house where horse carcass drops down chimney.
Fear test: staying in haunted house infested by cats.
Fear test: night watch with magic cats.
Fear test: staying in enchanted castle at night where the devil gives a moral speech and prophesies.
Fear test: spending night in house (hall) haunted by demon (monster).
Fear test: spending night in church.
Fear test: going into the church at night and ringing the bell.
Fear test: staying under gallows at night.
Fear test: spending night by grave.
Fear test: taking boy to frightful enemy's tent.
Fearless traffic with devils.
Fear test: playing cards with devil in church.
Hero plays skittles with demons.
Fear test: cutting devil's fingernails.
Fear test: fighting with spirits.
Fear test: passing through door guarded by savage hound and armed soldier.
Fear test: undergoing terrifying experience out of doors on Hallowe'en.
Fear test: bringing from a hill, seized by a demon, the fattest of goats.
Fearless traffic with ghosts.
Fear test: stealing clothes from ghosts.
Fear test: playing game with reassembled dead man.
Fear test: eating and drinking from skulls.
Fear test: fetching skulls from a charnel house.
Fear test: keeping goal in hurling-match for corpses.
The learning of fear.
Fearless hero frightened by being awakened with cold water.
Fearless hero frightened by being awakened by eels put down his back.
Vigilance test.
Waking contest.
Test: speechless vigil in church.
Test: vigil at tomb.
Test: sitting up with corpse. Wake.
Vigil for dead father.
Vigil for dead father: youngest son alone endures frightful experiences. Ceiling, floors, and walls knock together.
Three-night watch over grave to guard man from devil.
Other vigilance tests.
Watch for devastating monster. Youngest alone successful.
Watch for thieves in the king's garden.
Test: sleeping by princess three nights without looking at her or disturbing her.
Accomplishment of vigilance test.
Thumb cut and salt put on it in order to remain awake.
Dirk stuck into thigh in order to keep from sleeping.
Grains slowly munched in order to keep from sleeping.
Continual pricking with pin in order to remain awake.
Large fire and water for washing eyes as device of expectant lover.
Tests of endurance.
Endurance test: long dancing. Girl tires out many partners.
Test: enduring hardship. Tested by making girl serve woman who has leprosy, etc.
Endurance test: scalding mush scattered on heroine's naked body; rasp-tongued dogs lick wounds.
Test: sleeping naked on floor in cold. (Suitor test.)
Test: sewing clothes into boy's hands and tearing them off together with the skin.
Endurance test: hero maintains silence in the snake pit.
Hero pursues and kills fugitive in spite of bleeding wounds.
Test: long praying.
Test: repeating incantation continuously for months.
Tests of power to survive. Vain attempts to kill hero.
Heat test. Attempt to kill hero by burning him in fire.
Heat test: swallowing red-hot stones.
Test: swallowing heated brass and iron ornaments.
Burning food test. Attempt to kill hero by feeding him burning food.
Smoke test. Attempt to kill hero by smoke.
Smoking test. Attempt to kill hero by having him smoke fatal pipe.
Cold test. Attempt to freeze hero to death.
Poisoned food test. Attempt to kill hero by feeding him poisoned food.
Attempt to poison by druids.
Poisoned drink test. Attempt to kill saint by giving him poisoned drink.
Test: food with thorns. Hero given food in which thorns are hidden.
Poisoned clothing test. Attempt to kill hero by poisoning clothing.
Test: bite of poisonous snake.
Clam test. Hero is sent to capture a giant clam, so that he can be killed.
Killing trees threaten hero.
Bent tree test. Bent tree is released so as to tear hero to pieces.
Clashing rocks test: hero to pass between them.
Spine test. Attempt to kill hero by throwing him on sharp spine or spike.
Test: dancing on sharp instruments.
Vain attempt to kill hero on stairway set with razors.
Wedge test. Hero is caught in cleft of tree.
Hanging test. Unavailing attempt to kill hero by hanging.
Plank test. Attempt to kill hero by letting plank fall on him.
Precipice test. Hero is pushed over a precipice.
Pit test. Hero thrown into pit.
Toboggan test. Attempt to kill hero on dangerous toboggan.
Test: playing game with ferocious beast.
Bear demands that heroine play Blindman's Buff.
Drowning test. Unavailing attempt to drown hero.
Contests in endurance.
Contest in enduring cold.
Contest in enduring cold: frost and the hare. Hare tries to deceive frost by lying on frozen snow and saying, "Oh, how warm!"
Contest in enduring cold: wind overcomes frost.
Contest in enduring heat.
Contest in crossing river of fire.
Contest in remaining under water.
Contest in enduring thirst.
Contest in fasting.
Tests of character.
Bad character shown by the eyes.
Tests of generosity.

Which was the most generous husband, robber, or lover?. Woman has promised her lover to go to him on her wedding night. Husband lets her go. On way she meets robbers and tells her story. Robbers take her to her lover. She tells what has happened. Lover returns her immediately to her husband.
Which was most generous husband, lover, or magician (similar)?
Contest in generosity. Ruler vies with minister in generosity. Minister declared loser and condemned to die. Pardoned on acknowledging defeat.
Tests of patience.
Philosopher teaches son to beg before stone statues. In this way he will acquire patience.
Test of patience: king accepts strong reproof and criticism.
Test of patience: those who wish to enter city gate must endure insults of old men there who mock them.
Man shows his patience by accepting blow in face with stool thrown by his superior in monastery.
Monk fails in test of patience. He tries to live alone to test it. One day he loses his temper at a cup which overturns and he breaks it.
Test of patience by asking irrelevant riddles.
Test of curiosity.

Test of curiosity: mouse in jug. The new Eve. A woman has boasted of a lack of curiosity and blamed Mother Eve. The king entertains her in his castle. She may see everything but must not look into a certain silver jug. She does so and finds a mouse in it.

Test of curiosity: the clock. A man is promised a beautiful clock if he can mind his own business for a whole year. He does. The giver tells him he is the second man who almost made sure of getting the clock. The man asks how the other missed getting it; he loses the clock himself.

Test of curiosity: the paternoster. Plowman is promised a horse if he can say a paternoster without thinking of anything else. In the midst of the recitation, he asks if he will get the saddle and bridle too. He loses bargain.
Tests of honesty.
Test of honesty: man entrusted with treasure.
Tests of fidelity.
Fidelity of servant tested.
Test of fidelity (loyalty) of guard. (Faithful unto death.)
Test of fidelity by feigning death.
Cock feigns death to see what hens will say about him.
Test of fidelity through submitting hero to temptations.
Test of fidelity through offering suspected assassin opportunity to commit the murder.
Fidelity in love tested.
Lover's fidelity tested by going to bed with mistress and only kissing.
Lover's fidelity tested by making love to maid.
Wife tests her husband's fidelity by tempting him in the guise of another woman.
Lover's fidelity tested by substituting maid in mistress's bed at assignation. He must refuse her.
Old uncle tests nephew's fidelity by sleeping with his beloved.
Husband's (wife's) willingness to die for mate disappears when Death seems to arrive.
Old woman's willingness to die for daughter disappears when Death seems to arrive.
Rose given by supernatural wife to husband when he leaves for home will shed as many petals as times he thinks of her.
Test of fidelity by feigning sleep in same bed as calumniated hero or alone in the forest with him.
Tests of obedience.

Obedience of sons tested by offering them apple. They are each offered a slice of apple. The king says, "Open your mouth and receive what I give you". Eldest son insulted; youngest obeys and receives kingdom as reward.
Adam's (Eve's) disobedience blamed: blamer immediately disobeys orders.
Old man contented till forbidden to leave city. Immediately disobeys.
Pope tests women's disobedience: not to look into box.
Obedience of king's subjects tested by willingness to allow spear to be carried crosswise into houses. Way must be hewn.
King tests gardener's obedience by playing thief.
Tests of friendship.
Test of worthiness for friendship.
Apple test of worthiness for friendship. Father gives son three apples to offer to those he meets. If the man eats all, avoid him; if he divides, make friends with him.

Test of friendship: the half-friend. A man kills a hog and tells his friends that he has killed a man and asks where he can hide the body. All of them drive him away and only his father's half-friend remains true to him in his feigned trouble.
Of three friends the least loved proves true in emergency.

Test of friendship: substitute as murderer. A man in misery gives himself up as a murderer rather than endure further misery. His friend tries to take on himself the guilt and be substituted. The real murderer, touched by the generosity, confesses.
Test of friendship: to go with one to death. Everyman. He calls in Riches, Family, etc. Only Good Deeds remains with him.
The hare with many friends. In the final test none help and only her legs save her.
Test of friendship: death feigned to test debtor friends.

Test of friendship: the imagined refusal. Man wonders if his friend would lend him his palfrey. Decides he would refuse. Imagines that he has actually asked for the palfrey and has been refused. Cools toward his friend. The owner of the horse asks for an explanation. He agrees to lend him the horse and they are reconciled.
Test of friendship: the power of money. Spendthrift loses his friends in poverty.
Sultan takes disguise of beggar to test friends.
Friends desert when man reports loss of his money.
Friends refuse to fight against each other.
Sword too heavy to lift against a friend.
Pregnant wife left in charge of friend.
Friendship kept up even during sons' jealousy and enmity.
Test of friendship: to take a slap publicly from friend.
Test of friendship: mourner says dead husband can be touched only by sinless person; volunteers for cremating body immediately disperse.
Test of friendship: loyalty to condemned friend.
Tests of valor.
Tests of valor: tournament.
Single combat to prove valor.
Holmgang. Single combat on an island.
Fight with father's old friend, though only to mention who he is would assure the youth a friendly reception.
Combats at fords.
Test of valor: not flinching under a blow.

Test of valor: rousing servant's anger. Nobleman, when examining servants for hire, bids each stand before him and comb his long beard. Occasionally he snaps at them as if to bite them. Those who dodge he lets go; those who offer fight he employs.
Test of valor worthy for kingship: taking possession of royal insignia placed between two ferocious lions.
Test of valor: fight with giant.
Test of valor: attack by warrior and hound.
Warriors battle against leader as test of valor.
Prince chooses shorter but more dangerous road.
Master tests disciple by asking him if he will be willing to plunge with him into the Indus.
Test of strength.
Test of strength: pulling up tree by roots.
Test of strength: cutting tree with one stroke.
Test of strength: lifting stone (fireplace, etc. ) English: Wells 59 (The Turke and Gowin), 114 (Sir Isumbras); Icelandic: *Boberg; Danish: Schmidt DF XXXIX 55.
Test of strength: lifting sword.
Before undertaking rescue, bat tests strength by lifting stone.
Test of strength: breaking heavy glass bottle over loaf of rye bread.
Test of strength: prodigious jump.
Test of strength: heavy stone flung at boaster; he throws it back.
Test of strength: breaking spirited horse.
Strength contest: contestants stand with back to rock on opposite side, an iron ring around neck of each connected by chain. They tug until ring severs neck of one.
Test of strength: breaking witch's back.
Test of strength: wrestling.
Test of strength: pushing out heavy ferry.
Test of strength: pulling in two iron bars passing through hole.
Task: destruction of iron castle.
Test of strength: shooting through seven iron plates with arrow.
Mighty-of-His-Mouth and Mighty-of-His-Hands decide to live together to test strength. Strength of mind is winner.
Test of skill.
Test of hospitality.
Tests of gratitude.
Test of gratitude: magician makes pupil believe himself superior. Though he has promised magician great rewards he forgets his promise. Wealth removed.
Test for admission to warrior band.
Test of leadership.
Frightful meal as test of leadership.
Test of leadership (obedience): swallowing mouse without vomiting.
Test of the champion.
Test of championship: sitting on pillow covering egg without breaking egg.
Tests of character miscellaneous.
Test of industry.
Man tests industry of prospective servant girl.
Test of sensitiveness.
Test of fertility.
Stone under fertile woman produces milk; under barren woman produces blood.
Religious tests.
Angel helpers in religious test.
Belief in Christianity tested.
Heathen swallowed by earth. Proof of his belief.
Loathly deed performed as evidence of Christian virtue.
Druid attempts to shake king's faith by magic manifestation.
Man commanded by saint to leap into fiery furnace: unharmed.
Religious personages tested.
Magic manifestation required as proof in test of saintliness.
Saint tested by visit of deity in disguise.
Test of worthiness for bishop: plowing without plowshare.
Power of Christianity tested.
Saint drinks poison without injury as proof of power of Christianity.
Saint's horse miraculously preserved as proof of power of Christianity before fairy.
Transformation by saint as proof of Christianity before druid.
Wizard (druid) burned, saint saved in test of power of Christianity.
Power of other religions tested.
Power of Judaism tested.
Test of steadfastness of love for God: though warned in dream man refuses to part with sacred stone.
Test of righteousness.
Ability to cross bridge as test of righteousness.
Test of repentance.
Test of repentance: culprit exposed to situation identical to that in which he sinned.
Tests of social position.
Social rank determined according to portion taken from cauldron of food.
Tests for noble blood.
Fruitfulness of nature as proof of kingly right.
King chosen by test.
Test imposed on young princes as candidates for throne.
Two deities test virtues of a king.
The burning forge (smithy): he who salvages anvil will be king.
He who wins maiden queen is king.
Tests of sight.
Test of sight: stepping stones. Captives re-blinded if they cross stepping-stones without stumbling.
Tests of possession of magic powers.
Test of magic powers: telling sex of unborn goat.
Test of skill for a fakir: heating iron and passing it through hands without burning them.
Test of divine favor.
Test of goddess' favor: man throws away his wife's jewel-box to see if she can regain it with the aid of goddess.
Test of goddess's favor: husband drowns his son to see if his wife's tutelary goddess can bring him back to life.
Test of sex: to discover person masking as of other sex.
Test of sex of girl masking as man.
Test of sex of girl masking as man: peas spread on floor. Men tread firmly; women slip.
Test of girl masking as man: nuts and corn spread on floor.
Test of sex of girl masking as man: spinning wheel brought. Men take no notice; women interested.
Test of sex of girl masking as man: choosing flowers. Girl will choose a carnation; man a rose.
Test of sex of girl masking as man: ball thrown into lap. Girls spread legs to catch it; men not.
Woman throws apple to man in woman's dress. He puts his legs together to catch it.
Test of sex of man masking as girl: jumping over pit (only man succeeds).
Test of sex of girl masking as man: nuts and apples offered. Men put them in their shirts, girls into their handkerchiefs.
Test of sex of girl masking as man: warned by a parrot, she picks only one flower.
Test of sex of man masking as girl: arms placed among baskets and war-trumpet sounded. Man snatches arms.
Test of heirship.
Health test.
Recognition of good health by hearing voice.
Recognition of good health by smoke rising from chimney.
Tests of time.
Time measured by worn iron shoes.
Time measured by fit of ring.
Tests of space.
Land measured according to amount within person's view.
Land measured according to amount encompassed during certain hours.
Test of cleanliness by being shaken to see if lice fall off.
Contest of dogs. Two opponents test their powers by having their dogs fight.
Litter of puppies tested by throwing them one by one at hanging hide of wild beast, and keeping the one that grips hide. Puppy grows up to be great hunting dog.
Man and king compete by letting their domestic animals fight.
Shooting contest.
Contest: spear-casting.
Hunting contest.
Goaling match between fairies and mortals as test of supremacy.
Foot-racing contest.
Death as penalty for losing foot-race.
Foot-race between fairy and mortal.
Foot-race between giant and mortal.
Test of memory.

Test of memory: Solomon asks Marchus question, receives answer;  fourteen months later he asks second question based on first, again receives correct answer; four months later asks third question based on first two, again receives correct answer.
Beauty contest.
Test for attractiveness to men.
Golden apple as prize in beauty contest. Judgment of Paris.
Strangers umpire beauty contest.
Women to appear naked in beauty contest.
Contest between man and other being.
Contest between man and angel.
Acquisition and possession of wisdom.
Wisdom (knowledge) acquired from experience.
Shipwrecked shepherd distrusts the sea. He had formerly envied sailors.
Man bitten by snake fears snake-like rope.
Young ass avoids food eaten by animals before being slaughtered. Runs to his mother and asks to have all remains of the hog's food taken out.
Young sparrows have learned to avoid men. Sparrow quizzes his four young as to how to avoid danger from men. Their year of experience has taught them enough.
Old racehorse in mill laments vanity of youth.
Serpent (bird) having injured man refuses reconciliation. He knows that neither can forget their injuries.
Dove disregards experience and loses brood. Rebuilds her nest in the place where she has lost former brood.
Animal learns through experience to fear men. In spite of the warning of another animal he approaches man and is shot.

Tiger, jackal, and bear each learn to fear man. They report him as head-thumper (he has beaten the tiger), turn-twister (he has swung jackal by tail), and top-tumbler (he has fallen out of tree on bear).
Wisdom acquired from beating. Incognito prince, beaten for his courtesy, realizes his folly and returns home.
Counsels proved wise by experience.
Wise words of dying father. Counsel proved wise by experience.

Consider the end":  counsel proved wise by experience. Barber hired to cut king's throat sees on the bottom of the basin the words "Whatever you do, do wisely and think of the consequences. " He drops the razor and confesses.

Do not act when angry":  counsel proved wise by experience. Man returns home and sees someone sleeping with his wife. Though he thinks it is a paramour, he restrains himself and finds that it is a newborn son.
Never attack anyone before unsheathing and returning sword three times":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Sleep before committing suicide. After sleeping you will feel differently about suicide.
Do not draw your sword against the innocent":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Do not uncover weapon in an assembly":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Do not shed the blood of women":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Control your anger at the beginning":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Do not go where an old man has a young wife":  counsel proved wise by experience. Discovers a murder in an inn.
Do not marry a girl from abroad":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Do not leave the highway":  counsel proved wise by experience. Robbers encountered.
Do not prefer a new road to an old one. "  Those who take the new one are killed by robbers.
Take side road rather than main one where three roads meet":  counsel proved wise by experience.
A way short yet long":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Do not ask questions about extraordinary things":  counsel proved wise by experience. Those who ask question killed.
Do not cross a bridge without dismounting from your horse";  counsel proved wise by experience. Man breaks leg.
Never wager more than a groat":  counsel proved wise by experience. Man loses wife on wager.
Do not bet":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Do not visit your friends often":  counsel proved wise by experience. At last the man is treated shamefully.
Do not prolong a friendly visit. "  Guest stays so long that host gives him black bread instead of white.
Do not lend out your horse":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Do not walk half a mile with a man without asking his name":  counsel proved wise by experience. Man runs race unwittingly with his wife's paramour and loses his wife on the wager.

Rue not a thing that is past":  counsel proved wise by experience. Man lets bird go and then, having listened to bird's false declaration that she had a precious gem in her body, he tries to climb a tree after her and falls.
Never believe what is beyond belief":  counsel proved wise by experience. Man believes when bird tells him that she has a precious gem in her body.
Never try to reach the unattainable":  counsel proved wise by experience.

If you wish to hang yourself, do so by the stone which I point out":  counsel proved wise by experience. Father has left money which will fall out when the spendthrift son goes to hang himself in despair. " The Heir of Linne.
Go to Goosebridge":  counsel proved wise by experience. Man with disobedient wife finds mules beaten there and made to cross bridge.
Stay at church till mass is finished":  counsel proved wise by experience. Delay saves youth from death.
Do not trust the over-holy":  counsel proved wise by experience. Wife so modest she will not travel with husband (adulteress); priest so pious he will not tread on worm (thief).
Start your journey early in the day":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Prepare for night camp while it is still day":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Do not cross a swollen stream until it has run down":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Do not tell a secret to a woman":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Rise earlier":  counsel proved wise by experience. Man seeking explanation for being in debt arises earlier and catches his servants stealing.
Do not make a horse run down hill":  counsel proved wise by experience. Horse breaks its neck.
Do not keep bad company":  counsel proved wise by experience. Breaking of father's first counsel causes the breaking of all the others.
Don't be too greedy in making a trade":  counsel proved wise by experience. Man refuses fifty ducats for horse. Horse suddenly dies.
Do not adopt a child":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Do not trust a ruler who rules by reason alone":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Keep head dry, feet warm, and eat meat":  counsel proved wise by experience. King recovers from illness.
Never have to do with a woman unless wed to her":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Do not marry a woman before seeing her and finding her to be your equal":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Do not marry more than one woman". Man who wanted three, marries one and is weakened greatly.
Bathe by yourself and not in the common bathing place":  counsel proved wise by experience. Man forgets purse in bath house.
Move stool before sitting on it":  counsel proved wise by experience. Man thus saves self from falling into well.
When in a strange place look about you":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Do not sit on a bed without touching it first":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Ruler should follow advice of majority"  (not his own fancy): counsel proved wise by experience. Thus finds money on body of dead traveler.
Neglect not what four or five people say":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Do not go alone on journey":  counsel proved wise by experience. Helpful crab saves from attack by crocodile.
Do not take a woman's advice":  counsel proved wise by experience.
May God spare you from an evil man or evil woman. "  To teach a friend the wisdom of this greeting a man borrows money and then his creditor's coat from him. In court the lender is discredited.
Do not travel without money":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Don't require honor from a strange country": counsel proved wise by experience.
"Be cautious before allowing yourself to fall asleep in a strange place":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"Sleep not in an inn":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"A stranger does not close his eyes in sleep lest he close them in death":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"He who lies awake gains; he who sleeps loses":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"Before eating food at a strange place throw some at an animal and watch":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"A country not examined in disguise will always be ruined":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"Lean upon no relation in the hour of distress":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"Do not undertake to be an arbitrator without being asked":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"Do not make friends with a policeman (soldier)":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"You can only call your wife your own so long as she is with you":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"Do not send your wife for a long visit to her parents":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"Don't do anything without investigation":  counsel proved wise by experience. A purse full of money was found in dead man's pocket by gravedigger.
"Never give a cup made of a single ruby as a present to the king":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"Idleness begets woe; work brings happiness":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"Do not stand and watch two people fighting":  counsel proved wise by experience. Man does so and is called by both parties to depose in favor of both or he will be beheaded.
Counsels proved wise by experience miscellaneous.
Disciple who stays in a city where everything is sold at one price finds justice is not even there.
"Never be rude to a self-made man of low birth":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"Hardened clay is hard to mold":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"Never publish a man's sin if you can help it":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"Never dismiss and old servant for his first fault":  counsel proved wise by experience.
"When a man attacks you, kill him whether he be king or prince":  counsel proved wise by experience.
Boy who says "I know" gets into all sort of difficulties; now says "I don't know."
"Nothing happens that does not work for one's good":  counsel proved wise is experience.
"He who throws himself against a wave is overthrown by it":  proved true.
Precepts of the lion to his sons. Only the younger keeps them and is successful.
Precept of the lion to his sons: beware of man.
Precept of the lion to his sons: honor the woods.
Precept of the lion to his sons: keep peace with the neighbors.
Merchants try honesty for a year and find that it pays. So advised by priest when they said that they could not do business without dishonesty.
Fools learn to be peaceable. Two fools in the habit of striking people are brought together when they strike each other until they appreciate the value of peace.
Why great man plays with children. This is to be learned only when one has children himself. Anecdote of Agesilaus.
Enemies can be won more by kindness than cruelty. Romans learn this by experience.
Man learns the fear of Death by meeting Life. Life (old woman) beheads him and replaces his head backwards. Simpleton left in fear for hours before head is readjusted.
Wisdom (knowledge) acquired from inference.
Encounter with clever children (woman) dissuades man from visit. On way to a city meets children and they are so clever that he turns back home, fearing how clever their parents must be.

Cleverness of men disguised as peasants dissuades rivals from dispute. Wise men of two rival cities engage in dispute. One delegation disguises as peasants and debates with their adversaries. Latter withdraw fearing how clever the educated must be if their peasants are so learned.
Arrow as man's message shows lion how terrible man himself must be.
Blind man who feels young wolf recognises his savage nature.
Odor of the wine cask. How fine wine must been been to leave so good an odor.
Wisdom (knowledge) acquired from observation.
Sight of deformed witches causes man to release wife from spinning duty. They tell him that their deformity has come from too much spinning.
King observes retaliation among animals: becomes just. Dog breaks fox's foot; man breaks dog's; horse breaks man's leg; horse steps in hole and breaks his.
Understanding of universality of death from watching animals prey on one another.
King descends to bottom of sea in glass barrel to learn wisdom from observing fish.
Army saved from ambush by observation of birds' movements. Birds fly from part of woods in which ambushed men lie.
Ruler learns lesson from the example of an exiled king. Rewards the exile rather than a successful merchant.
Unscrupulous conduct of business learned from observation of usurer's own practices and used against him.
Ruler learns lesson from seeing city governed by king as uncharitable as he.
Hare instructs his sons to use their eyes to advantage.
Observation of dying people for a year takes man's thoughts from lust.
Ducklings take to water from instinct. Bridegroom thus brought to understand bride's expertness in lovemaking.
Birds having learned their possible dangers are forced from nest by mother.
Drops of water make hollow in stone: thus repeated impressions penetrate mind.
Lazy pupil determines to be more diligent by watching man building home one wattle at a time, and seeing how water fills hole one drop at a time.
Wisdom (knowledge) taught by parable.
Three thousand parables of Solomon.
Solomon proves to his mother the inferiority of woman's wisdom.
Minister taught by parable to make obeisance to the new king.
The dishes of the same flavor. Man thus shown that one woman is like another and dissuaded from his amorous purpose.

Monotony of restriction to one's favorite food. Counselor refuses to arrange extramarital pleasures for his lord. Ruler feeds him only his favorite food until the counselor protests the monotony. Ruler drives home his point.
Society is like a dish: must be properly mixed. Plates having salt, pepper, fish, etc. not edible without mixing.
To each his appropriate food. Woman gives morsel of various foods to each guest, with explanation.
Parable comparing canons to a stew made of their individual meals.
Priest walks in the mud. Congregation follows evil ways of priest. He walks in mud but they will not follow him. He thus shows them the folly of following his evil ways.

The gray and the black hairs: enemies reconciled. Duke summons two inveterate enemies. Has them tear out one of his hairs, one a gray, the other a black. Both pain him equally. He shows how their quarrels hurt him. They are reconciled.
Picking up water thrown on ground no harder than the undoing of slander.
Chair over fiery pit as figure of precariousness of life.
Rocks falling together and thread entering needle's eye suggest sexual intercourse: hence its beginning.
Men shamed for their cowardice by woman standing naked before them. (Usually connected with Jus Primae Noctis [T161]).
Wisdom taught by parable: cloud which gives rain to thirsting crops or drops it in ocean.
Monk shames accuser by telling parable. Wind, Water, and Modesty (Sense of Shame). The first two give their addresses but the third says she has no address as no one wants her.
Boy saves life by showing father foolishness of plowing up his crop. Father has been persuaded to kill child.
Difficulty of thinking of God when occupied with worldly affairs. Shown by test: holy man made to carry milk without spilling. So occupied he forgets to think of God.
Fool digs holes in edge of road. Only those departing from straight path will fall in. Truth of principle later seen.
Man kills nest of ants: so God punishes man.
Lotus flower flourishes as long as it is in water: king should not leave castle.
Stones shaken in jar: difficulty in learning many dialects.
Wisdom (knowledge) taught by parable.
Relative pleasures of sexes in love taught by parable.
Father bequeathes four pots to sons:  eldest finds earth in his; second, bones; third, rice husks; youngest, rupees (eldest to get land; second, cattle; third, grain; youngest to keep money).
Wisdom (knowledge) taught by necessity.
Crow drops pebbles into water jug so as to be able to drink.
Bear learns how to catch crabs with his hairy claws.
Wisdom learned from children.

Ungrateful son reproved by napve action of his own son: preparing for old age. Man gives his old father half a carpet to keep him warm. Child keeps the other half and tells his father that he is keeping it for him when he grows old.
Ungrateful son reproved by napve action of his own son: preparing for old age (wooden drinking cup or bowl).
Undutiful son rebuked by father. Father tells son not to drag him past the threshold, because he had dragged his own father only up to that point when he had thought of putting him out of his house.
Napve remark of child:  "You forgot to strike mother.". A father in habit of beating his wife remarks that he has forgot something. The child says, "I know. You forgot to strike mother."
Seducer about to seduce mother of child refrains when child wisely remarks that he is sad because his father has left his mother exposed to such dangers.
Wisdom of child decides lawsuit. King in disguise sees child's game which represents the case.
Clever prince overrules seemingly just decisions of king.
Learning the virtue of patience from children. When their meals are stolen, they quietly search for them.
Parents's misdeeds innocently betrayed by children.
The wine needs no further water. Guests asks small daughter of innkeeper for water to put into his wine. She says, "You will not have to do that for mother poured a whole tubful into the cask today."
Adulteress betrayed by little child's remark.
Child unwittingly betrays his mother's adultery. Tells father not to step across chalk line drawn around secretary; if he does secretary may do to him what he did to Mother the other day.
Wisdom (knowledge) acquired from animals.
Mouse teaches her child to fear quiet cats but not noisy cocks.
Animal gives wise example to man.
One wild goat steps over another. They thus pass each other uninjured on a cliff. This shows advantage of peaceableness.
Ass refuses to drink after it has had enough. Thus teaches lesson to master.
Trained deer drinks wine till he breaks his leg but thereafter abstains. Thus teaches lesson to master.
Woman will not follow donkey on safe path: attacked by robbers.
Squirrel tries to dip out lake with his tail: difficulty of reforming the world.
Big fish eat little: robber will plunder weak neighbors.
Animal behavior teaches man what to avoid.
Cock's second mate lets her stepchildren starve: woman warns husband accordingly.
Departing animal gives man counsels.
Crow inspects the three worlds in search of happiness.
Wisdom learned from example of insects.
Wisdom (knowledge) through education.
Youth educated by seven sages.
Lack of proper education regretted.
House dog blames master for teaching him lazy habits.
Man blames master for not correcting him in youth.
Untrained colt result of master's neglect.
Well-trained kid does not open to wolf.
Hostile dogs made friendly by having them fight common enemy, the wolf.
Educated men as choice company.
King prefers educated men as company.
Child confined to keep him in ignorance of life. Useless.
Other means of acquiring wisdom (knowledge).
Wisdom from old person.

Wisdom of hidden old man saves kingdom. In famine all old men are ordered killed. One man hides his father. When all goes wrong in the hands of the young rulers, the old man comes forth, performs assigned tasks, and aids with his wisdom.
Old men preferred as councillors.
Wisdom from god as old (one-eyed) man.
Wisdom from old man: always say, "if it pleases God."
Wisdom (knowledge) from sage (teacher).
Cynical philosopher lives in tub.
Advice from dervish.
Philosopher instructs youth regarding conduct.
Philosopher consoles woman for loss of son.
Wisdom from philosopher: give separate greetings to infants, youths, and old people.
Wisdom from philosopher: worldly honor like shadow. If one goes toward it, it flees; if one turns his back on it, it follows and at times catches up with one.
Wisdom from holy man.
Holy man's prayer reforms rich man. Holy man prays, "May God bless everything here that is good but cause to disappear all that is bad." Everything disappears.
Hermit explains why anger is sin.
Wise words of dying father. Counsel proved wise by experience.
Wise words of father.
Dying saint leaves wise message to followers. Message is cryptic, but is finally made clear.
Wisdom (knowledge) from women.
Hero directed on journey by princess.
Serpent directed on journey by his beautiful wife.
King has amours with great men's wives so as to learn secrets from them.
Caesar's scorn of his wife's advice leads to disaster.
Wife as adviser.
Wife of usurer saves husband through her prayers.
Wise words of dying woman (queen).
Knowledge from mysterious women met in the forest.
Wisdom from harlot to a king.
Wisdom from fools.
Wisdom from fool: make peace before rather than after the war.
Wisdom from fool: absurdity of tight-rope walker's performance.

Wisdom from fool: the present returned. Nobleman gives fool a present; he is to give it to no one who is not a greater fool. Master is dying; doctor tells fool that master is going to take long journey. Since master is making no preparation, fool gives him the present. Master thus brought to repentance.
Wisdom from fool: heaven refused. Fool says he does not want to go to heaven for he wants to stay with his master, who everyone says is going to hell. Master repents.
Wisdom (knowledge) from dream.
Deity appears in dream and gives instructions or advice.
Wisdom from dream: the leper with the cup of water. Man in dream willing to receive sacrament from unworthy priest.
Fate of parents revealed in dream. Mother shown in Hell; father in Heaven.
Dream advises against the popularizing of science.
Wisdom from angel.
Solomon pays heed to angel's warning. Rules wisely.
Trial rehearsed before stick in the ground as judge.
Wisdom acquired by hanging in a tree.
Wisdom purchased.
Man buys a pennyworth of wit.
Man to bring wife a purseful of sense.
Fool is told to get a pottle of brains. He tries to buy them. He finally learns that advice was to marry a clever girl.
One eye exchanged for wisdom. (Odin.)
Good counsels bought.
Wisdom from God.
Tree of knowledge.
Wisdom from books.

Wisdom from books bought at great price. (Sibylline). Nine books first offered at certain price. Finally after this is refused and the owner throws six of them into the fire, the king pays the same price for three of them. Finds them filled with wisdom.
Wisdom from books of the antediluvians.
Wisdom from continual reminder of foolishness in the past. Unjust judge skinned and his skin stretched over a footstool kept in the presence of judges, so as to remind them to be just.
Inscription on walls for condensed education.
Proverbial wisdom: counsels.
Counsel: if you take it you will be sorry; if you don't you will also be sorry. This advice given hero by helpful horse.
King questions six doctors.
King questions six doctors: what do you like best of all on earth?. That man has not what he wishes to have.
King questions six doctors: what do you like best of all on earth?. That all joys are mixed with sorrow.
King questions six doctors: what do you like best of all on earth?. That all evil and hypocrisy will have an end.
King questions six doctors: what must you most marvel at on earth?. That those who are most respected are the biggest fools.
King questions six doctors: what must you most marvel at on earth?. That those who speak of spiritual matters are usually the most depraved.
King questions six doctors: what must you most marvel at on earth?. That man lives in a state in which he cannot die.
Other maxims.
Crow flying away says, "A wise man remains not in the place of calamity; but a fool stays there, and sups fear and sorrow."
Proverbial wisdom: "Seek to win over the accuser, so that he causes you no annoyance."
Account of punishments prepared in hell brings about repentance.
Wisdom taught by suicidal example. Man is ordered by Senate to make tyrant stop bloodshed. He kills himself and family to satiate tyrant of blood.
Good and bad in all books. Author says that a prudent man notes only the good in a vain book; a malicious person, only the bad in a good book.
Wisdom from young man.
Wisdom from evil spirits.
Wisdom from brother-in-law.
Wisdom from robbers (thugs) who disguise selves and show cruel princess how she should treat her husband.
Other means of acquiring wisdom (knowledge) miscellaneous.
Humble Brahmin teaches king the difference between "mine" and "thine. "
Wisdom learned in underground kingdom: the passions of a human being could not be satisfied on earth.
Wisdom from neighbors.
Wisdom from fasting.
Possession of wisdom.
The years not counted. Man says that he is the youngest present, for he does not count the years before he became monk (or the like).
Varieties of wisdom.
"Forty-nine gates of wisdom"  open to Moses (and Solomon).
Seventy-two kinds of wisdom.
Wisdom wins contest of wisdom and wealth.
Minister's clever daughter-in-law uses wisdom to defeat Brahmin's wealth.
Wisdom lost by accepting bribes and gifts.
Acquisition and possession of wisdom miscellaneous.
Wise men.
Solomon as wise man.
Other biblical heroes as wise men.
Wise nations.
Wisdom from "Children of the East."
Wisdom from Egypt.
Wisdom from the Greeks.
Wisdom from the Hebrews.
Choices.
Hobson's choice: choose what is put before you or nothing.
Choice between eggs: one egg or none.
Choice between evils.
Four choices, all of which are evil; man to make one choice only.
Choice: free poverty or enslaved wealth.
Philosopher chooses poverty with freedom.
Man gives all his wealth away, for it is better to die than to give up virtue.
Town mouse and country mouse. Latter prefers poverty with safety.
Fly jeers at king's elephant for his lack of freedom.
Choice: plainness with safety or grandeur with danger.
Ass envies horse in fine trappings. Horse killed in battle; ass content.
Choice: loss of beauty or speech. Latter chosen.
Choice: suffering in youth or old age.
Present evil preferred to change for worse.
Don't drive away the flies. Wounded animal (man) refuses to have the flies driven away since they are now sated and their places will be taken by fierce and hungry flies.
Don't set a hungry guard over food. Parrot set to guard figs eats his fill. When replaced he calls attention to the fact that he is now full and therefore safer than another hungry parrot.
King refuses to exile gossipers. They would defame him among strangers. At home they serve to test the king's patience and to reform his life.
Do not pluck off the well-fed leeches. Wolf told not to do so lest hungrier ones take their places as he swims.
Old man chooses to be annoyed by occasional and loud chirp of swallows than by never-ending but soft chirp of sandpipers.
Oxen decide not to kill butchers, since inexpert killers might replace them.
Old woman prays for safety of cruel tyrant for fear a worse one will succeed him.
Heathcock prefers home with hardships to travel in foreign lands.
Monk goes to wilderness to escape work on material things. Finds that he must work to live and returns to monastery.
Choice of deaths.
Army faces enemy rather than the anger of their king who would kill them if they returned in flight.
Lamb prefers to be sacrificed in temple rather than to be eaten by a wolf.
Crab would rather be killed outright than imprisoned and starved.
Soldier asks to be stabbed in chest. Prostrate soldier asks enemy to stab him in chest instead of back in order to save his honor. Captor frees him and the two become friends.
Early death with fame preferred.
Saint chooses to die "after pride of youth" and before "misery of old age."
Captivity preferred to death.
Unsatisfactory life preferred to death.
Trickster overhears man praying for death to take him;  the trickster appears at man's house, usually in disguise, says he is God (or the devil). The man tells him to take his wife (or he runs away).
Escaped lamb delivers himself to shepherd rather than to slaughter.
Discontented ass longs for death but changes mind when he sees skins of dead asses at a fair.
Enemies make peace rather than slay each other.
Lion and wild boar make peace rather than slay each other for benefit of vulture.
Hostile dogs made friendly by having them fight common enemy, the wolf.
Choice: small injustice permitted rather than to cause troubles of state.
King overlooks wife's unfaithfulness rather than to cause troubles of state.
Senator overlooks wife's adultery rather than impair his reputation.
Man rebukes servants for telling him of his wife's unfaithfulness.
King chooses small inconvenience of personal troubles to great troubles for his kingdom. He suffers to help realm.
Man would rather pay 500 florins he did not owe than have it said he did not pay debts.
Rescue alone from shipwreck chosen over drowning with goods.
Choice between evils: pay tribute or lose both money and life.
Choice: apparent injustice over greater wrong.
Angel and hermit. Angel takes hermit with him and does many seemingly unjust things. Later shows why each of these was just.
Angel explains to hermit why God lets a sinner die in peace and have big funeral while holy hermit is slain by a wild beast.
God punishes many men because of one sinner, like a man who kills hive of bees for stinging of one.
Angel in form of young man shows skeptical hermit that ways of providence are inscrutable.
Youth made lame: had kicked his mother.
Lion sent to kill a man: frees him from possibility of sinning and sojourn in purgatory.
Angel takes cup from old man. Done lest he love the cup too much.
Angel (Jesus) kills man. Done because man is plotting a murder.
Angel kills man because he loves his child too much.
Saint gives liberally to gambler, little to beggar. Gambler is generous, beggar hoards.
Forestman who longs to do evil is sent to hell: writer, who repents, is sent to heaven. God justifies this to his sage.
Evil mother has fine funeral, good father poor.
Difficult choice between relatives.
Choice of freeing one son: adopted son or long-missing son.
Choice: blind son with long life or healthy son with short. Latter chosen.
Choice: foolish son always with him or four wise daughters who will leave him. Latter chosen.
Death preferred to other evils.
Death preferred to captivity.
Death preferred to dishonor.
Choice between evils miscellaneous.
Choice: staying at home with loving wife or going to tavern and having unfaithful wife. Man chooses latter.
Sheep and ignorant shearer. Had rather die than suffer longer from him.
Choice: a big piece of cake with my curse or a small piece with my blessing.
Better send an ugly woman to the devil than a pretty one. Man chooses ugly mistress.

Choice between bad master, bad official, or bad neighbor. Bad master can do evil if he desires to do so; bad official can harm a poor person and complain against him to his master; bad neighbor can betray secret things about his neighbors. Bad neighbor worst.
Bad choice between poor and miserly man. Neither makes good leader.
Rower prefers to be stoned by his master rather than remain out in the storm.
Contentment with evil master for fear of worse successor.

Weaver prefers master with one hedgehog. Insists on his master putting hedgehog out of house. When master refuses, weaver leaves. Next master has two hedgehogs, and next has three. Weaver returns to first master.
Man retains questionable bride for fear of getting one who is worse.
The smaller the evil the better. Therefore choose the smallest woman possible for a bride.
Take money instead of revenge. Fool advises uncle, in letter which he did not send, to take money from wife's paramour instead of revenge.
Prisoners given choice between emasculation and blinding.
God's punishment: the sinner may have twelve years of famine or twelve hours of heavy rainfall.
Physical pain preferred to poverty.
Choice: real and apparent values.
Wisdom chosen above all else.
Solomon, permitted by God to make any request, asks wisdom. Granted wisdom and wealth.
Choice between love and wisdom.
Health chosen as the most precious thing.
Choice between desire and duty.
Choice between useful and ornamental.
Fruitful tree chosen.
Athena chooses olive tree because of fruitfulness.
Peasant leaves honey tree standing. Sparrows and crickets ask peasant to leave tree standing. He refuses, but when he finds honey in the tree he consents.
Useful wins contest over beautiful.
Contest between rose and amaranth: worth lies not in beauty.
Pine and thornbush dispute as to their usefulness. Beauty of form does not give worth; pine grows slowly but it will withstand storms.
Fox and panther contest in beauty. Fox's spirit worth more than panther's skin.
Peacock proved to be bad king. Chosen because of beauty; too weak to defend his flock.
Peacock and crane in beauty contest. Better be able to soar like crane than to strut about like peacock.
Contest in beauty between swallows and crows (ants and flies): worth lies not in beauty.
Choice of a learned crow: a dead cat better than a golden crown.
In dividing property clever younger brother takes hind part of buffalo, upper part of tree, and use of curtain during night.
Usefulness better than speed.
Dog and hog dispute over their children: worth lies not in speed.
Goodness preferred to beauty.
Father with handsome son and hideous daughter. Advises both to look in mirror daily lest son exchange handsome face for bad character; daughter to triumph over face by good manners.
Useful and ugly preferred to expensive and beautiful.
Millstone preferred to jewels. Man shown jewels that cost much money; he replies that he has better stones (millstones) that earn that much.
King who experiences the cultural civilization of an empire in dream would rather be poor and primitive.
Strength preferred to cleverness.
Man criticizes the devil because his deeds are not fair. Devil says that they are strong nevertheless. Hence strong speakers rather than clever are to be preferred.
Hero, despising weapons, fights with fists alone.
Goodness preferred to wealth.
Man advised to choose good poor man for his daughter's husband rather than rich man.
Practical knowledge more vital than theoretical.
The bookman and the boatman: each ignorant of other's work. Bookman's swimming saves their lives.
Learned person worth two unlearned. Latter wastes time, former not.
Choice between worth and appearance.
Loudest mourners not greatest sorrowers.
Noisy things often empty.
Fox and noisy but empty drum.
Little coin in empty bottle noisy.
Among many vain words may be found some of wisdom.
Apparent beauty may be of the least importance. Ruler admires jewels's beauty but neglects to inquire about their marvelous virtues.
Choice between short and dangerous or long and sure way.
Choice between flattering lies and unflattering truths.
Raven drowns his young who promise to aid him when he becomes old. He saves one who admits he will not help, because he will have to carry his own young.
Quality preferred to quantity.
Quality of offspring preferred to quantity.
"Only one, but a lion". Lioness thus answers fox (hog) who twits her that she has only one cub.
The present preferred to the past.
Heed not the past.
Count only the waves before you. Fox sees man trying to count the waves. Advises him to count only those immediately before him and to pay no attention to those which have already passed.
Do not ask: "Why were the former days better than the present ones?"
Not what you were but what you are counts.
Wasp twits butterfly with coming from ugly chrysalis: unimportant where you come from.
Present values preferred to future.
Present possessions preferred to future possibilities.
A bird in the hand foolishly given away in hope of greater gain.
Today's catch of fish traded for prospective larger catch tomorrow.
Little fish in the net kept rather than wait for uncertainty of greater catch.
Lion leaves sleeping hare to follow the shepherd. Loses both victims.
Present possessions preferred to future.
Don't injure yourself to insure your family's future.
Man wagers he can run with his head off. Asked what it will profit him, he says that it will profit his family.
Man to be reforged chooses present unhappiness. He is in heaven and God is to reforge him, but he chooses not to change.
Children choose father they know rather than real father they do not yet know. Woman confesses that child is not by her husband. Child, however, chooses to keep the father he knows.
Man prefers servant girl who is present to her absent mistress.
Soldier prefers to live rather than die and be avenged on enemy.
Choices: little gain, big loss.
Weight of bodily member chosen rather than its loss.
Fox prefers to bear weight of his tail rather than give part of it to ape.
High wages bring expensive living.
Barber leaves inexpensive village for high wages in city. Finds cost of living more than enough to take all his profit.
In spite of master's advice disciple stays in country where everything has cheap price. Gets into trouble.
Wise man refuses income of half a kingdom since expenses will outweigh gain.
Man refuses cure which brings greater inconvenience.
Drunkard refuses cure of fever if it is to take away his thirst.
What one has is neglected in search for other things.
The monkey and the lost lentil. Lets all others he has in his hand fall in order to search for it.
Host wants to learn Hebrew even at risk of forgetting his own language.
The valuable neglected for the interesting.
Herdsman neglects his she-goats in favor of wild-goats. She-goats die; wild-goats run off.
Man leaves farming for fishing. When water dries up he goes hungry.
Better be content with what you have, than try to get more and lose everything.
Wealth and glory sacrificed for freedom and virtue.
Man refuses vast wealth because with it will come covetousness.
King lays aside crown since it brings too many cares.
Prince chooses exile and honor to foul life at his father's court.
Rich merchant is poorer in happiness than poor man.
Man refuses rich marriage with house filled with dangerous wild animals.
Choices: small inconvenience, large gain.
Bodily member(s) sacrificed to save life.
Beaver sacrifices scrotum to save life. Cuts it off and leaves it for pursuers.
Inconvenience disregarded when booty is in sight.
Wolf does not mind the dust. Told that dust from flock of sheep will annoy him; he finds it useful.
Snake is willing to suffer the indignity of serving frog king as mount because frog king gives him frogs to eat.
Slight inconvenience in weather, large gain.
The widow's meal. King upbraids wind for blowing away a poor widow's last cup of meal. Finds that the wind has saved a ship full of people by that very act. The king is humbled.
Less inconvenience in fighting though tired than in losing all for a little rest.
Priest sells his donkey because worry for its safety distracts him from prayer.
Small inconvenience, large gain miscellaneous.
Solomon refuses water of immortality for himself when he cannot have it for his possessions also.
Ape throws away nut because of its bitter rind.
Choices: important and unimportant work.
No time for minor fights when life is in danger.
Bull refuses to fight goat. Bull being pursued by lion tries to go into cave. Goat refuses to let him in. Bull must go on, for with lion pursuing he has no time to fight goat.
King ridiculed for inventing trifle of musical instrument but praised for constructing a great mosque.
Choices: kind strangers, unkind relatives.
Kind foster-parents chosen rather than cruel parents.
Lamb chooses her foster-mother, the she-goat. Owes more to her than to her own mother, who has deserted her.
Choice of associates.
Scarcity of real friends.
"A friend is known in need."
Socrates builds himself a little house. Criticized for its smallness he says, "I wish I had true friends enough to fill it."
Association of equals and unequals.
Great refuse to associate with lowly.
Boar refuses to fight with lowly ass.
Zeus refuses wedding present from snake. Presents to be received only from equals.
Prince refuses to play with common children.
Noble poets refuse to associate with truly good poet because of his lowly birth.
Peasant ashamed of being thrown off by ass. Shameful to be thrown by such a creature.
Wolf tries to make friends with lion: killed.
Dolphin and whale scorn crab as peacemaker.
Laurel and olive tree scorn thornbush as umpire in their dispute as to who is most useful.
Mouse on lion's mane. Lion angry at impudence of mouse.
Knight disregards insult by servant.
King refuses to quarrel with bird.
Leopard ashamed of having been bitten by lizard.
Rich man refuses to associate with poor sister.
Profitable association of great and lowly.

Prince of democratic tastes chosen. King asks three sons what kind of bird they would prefer to be. First: an eagle, because it is ruler of birds; second: a falcon; because it is beloved by the nobles; third: a bird which flies with many others, so as to receive advice. King chooses third.
Unprofitable association of unequals.
Lion licks sick man, who is thereby disgusted.
Marriage with equal or with unequal.
Wife chosen instead of fairy mistress. They let man choose between them.
Prince prefers first love to princess he later marries.
Unsuccessful marriage of jackals and turtles (different habits).
One's own kind preferred to strangers.
Bird refuses to maintain friendship with bird of different habits.
Man prefers to live with ordinary rather than with pious man. He will be virtuous by comparison.
Association of strong and weak.
Subordination of weak to strong.
Lion as king makes ass his lieutenant.
Lion makes lame goat his lieutenant.
Stupid fear company of clever.
Jackal realizes that the partridge was too clever for him and leaves.
Weak fear company of strong.
Earthen and brazen pots in river. Brazen pot thinks that they should stay together for company. Earthen pot, however, fears approach of brazen pot.
Buffalo refuses tiger's invitation to dinner. He sees fire prepared to cook him.

Association of rat with cat ceases as soon as mutual danger has passed. The rat threatened by the weasel and the owl allies himself with a cat caught in a net. Saved by the cat, he rescues the cat with precaution and then prudently renounces further relations with her.
Association of mouse with cat ceases as soon as mutual danger has passed.
Friendship of snake and frog ceases when snake wants to eat frog.
Association of cow and tiger: tiger eats cow as soon as she is hungry.
Association of tiger and crane. They soon quarrel.
Association of strong and weak miscellaneous.
Association of swan and swallow: swan unable to fly away from danger.
Associating with a bad friend is fatal: swan and crow. Swan is blamed when crow drops filth.
Association of young and old.
Profitable association of young and old.
Old ox yoked with young ox. Thus kept in order.
Foolish association of young and old.
Foolish youth in love with ugly old mistress.
Foolish marriage of old man and young girl.
Association of the good and the evil.
Contagiousness of bad company.
Ass buyer returns ass which has associated with lazy companions.
Stork killed along with cranes. Ill-advised associations end fatally.
God of wealth in bad company. Heracles on his arrival in heaven fails to greet Plutus, the god of wealth: he has seen him in too bad company.
Mirror begrimed by snail.
Bad associates bring death to bishop. Doctor loses his life for him and lawyer his soul.
Harm of association with flatterers.
Unnecessary choices.
Senseless debate of the mutually useful.
The belly and the members. Debate as to their usefulness. All mutually useful.
Tail and head of serpent quarrel as to usefulness.
Fortune, Intellect, Knowledge, and Health dispute as to which is the greatest.
Debate of tongue and other bodily members.
Common wives of man debate as to which has helped him most. Help of each was indispensable.
Tobacco, pipe, and match debate usefulness to smoker.
Deer, opossum, and snake each render indispensable aid to man. Foolishly debate their usefulness.
Rice, wheat, and dal dispute as to which is the best.
Dispute of hammer and anvil.
Wealth and wisdom dispute as to who is greater.
Elephant and ape debate about superiority. Owl gives them task neither can perform and ends futile debate.
Unnecessary choices of belief.
