Captured animal asks respite while he gives war alarm.
Wolf kept at door until children have been christened. He loses his feast.
Let me live as long as this candle lasts. Man who has sold his soul to devil thus escapes.
Escape by asking a last kiss. Uses the opportunity to attack adversary.
Ten (five) year respite given captive while he undertakes to teach elephant (ass) to speak. Captive explains to friends that in that time the captor, the elephant (ass), or himself is likely to die.
Respite from death until muddy victim may dry self in sun.
Respite from death until one pays a last visit.
Respite from death until visit is finished.
Respite from death until captive has taken six steps toward God. Takes prodigious ones and escapes.
Respite from death until prisoner is healed by magic object.
Woman escapes by ruse: must go to defecate.
Respite from death for drink of water.
Kidnapped woman escapes by asking for drink of water.
Jackal persuades woman to untie his legs so that he may get a drink.
Respite from death granted until wolf reads horse's passport. Wolf kicked to death.
Respite from death granted while wolf counts hairs in horse's tail. Wolf kicked to death.
Wolf is requested by tailor to be measured for suit of clothes; wolf beaten.
Respite from death until minister shows king how to reap pearls.
Definite respite from death granted.
A year's time granted to settle affairs before death.
God grants man twenty years more of life provided he plays no tricks.
Crocodile grants boy five days respite from death.
Escape by false plea: jackal asks to be able to clasp tree before crocodile kills it.
Respite from death until hero climbs tree. He flies away in machine stored there.
Escape from threatened captivity by pretending to send for object for captor.
Turtle allowed to go to pool to pick flowers before death. Escapes.
Respite from death until victim can fall asleep.
Captors give captive respite in order to witness alleged marvel.
Wait till I get fat. "  Captured person (animal) persuades his captor to wait and fatten him before eating him.
Wait till I am fat enough to race you. "  Hero to be eaten by cannibals when he is fattened enough to beat them in a race. He runs away.
Calf: "Wait till I grow up.
Let me catch you better game. "  Captured animal pretends to help captor bring more desirable victim. Escapes.
Wait till men come to take me from trap, then eat them.
Wait for the fat goat. Troll lets the first two goats pass on the bridge so that he may eat the biggest one. He is thrown in the water.
Dwarf persuaded to wait for ram. Lamb and ewe escape. Ram butts dwarf into river.
Ram promises to jump into wolf's belly. Gives him a hard knock. The stunned wolf thinks he has swallowed the ram.
Wolf is requested by horse to start eating from the rear; kicked to death.
Soak me in the pond so that I will be juicy.
Too dirty to eat. Trickster, cornered by leopard, leaps into swamp, then says he is too dirty to eat. Leopard smells of him and agrees.
Executioner kept busy or interested until rescue comes. Sometimes until he changes his mind.
Respite from death gained by long-drawn-out speech.
Respite from death gained by tale of the preparation of flax.
Respite from death gained by tale of the preparation of bread.
Respite from death gained by long-drawn-out song.
Formula-tale (Ehod) saves girl from devil. Unsuccessful imitation.
Escape by singing an endless song. The soldier's bargain with Death.
Tiger persuaded by jackals to settle argument. Tricked.
Death cheated by moving bed. The man who has chosen Death as his godfather has his bed turned around when he sees Death standing at the foot of his bed. He thus escapes death.
Man allowed to pick out tree to be hanged on. Cannot find one.
Escape by asking to die falling from a tree.
Man asks to be beheaded standing in tank of water. He ducks and executioners kill each other.
Escape by persuading captor to talk.
Attempted escape by persuading captor to talk fails.
Animal captor persuaded to talk and release victim from his mouth. Usually cock and fox, fox and wolf, or mouse and cat.
Cat fails to be beguiled into releasing mouse. The mouse tells the cat a tale. The cat answers at last, "Even so, I eat you up.
Frog escapes after telling crow to sharpen his bill before eating him.
Sheep persuade the wolf to sing. Dogs are summoned.
Crocodile persuaded to open his mouth. When he does, he shuts his eyes automatically and monkey escapes.
Rat persuades cat to wash face before eating: escapes.
Captive trickster persuades captor to pray before eating. Escapes.
Hare persuades cat to perform two gallops before eating him: escapes.
Escape because of plea that leaves means of egress open.
Jackal in tiger's house has permission to sit with tail hanging down between bamboo stems. Enlarges gap thus made and escapes.
Tortoise persuades tiger captor to put him in pocket with hole, escapes.
Thumbling in animal's belly persuades latter to go to his father's house for plunder: rescued.
Boy swallowed by fish that is thrown up on shore persuades tiger to cut it open with injunction not to look at him.
Jackal entrapped in elephant's carcass tells passing God to show his magic power by making it rain. Elephant's hide swells; jackal escapes.
Ass begs wolf to pull thorn out of foot before eating him: kicks wolf in mouth.
Escape by pretending to perform errand (do work) for captor.
Prince to giant: "Don't eat me up, and I'll prepare you a good dinner.
Man persuades robbers to postpone killing him until he can show them his treasure. Leads them into marsh and escapes.
Escape by pretending to dance so as to be untied.
Hare promises to dance if doorway is left free: escapes.
Escape from captor by means of flattery.
Escape by asserting that captor will have ill luck after killing victim.
Escape by asking girl about to murder him if she will have to assume all the guilt. She reconsiders.
Escape by false prophecy: if corpses are buried in city, it will become a ruin: king releases condemned man.
To get out of thieves' clutch, man reports high prices in another town.
Escape by false plea miscellaneous.
Wife accused of plan to escape weeps and threatens suicide so as to allay suspicion and escape.
Monkey in danger on bridge of crocodiles pretends that the king has ordered them counted.
Escape from robbers by pretending to be going the same way but separating at the first opportunity.
Escape from pursuers by pretending to be one of them.
Monkey saved from trap by feigning marriage.
Respite while captor acts as umpire between captives.
Wolf acts as judge before eating the rams. They are to go to the end of the field and run to him. They run at him and kill him.
Tiger to help foxes divide their young. Foxes escape into hole.
Murder feigned to effect escape. Knight is refused permission to leave city. He rushes to city gates and pretends that he has just killed a public enemy. Is aided in his escape.
A handy name. Thief is jailed for stealing a quarter of veal. Sends man named "Calf" to captor. " I took only one quarter of veal, but I am sending you a whole calf. " Is set free.
A plea for a larger audience. Fox asks cock to come down from a tree and sing for him. Cock asks fox to awake his companion, a dog, first. Dog kills fox.
Captor persuaded into illusory punishment.
Animal "punished" by being placed in favorite environment.
Drowning punishment for turtle (eel, crab). By expressing horror of drowning, he induces his captor to throw him into the water  his home.
Briar-patch punishment for rabbit. By expressing horror of being thrown into the briar patch he induces his captor into doing so. He runs off.
Men double up hare's legs and throw him on the ground as punishment. He escapes.
Burying the mole as punishment.
Bird punished by being thrown into air.
Birds caught in net fly away with it.
Burning the jackal. He expresses horror of that punishment. Sets fire to village from his burning tail. Why he has burnt tip on tail.
Thieving insect put in closely woven basket asks to be put in a loosely woven one so he cannot see.
Punishment which proves fatal to captor.
Turtle persuades an animal to swallow him: causes the animal's death and escapes.
Wolf punished by being married. After debate it is decided that marriage is the greatest punishment.
Thief begs for any punishment except the luxury of two wives.
Throwing the thief over the fence. Thief, surprised at theft says: "Do your worst, only don't throw me over the fence. " When thrown over, he escapes.
Murderer or captor otherwise beguiled.
Escape by posing as member of murderer's family or tribe.
Escape by posing as preceptor of tiger's deceased father.
Don't eat your nephews. "  Giants thus dissuaded.
Noman. "  Escape by assuming an equivocal name.
Fairy child injured by man who says that his name is "Self". Child tells mother, "Self did it.
Bee is eating the sweets. "  Man has eaten sweets and says his name is B. India: Thompson-Balys.
Escape under ram's belly. By hiding under the belly of a ram the hero escapes under the legs of the blind ogre.
The three teachings of the bird (fox). In return for release from captivity the bird (fox) gives the man three teachings. These usually mock the man for his foolishness in releasing what he has.
Cannibal sent for water with vessel full of holes: victim escapes.
Cannibal sent for water which magically recedes from him: victim escapes.
Escape by singing song. Captive gradually moves away and at last escapes.
Pursuer persuaded to sing while captive escapes.
Escape by teaching song to watchman.
Trickster, pretending not to see attacking enemy, sings song of friendship.
Escape by playing music.
Escape by playing magic music. Captor is compelled to dance while victims escape.
Escape by playing sleep-bringing music.
Escape by singing watchmen to sleep.
Musician in hell playing for the devils, purposely breaks fiddle strings. Must return to earth to repair strings.
Witch put off guard by playing on jew's harp.
Escape by persuading captors to dance.
Enemy in ambush (or disguise) deceived into declaring himself.

The cave call. ("Hello, house! ") An animal suspecting the presence of an enemy in his cave (house), calls and receives no answer. He then says, "Don't you know, O cave, that we have agreed that I must call you when I come from abroad and that you in turn must answer me? " The hiding animal answers and the other flees.
Crocodile masking as a log obeys suggestion that he move upstream. He thus betrays himself.
Crocodile in ambush betrays self by talking.
Sham-dead man deceived into making gesture. Obeys suggestion as to how dead man should act and betrays himself.
Sham-dead tiger betrayed by his live penis.
Sham-dead deceived into moving by absurd action.
Leopard concealed in bundle betrays self when threat is made to run spear through bundle.

Escape by laughing and crying at same time. Captured bird cries in thinking of her little ones and laughs under pretext that the hunter is wasting his time instead of taking the treasure which she pretends is in her house. The hunter leaves her.
Escape by putting captor off guard.
Escape by pretended lousing. Captive pretends to louse the captor but deceives him by cracking berries in the teeth (or the like).
Escape by pretended cooking. Girl pretends to be cooking meal for animal husband: escapes.
Escape from madman by sending him for cooking water.
Escape on ship on wheels after having deceived the captor into laying away sword and helm to receive pretended gift.
Man in devils' power makes them believe he will return and is permitted to leave. Deceives them.
Prisoner released on promise to wed guard (captor).
Prisoner released on promise of life-long allegiance.
Animal captor appeased by being fed captive's family.
Boy in hole escapes descending log by digging hole.
Murderer or captor beguiled miscellaneous.
Cannibals advised to be absent while hero is being cooked;  else he will not taste right. Hero escapes.
Cleanest girl to be eaten by ogress: clever girl shakes sesame into fire to simulate sound of burning lice.
Pursuer persuaded to put oil on a tree when he wants to climb after fugitives.
Trickster persuades pursuers to play fatal deceptive game.
Escape by deceiving the guard.
Escape by blinding the guard. Pepper or tobacco thrown into his eyes.
Red ants' nest broken and thrown down on ogre's head.
Escape from animals by blowing ashes into their faces.
Captive plays further and further from watchman and escapes.
Escape by pretended debate as to which must be judged. Jackals thus induce leopard to permit them to enter their cave, while he waits in vain.
Escape from captor by throwing objects to great distance which captor tries to procure.
Watchman outwitted by having rope stretched across the road while fugitives escape.
Abductors tricked into running race while captive escapes.
Escape by giving narcotic to guards.
Escape of girl foiled by hero's refusal to take narcotic.
Escape by making the watchmen drunk.
Escape by bribing the guard.
Escape by throwing money (treasure) so that guards fight over it.
Escape by deceiving the guard miscellaneous.
Escape by pretended bathing of guard. Boiling water used.
Man and woman escape by sending the she-bear to bring the woman's "forgotten" comb.
Guardian enticed away.
Tiger enticed away to gather berries: victims escape.
Tiger enticed away by slain pig.
Escape by disarming (making pursuit difficult).
Captor induced to disarm himself.
Captive dodges when captor tries to cut off his hand;  the hatchet sticks in a log and the captor is disarmed.
Disarming by a shooting test. The captor is thus induced to fire all his shots.
Person holds hat just outside shelter; enemies shoot at it,  either giving away their position or putting themselves at a disadvantage in having to reload.
Mice gnaw enemies' bow strings and prevent pursuit.
Army of mice save kingdom from enemy invading force by gnawing their provisions, ammunition, etc., to shreds.
Captor's powder is removed, ashes substituted: gun does not discharge.
Escape by arranging captor's clothes so as to delay him.
Escape by throwing captor's clothes on the fire.
Master thief persuades captors to dive into water: steals their clothes.
Sleeping enemies' hair tied to an object prevents pursuit.
Hair of sleeping maiden tied to tree so that she is not able to rise.
Holes bored in enemies' boats prevent pursuit.
Paddles broken in enemies' boat prevent pursuit.
Cutting thongs of sleds prevents pursuit.
Captive tied to captor escapes by tying end of rope to a post.
Escape by help of confederate.
One animal saves another by frightening enemy away.
Free animal saves its captured friend.
Crow and rat release deer from snare.
Confederate sings and delays pursuers so that fugitive escapes.
Monkey attracts attention of mowers until young birds can fly away from the harvest field.
Monkey saves condemned birds through feigned dream.
Fugitive's confederate misdirects pursuer.
Confederate cuts rope almost in two so that prisoner breaks it and flees.
Bird's call attracts attention of pursuer so that trickster escapes.
Escape by help of confederate miscellaneous.
Confederate hides fugitive.
One animal swallows another to save him from pursuer.
Tiger-mother hides concealed guests in jar.
Confederate sits on hero and saves him.
Rescuer disguised as officer gains custody of prisoner.
Boys scolded in order to conceal their identity.
Son mentioned as daughter in order to save him from enemy's pursuit.
Boys warned by dogs' names to escape.
Sons warned by talk to oaks to hide.
Confederate in disguise helps man escape.
Confederate in disguise as beggar helps to escape.
Helper dressed in bear's skin helps to escape.
Confederate in disguise as "troll" frightens king's men, while his daughter helps prisoner to escape.
Confederate saves fugitive by shammed pursuit.
Confederate causes confusion so that prisoner can escape.
Prisoner escapes by means of wolf which he lures near by smearing honey on the feet.
Escape by cutting fetters on stones, etc.
Confederate persuades captor to throw away disguised trickster.
Other means of escape.
Wolf descends into well in one bucket and rescues fox in the other.
Fox climbs from pit on wolf's back.
Prisoner kills his watchers who enter to torture him. Escapes.
Captors lured into drowning selves.
Exaggerated tales about escapes.
Escape from suspicion of crime.
Fool's brothers substitute a goat for the body of the man he has killed: thus save him.
Statue mourned and buried in order to account for murdered person.
Insect in nose of murdered person simulates snoring and allays suspicion.
Waxen statue left instead of abducted queen.
Captive throws his hat to lions who fight over it while he escapes.
Captive throws his shoe at serpent who chokes while he escapes.
Sleeping potion given to man who is to pass the night with a girl.

Paramour unwittingly drinks sleeping potion. Is thought dead and placed in a chest. Chest is stolen. When he escapes he is accused of being a robber. He is saved by his mistress's maid who explains all, transferring the role played by her mistress to herself.
Trickster persuades pursuers to ride in his basket. Leaves basket on limb of tree and escapes.
Hero tests the rope on which he is to be pulled to upper world. By placing stones on the rope he discovers his companions' treacherous plan to cut the rope.
Hero hides in treasure box and thus circumvents plot to leave him below when companions pull up box.
Cutting rope to kill ogre who is climbing the rope to reach his victim.
Small animal in mouth of larger causes captor to spit him out. (Defecates.)
Escape by catching hold of limbs of tree while passing under it.
Escape by announcing great catastrophe (end of world or the like).
Birds escape death by flying away with net.
Capture by deception.
Victim enticed into voluntary captivity or helplessness.
Deception into entering bag.
Birds enticed into bag.
Deception into magic bag which closes on prisoner.
Leopard persuaded to enter bag in order to see trickster perform marvel.
Miser induced to thrust his head into bag;  noose pulled by thief afterwards.
Ogre frightened into rolling self in mat: burned.
Witch tells boy to pass down some of fruit from tree, catches hold of him and puts him in her sack when he bends down.
Deception into allowing oneself to be fettered.
Deception into allowing oneself to be tied.
Animal allows himself to be tied so as to avoid being carried off by storm.
Animal allows himself to be tied to another for safety. Carried to his death.
Animal persuaded to be tied by promise of food.
Animal persuaded to be tied through curiosity to learn secret names.
Ogre allows self to be tied so as to learn magic.
Animal allows self to be tied so as to learn music.
Faithless wife ties sleeping husband's hair to bed, allowing lover to kill him.
Women bind warrior's hair to wall of hostel while he sleeps.
Deception into putting on a collar.
Hare persuades wolf and fox to put their heads in loops on rope and thus strangles them to death.
Deception into entering box (or prison).
Victim tricked into prison and kept there.
Trickster persuades policeman to take his place in the stocks. Then tricks policeman's wife into giving him jewels.
Victim tricked into entering box.
Victim tricked into jumping in a box by making him think he is going to heaven.
Tiger enticed into coffin.
Dupe tricked into entering hollow tree.
Victim tricked into entering basket.
Woman persuaded to hide head in jug: she is caught.
Animal lured into lion's den.
Victim lured into following deer sent by demon to cave. Dies of suffocation.
Fish enticed into trap (promised new skins).
Deceived lion stuck in cave entrance; becomes food for hare.
Fox deceives lion into entering pit.
Deception into allowing oneself to be hanged. ("Show me how! ") Executioner must show the hero how to use the gallows. The hero hangs the executioner.
Deception into bottle (vessel). Insects (or a spirit) having escaped from a bottle are told that they cannot return. They accept the challenge and go back into the bottle.
Cock persuaded to crow with closed eyes. Seized.
Dupe persuaded to close eyes and open mouth;  then hot stones are thrown down throat.
Giant tricked into becoming mouse. Cat eats him up.
Dragon enticed into pot while in its child-form, boiled, so it can see "courage".
Dupe induced to waste his bullets, then seized.
Dupe lured away from protection of friends: captured.
Dupe persuaded to ride on trickster's back: captured.
Foxes crawl into whale's house and are killed.
Victim trapped.
Animal trapped through curiosity as to what the trap is.
Claim that a trap is a prayer house.
Frog causes deer to dance into snare.
Leopard traps lion by having two doors to cave, one large, one small. Lion enters large entrance and leopard leaves by small and attacks back of lion.
Tortoise leads elephant down wrong trail into trap.
Birds led into trap by promise of a feast.
Wildboar captured in church.
Intruder captured in chimney. Burned.
Capture in pitfall.
Mats over holes as pitfall.
Capture in trap seat.
Knight captured in pitfall while his horse escapes.
Capture in trap bed: victim dropped into dungeon.
Pit placed under a bed.
Dupe tricked into well: left there.
Tiger enticed into pit by being tempted to leap after boar-leader.
Snapping door. Traps victims.
Capture by closing entrance to victim's home.
Dupe lured into hole and entrance closed.
Tiger persuaded to walk into house: locked in.
Capture by tarbaby. An image covered with tar (or other adhesive substance) captures the intruder who addresses it and finally strikes it so that he sticks to it.
Capture by tarring back of a horse.
Capture between branches of tree. Small animal lures large one, who cannot get loose.
Victim captured in a noose.
Victim burned in building.
Capture by decoy.
Capture by feigning death.
Capture by hiding in animal carcass. Animal who comes to eat of carcass caught.
Man plays dead and hides in money chest: catches thief.

Capture by hiding under screen (grass, leaves, etc.)  Africa (Kaffir): Theal 30 No. 1, (Basuto): Jacottet 100 No. 15, (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 384 No. 2; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 79 No. 15, 95 No. 18 (hollow tree).
Capture by hiding in disguised objects.
Capture by hiding in disguised ship.
Capture by hiding in artificial animal.
Trojan wooden horse. Permits capture of the city by concealing soldiers.
Capture by hiding in artificial elephant.
Capture by hiding in artificial bird.
Capture by masking as another.
Abduction by fraudulently giving signal of husband's return.
Capture by imitation of animal's voice.
Birds captured by imitating their song.
Attempted capture by causing animal to make noise.
Attempted capture by causing owner's pig to squeal at night.
Attempted capture by ringing cowbell to sound as if cow has wandered far away.
Bird catches fishes by imitating voice of friend.
Capture by feigning illness.
Capture by hiding in baskets of food.
Capture by putting on the clothes of slain enemy.
Stranger asks woman for fire: abducts her.
Capture by hiding in hollow tree.
Witch pretends to be starving beggar woman in order to capture child.
Hare carries disguised lion covered with honey, thus luring animals into trap.
Other deceptive captures.
Unicorn tricked into running horn into tree.
Lioness enticed into putting head into wall to pursue hare who escapes through hole. Gets stuck.
Victim enticed into dancing: captured.
Crabs induced to take moonlight walks: eaten.
Deception by having victim pick trickster's teeth.
Capture by sight of women's breasts. Women with uncovered breasts meet hero. He averts his face and is captured.
Sight of women's breasts used to appease enemies.
Sight of unclothed women calms rage of youthful hero.
Capture by luring merchant to look at supposed bargain.
Capture by taking aboard ship to inspect wares.
Capture by intoxication (or narcotic).
Capture with aid of sleep-bringing music.
Fortress captured as harper puts garrison to sleep with music while besiegers place fingers in ears.
Man is made drunk and left in temple at mercy of demons.
Capture of castle by pretending to surrender and entering.
Capture through the wiles of a woman.
Woman (Amazon) in disguise invites enemies singly into forest and overcomes them.
Amazonian woman disguised as leper seduces and binds enemies one by one.
Capture by luring to courtesan's house.
Attack made on groom after he has been invited to female apartments to have meal with bride.
Adulteress lures husband so as to have him killed.
Castle captured with assistance of owner's daughter. She loves the attacker.
Capture by lying in wait in enemy's haunt.
Capture by blinding.
Enemy blinded with chili powder and overpowered.
In duel with long poles the ogre is forced into the pig-sty.
Fairy wins kiss in game;  embraces woman and flies off with her through skylight (smokehole).
Maiden sent to rendezvous with lover, who is captured.
Woman lured into the forest and captured.
Princess lured into the forest by harp-playing boy or thief.
Killing or maiming by deception.
Fatal deception into trickster's power.
Victim lured into house and killed.
Animal enticed into palace after it had long fed out of trickster's hand.
Enemies invited to banquet and killed.
With help of captor's daughter, prisoners slay many of his soldiers at a banquet.
Enemies invited to feast and poisoned.
Jackals persuaded to enter pit to escape coming storm. Killed.
Cruel king lured to enemy's power by invitation to false execution. He comes to see a girl die and is killed himself.
Hostile visitors lured into iron house concealed by wooden walls. Hosts set fire to house.
Pretended friend puts food on far side of hidden ditch, victim falls in and is killed.
Victim burned in his own house (or hiding place).
Dupe's house set afire so that he is burned in trying to put out fire.
Boy teaches giants how to lay a carpet of dried grass and naphtha over the hard ground floor of their cave, sets fire to it and thus suffocates them.
Men lured to their death when their fields are set on fire.
Monkey lures tiger into tree-top and sets fire to it.
Owner burns intruder in house.
Stag killed by lion into whose den the fox puts him.
Whimbrel sends his adulterous mate to meet him in cave. He has arranged with lion to be there to eat her.
Hare tricks civet cat into being eaten by lion.
Overcurious dupe enters trickster's basket and is killed.
Victim lured by kind words approaches trickster and is killed.
Fox persuades cock to come down and talk to him. Kills him.
Fox tries to persuade cock to come down and talk to him. Cock calls dog and fox flees.
Spider invites wasp (fly) to rest on her "white curtain". Eats her.
Dogs listen to wolves' hypocritical words. Are killed.
Cat invites hens to a feast and kills them.
Owl invites cricket to share his nectar. Kills him.
Snake promises to do no harm to frog. Kills him.
Cat acts as judge between sparrow and hare; eats them both.
Hawk persuades doves to elect him their king. Kills them.
Tiger flatters cow into showing that she has few teeth. Kills her.
Weasel induces cuckoo to tell him that it cries at night when asleep. Hence weasels can kill cuckoos.
Wounded wolf persuades lamb to bring him a drink, adding that he will get his own food.
Boat lured to land with kind words and wrecked in order to take vengeance on the men.
Cat makes truce with mice. When they have become friendly, he eats them.
Fish tricked by crane into letting selves be carried from one pond to another. The crane eats them when they are in his power.
Fish, lured by kind words, are killed by old man.
Cat lures young foxes from den with music. Kills them.
Jackal feigns holiness but seizes worshipping rats.
King of fishes eats his subjects as they pay him their respects day and night.
Serpent asks his victim to feed him with honey, then seizes and swallows him.
Victim told to stand ready by tree to catch bee nest as it falls;  trickster throws club at him instead.
Dupe lured to supposed dance and killed.
Victim persuaded to disarm. Killed.
Man killed with sword, which he himself is tricked into passing to captured enemy.
Giantess killed with the spear she herself has given hero.
Victim's arrows made harmless.
Deception by hiding weapons.
Fairies in animal form persuaded they will hear music better in own shapes. Are killed.
Women draw warrior aside so that confederate may kill him.
Sham doctor kills his patients.
Sham doctor kills ogre (giant).
Victim persuaded to hold out his tongue: cut off. Robbers induced by various excuses (to learn to sing, to learn foreign language, to have a hair taken off the tongue).
Cormorant's tongue pulled out by putting louse on it.
Victim persuaded to hold out tongue: bitten off.
Elephant killed by cutting off trunk which is poked into cave after victims.
Man causes victim to bite his tongue off.
Man persuaded to hold out hand for alleged letter from king. Hand cut off.
Hoodwinked dancers. A trickster induces ducks to dance with closed eyes and kills them.
Dupe persuaded to relax vigilance; seized.
Fox persuades bird to show him how she acts in a storm: he devours her. (Bird has advised other bird how to avoid the fox; he is revenged.)
Cannibals persuaded to take snuff: killed.
Dupe persuaded to sing (dance) on trickster's body. When he approaches the mouth he is killed.
Fox shams death and catches crows that come to feed on him.
Cheese smeared on crab lures giant to smell him. Crab pinches giant's neck and kills him.
Bloodthirsty animal by trickery admitted to fold: kills peaceful animal.
Fox in sheepskin gains admission to fold and kills sheep.
Fox feigning illness admitted to hen-roost and kills the hens.
Wolf tries to cheat ewe by posing as ram.
Victim killed while being bathed.
Slave washing mistress's back in stream pushes her into crocodile hole.
Trickster sends dupe to well for drink of water; pushes him in.
Monkey killed by girls who pretend to wash its buttocks.
Dupe induced to look about: seized and killed.
Jealous wife tells sister to look below: pushes her over cliff.
Victim persuaded to look into well or pond: pushed in.
Fencer calls opponent's attention to something behind him: when opponent looks around he cuts off his head.
Female confederate disrobes before hero, who is attacked when he looks away.
Man gets bear off guard by telling her to listen for hunters: kills her.
Victim persuaded to look for certain tree: pushed over cliff.
Man asked to look at birds: pulled into pool.
Man lured into aiding trickster who has feigned an accident or needs help. Is killed.
Victim killed while asleep in killer's house.
Dupe tricked into sleeping. Killed.
Dragon deceived into listening to tale: hero cuts off its head.
Ferocious boar fed and put to sleep by rubbing. Killed. (Aper.)
Victim killed while load is being taken from his back.
Victim lured into trough: is pounded up with poisoned fish.
Fatal deception into trickster's power miscellaneous.
Victim enticed into eating: killed when off guard.
Victim lured into approach by false token.
Victim enticed into drinking by over-salting his food: killed when off guard.
King who demands milk from all hornless cows forced to accept bogstuff milked from wooden cows: he dies.
Camel lures wolf into looking at the writing on his breast. Crushes wolf.
Supernaturals tricked into (fatal) exposure to daylight.
Deception into fatal substitution.
Substitute for execution obtained by trickery.
Substitute for execution obtained by trickery. Report that man executed just then will be king in heaven.

Dupe persuaded to take prisoner's place in a sack: killed. The bag is to be thrown into the sea. The trickster keeps shouting that he does not want to go to heaven (or marry the princess); the dupe gladly substitutes for him.
Dupe persuaded to take prisoner's place suspended in air.
Dupe persuaded to take prisoner's place in pit.
Tied animal persuades another to take his place.
Raja substitutes himself for condemned man. Made to believe that this will take him to heaven.
Dupe persuaded to be killed in order to go to heaven.
Dupes persuaded to be burned, thinking they will be sent back with gifts.
Dupe persuaded to play for wedding party. Takes place of trickster, who sets fire and burns him up.
Pursuer persuaded to take fugitive's place in supposed swing. Hanged.
Trickster being attacked by ferocious animal persuades dupe to take his place.
Fatal deceptive game.
Deceptive game: burning each other. Dupe burned (boiled) to death.
Deceptive game: hanging each other. Dupe really hanged.
Fatal game: drowning.
Fatal game: throwing from cliff. Spider throws its young; other animal imitates.
Fatal swinging game. Old woman causes swing to break when her rival is swinging.
Deceptive game: bear cubs sway in tree.
Fatal game: dying and reviving. Hero has power of resuscitation but fails to revive his enemy.
Deceptive game: throwing away knives. (Not fatal.)
Fatal game: shaving necks. Dupe's head cut off.
Fatal game: sewing each other up. Hare is partly sewed up, but he sews antelope entirely up so that he dies.
Shooting game: blind man's arrow aimed. It kills his friend. (Balder's death.)
Jealous husband tricks blind poet into slaying wife's lover with infallible spear.
Fatal apple-throwing game.
Fatal game: putting heads in notches.
Fatal game: rolling down hill on barrel. Dupe crushed.
Fatal duel: brother kills brother in pretended game.
Deceptive sword-game: brother killed.
Deceptive game: butting one another like rams. Robbers kill selves.
Fatal deceptive game miscellaneous.
Deceptive game: fox wants to be frightened;  titmouse whistles for dogs and the fox is nearly caught.
Deceptive hide and seek game. Hide and seek game proposed by seven demons so as to kill hero.
Deceptive game: "Eat me up!. " Camel is killed by lion.
Fatal swimming race. To trick spirits hero proposes a swimming race. As each spirit arrives, hero drowns it.
Fatal deception by narcotic (intoxication).
Fatal intoxication.
Army intoxicated and overcome.
Slaughter of drunken enemies in banquet hall.
Judith and Holofernes: girl from enemy camp chosen to sleep with intoxicated general kills him in bed.
Girl kills man sleeping with her.
Fatal deception by giving narcotic.
King given sleeping potion and then beheaded in his bed by his wife.
Groom murdered, while watchmen and bride are brought to sleep by music.
Boy makes adversary insensible by substituting opium for half of tobacco in pipe.
Drug introduced into half of fruit from enemy's fingernail where it has been hidden.
Deception by pretended lousing.
Ape pretends to louse heron, but plucks out his feathers.
Fatal deception by pretended combing of victim's hair.
Dupe tricked into killing himself.
Poor man deceives rich man, plays tricks on him, causes his death.
Dupe tricked into jumping to his death.
Intruding wolf tricked into jumping down chimney and killing himself.
Ape tricked into jumping on to stakes and killing himself.
Monkey tricked into jumping in water and drowning self. Jackal hides in reeds which screen water.
Dupe tricked into jumping on supposed funeral pyre of beloved.
Dupe induced to jump over precipice.
Animals (giants) enticed over precipice.
Dupe crowded over precipice.
Dupes persuaded to be thrown over precipice.
Dupes deceived into falling over precipice.
Dupe crowded into the water: drowns.
Dupe forced on to thin ice: drowns himself.
Man leads pursuers to edge of thin ice, swerves suddenly;  they fall through the ice.
Cannibals enticed to climb slippery barricade: fall.
Animal left out of his element: dies or escapes.

Beaver and porcupine trick each other. Beaver carries porcupine and abandons him in the center of a lake. Porcupine causes the lake to freeze and escapes. He then carries beaver and abandons him in the top of a tree.
Dupe tricked on to slippery road lined with knives. He kills himself.
Snake killed by putting knives in animal he is swallowing.
Animal killed by axes (knives) left in tree.
Giant impales self on javelin fugitive holds behind himself.
Robbers make stairs slippery so that bathing prince falls.
Dupe tricked into measuring boar whose bristles are poisoned.
Murder by strategy.
Feigning death to kill enemy.
Sham death to wound enemies. Trickster lets himself be buried alive and stabs his enemies from the grave when they come to defile his body.
Man feigns death to stab brother who comes to grieve.
Sleep feigned to kill enemy.
Sham dead king jumps up and kills the nearest slave.
Feigning deafness to lure enemy close and to kill him.
Robbers' (giants') heads cut off one by one as they enter house.
Robbers' (giants') noses cut off as they enter house.
Robbers' (giants') hands cut off as they enter house.
Giant's (giantess's) head cut off as he (she) looks out.
Men lured into serpent pit one by one and killed.
Ogre suitor persuaded by woman to bury her murdered lover: she cuts off his head.
Disguised hero attacks enemy at feast.
Disguised shipwrecked men admitted to the king's house kill him at Yule feast in revenge for murder.
Murder from ambush.
Bear killed from ambush as he leaves his cave.
Rock hurled down hill slays enemy passing below.
Slaying under cover of darkness.
Dancer stabs spectator. Uses one of the figures of the dance as a ruse.
Peacock helper dances before enemy army of hero;  flame of fire from her tail burns them all to ashes.
Treacherous murder during hunt.
Man murdered while praying.
Fox rids himself of fleas. He lets himself sink in water somewhat with a bundle of hay. The fleas gather on the hay-bundle and he dives into the water.
Artificial whale made as stratagem. Enemies surprised and killed.
Murder by bleeding: taking more blood than victim realizes.
Person cuts drawbridge partly through. Giant falls into moat.
Victim pushed into fire.
Hero entices enemies into building and sets fire to it.
Victim pushed into water.
Slaughter of animals by stampede.
Murder through transformation.
Serpent transforms self to staff, is picked up and bites enemy.
Murder by strategy miscellaneous.
Murder by leaving poisoned wine.
One-eyed doe outwitted by approaching from her blind side. Accustomed to feed on a cliff with her sound eye next the land.
Ruler promises minister that he will not kill him "on any day of his life. "  Dispels his suspicions. Has him killed at night.
Pretended flight draws victims.
Murder by slipping gold coins into meat customarily demanded by enemy.
Murder by feigned quarrel. Peacemaker killed.
Men deceived into killing each other.
Hero, who has eloped with affianced wife of king, induced to return to court and treacherously slain during enforced absence of his sureties at drinking bouts.
Murder by pushing off cliff.
Old wife provokes sparrow to speak and therefore drop new wife whom he is carrying in his beak.
Concealed weapons in food basket sent king: kills servant who opens it.
False message from other world causes man to go on funeral pyre.
Hare causes pursuing she-bear to stick between trees and kills her.
Treacherous murder of enemy's children or charges.
Sham nurse kills enemy's children.
Trickster employed to educate baby crocodiles: he eats them instead.
Trickster pollutes nest and brood of bird.
Trickster eats all of tiger's cubs but one. Counts that one many times and deceives tiger.
Fox as shepherd. A woman in search of a shepherd tries the voices of applicants. The wolf and the bear are rejected, the fox accepted.
Deception into killing own family or animals.
Man betrayed into eating his own children.
Man betrayed into eating his own children and setting the village on fire.
Man betrayed into killing his wife or grandmother.
Trickster's false report of high prices causes dupe to destroy his property.
Cows killed for their hides when large price is reported by trickster.
Wives killed when large price for his mother's (wife's) corpse is reported by trickster.
Dupe burns house because trickster reports high price paid for ashes.
Enemies each burn own houses to be able to sell ashes.
Angry man kills his own horse by mistake. Trickster has shifted the places of his horse and that of the dupe.
Hermit (deceived by the devil) kills his own father, supposing him to be the devil.
Deceptive agreement to kill wives (children). Trickster shams the murder; dupe kills his.
Woman tricked into giving poison to her husband: thinks it a love-philtre.
Bird flies on head of dupe's child. Dupe strikes at bird and kills child.
King causes his own men to be burned and killed, by mistake or illusion.
King lured to send his sons on fatal quests and to kill nephews.
Various kinds of treacherous murder.
Murder by choking.
Deserted wife chokes departing husband. Asks for one last kiss.
Murder by throwing hot stones in the mouth.
Murder by hot iron in mouth.
Killing tiger by throwing hot hatchet into mouth.
Murder by thrusting spear (tongs) into mouth.
Murder by throwing hot fruit into victim's mouth.
Murder by feeding with bread full of pins.
Murder by throwing poisoned bread into mouth.
Murder by putting clod into person's windpipe.
Animal killed by forcing ball (of hide, wax, etc.) into throat.
Murder by feeding with honey-covered sharpened cross-pieces of wood.
Animal (monster) killed from within.
Ungrateful river passenger kills carrier from within. Crawls inside during the passage. (Porcupine and buffalo.)
Jackal, swallowed by elephant so it can drink water in his belly, eats elephant's liver and kills him.
Ungrateful rat defecates upon head of (or kills) octopus that rescues him from sea.
Man transforms self to gadfly to enter giant's stomach and kill him.
Man kills giant bear by crawling inside and cutting his way out.
Animal tricked into seizing hollow log. Man reaches through and pulls animal's heart out.
Murder by squeezing.
Murder by lacing corset tight.
Murder by wrapping snake around man.
Crab carried by crane, clings round his neck and cuts off his head with pincers.
Murder by crushing in false embrace.
Murder by burning.
Murder by scalding.
Murder by burning in hot oil.
Murder by burning arrow.
Murder by destroying external soul.
Gradual murder by piecemeal destruction of separable soul.
Murder by blinding.
Killing by throwing hot salt into eyes.
Murder by drowning.
Other kinds of treacherous murder.
Murder by putting mouth of pot over victim's head.
Murder in one's sleep.
Woman's father and brothers kill her husband in sleep for having married against their wishes.
Heroes dislike to kill sleeping people.
Man murdered at his wife's side.
Woman marries king feigning that she can heal him, and murders him in sleep. Afterward she takes the kingdom together with his counsellor.
Hero attacks and kills at night hero who wanted to go to sleep before their fighting.
Tent torn down over man, and he is then killed.
Rafter supporting giant's house cut half through, so that it can be drawn down from the outside, and the giant killed.
Murder from behind.
Thorns planted so that birds are killed when they light on field.
Post-hole murder: people invite boy to enter post-hole and then try to crush him with log.
Other fatal deceits.
Flesh of certain animal alleged to be only cure for disease: animal to be killed. (The sick lion.)
Blood of certain animal said to be sweet. Its death thus brought about.
Disease to be cured by heart of monkey.
Tit for tat. Wolf tells sick lion that fox does not esteem him. Fox overhears it. Later fox tells lion that his only cure lies in his wrapping himself in the wolf's skin. Wolf is killed.
Flesh (vital organs) of certain person alleged to be only cure for disease.
Brain of snake said to be only cure for monkey's disease. Monkey to be killed by snake when he goes to hole.
Ogress wife demands eyes of six wives of raja or she will die.
Camel induced to offer himself as sacrifice. Other animals feign to offer themselves to the lion as food. The lion eats the camel.
Rope cut and victim dropped. Man is being hauled up on the rope.
Rope of mountain-climber cut and victim dropped.
Barber killed when hero reports king's ancestors need his services in heaven.
Man with deformed head slays his barbers.
Secret of strength treacherously discovered.
Pretended exchange of confidences as to the one thing that can kill.
Hero tells enemies how he may be killed.
Secret of external soul learned by deception.
Daughter pulls out father's magic life-containing hair. As soon as it is taken out he dies.
Uriah letter. Man carries written order for his own execution.
Message of death. Man carries unwittingly an oral order for his own execution.
Leopard and crocodile both sent for the dog. Neither has seen a dog nor have they seen each other. Man sends them to the same place saying that the dog will be there. They kill each other.
Message of death lost.
Fatal deception: changed message from oracle.
Dupe induced to stand under falling tree.
Dupe persuaded to climb tree. Tree felled and dupe killed.
Tree cut down to get at victim in top.
Dupes lured onto tree-trunk bridge; fall to death.
Man is lured into sitting in a mechanical chair and is killed.
Magic horse lent by fairy in disguise brings about death of mortal.
Murder induced by bribery (lands, riches, wives).
Person thrown out of magic airship and killed.
Dupe persuaded to go to dangerous place; killed.
Brother causes brother's death by sending him to robbers and giving false advice.
Deception into self-injury.
Deception through false doctoring.
Remedy: covering with dry leaves. Victim burned up.
Eye-remedy. Under pretence of curing eyesight the trickster blinds the dupe. (Often with a glowing mass thrust into the eye.)
Fool deceived into curing headache by removing his eyes.
Ashes as remedy for sore eyes.
Making the dupe strong. The false doctor injures him.
Making the dupe strong by castration.
Making the dupe strong by scalding.
False beauty-doctor. The trickster pretends to make the dupe beautiful. Injures him.

Making the beard golden: "such a one". A man named "Such a one" persuades an ogre to have his beard gilded. He covers it with tar and leaves the ogre caught to the tar-kettle. The ogre with his tar-kettle wanders about and asks everyone, "Have you seen such a one?
Painting" on the haycock. The fox persuades the wolf to lie on the hay in order to be painted. He sets fire to it.
Making wife beautiful by burning her.
Burning children on promise of giving them fawn's beautiful spots.
Painting" with a red hot iron.
Trickster to give wings to tiger. Wounds him fatally.
False hair-restorer injures patient.
Trick: breaking legs for prowess in dancing (or for swiftness).
Pepper given as ointment for burns.
Pepper up noses as remedy.
Pepper rubbed on injured skin.
False remedy for toothache.
Biting on stone given as remedy for toothache. Teeth injured.
Leopard wants teeth filed: large stone dropped from tree knocks all leopard's teeth out.
Beetles and barley introduced into wounds on pretence of healing them.
Feeling pulse: doctor severs arteries instead.
Hare flatters other animals into letting it bite off their ears.
Deception into disastrous attempt to procure food.
The tail fisher. The bear is persuaded to fish with his tail through a hole in the ice. When he is attacked and tries to escape, he loses his tail.
Tail buried (hair tied). Dupe bound fast and then attacked.
Hair tied to basket so that dupe kills self when she throws basket down.
Basket tied to wolf's tail and filled with stones. Wolf is persuaded that it is filled with fish.
Bear persuaded to slide down rock. Wears off tail.
Dupe persuaded to steal food: cannot escape.
Wolf overeats in the cellar (smokehouse). Cannot escape through the entrance hole.
Jackal eating into elephant's dead body becomes a prisoner when it dries up;  is released when storm moistens hide.
Wolf tied to cow's horns. The fox ties one end of the rope around the wolf's neck, the other to the cow they intend to eat. The cow drags the wolf to the house where the man skins it.
Water-monster, trying to pull horse into water, is dragged to house where he begs for his life and is spared.
Bear throws hens to the fox, falls from the roof-beam, and is beaten.
Wolf brings cake from the window-sill. He imitates the fox in so doing, but rings a bell, so that he is beaten.
Turtle induced to rob in a man's garden.
Otter persuaded to rob: beaten.
Fox eats cake: gets brass pot caught on neck.
Thieving wolf persuaded to stick head through handle of jar of wine so as to be able to carry it off and also sing.
Getting honey from the wasp-nest. The dupe is stung.
Dupe allowed to guard "king's drum": it is a wasp nest.
Dupe allowed to guard "king's girdle": it is a snake, which bites him.
Dupe persuaded to pick up biting ants.
Dupe persuaded to sit on ant hole. Hindquarters eaten.
Animal made to believe sound of swarming bees is that of her children singing in school. Rushes to water to relieve stings and is drowned.
Dupe induced to strike at bee's nest: badly bitten.
Beginning with the smallest. Animals are to eat one another up to avoid starvation. The fox persuades them to start with the smallest.
Eating his own entrails. The fox persuades the wolf to do so.
The fox suggests eating his own brains. The wolf, wanting to get brains, strikes his head against a tree.
Tiger persuaded to eat own eyes.
Dupe imitates trickster's thefts and is caught.
Dupe made to sit on hot stone.
Jackal persuaded to come to fireplace for food. Burns self.
Hot porridge in the ogre's throat. He is tricked into burning his throat.
Dupe persuaded to climb rope for food: rope breaks.
Stone (hard fruit) thrown into greedy dupe's mouth.
Trickster pretends to give dupe magic power to produce food. Injures him.
Dupe told he can get meat by putting hand up animal's anus: animal drags him.
Jackal puts head in anus of sham-dead camel: caught and punished.
Dupe injures self on fence of thorns surrounding food-plants.
Dupe otherwise persuaded to voluntary self-injury.
Borrowed feathers. Dupe lets himself be carried aloft by bird and dropped.
Flight by putting on bird feathers. Dupe falls.
Water bird takes dupe to sea: shakes him off into water.
Elephant offers to let chameleon hold on to his tail: it is oiled and chameleon falls off.
Dupe induced to eat sharp (stinging, bitter) fruit.
Monkey "shares" ointment with tiger: produces sores.
Dupe persuaded to eat stones.
Dupe induced to eat filth (dung).
Dupe induced to drink urine.
Dupe persuaded to oversalt (overpepper) food.
Dupe fed oversalted food.
Dupe persuaded to rub salt on wounds.
Dupe persuaded to scald self with hot water in order to learn languages.
The bear bites the seemingly dead horse's tail. Is dragged off by the horse.
Diving for sheep. Dupe persuaded that sheep have been lost in river.
Dupe induced to dive for alleged jewels.
Diving for clothes.
Diving to become strong.
Dragon attacks own image in mirror.

Robber persuaded to climb down moonbeam. A man hearing a robber enter tells his wife aloud that he always makes a prayer and then enters the house by climbing down a moonbeam. The thief tries it and falls.
Dupe persuaded to get into grass in order to learn new dance. Grass set on fire.
Crocodile hides in strawstack and is burned to death.
Dupe allowed to guard "king's litter": sticks in mud.
Gun as tobacco pipe. The trickster gives the ogre the gun to smoke.
Deer persuaded to butt head into tree. Kills himself.
Serpent's jewel is covered with spiked helmet so that when he tries to recover it he strikes and is spiked to death.
Dupe digs till he dies of exhaustion. Rabbit entertains the wolf with his antics until the rabbit's wife can change to another hole. The wolf continues to dig.
Dupe persuaded to transform self into animal. Cannot change back.
Man dupes animals into turning their tongues upside down.
Duck persuades cock to cut off his crest and spurs. The cat attacks the duck, who cries, "peace, gentlemen, peace!
Dupe induced to incriminate himself. Taught incriminating song or persuaded to wear incriminating clothes.
Trickster teaches a dupe a strange language.
The laborer teaches his master birds' talk. Puts him in a sack and beats him.
Teaching Latin. Cuts off tip of pupil's tongue or orders him to lick cold iron pupil injures himself.
Peas strewn on stairs so that person will slip.
Fairy induces hero to dive into lake which makes person old.
Dupe tricked into sitting on hot iron.
Fox persuades bear to lie in the haycock and wait for sheep. He sets fire to the hay.
Dupe tricked into breaking tabu by lying.
Men tricked into bathing in "disease-water".
Dupe sleeps on the "king's bed": falls into well beneath and dies.
Persons duped into injuring each other.
Blind men duped into fighting.
Blind men duped into fighting: money to be divided. Trickster says that he is giving one of them money to be divided with the others. Gives it to none. They quarrel and fight.
I don't believe you have a gold coin. "  Trickster handed money by each of four blind beggars, each thinking that member of group speaks.
Blind men duped into fighting: stolen meat. The trickster steals one piece of meat. The blind accuse each other and fight.
Blind men duped into fighting: strings leading to water removed.
Ogres (large animals, sharp-elbowed women) duped into fighting each other. Trickster strikes one so that he thinks the other has done it.
Enemies duped into fighting each other.
Missile thrown among enemies causes them to fight one another.
Object thrown into air causes enemies to fight over it.
Bird lighting on the heads of group of men causes them to kill one another with blows on the head.
Undesignated present starts quarrel for its possession.
Liar brings about fight between dupes.
Trickster tells lies to fishes and causes them to fight.
Jackal tells tales so as to get buffalo and tiger to kill each other;  feeds on the meat.
Liar brings enmity between friends.
Trickster attempts to bring friends to fight. (Plans that one kill the other.)
Calumniators try to bring friendly kings to fight, but fail at last.

Woman makes trouble between man and wife: the hair from his beard. She tells the wife to increase her husband's love by cutting a hair from his beard. Also tells the husband that his wife will try to cut his throat. He kills his wife.
Woman makes trouble between man and wife (to lick husband's body).
Woman makes trouble between man and wife: to keep certain rendezvous.
Woman induces men to fight over her and kill each other.
Falsified message brings about a war.
Men disrobe and report they have been attacked: bring about war.
Message falsified to bring about death of lovers.

Dissension aroused in army by casting suspicion on general. A general destroys everything except what belongs to the general of the enemy. Thus he brings about suspicion that the two leaders are in league.
Brothers duped into killing each other by slander that one of them is father to the other's child.
Goddess arouses heroes' jealousy and eternal fighting.
Treacherous counselor persuades king's son to woo his father's young bride whom he is sent to get, and as he tells the king that he is her lover both are killed.
God persuades hero to substitute a false bride for his father;  this results in a fight where the son kills the father.
Deceptions into self injury-miscellaneous.
Dupe puts hand (paws) into cleft of tree (wedge, vise).
Dupe wishing to learn to play fiddle has finger caught in cleft of tree.
Dupe wishing to learn to play flute puts tongue in split bamboo.
Ogre's (dwarf's) beard caught fast.
Dupe caught in crack in ground. Dies.
Ogre helps tortoise who snaps jaws to and catches him.
Bending the tree. Hero bends tree over but when he catches breath the tree shoots him to the sky.
Tree becomes light (after all honey has been collected from nests), springs back and kills tribe's enemies.
Abandonment on stretching tree. A man is induced to get into a tree which magically shoots upward.
Dupe persuaded to climb tall tree. Falls.
Fox rings the bell. The bear eats a horse which has a bell tied around its neck. The fox rings the bell and gets blamed.
The oath on the iron. The trickster takes an oath by touching iron (a trap). The dupe imitates but hits the iron so hard that he gets caught.
Animal gets bait from trap by luring another animal into it.
Dupe induced to sit on sharp stones (concealed as soft seat).
Ogre induced to sit on reversed harrow.
Wolf (lion) approaches too near to horse: kicked in face.
Wolf (lion) as sham doctor looks at horse's foot: kicked in face.
Sow kicks wolf into stream when he comes close to baptize her pigs. Thus she saves them from him.
Dupe tries to dig up alleged treasure buried in ant hill: bitten by snake and killed.

Peter receives the blows twice. Peter and Christ are sleeping in the same bed. The drunken host returns home and beats Peter, who thereupon changes places with Christ. The host then comes in to beat the other lodger and beats Peter again.
Dupe persuaded to throw away his knife. Later must go hungry because he has no knife to cut the meat.

The lying goat. A father sends his sons one after the other to pasture the goat. The goat always declares that he has had nothing to eat. The father angrily sends his sons from home and learns, when he himself tries to pasture the goat, that he has been deceived.

Casual words uttered by dupe used to cheat him of his property. A miser is persuaded by his servant to fast nine days. He calls out on the fifth day "the half" and on the ninth "the whole". She makes people believe that he is making his will and giving everything to her. It is so ordered.
Animals hidden in various parts of a house attack owner with their characteristic powers and kill him when he enters.
Man persuaded to go to store with scythe. Is tied up as madman.
Secret learned by intoxicating dupe.
Plot to induce king to commit a crime. His line thus will forfeit succession.
Dupe tricked in race into falling into a pit.
Falling beam in cave kills travelers lured within.
Minister dupes raja into entering body of dead parrot, then enters rajah's body.
Dupe deceived concerning the thunder; finally killed by it. The dupe has asked the trickster to tell him when it thunders.
Sheep makes fox believe that the hunter is a priest, the dog his servant, etc.
Hot tin under the horse's tail. The smith promises to make the horse wild. The numskull on the horse's back.

Rat leaves serpent behind, through spared to rescue him. The two are imprisoned together in a sevenfold cloth covering. The serpent refrains from eating the rat so that the latter can gnaw the cloth for them. The rat gnaws his own way out and leaves the serpent.
Tiger persuaded to cross river carrying vat rim-upwards. Trickster fills it with stones and tiger loses it.
Deception into humiliating position.
Humiliated or baffled lovers.
Vergil in the basket. A lover who is to be pulled up to his mistress's window is left hanging in the basket in the public gaze.
Lover caught in roof.
Lover left standing in snow while his mistress is with another. He later tricks her into standing a whole day in July in a tower naked exposed to the sun and flies.
Terrorizing the paramour (importunate lover).

Woman dares husband to try his sword on pile of clothing which hides her paramour. Stops him just in time. Later the paramour entices her to come to him. Exposes her naked, except for face, to his friends.

Adulteress frightens paramour with cries of "Rape!. " Then she removes her husband's suspicion by feigning a fit. Later the paramour tricks her to his room and shows her naked, except for face, to her husband.
Prostitute frightens lover with cries of "Thief!. " Gets his money.
Hercules spins for his beloved. Is forced to dress as woman and discharge womanly duties including spinning.
Importunate lover induced to dress as woman and sift flour. Is shown to his wife.
Importunate lover is induced to undergo series of humiliations. (1) Disguise as bakery woman. (2) Disguise as priest. (3) Disguise as corpse. (4) Hiding in wine skin. Humiliated each time.

Aristotle and Phyllis: philosopher as riding horse for woman. The philosopher warns the king against uxoriousness. In revenge the queen beguiles the philosopher into letting her ride him on all-fours. The king comes and sees.
Hidden paramour taken to his own wife. He hides in a chest. The chest is taken by a creditor who unwittingly delivers it to the paramour's wife.
Tale of the basin. Lover caught on magic basin and left in embarrassing position.
Importunate lovers led astray.
The entrapped suitors. (Lai l'ipervier.) The chaste wife has them one at a time undress and hide. The husband and guests come and chase them off.
The entrapped suitors: the chaste wife tricks them into casks. The husband takes the casks to the marketplace where he opens them.
The entrapped suitors: the chaste wife has them caught. Forces them to work for her.
The entrapped suitor: tricked into room where he is left to himself.
Importunate lover imprisoned and starved: later given choice of lady or food. Chooses food.
Lover hidden by wife in room made to fall into deep pit of treacle.
Importunate lover (priest) is forced to hide in chest. Husband takes the chest to the waiting congregation. Clever priest comes out enacting the resurrection of Lazarus.
Four importunate lovers are forced to hide in four-compartmented chest which is sold.
Importunate suitor enticed into sack and beaten by husband.
Priest caught in lasso by rival lover. Mistress tells knight of priest's demands. Knight has her give assignation, and arranges around her a string lasso which he pulls, and catches priest.
Importunate suitor has his head shaved and tarred and is put into a sack and returned to his men.
To get "nothing" and to show it. Wife pushes lecherous king first into glue and then in the closet with feathers. That is "nothing"   neither bird nor man.
Suitor locked in pigsty.
Suitors one by one enticed into graveyard and left together. They later get revenge.

Suitors as corpse, angel, and devil. First induced to lie in coffin, second to sit up with the "corpse", and the third to carry a firebrand. " Corpse" thinks others are angel and devil. All come to blows.

Three women humiliate importunate lover. First has him hide on thorns, second has him fall into a hole, third has him fall asleep in the street. In revenge he shows them naked, except for face, to his friends.
Girl asks importunate lover for weapon to use against her father. Instead, she uses it to defend herself against the suitor.
Importunate lover beaten and sent on street bearing humiliating placard.
Importunate lover tied to tree.
Importunate lover beaten with canes filled with straw. He thinks he is severely wounded.
Obscene tricks are played on repugnant simpleton who wishes to marry.
Importunate lover is given a rendezvous. Obscene tricks played on him.
Wife takes lover beneath tree where she has told husband to hide. When he begins to kiss her, husband shouts "Keep a little for me. " Lover, shamefaced, runs away.
Woman tricks importunate lover with the head of a pike. Thereafter he thinks the vagina is toothed.
Mistress deceives lover with a substitute.
Bride escapes from foolish husband and leaves goat as substitute in bed.
Mistress sends man's own wife as substitute without his knowledge.
Chaste woman sends man's own wife as substitute (without his knowledge). Then the first woman's husband is substituted for the importunate lover, who has his own wife seduced.
Wife (mistress) substitutes for mistress (wife). The woman has been asked for a rendezvous. She tells the suitor's wife and they exchange places.
Chaste woman substitutes corpse for herself in the bed of an insistent suitor.
King's daughter deceives king by substituting her maid.
Lover given rump to kiss. Sometimes the trick is played by a rival lover. (Chaucer's Miller's Tale).
Lover put off by deceptive respite.
Lover put off till girl bathes and dresses. She escapes.
Suitors put off till web is woven. Unwoven each night. (Penelope.)
Respite from wooer while he brings clothes all night. The girl wastes time trying them on.
Girl refuses to dance with a devil until she is well dressed. The devil brings things till the cock crows. Another girl asks for all the things at once and must dance until she dies.
Girl asks undesired lover to take off his boots. She pulls off one partway and escapes.
Girl tells physician-seducer she cannot meet his wishes until after he bathes. Prepares the bath herself and pours acid into it.
Woman leaves importunate lover waiting in her room. Feigns illness and then escapes.
Girl puts off consummation of marriage to undesirable suitor by saying her "stomach is sick".
Girl asks undesired lover to follow her but not to step on her shadow.
Girl says she has made vow not to marry until pilgrimage is made.
Girl as umpire in suitor test (shooting arrows) escapes.
Importunate lover kept overlong at supper: must leave.
Escape from undesired lover by alleging menstrual period.
Abducted princess tells her abductor to wait for her menstrual period of 12 years to terminate.
Woman humiliates would-be lover. Knowing that he has deceived another by paying her with gilded coin she answers: "You will have to pay in better coin than is your wont!
Chaste woman refers lover to her husband for permission.
Chaste woman refers lover to his wife.
Lover deceived by false suicide agreement. The woman persuades her lover to jump from a cliff; she will follow. She does not jump.
Lover's anger softened by sham suicide attempt. Is later scorned.
Lover humiliated by his impotence.
King tricked into sleeping with hag.
Disguise as man to escape importunate lover.
Girl plays at dice with her suitors: locks them up when they are defeated.
Deception into humiliating position miscellaneous.
Trickster rides dupe horseback. Usually by feigning sickness he induces the dupe to carry him and then boasts that the dupe always acts as his horse.
Trickster rides dupe a-courting. Feigns sickness and persuades dupe to carry him. Thus wins the girl.
Priest trapped in window and humiliated.
Holding up the rock. Trickster makes dupe believe that he is holding up a great rock and induces him to hold it for a while.
Holding up the roof. Fox pretends to be holding up the roof; hence cannot help the bear, who must do the threshing alone.
Fox pretends to be guarding the sky and watching the earth.
Holding down the hat. Dupe persuaded to guard hat supposed to cover something valuable. It covers a pile of dung. (Dupe's goods are sometimes stolen.)
Dupe persuaded to fight with alleged gold-dropping bear: trickster meantime steals his clothes.
The general hatches out an egg. The page induces the general to take his place in sitting on the eggs. Then he calls the king to look.
Person hypnotized into believing himself transformed.
Man falsely reported insane. No one will believe him.
Man carried and dropped in mid-stream.
Amorous intrigue observed and exposed.
Threat to tell of amorous intrigue used as blackmail.
The bag of lies: threat to tell of queen's adultery. The boy, who is to tell the bag of lies, is stopped and his wishes granted.
Princess made to speak desired words when hero threatens to report (falsely) her amorous conduct.
Educated chickens tell of woman's adultery. A trickster undertakes to teach a woman's chickens to talk. When he reports that they are saying that she has slept with the priest, she pays him off.
Man hidden in roof sees girl and lover and falls: they flee and leave him in possession.
Man having seen woman and lover from roof threatens to tell about it; is paid to stop.
Man hidden in roof (or elsewhere) sees girl and lover: blows horn. They flee and leave him in possession.
Observer of intrigue insists on sharing in it (or enjoys the girl after putting the man to flight).
Lovers observed in intrigue make absurd excuses. (Afraid of ghosts, have chill, etc.) Italian Novella:
Amorous intrigue exposed and faithless husband humiliated.
Wife surprises husband in adultery and shames him into giving her all she desires.
Adulteress tells lover "I can see the whole world. "  Hidden shepherd asks "Can you see my lost calves (ass)?
The Lord above will provide. A youth and maid come under tree. " Who shall provide for our child? " "He above (God) will take care of it. " The man in the tree: "I will do nothing of the kind!
Man abed with his wife is frightened away by an intruder who steals his clothes.
Abbess puts priest's trousers on her head. Suddenly called up while abed with the priest, she thinks to put on her coif. Discomfited by nuns whom she has denounced for incontinence.
Discovery of abbot's (abbess's) incontinence brings permission to monks (nuns) to do likewise.
Girl who cannot keep silent thereby provokes her rival to admit unchastity.
Girl refusing her lover final kiss provokes rival to admit selling kisses.
Woman draws a pelt to her instead of her husband. A woman asks of her husband a hair which will magically draw him to her. He gives her a hair from a pelt.
Priest draws a sow to him instead of a woman. He asks for a pubic hair which will draw the woman to him. Sow's bristles substituted. Sow rushes to church.
Rascals pull off judge's breeches and leave him exposed.
Mock initiation for dupe.
King induced to kiss horse's rump: trickster then threatens to tell.
Opposing witnesses's pockets filled with dung. Discredited.
Hostile brother-in-law made king's inferior by being tricked to hold his sword, while the king arranges his breeches belt. (Old custom).
Seduction.
Mortal woman seduced by a god.
Woman won and lost by a ruse.
Seduction by disguise or substitution.
Seduction by masking as woman's husband.
Seduction by masking as woman's husband: "Why you have just left!. " After the seduction the husband comes and the wife shows surprise.
Trickster kills husband and puts on his skin so as to seduce wife.
Husband's twin brother mistaken by woman for her husband.
Seduction by wearing coat of invisibility.
Seduction by impostor.
Seduction by posing as a god.
Seduction by posing as Angel Gabriel.
Seduction on promise that issue will be the fifth Evangelist.
Seduction on feigned orders from angel to engender a pope. Girl born.
Seduction by posing as doctor.
Girl persuaded to sit on certain plant: seduced. Man as sham doctor tells her how to heal her burnt groins.
Seduction by sham process of retrieving lost gem.
Seduction by sham process of repairing vagina.
Seduction by pretending to give childless man's wife medicine. When husband comes at cockcrow as he was told, trickster says he came too late and they must do it again.
Seduction by posing as magician. (Sham incantation, etc.) Italian Novella:
Seduction by feigning enchantment.
Seduction attempted on promise of magic transformation: woman to mare. Finishing the tail.
Seduction by posing as a relative.
Seduction by posing as nobleman.
Prostitute poses as noble woman.
Seduction by posing as holy man (churchman).
Tricksters persuade women that they must share their marital intimacies with them.
Seduction attempted on threat of performing miracle.
Girl disguised as friar gets into priest's bed.
Seduction by posing as saint.
Seduction by posing as teacher or instructor.
Seduction by pretending to instruct (or to need instruction) in marital duties.
Seduction under pretence of teaching a game.
Seduction upon false promise of marriage.
Seduction by offering protection against non-existing danger.
Seduction by posing as beggar.
Seduction by posing as leper.
Seduction by posing as merchant.
Seduction by masking as soldier.
Seduction: weaver posing as king.
Lover's place in bed usurped by another.
Serving-man in his master's place.
Master in serving-man's place in woman's bed.
Leper intercepts letter and takes paramour's place with princess.
Old woman intercepts letter and takes girl's place in man's bed.
Letter delivered to wrong man. He substitutes for the lover.
Vengeful paramours send syphilitic man to substitute in woman's bed.
Man caught running by guards has to tell his destination. One of the guards substitutes for him with his sweetheart.
Woman substitutes for her daughter in the dark.
Use of drugs to usurp lover's place.
Woman drugs sister and substitutes for her with lover.
Woman mistakes passer-by for lover. Substitution in the dark.
Moorish (black) girl substituted for mistress (in the dark).
Man intercepts love letter and takes lover's place in elopement.
Devil comes to rendezvous instead of woman's lover.
Trickster shifts married couples in bed. Old man married to young woman and young man married to old woman. The shift is satisfactory to the young couple.
Seduction by man disguising as woman.
Man disguised as woman admitted to women's quarters: seduction.
Man disguised as pregnant woman admitted to girl's bed.
Seducer successfully disguised as washerwoman for fifteen years. Finally exposed.
Man wishes to learn and gains entrance to learned girl's presence in woman's disguise.
Man disguised as woman abducts princess.
Man disguised as woman courted (married) by another man.
Man disguised as woman beguiles hostile chief. Infatuates him and then kills him in drunken sleep.
Men disguised as women enter convent and seduce impious nuns.
Girl masked as man wins princess's love.
The lovely ascetic (girl in man's clothes) wins love of a rich woman.
Man disguised as gardener enters convent and seduces nuns.
Messenger from lover to girl-captive in harem poses as a singer who amuses the harem ladies in their apartments.
Seduction by feigned death. The girl comes to the man's wake or funeral.
Death feigned to woo maiden. She shows remorse when she hears of his death.
Hero feigns death and is copulated with by divine maidens.
Seduction by feigned sleep. The guest in the conjugal bed feigns sleep as he effects seduction.
Seduction by feigned illness.
Seduction by asking for sham cure for sham illness.

Seduction by feigned stupidity. Cautious farmer seeks laborer who knows nothing about sex. Trickster makes silly explanation of copulation of animals. When admitted into service, seduces both farmer's wife and daughter.
Disguise as animal to seduce woman.
Girl tricked into man's room (or power).
No!. "  The princess must answer all questions by "No". By clever framing of his question the hero wins her to his desires.
Seduction by taking aboard ship to inspect wares.
Seduction by scattering jewels. Girl seized when she tries to take jewels.
Seduction by enticing woman to inspect wares in tent.
Seduction by promise of jewels.
Seduction by having maiden placed in floating chest.
Seduction (or wooing) on an aerial journey.
Seduction (or wooing) by stealing clothes of bathing girl (swan maiden).
Magic helper brings girl to hero's bed.
Girl tricked into man's room (power)  miscellaneous.
Fresh hides spread on grass; girl slips up and is deflowered.
Woman enticed to upper world on a stretching tree.
Seduction by luring woman to platform to look for distant ship.
Woman enticed into man's room by feigned illness.
Seduction by sham beauty test. Trickster dupes two girls into submitting to test. Both seduced.
Girl tricked by use of drugs. Subsequent pregnancy used to force her into marrying seducer.
Seduction by priest who insists on woman having confession in his own house.
Trickster agrees to carry old woman and girl across stream: carries girl across and rides off with her leaving old woman on other side.
Leak in roof over woman's bed: in rain must go to bed with trickster.
Entrance into girl's (man's) room (bed) by trick.
Entrance to woman's room in hollow artificial animal.
Entrance to woman's room in golden ram. Princess's curiosity aroused and the golden ram carried into the room. The youth is concealed inside.
Entrance into woman's (man's) room by hiding in chest.
Man carried into woman's room hidden in basket.
Entrance into woman's room in lamp stand.
Heroine in hiding-box which is bought by prince.
Man in magic hiding box bought by girl's father.
Man drawn up into female apartments on rope.
Man drawn up into female apartments in basket.
Man disguised as woman carried into princess's room: marries her.
Tunnel entrance to guarded maiden's chamber.
Girl seduced from beneath ground.

Tale of the cradle. Two youths pass the night with a family where all sleep in a common room, with a cradle at the foot of one of the beds. The moving of the cradle in the night confuses those walking about so that the strangers sleep with the wife and the daughter.
Hero flies to maiden's room. Enters her tower by means of artificial wings (or on flying horse).
Hero flies on magic carpet to maiden's room.
Man is ushered into maiden's room by maidservant. He then takes the latter's place in the mistress's bed.
Lover gets into maiden's room by means of a ladder.
Other means of entering into girl's (man's) room (bed).
Disguise to enter girl's (man's) room.
Lover disguised as porter gains access to princess's room.
Disguise as madman to enter girl's room.
Trickster gains access to woman's room disguised as peddler.
Man disguised as groom enters mistress's room.
Man feigns sick in order to enter room of princess skilled in healing, and woos her for his friend.
Trickster gains access to woman's room by pretending he has news of her absent lover.
Access gained by the aid of rival's mule. Man tries in vain to learn the identity of his friend's mistress. Mounts his friend's mule, which takes him to the secret rendezvous.
Lover visits guarded maiden while harper puts mother to sleep.
Access for seduction gained by removing locks.
Lover gets self carried into beloved's house to wait for clean clothes after a purposeful fall in mud.
Man burns down own neighboring house to gain access to bedroom of beloved.
Entrance into woman's room through concealed door.
Trickster pretends to seek lost ball by woman's bed: seduces her.
Admission to woman's room by means of cap of invisibility.
Woman persuaded (or wooed) by trick.

The weeping bitch. A procuress throws pepper into the eyes of a bitch so that she weeps. She pretends to the virtuous woman that the bitch is a woman transformed because of failure to respond to her lover. The woman is persuaded.
Death feigned to woo maiden. She shows remorse when she hears of lover's death.
Woman deceived into sacrificing honor. Ruler promises to release her brother (husband) but afterward refuses to do so.
Trickster offers food for woman's favors which will completely satisfy him. He refuses payment on grounds that he is not satisfied.
Seduction by bearing false order from husband or father.

Both?. "  The youth is sent to the house to get two articles. He meets the two daughters and calls back to the master. " Both? " "Yes, I said both! " replies the master. The youth has his will of both daughters.
Trickster masking as girl's father advises intercourse with trickster. She obeys.
Seduction by bringing false order from husband.
Trickster asks husband for one thing and the wife for another. The husband's order: "Let him have what he wants.

Trickster friar seduces woman under pretence of administering forgotten sacrament. When the woman objects, the husband who thinks the friar is engaging in a legitimate process, orders: "Bear the ordeal in peace.
Fox sleeps with tiger's wife by giving her deceptive message from her mate.
Seduction by bearing false order from mother.
Friar undertakes to awaken girl. He follows her mother's order according to his own interpretation.
Trickster masking as bridegroom tells bride that he comes at her mother's request.
Seduction by bearing false order from lover.
Altered letter of execution gives princess to hero. On his way robbers steal the letter and change it so that instead of being killed he is married to the princess.
Lover's gift regained. The husband appears before payment can be made to wife.
Girl shows herself naked in return for youth's dancing hogs.
Beggar buys right to sleep before the girl's door, at foot of bed, in the bed. Usually with jewel.
