Transformed person sleeps before girl's door, at foot of bed, in the bed. Is disenchanted upon admission to the bed.
Progressive purchase of favors: the anatomical progression.
Seduction by begging into woman's room to get warm.
Innocent girl sells her "love" and later receives it back. When she tells her mother what has happened, she is beaten. Thinking to right matters, she demands that the knight return what he has taken.
Seduction of person ignorant of sexual intercourse.
Putting the Devil in Hell. Obscene trick used to seduce woman.
Putting the Devil in hand.
Friar adds missing nose (fingers) to unborn child: foetus is imperfect and he will substitute for absent husband. Is praised by the latter on his return.
Woman abducted by giving her medicine which appears to have killed her.
Second daughter won by representing first as dead.
Monk persuades a father to set daughter afloat in box: monk seduces her.
Seduction by making woman jealous of co-wife.
Bride-stealing.
Lover steals bride from wedding with unwelcome suitor.
Parson deceived into marrying his intended bride to her real lover. The parson thinks it is a mock-wedding, but it turns out to be real.
Lover's foster brother (friend) steals bride from wedding with unwelcome suitor.
Father tricked into giving away disguised daughter in marriage.
Rat changes name and wins wife intended for leopard.
Lover in disguise abducts beloved.
Lover masks as king, knight.
Lover masks as minstrel.
Man gets bridegroom drunk and enjoys the bride.
While chief is performing suitor task, rival steals the bride.
Woman engaged to marry by trick.
Princess tricked into engaging herself to suitor rejected by her father.
Fool passed off as very eligible young man by matchmaker.
Seduction by alleged vision promising woman to man.
Seduction of wife by alleging that husband's vision compels him to leave home.
Incestuous marriage arranged by trick.
Seductions miscellaneous.
Trickster pretends lameness and is taken on woman's back: violates her.
Trickster throws corpse into river and accuses princess of murder: marriage to avoid scandal.
Female overpowered when caught in tree cleft (hole in hedge).
Man won over by woman's obscene trick.
Lecherous trickster seduces women from tree and loses them.
Trickster sends letter ordering bearer detained and meanwhile steals bearer's wife.
Husband persuaded to dig up a treasure buried in an ant hill. He is poisoned by a snake and his wife taken.
Long distance sexual intercourse. Trickster by magic has intercourse with woman across stream.
Trickster and girls play obscene tricks on one another.
Woman seduces boy by feigning illness (chill, etc.)  Italian Novella: Rotunda; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 887.
Man coveting his friend's wife causes her to leave her husband. Friend mutually agree to beat wives. Trickster only pretends to do so while other beats his and angers her.
Seduction by giving aphrodisiac. Woman tricked into standing naked in stream; medicine put into water.
Guest at inn is told that there is but one available bed: that of the mistress.
Lucretia seduced through threat. Sextus says he will kill her and leave a naked slave in her bed to bring dishonor on her house. She yields.
The trickster with painted member. The father wants his daughter's child to be a bishop.
Additional seductions.
The taming of the wild prince. Lost in the woods the little prince grows up among wild animals; lets no one come near him. Only a servant girl succeeds in taming him.
The unusual names. Assuming unusual names, the servant deceives the girl, her mother, and her father.
Seduction: trickster shows girl how to store up warmth for winter.
Woman secures man's spear (arrow), lures him with it into her hut.
Teacher seduces pupil left in his charge.
Dupe's property destroyed.
Dupe's goods destroyed.

Plowing the field: horse and harness destroyed. The youth is told to come home from plowing when the dog does. He beats the dog so that it runs home; then he destroys the horse and harness and goes home.
Lighting the road (or painting the house red). The house set on fire.
Guarding the door. It is lifted off and carried away.
Take care of the stopper!. The son puts the stopper into his pocket, and all the tar (beer) runs out.
Repairing the house. House or furniture destroyed.
Tearing up the orchard (vineyard). Rascal has been told to cut wood.
Closing the door tight: with iron nails.
Whetting the knife: the whole blade whetted away.
Clearing land: axe broken.
Threshing grain: granary roof used as threshing flail.
Mowing grass: the meadow torn up.
Clearing out manure: digs hole.
Cleaning out manure: piles it high.
Covering the whole wagon with tar.
Filling the pen. Told to fill locked pen trickster chops up wagon and mules and throws them in.
Sowing grain: does so in unplowed field.
Trickster saws legs of table so that it collapses.
Fixing fences: trickster cuts fence down.
Twisting twine: trickster cuts it.
Dupe's animals destroyed or maimed.
Building a bridge of cattle. Ordered to build a bridge not of wood, stone, iron, or earth, the trickster uses the carcasses of cattle.
Casting eyes: animal's eyes. Ordered to cast eyes on this or that, the trickster kills animals and casts their eyes at the object.
Cleaning the horse. Washing him in boiling water or currying him with a razor.
Horse's intestine fastened to stone. Horse twists intestines out of himself.
Making sheep laugh and dance. Told to bring in sheep laughing and dancing, trickster cuts off their upper lips and breaks their legs.
To drive cattle to jungle: trickster kills a bull every day.
Tying the cattle: trickster ties them so tightly they are strangled.
Watching the goats: "Hit them if they wander. "  Trickster kills them.
Trickster exchanges master's tame horse for vicious bullock.
Members of dupe's family killed.
Caring for the child: child killed.
Cleaning the child. Intestines taken out and cleaned.
Child taken to defecate over ant hole.
Cleaning the children. Impales them.
Washing the grandmother in boiling water.
To heat water for master's bath. Servant pours boiling water on him.
To cover house with straw: suffocates mother under straw.
Trickster deceives dupe into killing his own children.
Blinded slave's revenge. Threatens to jump from tower with lord's children unless lord blinds himself. Lord does so but slave jumps with children nevertheless.
Master's mother killed: wood heaved on her head.
Deception connected with adultery.
Cuckold. Husband deceived by adulterous wife.
Solomon as cuckold.
Cuckold feigns to be asleep when paramour calls.
Adulteress outwits husband.
Adulteress kills home-coming husband.
Wife of philanderer gets revenge by having an affair herself.

The husband locked out. An adulteress returns home late at night and her husband refuses to admit her. She threatens to throw herself into the well. The husband goes after her. She enters the house and bars him out.
Adulteress refuses to admit husband under pretence that he is a stranger.

The cut-off nose. (Lai of the Tresses.) A woman leaves her husband's bed and has another woman take her place. The husband addresses her, gets no answer and cuts off her nose (hair). In the morning the wife still has her nose (hair). The husband is made to believe that it has grown back by a miracle (or that he was dreaming).

Cut-off finger proves wife's chastity. A chaste wife substitutes a maidservant for seducer. A finger and ring are cut off as proof of wife's unfaithfulness (chastity wager with husband). Refuted by husband, who knows they are not his wife's.

The wife's equivocal oath. A husband insists that his wife take oath that she has been intimate with no one but himself. The paramour masks as ass-driver. She hires an ass from him, falls down, and lets him pick her up. She then swears that no one has touched her except her husband and the ass-driver.
Adulteress gets rid of husband while she entertains lover.
The husband in the chicken house. The husband returns unexpectedly and surprises his wife with her lover. She makes the husband believe he is pursued and hides him in the chicken house.
Husband duped into doing penance while rascal enjoys the wife.
Husband duped into believing he is in purgatory.
Returning husband beaten by servants. Mistaken for lover whom he has told them to beat.
Husband beaten by paramour. Husband, dressed in wife's clothing, is beaten by forewarned paramour. The latter says that he is testing the wife's fidelity to her husband.
Husband hides in curtain to catch paramour. On entering, paramour threatens to kill husband if he should appear.
Cuckold husband hides under bed.
Husband hides in chest to catch paramour.
Adulteress locks up hidden husband and meets lovers.
Wife has hiding husband carried off in basket by thieves.
Wife throws husband down precipice so she can be with lover.
Adulteress has lover unload wood on doorstep. This keeps husband out.
Adulteress sets husband to watch for intruder while she entertains the paramour.
Illness feigned to call physician paramour.
Adulteress pretends to go to say her prayers. Keeps tryst with paramour.
Adulteress gives paramour tryst in house of ill-fame. Meets husband who leaves in shame.
Paramour unties mare. Husband chases mare while the wife entertains the paramour.
Adulteress throws small coffer out of window. While the husband retrieves it the paramour changes hiding places.
Lover masks as pregnant woman: adulteress sent by husband to act as midwife, meets lover.
Adulteress together with lover while husband sleeps.
Wife drugs husband and visits paramour.
Husband frightened into sleeping alone. Adulteress has servants impersonate demons.
Adulteress makes excuse to go and attend to bodily needs: meets lover.

The animal in the chest. The husband has locked the surprised paramour in a chest while he fetches his family as witness of his wife's unfaithfulness. She frees the lover, substitutes an animal, and discountenances the husband.
The husband's good eye covered. The wife holds a cloth in front of his one good eye, so that he cannot see the paramour.
Adulteress binds husband's eyes and causes him to sing incantations concerning the adultery.
The husband's good eye treated. The wife pretends to treat his one good eye, so that he cannot see the paramour.
Physician treating man's eye covers his one good eye. Entertains his patient's mistress.
Girl covers nurse's one good eye so that she cannot see her lover.
Adulteress extinguishes light to hide her paramour.
Adulteress covers husband's eyes during incantation. Meanwhile paramour escapes.
Adulteress persuades husband to milk cow with his eyes blindfolded: meets lover.
The faithless wife asks her gullible husband how he would act if he were blind. The husband closes his eyes; meanwhile the lover escapes.
Wife washes husband's hair hiding his eyes while lover escapes unseen.
Wife has husband look for hole in pot she has bought, allowing lover to escape unseen.
Wife shows husband her milk-filled breasts and squirts milk in his eyes allowing lover to escape unseen.
Paramour escapes by disguise.

The lovers as pursuer and fugitive. The wife is visited by two gallants. When the husband approaches, one goes out with drawn sword; the other hides in the house. She convinces her husband that she has given refuge to a fugitive.

One lover disguised and carried out of house by other. The wife has the lover put on a robe and stand in the corner; she tells the husband that a tradesman has left the robe and will return for it. The other lover comes and she gives him the "robe".
Paramour poses as doctor.
Paramour in vat: disguise as vat-buyer. Husband thinks he is testing the vat.
Lover hidden in chest with feathers. Husband believes he is a devil.
Paramour falls in cesspool. Husband thinks he is a demon.
Paramour poses as unsuccessful suitor. When surprised with the wife he tells the husband that he has been trying to force the woman, with no success. The wife supports the statement.
Paramour escapes disguised as monk.
Paramour disguised as pregnant woman.
Paramour poses as robber.
Paramour disguised as cloth merchant is surprised by the husband. He asks the woman to be paid for a pretended sale.
Paramour leaving love-tryst is met by husband. Pretends he had come to see him on business.
Paramour escapes by pretending to be returning borrowed basket.
Escaping paramour said to be a deity.
The enchanted pear tree. The wife makes the husband, who has seen the adultery from the tree, believe that the tree is magic or that he has seen double.
Husband who has surprised wife and paramour is made to believe that he has had an illusion.
Paramour successfully hidden from husband.
Paramour successfully hidden in chimney (fireplace).
Paramour successfully hidden in chest.
Paramour placed in chest and covered with clothing.
Paramour hidden under the wash.
Paramour hidden in the bed.
Wife hides lover under bed. When husband comes in she drops candle and sends him out for another, allowing lover to escape unseen.
Paramour hidden behind a screen.
Lover escapes behind the sheet which wife holds up to show her husband.
Husband busied with performing task while paramour escapes.
Paramour rolled into a carpet.
Husband in hanging tub to escape coming flood. The priest who has thus duped the husband enjoys the wife.
Underground passage to paramour's house. (Inclusa.) Woman goes from one to the other. Her husband is made to believe that the woman next door is her sister.
Adulteress falls in mud at lover's door. She deceives her husband by saying that she must enter and clean her dress.

The Lord above; the lord below. A husband returning home surprises a woman and her paramour and a numskull who has blundered in. The woman hides the numskull in the bed and the paramour under it. The husband, who is leaving on a journey, lifts his hands to heaven and says, "I commend you to the Lord above. "   The numskull: "Commend her rather to the lord below!
Friar's trousers on adulteress's bed: relic to cure sickness. The husband is duped into believing that the friar has come to visit the sick.
The feigned wedding-feast. The husband returns unexpectedly to find his wife entertaining the paramour with a sumptuous feast. He is made to believe the feast is in honor of some newly-weds.
Wife confesses to disguised husband. She suspects the fraud and persuades him that she knew the ruse and was testing him. He begs forgiveness.
Husband transformed to goat must witness wife's adultery. The devil has let him see his wife's unfaithfulness in this way.
Gullible husband under the bed.
Adulteress tells her lover how she loves her husband. She thus deceives the spying husband under the bed.

Adulteress tells how she may save her husband's life. Discovering him under the bed, she tells lover that at temple she has learned that her husband is to die soon unless she prevents death by sleeping with a strange man. The husband is satisfied.

Gullible husband behind the tree. (Tristan and Isolt.) Husband goes to wife's love tryst and hides behind a tree. The wife, having learned of his presence, tells lover that he should not allow their innocent relations to lead to gossip. Husband is appeased.
Adulteress transforms her husband into an animal to get rid of him. (The Tsar's Dog.)
Adulteress transforms man to stone up to the waist.
Woman has husband made monk while he is drunk, so as to get rid of him.
Death feigned to meet paramour. Meetings in the grave (grave box).
Wife feigns death and slips out to lover.
Death feigned so man can live with mistress.

Sexton's own wife brings her offering. The priest grants to the sexton the offerings brought by all women whom the priest has loved. The priest always calls out "Take" when these women offer. The sexton's own wife comes. The priest calls out "Take!

Husband frightened by wife's paramour in hog pen. The husband sees the paramour who has hidden in the pen and says, "Who are you? " "I am a miserable hog. " The husband thinks that his hogs are possessed.

The marked coat in the wife's room. A procuress obtains a woman for her client by leaving a marked coat in her room. The husband drives the wife away and she joins her lover. The procuress then goes to the husband and alleges that she lost a coat with certain marks. The husband is deceived and takes the wife back.
Husband unwittingly instrumental in wife's adultery. (Usually shares his bedmate with others, not knowing that she is his wife.)
Husband rescues wife's paramour. Not knowing lover's identity, husband takes him to his wife and entrusts him to her care. He then leaves on a trip.
Wives wager as to who can best fool her husband.
Woman warns lover of husband by parody incantation.
Woman warns lover of husband by singing song.
Woman encourages paramour by song.
Adulteress makes believe that her suspicious husband is insane. He is taken away.
Adulteress outwits husband miscellaneous motifs.
Woman has paramour steal her husband's clothes. Paramour gains entrance disguised as the husband. The husband without his clothes is driven away from his home.
Wife surprised in adultery feigns death. Comes "back to life" on hearing husband say he has seen nothing.
Lover carried away on mistress's shoulders so that his footprints will not be visible in the snow.
Lover leaves horse outside house as husband comes up: wife tells husband their cow has foaled a horse.
Unfaithful wife communicates with lover by pouring milk into stream.
Wife's attendants on trip chase wrong man as suspected lover and miss real lover.
Husband deceived as to noise made by hidden paramour.
Woman cooks food for paramour.
Adulteress detected by food she prepares for paramour.
Husband outwits adulteress and paramour.
Husband discovers wife's adultery.
Adulteress detected: husband secretly drops dye on her dress.
Adulteress detected by food she prepares for paramour.
Husband returns home secretly and spies on adulteress and lovers.
Husband returns secretly and kills unwelcome suitor.
Husband feigns blindness and avenges himself on his wife and her paramour.
Husband feigns illness to surprise wife with paramour.
The husband sets house afire and ousts hidden paramour.
Trickster sets fire to barrel of tow in which paramour is hidden. The paramour, naked, runs out carrying wisps of burning tow. The trickster tells the husband that he has raised the devil.
Husband carries off box containing hidden paramour. Latter exposed (otherwise discomfited).
Dying woman lures paramour into chest. Asks husband to bury chest with her.
Chest containing paramour unwittingly taken away by husband.
Lover hidden in hen-coop discovered by husband.
The devil in the barrel. The naked lover hides himself in a sooty barrel. The husband receives from a curious gentleman a good sum of money for showing him the "devil".
Old Hildebrand. Hidden cuckold reveals his presence by rhymes. He responds to the rhymes made by the wife and paramour concerning their entertainment.
Adulteress binds husband's eyes and causes him to sing incantations concerning the adultery.
Husband discovers wife's adultery by riddling conversation. In this indirect manner the wife confesses and promises reform.
Husband discovers paramour's love letter in his wife's purse after having made her drunk.
The husband prepares to castrate the crucifix. The artist's wife's paramour poses as a crucifix when caught. When he sees the husband's preparations, he flees naked.
Husband castrates paramour.
The husband meets the paramour in the wife's place. Beats him (or cuts off privates).
Husband hides in wife's room and kills paramour.
Husband catches paramour in pitfall. The wife sends her maid to investigate. The maid falls in and finally the wife herself. The husband calls the neighborhood to see them.
Husband (god) traps wife and paramour with magic armor. (Vulcan, Mars, Venus.)
Husband proves intrigue by secretly blacking paramour's mouth. When he returns, his wife's face is black.
Blades (broken glass) to wound and detect wife's lover. (Often on window.)
Cuckolded man shuts wife's paramour in chest and lies on the chest with latter's wife.
Cuckold unwittingly lies with wife on chest containing her hidden paramour.
Husband tricks wife into riding a mule which has been denied water. On fording a stream the mule plunges into the water. Wife drowns.
Husband in disguise begs food of his wife's suitors.
Husband outwits wife and paramour miscellaneous motifs.
Husband collects fee from paramour. Surprised paramour pays.
Husband surprises wife and paramour. Rebukes them for not shutting the door.
Illness feigned to go to mistress. Husband leaves bed to go to serving maid.
Husband takes place of paramour. Beats or otherwise discomfits wife.
Husband catches paramour by using wife's pre-arranged signal.
Husband persuades wife to light wicks and carry knife in hand before committing adultery: lovers frightened away.
Alleged speaking privates. Husband pretends that his wife's privates tell him of her adultery.
Husband discomfits paramour and wife by clever remark showing that he knows all.
Husband kills surprised paramour. Wife persuades him he has killed thief.
Trickster outwits adulteress and paramour.
Trickster discovers adultery: food goes to husband instead of paramour.
Trickster discovers adultery: gets food prepared for paramour.
Trickster as sham magician makes adulteress produce hidden food for her husband.
Trickster makes woman believe that her husband is coming to punish her adultery. She confesses.
Trickster sends his master running after the paramour. Though the master does not know of the adultery, the lover is thoroughly frightened.
Trickster as sham magician buys chest containing hidden paramour.
Sham magician has paramour fall in a trap. Has trained bird to cling to him.
Trickster discovers woman's paramour and hides him in outhouse: rewarded by husband.
Second lover burns paramour at window with hot iron.
God Vishnu in shape of nephew scares and torments his aunt's lover.
Other deceits connected with adultery.
The lover's gift regained.

Lover's gift regained: the broken (removed) article. The lover breaks (or removes) an article of household equipment and convinces the husband that for that reason the wife has confiscated that which he gave her as a present.
Lover's gift regained: horse and wagon as gift. The lover regains gift of horse and wagon by pretending to the husband that the wife has confiscated them because he brought wood of uneven quality.

Lover's gift regained: borrowing from the husband and returning to the wife. The lover borrows money from the husband with which to corrupt the wife, later telling the husband that the money was returned to the wife during the husband's absence.

Lover's gift regained: accidental discovery of identity. The lover, ignorant of the identity of the husband, tells him of his experience with the wife. The husband persuades the lover to lead him to the scene, where the wife is compelled to restore all but a small part of the money.
Lover's gift regained: piece of cloth as gift. The lover regains by a ruse and thievery the borrowed piece of cloth which he has presented to his mistress.
Lover claims payment for cloth in the presence of the husband. The woman returns the cloth but puts a live coal in it. Destroys his whole supply.
Lover demands return of cloth on threat to await the husband's return.
Lover's gift regained: jewelry as gift. The lover presents the wife with a valuable piece of jewelry, which he regains by pretending to the husband that he has left it as a pledge.
Lover's gift regained: anser venalis (goose as gift). The lover regains his gift by a ruse (obscene).
Lover delays the gift of the goose hoping to obtain greater favors. Finally has to flee.
Lover's gift regained: refusal to leave bed. Woman fearing exposure returns money.
Lover's gift regained: spending money to purchase lover's worthless goods.
Lover's gift regained: payment with worthless money. Lover bargains with the husband. Pays him with worthless money.
Prostitute paid with counterfeit money.
Husband gets gift which paramour has given to wife.
Lover blackmails adulteress.
After seducing priest's wife, peasant demands earrings as price of silence. He thus avenges himself on priest who has cheated peasant's wife of her earrings.
Husband duped by paramour into taking his wife to him. She is veiled.
Innocent confessor duped into being go-between for adulteress and lover. By following suggestions in her false accusations to confessor the lover reaches her side.

Wife takes servant's place and discovers husband's adultery. The husband says that he is going into a state of meditation with a cloth over his face. He substitutes a servant and goes to his mistress. The wife finds the deceit and takes the servant's place. On his return the husband tells the supposed servant of his adultery.
Paramour feigns loss of genitals in order to obtain the husband's confidence.
Adulteress uses the public baths as a meeting-place with her lover. A naive remark by her child exposes the deception to the husband.
Woman excites peasant (secretary), who draws line on floor and dares her to cross it. When she does, adultery is committed.
Seventy tales of a parrot prevent a wife's adultery. The parrot keeps her interested until her husband's return.
Faithless wife kills magic parrot which has betrayed her.
Peacock left as spy on adulterous wife.
Dog guards chastity of master's wife during his absence.
Paramour sends prostitutes in disguise to take mistress to "convent". Husband is deceived by the ruse.
Adulteress disguised as boy elopes with paramour.
Student extends his course so as to enjoy the professor's wife.
The "loyal" adulteress. Complacent in all except kissing. Explains that her mouth is the only part of her body which has promised fidelity to her husband.
Faithful wife in disguise saves husband from punishment for adultery.
Deceiver falls into own trap.
Deceiver falls into his own trap (literally). Arranges a trap or pitfall but is himself caught.
Pitfall arranged but victim escapes it.

Man falls into sacrificial grave prepared for others. Rich man orders poor people to dig a grave in order to bury all in it as sacrifice to avert famine. But a Christian frees them and promises those who become Christian a living. The rich man himself falls in the grave and dies.
Thief-catcher caught by his own magic club.
Deceiver falls into his own trap miscellaneous incidents.
Substituted caps cause ogre to kill his own children. The hero and heroine change places in bed with the ogre's children and put on them their caps so that the ogre is deceived.
Substituted string causes ogre to be killed. Intended victim of cannibal is marked by thread around ankle. Changed in night to host.
Guest to be killed suspects plot and forces host to sleep in his bed. Brothers come home and kill their father.
Girl takes place of impostor in marriage bed; impostor's mother beats her, thinking she is heroine.
Noose changed so that ogre's daughter is dragged to death.
Kid puts one of tigress's cubs in his place: she eats the cub.

Message of death fatal to sender. (Gang nach dem Eisenhammer.) A man is sent by the king to burners of a kiln who have been instructed to throw the first arrival into the fire. The intended victim goes elsewhere and the king's son (or the man's accuser), who next arrives, is burned instead.
Person sends wrong man to sleep with king's daughter. In revenge villain orders whoever first enters temple to be killed. Villain accidentally enters and is slain.
Shoot any thief who comes. "  King unwittingly shot.
Poisoner poisoned with his own poison.
Would-be poisoner forced to drink poisoned cup.
Person trying to blow poison on another is himself poisoned.
Wife poisons husband who in turn poisons her. Before he dies he forces her to drink from the same cup.
Person gives his wife a poisoned drink; she pours the two drinks together. They both die.
Poisoner's own son takes the beverage intended for step-brother.
Son who intends to poison father drinks the poison by mistake.
Snake killed by incantation he has taught clever woman.
Father delivering daughter to be eaten by cannibal is himself eaten.
Ogre's own moccasins burned. The ogre plans to burn the hero's moccasins while they are camping together, but the hero exchanges the moccasins.
Marooned man reaches home and outwits marooner.
Marooned egg-gatherer. The father-in-law has the youth hunt eggs on an island and deserts him, but the youth outwits him.
Marooned man hides himself in ogre's clothes and outwits him.
Substituted arrows. Hero given arrows with soft points and sent after dangerous enemies. The deception discovered and the enemy discomfited.
Deceiver in swinging contest killed. Old woman planning to kill hero in swinging game by cutting rope is killed when hero cuts the rope first.
Tiger in sheep's clothing stolen by sheep-thief.
Thief climbing rope discovered and rope cut. He has tricked the guardian of the food-supply in the tree (by imitation of the owner's voice or the discovered pass-word) to let down the rope.

Lawyer agrees to pay debt on winning his first case. He refuses to plead so as not to pay. Debtor sues him for double the amount due him. If he wins he has to pay and if he loses he has to pay double. He settles debt.
Woman who engages false bridegroom for her daughter has plans go astray. Daughter is seduced.
Monkey instead of girl in floating basket: hermit made laughing-stock. He has persuaded girl's foolish father to place her in the basket. Prince takes girl and leaves monkey in her place.
Would-be killers killed.
Earl killed in combat with man he has undertaken to kill.
Treacherous counselor killed in treacherous ballgame he himself has arranged.
Boiling water meant for cooking hero used for man who has prepared it.
Sons have servant impersonate dead father and falsify his will. Servant deceives them by favoring himself.

The bribed boy sings the wrong song. The sexton steals the priest's cow. The next day the sexton's son sings, "My father stole the priest's cow. " The priest pays the boy to sing the song in church. But the sexton teaches the boy a new song, "The priest has lain with my mother," and this is sung in church.
Fox leads ass to lion's den but is himself eaten. When he gets there the ass kicks him so that he falls on the lion's bed.
Cock's advice proves disastrous to himself. He causes the ox and the ass to rebel but the master learns the cause of the trouble and kills him.

Partnership of Honesty and Fraud: Fraud loses. Fraud has cheated his partner, Honesty. They hire a housekeeper. Fraud is to have use of her right side, Honesty of her left. The left side is of little use. Fraud falls in love with her and pays Honesty double all his losses to relinquish his rights.
Maids must rise even earlier. They have killed the cock for waking them too early, but their mistress punishes them.
Flattering foreman tricked by his master. He always answers his master's remarks, "I have thought of the same thing too. " He falls into the trap when his master says, "I am going to sow salt.
Ambushed trickster killed by intended victim.
Husband intending to push wife down mountain is pushed over by her.
Mole as trickster killed in his own tunnel. He tricks the fox by going through the tunnel and eating the common food, but the fox sees the molehill and kills him.
Animal strangled by victim which he tries to eat.
Woman ordered to strip has lover turn his back; pushes him into water (pit).
Woman bitten by own fierce watchdog.

Woman who tries to push husband into river falls in when he steps aside. She drowns because she has tied his hands and he is unable to aid her. (She also thinks he is blind because she has fed him rich food to induce blindness.)
The lawyer's mad client. (Pathelin.) On the advice of a lawyer, the client feigns insanity when arraigned in court. When the fee is demanded, he still feigns insanity.
No argument good without a witness. "  Lawyer's client therefore refuses payment of fee.

Sham dumb man wins suit. The trickster meets a man in a narrow place in the road and calls out to him to make room. The man refuses and the trickster turns over the cart. In court the trickster plays dumb. The plaintiff says, "He is not dumb; he called out to me several times to get out of the way. " Damages are assessed against the plaintiff for negligence.
Unjust official outwitted by peasant who quarrels with him and thus turns the attention of the ruler to the abuses.
The order for six loads of snow. The order is given by the king in winter. The courtier waits until summer to present the order. Gets money as substitute.

Spying parent jolted in basket. A lover is let down into a girl's room at night in a basket. The spying parent stumbles into the basket and is jolted about by the lover's confederate. The parent thinks the devil has got him and leaves the lovers in peace.
Trickster eats his own dog. Trickster sells dog for mutton or for opossum. He later eats the dog which has been given to a friend of his by the purchaser.

Unjust banker deceived into delivering deposits by making him expect even larger. In order to make the impression of honesty he delivers the one chest of money. The ten chests which he then receives are filled with stones.
Blind man gets back his stolen treasure by making thief expect a larger one.
Retrieving the buried treasure. Buried money is stolen. Blind owner pretends that he is going to bury more. Thief returns the money hoping to get all. Blind man recovers original treasure.
Blind man asks thief to invest a larger sum for him. The greedy thief puts back the stolen money hoping to get more. The blind man recovers his money.
Dwarf himself falls in love with girl he has seduced by magic love, and loses her as he is forced to remove his magic.
Sage's advice followed: he is killed so that sacrifice can be mixed with his blood.
Bear (tiger) substituted for woman in floating box;  kills villain who tries to steal the woman.
Swindlers allowed to hide money: proves to be basket of stones.
Pretended sick man aroused by beating.
Woman, who pretends to faint, comes to life when beaten by magician in order to drive out alleged evil spirit.

Magician challenged to make good his false claim. Says he can take black and white dogs and make them gray and then reverse process. Trickster furnishes gray dog and challenges magician to show his power.
Originator of death first sufferer. After the culture hero has instituted death, his own child dies and he repents in vain.
Inventor of death machine is first to use it.
Disguised trickster beaten by man he is trying to frighten. Disguise as ghost.

Big 'Fraid and Little 'Fraid. "  Man decides to frighten another (or his son or servant). He dresses in a sheet; his pet monkey puts on a sheet and follows him. The person who is doing the scaring hears the victim say, "Run Big Fraid, run; Little Fraid'll get you. " The scarer sees the monkey in the sheet, runs home.
Tables turned on procuress by chaste wife. The old woman is enticed into the wife's room, beaten, and driven forth naked.
Seller of pardons robbed by man whom he has pardoned beforehand. The defence declared good by the judge.
The treasure-finders who murder one another. Two (three) men find a treasure. One of them secretly puts poison in the other's wine, but the other kills him, drinks the wine and dies.
Tail sticking from ground betrays killing of calf. So arranged by servant in revenge on his master.
The easier job. Men exchange jobs because each is made to believe that the other's is easier. It is not.
The woman as cuckoo on the tree shot down. The anger bargain is to cease when the cuckoo crows. The ogre's wife climbs the tree and imitates the cuckoo. She is shot down.
A man in place of a cuckoo. A cruel master commands his serf to climb a tree and imitate the cry of the cuckoo; he shoots the "cuckoo.
Woman killed. Disliking early rising, the servant kills devil's mother or grandmother, who crows in place of the cock.

Teacher instructs pupil in the art of love: cuckolded. Student, ignoring woman's identity, seduces the teacher's wife, and reports success to him. The teacher makes futile attempts to surprise wife with pupil.
Trickster's eggs become an omelet. Tries to avoid paying tax by hiding eggs in his breeches. The collectors make him sit down.
Trickster makes believe he has found a purse (which he had filled with lead). Merchant claims it and pays ten crowns for it. Trickster wins ensuing suit.
Deception through bluffing.
Ogre (large animal) overawed.
Ogre made to believe small hero is large: overawed.
Tiger made to believe porcupine bristle is his enemy's hair: overawed.
Boys threaten to harness tiger. They have jumped on him from behind and he cannot see. He buys them off.
Weak animal (man) makes large one (ogre) believe that he has eaten many of the large one's companions. The latter is frightened.
Weak animal shows strong his own reflection and frightens him. Tells him that this animal is threatening to kill him. (Usually hare and lion.)
Weak animal shows strong his own reflection and makes him believe that it is the head of the last animal slain by the weak.
Man shows ghost its own reflection and frightens it.
Man shows demon reflection and frightens him.
Bluff: only one tiger; you promised ten. Child (or shepherd) calls out to the small hero (ape, hare) and makes the tiger (ogre) think that he is lucky to escape alive.
The wolf flees from the wolf-head. The sheep have found a sack and a wolf-head. They make the wolf believe that they have killed a wolf, and he flees in terror.
Enemies frightened away by making them think they will be eaten.
Spirits frightened away by making them think they will be eaten.
Leopard frightened away by report of lizard's presence. Lizard has bitten leopard before.
Trickster pretends to hunt certain tree with which his ancestors have killed tigers. Tiger frightened away.
Bluff: small (lame) hero makes demon believe he is a god and threatens to eat him. Demon terrorized.
Bluff: hero to brother, "You take one and I can manage the rest.
Trickster purports to be deity's messenger to procure demon-skins for his drum. Demons bribe him instead of devouring him.
Ass claims to have killed cow: frightens tiger.
Lion frightened away by stabbing at it from inside iron cage.
Large animal frightened by smaller showing him well rope (for his tail), curds (for spit), winnowing fans (for ears).
Tiger made to believe that his captor has eaten many crabs. Tiger fears crabs and releases him.
Fox overawes lion cubs by his boasting and eats their food.
Hare as ambassador of the moon. Hare claiming to be ambassador of moon shows elephant the moon irritated in a spring. Elephant is persuaded that the moon is angry.
Big shoes in front of the barn. Man makes giant shoes and places them so that ogre thinks a giant lives there.
Ogre overawed by hero's boasts about marvelous relatives.
Bluff: thunder said to be the rolling of hero's brother's wagon. Ogre overawed.
Bluff: millstones said to be pearls of hero's mother. Ogre overawed.
Bluff: huge cauldron of tar said to be kitchen-pot of hero's mother.
Bluff: harrow said to be comb of hero's mother.
Bluff: plow said to be hoe of hero's mother.
Hero proves himself a cannibal by trick vomit-exchange.
Hero frightens dog into giving up eating men by pretending to eat own entrails.
Ant-eater deceives jaguar by excrement-exchange.
Monkey pretends that his house always answers him.
Goat pretends to be chewing rock. Frightens wolf.
St. George's Dogs"  (wolves). The man says, "St. George's dogs are coming! " The ogre flees.
Dogs are chasing you," says ox to jackal. Really water gurgling in the ox's stomach.
Tiger thinks sound of water dropping is sound of dreadful monster: flees.
Giantess frightened of leaving cave because of hero's statue in entrance.
Tiger frightened at hearing unknown wind.

The bear trainer and his bear. (Schrdtel und Wasserbdr.) Ogre is driven out by hero's bear. The next year the ogre asks, "Is the big cat still living? " Hero says that it now has many kittens. Ogre is overawed.

Wages: as much as he can carry. To get rid of the boy the troll offers him as large wages as he is able to carry. Boy says that this will be too much, that he will be contented merely with what the troll can carry.
Ogre made to believe hero has withstood fire. Hero escapes and after the room he has been in is burned he returns and is found sitting in the ashes. " It was a bit hot," he says.
Giant persuaded that hero has pushed hole in wall with bare hand. Hole bored before.
Dog pretends to be calling dog in the moon when he barks.
Troll bluffed away from christening. He is invited but told that guests will include the Virgin Mary, Thor the Thunderer, etc. He stays away but sends the finest present.
Bluff: hero professes to be able to perform much larger task than that assigned.
Felling the whole forest. Told to bring in a tree, the hero asks, "Why not the whole forest? " The ogre is frightened.
Bluff: told to bring home a tree, hero prepares to bring home six.
A thousand at one shot. Told to shoot one or two wild boars, hero asks, "Why not a thousand at one shot? " The ogre is frightened.
Bluff: told to bring home an ox, hero prepares to bring home ten.
Bringing the whole well. Told to get water, hero demands bucket large enough to bring in the whole well. The ogre is frightened.
Bluff: told to bring water in an ox skin, hero prepares to dig a canal.
Wrestler claims to be able even to carry away a mountain.
Hero threatens to pull the lake together with a rope. The ogre is intimidated.
Hero threatens to haul away the warehouse with a rope. The ogre is intimidated.
Trickster threatens to throw weight into a cloud: ogre intimidated.
Ogre terrified by woman's legs. He has formerly been caught in a vise. On his approach, the man's wife stands on her head and ogre thinks her legs are a vise. He flees.

Bear frightened away by man threatening to cleave its skull with his penis. He meets a woman who, upon being told what man had threatened, shows him a vestige of the cleaving she once got. Only partly healed.
Ogre terrified by an iron man. In order to save the king's daughter from the ogre an iron man is forged.
Other bluffs.
Bluff: provisions for the swimming match. In a swimming match from a ship the hero takes a knapsack of provisions on his back. His rival is afraid and gives up.
Bluff: climbing the mast. In a contest in climbing the mast the hero falls into the rigging. " You do the same thing," he challenges. The sailors are persuaded of his expertness.
Bluff in court: the stone in the purse. A poor man has a stone in his purse to throw at the judge if he is sentenced. The judge thinks that he has money to use as a bribe and acquits him.
Trickster's boasting scares his powerful opponent from contest.
False boasting of having killed his foster-brother makes his men follow the boaster.
Goat singing a threatening song bought off with food and jewels.
Bluffing threat.
Sham threat: "In earnest or in jest?. " A man asks another who has brushed against him: "Did you do that in earnest or in jest? " "In earnest. "  "I am glad, for I don't like that kind of jesting.
Sham threat: either .

Sham threat: something he has never done before. Beggar says, "If you do not give me alms I shall have to do something I have never done before. " The alms are given and he is asked what he would have had to do. " Work.
Sham threat: the faked duel. Two who had challenged each other agree to hold a sham duel.
Sham threat: if I were not a philosopher I should break your head for you.
Girl's sham threat in order to evade husband till lover returns.
Sham threat of war holds ships back so that there suddenly are enough men to man defending ship.
Sham dream prophesying shipwreck makes people leave ship so that there is room enough for man who wants to go.
King menaced into giving his daughter by means of borrowed fleet.
Pretended anger.
King persuades men to follow him, pretending that he is going to make peace with his brothers, instead battle.
Bluff: insult repeated as harmless remark. The trickster makes an insulting remark, but when called on to repeat what he said he changes it so as to turn aside wrath.
Boast where the master cannot hear. The servant boasts that he has scolded his master.
When he is looked at too threateningly hero feigns failing ability to go on horseback.
Threat to build a church in hell. When the man makes this threat, he is let out of hell.

Bluff: wealth gained by seeming to be in the king's confidence. Courtier asks the king for a reward that will cost nothing. He gets permission to listen to the king's devotions. He now receives bribes because of his apparent influence.
Shoemaker offers to trim the peasant's feet to fit the shoes. The peasant prefers to accept the ill-fitting shoes.

Herdsman threatens invasion with enormous herds: bought off. He hires himself as herdsman of all his master's flocks for ten years. He then sends notice to surrounding peoples that he is coming with his master's flocks to graze. They bribe him to stay away.
Trickster falsely reports impending invasion from his own people. Receives money to buy them off.

Adventurer on otherworld island sees great hornless oxen guarded by giant: tries to frighten them.  ". Why dost thou frighten the stilly calves? " says the huge herdsman. " Where are the dams of these calves? " asks the adventurer. " They are on the other side of yonder mountain," said he. So he went thence.
Miracle must wait till one man is sacrificed. No one volunteers and it does not need to be performed.
Bluff: the rare vintages. Host serves many rare vintages and gets a reputation for his wine cellar. But there is only a small jug of each vintage.
Man falsely claims to have killed elephant with his flat hand. Rewarded.
Fox threatens to catch bird, who feeds him her young as appeasement. He threatens to push down tree or to fly.
Sham duel in order to bring about recognition.
Feigned ignorance about person's identity in order to tell one's frank opinion of him.
Feigned ignorance of person's identity in order not to reveal king.
Feigned ignorance about the whereabouts of hero's weapons and horse in order to keep him as monk.
Illiterate man pretends to be weeping because he cannot make others understand the book he is reading.
Woman frightens robber away by telling him parrot's cry is husband's voice.
Deception by disguise or illusion.
Deception by disguise.
Disguise by putting on clothes (carrying accoutrements) of certain person.
Fool wears king's crown.
Lover disguised in slain enemy's clothes.
Taking king's place by changing dresses.
Dog procures disguise from magician to frighten tiger.
Lover disguised as other knight in order to reach sweetheart.
Gods (saints) in disguise visit mortals.
Mortal entertained by disguised god.
Goddess in disguise visits earth and is waylaid by thieves. They set her free after she promises to tell them the fate of the new-born prince.
Gods (spirits) disguised as beggars. Test hospitality.
Deity disguised as old man (woman) visits mortals.
God disguised as doctor cures mortal.
Deity takes form of particular person to visit mortals.
Fate takes form of Brahmin's pupil in order to lure him to his prophesied death.
Angel takes form of certain person.
Deity takes form of animal to visit mortals.
King in disguise.
King disguised beaten by his own men.
Incognito king helped by humble man. Gives reward.
Incognito king is asked by humble man to aid him.
Incognito king joins robbers.
Incognito king joins robbers: to take only six shillings. The robber tells him that he must take no more, since the king has so many robbers.
Incognito prince joins gamblers. He is beaten for showing courtesy. Realizes his folly and returns home.
Prince disguises as another prince to woo princess.
Incognito king is given hospitality by fisherman. Rewards him with a city.
Incognito king in victor's court. Asks forgiveness.
Ruler disguises as goblin to frighten uxorious priest.
King disguises as common soldier and is killed. Fulfills prophecy that insures victory.
Incognito queen (princess).
Queen flees husband's persecution disguised as knight.
Incognito princess travels as bishop (monk).
Disguised queen visits her husband and begets child with him as assigned.
Incognito king rewards farmer for gift.
King disguised as peasant flees battle.
Incognito prince (king) sold into slavery. Disguised as sailor.
Incognito king comes to the aid of an enemy who has refused to vilify him.
Incognito king rewards strangers who treat him as companion.
Lecherous prince disguises as merchant in order to kill his grand-children.
King in disguise of merchant is given hospitality by enemy.
King disguised as own messenger.
King disguised as mountaineer.
King in disguise to spy out his kingdom.
Fallen king in disguise recognized by former ally and helped.
King in disguise as one of his own men rescued in fighting alone against four.
Count in disguise.
Disguised husband visits his wife.
Disguised husband wins his faithless wife's love.
Disguised husband shows his wife that he is not repulsive, as she thinks him.
Disguised husband shows his wife that he is not a good-for-nothing as she thinks him.
Disguised husband spies on his faithless wife.
Woman in disguise wooed by her faithless husband.
Prince disguised as merchant seduces a queen.
Wife substitutes for princess, who has been jailed with husband. Before judge says: "What harm is there in a man being with his own wife?
Wife disguised as fakir makes her husband, the king, fulfill her will.
Husband twits wife regarding "bought kiss"; she makes him buy one from her by disguising herself.
Humble disguise. (Cap o' Rushes, Peau d'vne Allerleirauh.) Usually in rough clothing.
Disguise with hood dropping low over the face.
Return home in humble disguise.
Pious pilgrim dies unknown in his father's house. (Miraculous manifestations.)
Ugly disguise.
Disguise as menial.
God disguised as menial.
Girl in menial disguise at lover's court.
Menial disguise of princess's lover.
Hero in menial disguise at heroine's wedding.
Scholar disguised as a rustic along road answers questions of school inspector in Greek, Latin, and Hebrew.
Gardener disguise.
Pope disguised as caulker.
Disguise as woodcutter.
Disguise as potter.
Disguise as goose-girl (turkey-girl).
Disguise as tender of birds.
Disguise as herdsman (shepherd, swineherd, etc.)  DeVries FFC LXXIII 324; Schoepperle II 583 s.v. "disguises"; Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: Boberg.
Disguise as porter.
Disguise as stable-boy.
Disguise as peasant.
Wise men disguise as peasants.
Disguise as cobbler (shoemaker).
Nobleman disguises as cobbler to woo woodcutter's daughter.
Disguise as carpenter.
Disguise as smith.
Disguise as slave.
Disguise as wanderer.
Disguise as beggar (pauper).
Disguise as fakir.
Disguise as palmer (pilgrim).
Disguise as harper (minstrel).
Disguise as poet.
Disguise as merchant.
Disguise as peddler.
Queen disguised as peddler.
Queen disguised as peddler sells children poisoned cheese.
Disguise as gypsy.
Disguise as sick man.
Disguise as leper.
Scald-head disguise. To avoid having his gold hair seen, the hero covers his head with a cloth and says that he has the scaldhead.
Disguise as madman (fool).
Wise man disguised as buffoon.
Lover approaches mistress disguised as fool.
Sharp man pretends to be stupid so as to be included in plans and conversation of plotters.
Disguise as deformed men to secure entertainment.
Animal feigns lameness.
Deception by pretended faint.
Disguise by changing bodily appearance.
Disguise by dyeing beard. Youths have been advised never to serve a man with a red beard. The trickster dyes his beard black.
Disguise by painting body.
Disguise by veiling face.
Veiled adulteress flees with paramour who has enlisted duped husband's aid.
Youths wear false beards (of grass, wool).
Disguise as hairy man by putting on lambskins.
Disguise by dyeing complexion.
Disguise by cutting one eye out.
Beautiful woman in hideous disguise.
Beautiful woman blackens face as disguise.
Disguise by painting body.
Disguise as old man.
Disguise in wooden covering.
Girl in menial disguise at lover's court.
Disguise in bark of birch.
Disguise by cutting off hair.
Animal disguises as human being.
Lion disguised as monk.
Fox disguised as scholar.
Bad breath and forked tongue reveal identity of snake-king in guise of human.
Tiger disguises as human being.
Man disguises as animal.
Man disguises as tortoise.
Man disguised as elephant.
Man disguised as lamb.
Man disguised as bear.
Satan disguised as deer.
Disguise as layman. Priest disguises as layman.
Disguise as professional man.
Disguise as doctor.
Lover masks as doctor to reach sweetheart.
Girl disguised as doctor exposes queen's paramour who is masquerading as woman.
Poor girl masks as doctor and is made court physician.
Trickster masks as doctor and punishes his cheaters.
Girl masks as doctor to find departed lover.
Animal disguised as doctor.
Disguise as physician to poison enemies.
Woman masks as lawyer (judge) and frees her husband.
Disguise as barber.
Disguise as hospitaller.
Disguise as soldier.
Disguise as dancer.
Twelve men in disguise as carpenters are engaged to build hall for the king's wedding: they abduct the bride.
Disguise as astrologer.
Disguise as churchman (cleric).
Disguise as monk.
Lover disguised as monk or friar meets sweetheart.
Disguise as ascetic.
Lover masks as anchorite to reach sweetheart.
Disguise as missionary.
Disguise as priest.
Bishop disguised as priest.
Disguise as holy man.
Ogre disguised as holy man.
Barber passes for a brahmin.

Disguise as saint. Man beats wife for spending too much time at church. Wife has maids dress as her patron saints and when the husband repeats the beating she calls on them for help. The husband is beaten.
Disguise as yogi.
Disguise as deity (or spirit).
Disguise as angel.
Woman disguised as angel of death.
Disguise as goddess.
Service under a false name.
Disguise by changing name.
Shipwrecked men call themselves by false names.
Service in disguise.
Service in disguise in order to seduce king's daughter by putting love charm in her food.
Lover in disguise as duke's son takes service under king with his followers in order to abduct his sister.
Disguise by changing voice.
Disguise as ghost.
Multiple disguise: one person disguising successively seems to be many.
Disguise for spying.
Disguise of man in woman's dress.
Husband disguises as woman to spy on wife.
Boy disguises as woman to embarrass incontinent priest.
Disguised man takes bride's place: deserts, leaving a she-goat in his place for the foolish bridegroom.
Disguise as a weeping woman to attract attention.
Disguise of woman in man's clothes.
Boasting coward exposed by wife who masks as highwayman and robs him.
Woman disguised as pilgrim engages lover in conversation and learns of his faithlessness.
Repentant nurse disguises as hermit.
Girl in man's clothes avenges her father.
Wife disguises as a man and outwits landlord of inn when he tries same trick he has played on her husband to get all of his goods, etc.
Disguise of woman as a soldier.
Virgin living disguised as a man and unrecognized in a monastery becomes abbot (St. Eugenia).
Woman in male disguise made king.
Woman in male disguise made minister.
Disguise as devil. Priest disguises as devil and "haunts" neighbor's house. Buys it cheaply.
Tricksters change man's furniture. He thinks it is the work of demons. He sells them his house cheaply.
Other deceptions by disguise.
Wolf puts flour on his paw to disguise himself.
Girl marries lover who thought her dead. On reviving she changes her name and disguises her appearance. Eventually marries her former lover.
Monkey dresses in dead mistress's gown;  frightens household.
Jester disguises as prince.
Friar disguises as soldier and steals from concubine.
Warriors whitewash weapons thus disguising identity of one of their number who bears white-handled battle-axe.
Disguise as foreign ambassador.
Disguise by carrying false token.
Disguise as drunkard.
Housemaid disguised as minister.
Disguise as older brother to obtain blessing.
Disguise as child (in cradle).
Husband disguised as wife's brother.
Husband and wife disguised as brother and sister.
Disguise as dupe's daughter after having killed her.
Deception by substitution.
The Virgin Mary substitutes for a mortal.
The nun who saw the world (Sister Beatrice). The Virgin takes the place of the nun in the nunnery while the latter is living a life of shame.
Virgin substitutes in tournament. A knight hears masses so long that he absents himself from a tournament. The Virgin takes his place.
Virgin Mary substitutes for woman whom husband has pledged to the devil. Devil flees.
Living person acts as image of saint.
Man acts as statue of saint in order to enter convent.
Wife deceives husband with substituted bedmate.
Bride has maid sleep in husband's bed to conceal pregnancy.
Wife sends mistress to her husband disguised as herself.
Wife takes mistress's place in husband's bed. Brings about reconciliation.
Wife takes mistress's place in husband's bed: husband sends message of death.
Wife takes mistress's place in bed but is deceived in turn. Husband had tired of the mistress and had previously substituted servant.
Wife takes mistress's place in husband's bed. The husband, unaware of the substitution, asks his friends to share his good fortune.
Wife substitutes for her sodomist husband.
Wife substitutes an old woman for herself in her husband's bed.
Wife has maidservant impersonate her while she goes to her lover.
Husband deceives wife with substituted bedmate.
Husband has his strong servant substitute in bed with strong wife. The supernaturally strong wife is about to kill her husband.
Husband has servant substitute in bed. Instructed not to deceive him while he is calling on mistress. Instructions are not followed.
Substitute bridegroom to save husband from poison maiden.
Groom deceives bride with substituted bedmate and hides self in order to learn the secret she has promised to tell.
Fairy visits queen in her husband's shape and begets son with her.
Substitute in battle.
Warrior deceived into attacking substituted pillar-stone. Stone bears enemy's dress (crown).
King, fearing death at hands of enemy, forces follower to take his place on throne. Follower is killed.
Deception by substitution: wife substitutes calf for beggar whom drunken husband wants to catch and abuse.
Deception by substitution of children.
Substitution of children to gain inheritance.
Deceptive report of birth of heir. Queen tells king anxious for an heir that she is to give birth to a son, but that ill will befall the son if king looks upon him.
Substitute for task.
Impotent husband deceives wife by having a substitute in virility test.
Ruler has favorite perform tasks so that he may himself win a bride.
Substitute on quest.
Substituted letter. A letter is changed on the way to its destination so as to falsify the message.
Forged letter: god of death replaced by another.
Sleeping potion substituted for poison.
Substitute sacrifice.
Inferior animals substituted in sacrifice.
Person substitutes for human sacrifice.
Hero substitutes for princess as gift to monster. Kills him.
Servant impersonates dead master and makes a false testament.
Rascal in dead man's place in bed makes dead man's will.
Younger and preferred brother substituted by mother for elder to deceive father.
Substitute specimen for laboratory test.
Substitute specimen in urinalysis.
Substitute specimen in blood test.
Deception by feigned death (sleep).
Death feigned in order to be carried.
Hero sewed up in animal hide so as to be carried to height by bird.
Death feigned to meet lover.
Death feigned to learn how soldiers are resuscitated.
False tidings of one's own death in order to be able to leave without notice.
False tidings of another's death in order to secure his bride.
Death feigned to establish reputation of false relic. False resuscitation.
Death feigned in order to enter land of dead.
Trickster shams death to get food.
Trickster feigns death and eats the ripe fruit from the tree.
Trickster shams death and eats grave offerings.
Deception by pretending sleep.
Illusions.
Deception by legerdemain.
Deception: climbing silk thread tossed upward in air.
Sham cure by pretended extracting of object from patient's body.
Camouflage.
Army appears like forest. Surprises enemy. Each soldier carries branches. (Birnam wood comes to Dunsinane.)
Reeds make ships appear like island.
Love letter hidden in apple.
Wound masked by other wound in order not to be recognized.
Banners of army appear like flock of many-colored birds.
Clods thrown up by hoofs of horses appear like flock of birds.
Deception by sham blood. By stabbing bag of blood (or otherwise) trickster makes dupe think that he is bleeding.
Absent person seems to be present.
Illusory enemies.
Phantom army attacked.
Objects (animals) attacked under the illusion that they are men.
Two soldiers slay each other thinking they are slaying a common enemy.
Slayers magically made to believe stone their enemy. They behead it.
Comrade slain under the illusion that he is an enemy.
Invisible man eats bread and boy and girl quarrel. Each thinks other had eaten bread.
Deception: mirror-reflection convinces dupe he is trickster's captive.
Images set up to resemble watchmen.
Hero wears so many different costumes that he is believed to represent a host.
Illusion of death.
Dead made to appear alive.
Lighted sponge in mouth of dead causes illusory breathing.
Illusions in landscape.
Mirage. Illusory water and land.
Following luminous tree in the desert.
Mists which lead astray.
Enemies magically caused to lose sight of each other while hunting.
Mock sunrise. Contract is to be fulfilled at dawn. Wolf makes fire as mock sunrise. Is caught.
Mock sunrise: person causes cock to crow (simulates cock crow).
Mock sunrise: dupe made to believe that flaunted bare buttocks are the rising sun.
Mock sunrise causes supernaturals (thieves) to drop burdens and flee.
Travelers mistake brushwood at a distance for a ship.
Companions separated by illusory city.
Illusory shapes of animals made to appear on hilltops.
Illusory mountain (hill).
Tuatha Di Danann cause island to appear to be  "hog's back".
Illusory sounds.
Echo answers.
Deceptive nocturnal noise. Wood-spirits imitate falling of trees, etc.
Fairies cause sound to appear to come from various directions.
(Saint's) bell heard but never found.
Illusory light.
Other illusions.
House seems to be afire.

Deceptive cure by illusion. Man told that he can be cured only with blood of his own child. He is made to believe that the child is killed. When he learns that the child is still alive, the excess of joy cures him.
False Paradise. (The Old Man of the Mountain.) Potion is given to dupes who are led into what they believe is Paradise. They are then forced to rob and kill to regain admittance through death.
Injurious food (drink) has delusive sweet taste.
Illusory night (darkness).
Palace appears to be floating on water actually glass.
Other deceptions by disguise or illusion.
Deception by hiding.
Trickster hides in bag in order to be carried. His father imitates and is beaten.
Trickster hides in box in order to be carried.
Trickster hides in basket and is carried.
Girl hides lover under clothing upon which she sits.
False proof: cloak dipped into water used as evidence of stormy weather.
Impostures.
Marital impostors.
The false bride (substituted bride). An impostor takes the wife's place without the husband's knowledge and banishes (kills, transforms) the wife.
Circumstances of substitution of false bride.
False bride takes true bride's place on the way to the wedding.
False bride takes true bride's place when child is born.
False bride takes true bride's place at fountain. The true bride, left by her husband for a short time at a fountain, is supplanted by a moor or gypsy, who transforms her.
False bride finishes true bride's task and supplants her. The true bride must perform a certain task to win her husband and, being exhausted, commits the task to a slave.
Old woman substituted for bride in bridegroom's bed.
Man palms off elder daughter as younger on wedding night.
She-bear as false bride. Compels true bride to exchange places.
Ghost-ogress pushes bride into hole in tree and takes her place.
False bride steals true bride's garments in bath.
False bride makes child cry and demand mother's clothes and ornaments.
Prince substitutes peasant girl for the king's daughter he has got for his father but with whom he himself has fallen in love.
Impostor kills fairy, hides body and dresses in fairy's clothes.
Treacherous disposal of true bride by false.
True bride transformed by false.
True bride pushed into water by false.
True bride lives in fish's belly.
True bride sits spinning at the bottom of river.
True bride's children thrown away at birth (by false bride).
Reinstatement of true bride.
Substitution of false bride revealed by animal.
Substitution of false bride revealed by true bride in her animal form.
True bride takes house near husband. Thus eventually secures his attention.
False bride fails when husband tests her. Uses slipper test, jumping test, or the like.
False bride's mutilated feet. In order to wear the shoes with which the husband is testing the identity of his bride, the false bride cuts her feet. She is detected.
False bride fails when magician tests her.
True bride reincarnated as reed reveals truth.
True bride reinstated by acting as mysterious housekeeper.
Snake adopts true bride thrown into well.
Man in woman's clothing poses as bride for beggar.
Penniless bride pretends to wealth.
The false virgin. Various deceptions practiced to mask bride as virgin.
Abductor pretends to have been sent to fetch princess by lover.
The false bridegroom (substitute bridegroom). Takes the place of the true bridegroom.
Monk becomes husband to girl at night, so that his friend may have dowry.
Through power of saint, man is caused to assume lover's form and sleep with princess. Lover plots death of saint, but is accidentally slain in his place.
Handsome man substituted for ugly as bridegroom: wins bride.
Robber bridegroom. Robber marries girl under pretence of being a fine gentleman.
Penniless bridegroom pretends to wealth.
Penniless wooer: patch of land. After marriage he takes the bride to look at his land. He puts on soiled clothes. She looks at the land; he points to the patch on his clothes. " That patch is mine.

Penniless wooer: money in hand. An uncle gives the boy a coin and food to hold while he woos for him. He tells the girl's father that the boy has a piece of money in hand and plenty to eat. Wins the girl.
Penniless wooer: helpful animal reports master wealthy and thus wins girl for him.

Penniless wooer.  ". House of my father with one hundred fifty lights and goat pen. " When the servant in bed so remarks the master marries his daughter to him. Arrived at the hut, he explains that the lights are the stars whose beams enter through the cracks in the roof. One goat is tied to the tree.
Man wins girl's love by pretending to wealth and nobility. Deception is discovered and impostor is banished.
Forged credentials used to win girl. Theft of gems.
All of these are mine,"  says wooer as he strokes his whiskers. The girl thinks he is indicating the fields and live stock past which they are riding.
Slave poses as treasurer's son and carries letter purporting to ask for hand of merchant's daughter in marriage.
Monster disguises and wins girl. Borrows wedding garments one by one; later returns them one by one and reveals monster form.
Ugly fish borrows skin of handsome fish for courtship and marriage.
Ogre imposes on widow by assuming form of dead husband.
Marital impostors miscellaneous.
Husband poses as wife's brother.
Substituted children.
Parents exchange children.
Son of the king and of the smith exchanged.
Two mothers exchange their children, a boy and a girl.
Queen changes her own ugly twins for slave's pretty son. Later recognizes the better character of the twins, and changes back again.
Woman substitutes child for her own and sells it. Exchanges sleeping places.
The false heir.
Nurse exchanges children so that the preferred child will be assured of wealth.

Man is made to believe that his married daughter has borne a child. In reality it is a foundling. When the supposed mother dies her father is about to forfeit dowry, when the child's real parents claim him.
Barren woman pretends to bear child. Substitutes another woman's child.
Woman pretends to be mother of child chosen to be king.
Midwife takes child and substitutes it for king's stillborn child.
Queen passes off girl-child as boy by having pandits say raja must not see his son for twelve years.
Barren wife makes child by magic and claims it as her own.
False daughter: accepted as one's resurrected child.
Treacherous impostors.
Impostors abandon (or kill) their companion and usurp his place.
Impostors throw hero overboard into sea.
Impostor tries to push foster brother into the water and then cuts rope so that he drifts alone out on the sea in boat without oars.
Impostors abandon hero in lower world. Usually let rope drop on which he is to be raised.
Impostors kill hero.
Impostors throw hero into pit.
Impostors throw hero into prison.
Impostor leaves hero alone on island.
Impostor abandons hero on high hill. Pulls down rope on which he is to be lowered.
Impostors claim reward (prize) earned by hero.
Impostor forces oath of secrecy. Hero or heroine swears not to tell of imposture.
Impostor forces hero (heroine) to change places with him (her).
Impostor (magician, demon) takes the place of the king. The ladies of the harem recognize the false king, and the true king is reinstated.
Impostors steal rescued princess.
Impostors exposed by girl at her wedding.
Impostor claims to be father of princess's child.
Impostor impersonates dead count.
Rascal pretends to be dead man's heir and receives money.
Disguised flayer. An impostor dresses in the skin of his victim.
Disguised flayer tightens skin to look beautiful.
Impostors tricked into carrying hero in box. Woman makes them think they will have her as reward.
Impostor demands box in name of king.
Imposition by sham sickness.
Person pretends sickness can be cured only with death (humiliation) of another.
Mother-in-law's head is shaven, face blackened and she is led around city on ass-back as only cure for malady of daughter-in-law.
Sham prowess.
Sham warrior.
Boastful fly-killer: "seven at a blow". A tailor who has killed seven flies writes on a placard: "Seven at a blow. " He is received as a great warrior.
Boastful elephant killer: killed at one blow. Elephant has been poisoned.
Runaway cavalry-hero. When the sham hero goes to war his horse runs away with him. To save himself he grasps a cross from a graveyard and waves it from side to side, putting the enemy to flight.
Runaway cavalry hero tears out limbs of dead trees.
Sham-warrior intimidates soldiers with his boasting.
Sham-warrior boasts and is employed at palace.
Tiger intimidated by boasting of the sham-warrior.
Boastful coward frightened by conspirators.
Ordinary man assumes high sounding name and challenges enemy chief to single combat. Latter is frightened into believing him to be of exceptional prowess and desists from attacking the city.
Sham prince (nobleman).
Brahmin takes shape of a prince.
Servant takes prince's horse and clothes and passes self off as prince.
Poor boy said by helpful cat to be dispossessed prince. This is believed.
Poor boy said by helpful animal to be dispossessed prince (wealthy man) who has lost clothes while swimming (in shipwreck).
Better things at home. A poor boy posing as a prince in the king's court always says that he has better things at home.
Brothers pose as princes, deeming their parentage not worthy of their merit.
Impostor claims to be earl's son in exile.
Adventurer poses as son of dead king.
Wooing emissary poses as king and suitor, but is refused.
Impostor appears with letter authorizing that he be set on the throne.
Thieves set up poor weaver as prince and thus get possession of tribute and gifts.
Sham brave man.
Coward boasts that he has frightened bear away. His wife has killed it and he has fled.
Sham rich man.
Helpful cat borrows measure for his master's money. The master thus gains a reputation for wealth.
Drunken man by pretending to want to buy an elephant makes king think him rich.
Sham physician.
Sham physician cures people by threatening them with death.
Man undertakes to cure fat abbot of stomach ailment. Starves him until he admits he can eat anything.
Patients frightened from hospital by harsh treatment.
Sham physician pretends to diagnose entirely from urinalysis. Really from observation and inference from trifles.
Pepper as universal remedy of sham doctor: accidentally works.
Sham physician predicts the sex of the unborn child.  ". From one side it looks like a boy, from the other a girl. " The woman bears twins and the husband pays the doctor.
Sham physician: using the flea powder. Catch the flea, open its mouth, and place the powder inside.

Sham physician: making the girl grow up. A king wants his daughter to grow up quickly. The physician says that he must send away for the medicine; meantime she must be shut up. After several years they show her to the king. She has grown.
The sham physician and the devil in partnership. The devil is to enter the girl and the physician will collect reward for driving the devil out.
Cheat: demon kills people so his pupil can resuscitate them and get reward.
Sham physician refuses to take his own medicine: unmasked.
Sham physician gives relative a medical degree.
Ignorant youth buys a medical degree.
Ignorant doctor draws his prescriptions by lot.
Sham physician hands out prescriptions haphazard.
Sham wise man.
Sham wise man gives a purgative and helps find a lost horse. His pills get the credit.
Sham wise man claims to find stolen goods by incantation. He has really forced thieves to show them to him.
Sham wise man hides something and is rewarded for finding it.
Sham wise man sees jewel hidden and is rewarded for finding it.
Sham wise man declares who committed the theft: robbers.
Sham wise man does not know where his own house is. Unmasked.
Sham wise man stays alone feigning study. Is really killing flies.
Sham wise man (girl's confederate) interprets pretended dream for girl. Insists she be allowed to marry man of her own choice.
Sham wise man pretends knowledge from dream: really overheard conversation.
Sham wise man burns house where he pretends to keep his marvelous books, and is free from being called again.
Sham wise man accidentally predicts weather correctly.
Boy, posing as magician, agitates purported all-knowing pig's head in front of his enemies, identifying them as dishonest men.
Sham teacher. Pretends to read a document brought him as a letter. It is a tax receipt.
Sham churchman.
Sham parson (priest).
Peasant as priest preaches on the troubles of laymen.
Sham parson repeats same expression over and over or says a few words of Latin.
Parody sermon.
Sham parson: the sawed pulpit. He has sawed the pulpit almost through. He predicts a miracle. The pulpit falls down.
Sham priest dupes man into believing he can discover treasure.
Sham holy man.
Jackal as sham saint.
Pretender as pope.
Woman in disguise becomes pope. (Pope Joan.)
Devil disguised as monk.
Sham bishop.
Sham abbot.
False prophet.
Mohammed puts seed in his ears and when doves trained to feed there come, he tells people that they bring messages from God.
Sham magician.
False magician exposed by clever girl.
Sham magician promises to induce love by magic. Dupe is frightened (to death, robbed, or otherwise discomfited) by magician or confederate.
Master posing as magician plays tricks on his servant.
Sham magician belches fire to frighten dupes.
Trickster impersonates necromancer to seduce latter's wife.
Sham magician makes wife believe that he (she) can be transported by demons.
Sham astrologer.
Sham crystal-gazer.
Alchemist.
Alchemist steals money from corpse and claims he has made the silver.
Alchemist secures payment for his "secret".
Juggler promises to fly from one house to another. Keeps crowd waiting until dusk and then makes his escape.
Sham prowess in hunting (fishing).
Bought game (fish) used to prove prowess in hunting (fishing).
Sham prowess miscellaneous.
Sham traveler. Boasts falsely of voyage and receives canoes which he appropriates.
Warrior buries oversized armor so as to convince posterity of soldiers' gigantic size.
Servant poses as master.
Impostors: servant enters dead body of master and takes his place.
Sham deity.
Weaver poses as deity.
Sham miracles.
Man behind statue (tree) speaks and pretends to be God (spirit).
Husband answers behind the statue when wife wants to know how to fool him. He says to feed him well.
Trickster hides in hollow tree and eats food he has persuaded his wife to bring to feed a bird.
Man behind the tree threatens his debtor. The latter thinks God is calling and repays the debt.
Boy behind the tree tells woman about the bad food he gets. She thinks God is speaking and gives him good food.
Maid behind statue of Virgin advises the mistress to give the servants better food.
Husband behind saint's statue advises wife to spin.
Wife behind tree advises husband against having his wife work.
Husband as God behind the tree forces his wife to confess adultery.
Man as God behind the tree forces the girl to admit having an illegitimate child. Or prophesies himself as father so as to marry the girl.
Girl behind the tree advises the unwilling suitor. Believing it to be the advice of angels, he marries her.
Wife behind tree advises the husband about his marital duties.
The man behind the crucifix says "Good Evening" to the drunk man, who thinks Christ is speaking to him.
Hidden man behind image gives unwelcome answer to suppliant: image blamed.
Sexton behind crucifix tells old maid she will have no husband;  she tells Christ Child that he knows nothing about it, she is praying to his mother.
Sexton behind statue tells old maid praying for a husband to raise her foot to her neck.
Trickster concealed in sacred tree advises that he is to marry the princess.
Trickster in tree advises that tree and fruit belong to him. Others think God speaks and leave.
Impostor acting as God in tree suspected and tree burned.
Alleged idol promises teacher certain payment for his book when finished. Dupe overhears and pays him bargain price for what he is later to receive.
Man hidden behind idol in temple tells robbers they will have good booty but should leave half of it in the temple.
Oracular images occupied by spirits or priests who give the answers.
Statue made to raise its arm. Woman wishing to go on pilgrimage (to meet lover) makes believe that statue of saint has raised its arm in answer to her prayer.
Sham miracle. Priest makes congregation believe the painting of the Virgin weeps real tears.
Jackal inside carcass of bullock makes people think his voice is God's.  Demands gifts.
Living man at the grave pretends to be dead man speaking.
Sham miracle: may the grass grow up!. Tricksters who have done no mowing say to their master when he angers them, "May the grass grow up again! " He finds it is full height.
Sham miracle: wallet (bee-hive) changes to wasps. Tricksters put a wasp nest in the wallet (bee-hive). When the master claims it they give it to him with the curse, "May it turn to wasps! " It does.
