Sham miracle: rupees turn to ashes. Cheat tells man rupees carried by horse in sack will turn to ashes if man's tired wife rides on its back. Man promises to pay him back if that should happen. Ashes fall from under saddle when woman does and cheat collects.
Sham miracle: may the food turn raw. Lazy wife takes uncooked food to husband in field.
False miraculous relic.

Two friars take arm from corpse and allege it is a miracle-producing relic. One of the tricksters questions its powers in public. Feigns being struck dead. Feigned resurrection. Tricksters enriched as a result.
Other impostures.
Deception by playing deaf and dumb.
Trickster feigns deafness and gets hospitality from miser.
Ubiquitous beggar. In disguise obtains alms three times from the same person.
Trickster poses as helper and eats women's stored provisions.
Girls keep up appearances to deceive suitors as to their desirability.
The lisping sisters. The girls have been warned against speaking, but forget and are found out.
The girl who ate so little. When the suitor sees her baking he finds that she can eat.
Girl claims to have overeaten on a nightingale's thigh.
The girl with the ugly name. Her mother gives her a new one but the girl does not recognize it and her mother must call her by her old name.
Ugly women complain of falling flowers. King hearing them supposes them delicate and beautiful.
Blind fiancie betrays self. Mistakes one object for another.
Rearing the large-headed and large-eyed bird. When the one rearing the owl learns its age he kills it.
Devil disguised as candidate for confirmation.
Devil disguised as man goes to church.
Brother (sister) secures blessing due to another.
Impostor: one sister borrows another's clothes and gets religious blessing in her place.
Hare (jackal) makes horns of wax and poses as horned animal. Horns melt by the fire.
Devil tries to pass for Jesus. Forbids man to cut wood on Sunday. Disappears when man demands to see the wounds on his hands and feet.
Wise man sent by king to rival to give him interested advice.
Hypocrites.
Hypocrite pretends friendship but attacks.
Man pretends friendship but attacks king to avenge violation of his wife.
Friendship feigned to avenge murder.
Wolves sign false truce with sheep. After the dogs have been dismissed the wolves devour the sheep.
Wolf poses as "grandmother" and kills child. (Red Riding Hood.)
Wolf poses as mother and kills child.
Ogre father poses as mother and kills child.
Bogey imitates mother and kills child.
Hyena poses as father and kills child.
Leopard poses as brother and kills child.
Tiger-ogress pretends to be girls' mother: explains tail as boil.
False friend causes man to eject his wife. He then seduces her.
Enemy invited for marriage with relative attacked.
Enemy invited to meeting and attacked.
Women pretend to weep over warrior's wounds while attempting to inflame them.
King has wounded ally attended by leeches, but bribes them to introduce beetles, awns of barley, etc. into the wounds.
Child adopted by rich man in order to get rid of him.
Betrayal by a kiss.
The bitten cheek. In payment of a debt, a woman permits a man to kiss her; he bites her cheek so that she has a permanent mark.
Man pretends to kiss relative: bites him instead.
Man embraces other to see if he carries gold in his girdle.
Unsuccessful suitor pretends friendship with woman's husband. Kills him while on a hunt.
Badgers treacherously slain in violation of pledge given by prince.
Crow accepts owl's hospitality then burns owls to death.
Fox confesses to cock, then eats him.
Double dealers.
Dog alternately bites and caresses hares. Is he friend or enemy?
Dog at his master's table is friendly to guest. On the street he barks at him.
Magpie leads other magpies into his master's net. Promises them that the master will teach them to speak.
Trickster makes basket for his partner tiger to carry meat, but does not sever bamboo from roots. Tiger left behind.
Same reward promised to many helpers.
King's daughter secretly pledged to many to win their aid.
Supernatural personages seen in dreams advise opposing kings how each can overcome the other.
Helper steals object obtained at end of quest.
Jackal persuades deer to steal from farmer, then informs farmer who catches deer.
Double dealing physician.
Double dealing physician hired to poison his master who has sent him to poison enemy.
Crow gets to owls pretending crows have cast him out. Having learned secret retreats of owls, he returns to crows and leads them to victory over owls.
When wolf pretends to slander tiger fox agrees;  later tells tiger he was trying to test wolf's malice.
Pretended virtue.
Adulteress feigns unusual sensitiveness.
Adulteress pretends shame before male statue (mirror, male fish).
Adulteress pretends to faint when her husband strikes her with a rose. She has allowed her lover to abuse her.
Adulteress feigns great disdain of men;  will look at none but husband (and lover).
Women adorn their heads, though they are immoral below.
The oversensitive bride.
The bride's (wife's) false modesty. Wears gloves, etc. to bed.
Girl who is frightened by love becomes insatiable.
Oversensitive bride pleads a headache (or other excuse). Groom retaliates with similar plea when she changes her mind.
The oversensitive or hypocritical widow.
Doctor prescribes sexual intimacy for widow's ills. She claims to prefer death. Change of heart on daughters' plea. Daughters adopt treatment as a preventive.
Wanted: a husband to manage estate. Widow who claims to abhor intimacy rejects a eunuch with business qualifications.

Overlooking the insult. Man consoles daughter whose husband is dying by telling her he has picked another husband for her. She feels insulted. No sooner does her husband die than she asks her father for details.

Pretended honesty to mulct victim. Trickster claims to have found a bag of gold. Confederate claims and receives it upon correct identification. Spectator is thus deceived into trusting the trickster with a large sum of money.
Boy pretends to take long trip in order to pay debt of a penny. Thus he gets man's confidence and robs him.
Fox confesses sins but is immediately ready to steal again.
The wolf in the company of saints. Promises to give up slaying animals. After wringing the gander's neck, excuses self saying: "He should not have hissed at the saint.
Hypocritical stepmother weeps as she tells departing husband she will take good care of stepchildren though they beat her (she beats them instead).
Hypocrite refuses gifts orally but stretches out his hands.
Pretended piety.
Apparently pious man (sadhu) a thief.
False ascetic in partnership with tiger shares his prey.
Detection of hypocrisy.
Treacherous plan of hypocritical animal detected and prevented.
Wolf offers to act as shepherd: plan detected.
Wolf proposes abolition of dog guards for sheep: plan detected.
Fox feigns to be playing with sheep: dog drives him off.
Dog caresses sick sheep: shepherd knows that he hopes for sheep's death.
Wolf tries to entice goat down from high place: plan detected.
Famished wolf asks sheep to bring him water: plan detected.
Wolf offers to act as midwife for sow: plan detected.
Cat offers to act as doctor for cock and hen: plan detected.
Crocodile tells dog to drink in river without fear: plan detected.
Cat hangs on wall pretending to be dead: mice detect plan.
Fox's plan detected by crickets: cricket wings in his excrement.
Jackal as nurse for leopard cubs eats their food. Chased by leopard.
Thief tries to feed watchdog and stop his mouth: dog detects plan.
Chaste" woman surprised in adultery.
Holy" hermit surprised in amorous intrigue.
Appearance of Death exposes hypocrisy.
Woman and sick husband.  ". Would that Death take me in his stead. " When Death comes she points to her husband.
Other hypocritical acts.
Peasant has kind words for daws, but drives them from his seeds.
Illness feigned in order to learn secret.
Illness feigned in order to get better food.
False guardian betrays refuge of fleeing lovers.
Love falsely pledged for wooer's benefit.
Hypocrisy concerning thefts.
Man announces finding lost jewel, but so softly that no one hears. He thus has clear conscience.
Hypocrite will not share in stolen chicken only takes some gravy.
Hypocrisy concerning charity.
Hypocrite breaks vow to give coin in charity. Finds coin is short weight.
Thief robs blind miser of his hoard and gives a tenth away in charity in form of a banquet to the poor.
Miser goes to mass before committing usury.
King sends regrets for death of man he has ordered executed.
False accusation.
Falsely accused minister reinstates himself by his cleverness.
Falsely accused hero sent on dangerous mission.
Jewel presented to king brings false accusation of theft.
Slanders.
Calumniated wife.
Man's mistress accuses his wife of having leprosy.
Potiphar's wife. A woman makes vain overtures to a man and then accuses him of attempting to force her.
Telling a story to allay a woman's amorous desires.

Woman makes vain overtures to stepson and falsely accuses him of murder. She tries to poison him but her own son accidentally takes the beverage and apparently dies. Plot is revealed when doctor states that he had substituted sleeping potion for the poison.
Spurned woman accuses man of theft.
Friar refuses to keep promise after enjoying woman and is accused of rape. Castrated.
Adulteress tricks husband into killing allegedly importunate lover.
Mother falsely accuses son of incest with her.
Girl falsely accuses bishop.
Woman slandered as adulteress (prostitute). (Usually by unsuccessful suitor.) (Crescentia, Genoveva, Susanna.)
False tokens of woman's unfaithfulness. Tokens are stolen from the woman, or her secret markings are seen by treachery.
Fingers as false token of wife's unfaithfulness. She has substituted a maid and the gallant has cut off the maid's finger.
Leper (beggar) laid in queen's bed. She is thus incriminated.
Man puts donkey's foal under princess's bed-cover and accuses her of lying with it.
Page is duped into hiding under woman's bed (behind curtain).
Maidservant's confederate feigns coming out of woman's bedroom.
False abortion placed in innocent woman's bed.
Man taking refuge in woman's house causes her false accusation.
Villain brings (threatens to bring) naked servant to woman's house. Threat of false accusation of indiscretion forces woman to yield.
Other means of incriminating innocent woman.
Handkerchief left in woman's room to cause accusation. (Othello.)
Giving madman food causes woman to be falsely accused.
Princess disguised as man is accused of illicit relations with queen.
Girl disguised as man accused of infidelity.
Rich woman, when her advances are repulsed by an ascetic (really a girl in man's clothes) accuses her of adulterous assault.
Man falsely accused of infidelity.
Animal-birth slander. A woman is accused of having given birth to animals. Her children are put out of the way and animals substituted.
Jealous queens tell child-bearing queen to put her head in the hole at the bottom of grain-bin, so that she fails to see what she delivers.
Animal-descent slander. Malicious story that man is son of an animal.
Slander: woman has given birth to objects.
Stone substituted for newly-born babies.
Log-birth slander.
Prophecy of ogre-child so that pregnant woman will be killed.
Innocent person accused of murder.
Innocent woman accused of murder.
Innocent woman accused of killing her new-born children.
Innocent woman accused of eating her new-born children.
Bones of puppies as false evidence of wife's having eaten her new-born child.
Queen falsely accused of having poisoned husband. Ignorant doctors cannot diagnose king's illness. Queen burned at stake.
Girl falsely accused of murdering her lover. Investigation reveals poisonous breath of toad as cause of death.
Incognito queen falsely accused of having killed child left in her care.
Man falsely accused of murder.
Anchorite falsely accused of murder.
Man accused of having starved woman to death and taken treasure.
Person wounds self and accuses another of attempting murder.
Murderer makes outcry so that innocent person is accused of murder.
Warrior falsely accused of having killed his sleeping adversary. Not supposed to have been able to do it if latter was awake.
Calumniated wife: substituted letter (falsified message). The letter announcing the birth of her children changed on the way to the king, so that the queen is falsely accused.
Husband's letter ordering the calumniated wife to be treated well is altered into an order of execution.
Man slandered as having deflowered princess.
Brother accused of paternity of mystically impregnated sister.
King's faithful servant falsely accused of familiarity with queen.
Innocent woman accused of using witchcraft. Sham sickness.
Woman slandered as an ogress.
Slander: woman said to be possessed of demons.
Girl reported possessed of demon: suitors frightened away.
Knight falsely accused of sedition.
King's advisor falsely accused of treason. Accusers exposed and punished.
King's man falsely accused of being in the secret service of another king.
False accusation of theft.
Desiring woman they quarrel over, man accuses group of men of having abducted his wife.
False queen puts horseflesh in bed of one with child so as to identify her as horse-eating thief.
Slander: prince is bastard.
Slanders miscellaneous.
Jealous monk falsely accuses novice of laziness.
Sick crew accused of being magicians so that nobody wants to have anything to do with them.
Stepsisters scatter sugar in girl's litter so that flies congregate;  would-be bridegroom disgusted and tells bearers to abandon her in jungle.
Family is accused of stinginess by recipients of their hospitality.
Trouble-makers.
Trickster makes two friends each suspicious of the other's intentions.

Cat brings suspicion between eagle and sow. Eagle lives in the top of the branches, cat in the middle, and sow at bottom; all are happy. Cat tells eagle that sow is trying to root down the tree: eagle is frightened and dares not leave tree. Cat tells sow that eagle plans to carry off pigs: sow dares not leave. They starve and fall victims to the cat.
Envious jackal makes lion suspicious of his friend, the bull. The lion kills the bull.
Woman destroys men's friendship by pretending to whisper to one.
Trickster fills supposed treasure box with trash. Joint owners each accuse other of theft.
Treasure-animal introduced into family's flock in order to stir up dissension and enmity.
False message of love carried to hero and maiden by troublemaker.
Servant lays skin of dead dog in the bed of his mistress and master. Makes trouble between them.

The complaint about bad breath: trouble for the king's favorite. A steward advises the courtier to hold his head away when serving the king, since the king objects to his bad breath. He then tells the king that the courtier holds his head back to avoid the king's bad breath.
Officers praised in reverse from their real merit: trouble for them and their master.

The priest's guest and the eaten chickens. The servant who has eaten the chickens tells the guest to flee because the priest is going to cut off his ears, and he tells the priest that the guest has stolen two chickens The priest runs after him.
Trouble-maker in night-lodging. Comes riding a wolf and asks for hospitality. Wolf kills sheep. Beehive in bed. Bees sting family and cause father to kill son.
Jealous courtiers shake king lion's confidence in his councillor, the virtuous jackal, by accusing the jackal of stealing the lion's food.
Two persons separately informed about each other's death.
Innocent made to appear guilty.
The corpse handed around. (The thrice-killed corpse.) Dupes are accused of murder when the corpse is left with them. The trickster is paid to keep silent.
Live man thought to be returning corpse pleads with trickster to save him.
Unresponsive corpse. Corpse is set up so that dupe addresses it and when it does not respond knocks it over. He is accused of murder.
Dead dog set up so that woman knocks it over. Must pay damages.
Legs of a corpse cause accusation of murder.
Trickster wounds self and accuses others.
Animal nurse wounds self so as to throw blame for eaten young on other animal.
Evidence of crime left so that dupe is blamed.
Blood smeared on innocent person brings accusation of murder.
Bloody knife left in innocent person's bed brings accusation of murder.
Slanderers kill a woman and put her body near Buddha's cell.
Innocent man compelled to write treasonable letter. It brings about his death sentence.
Sham blind man throws suspicion on real blind. He admits his deception so that his companion, who is really blind, is punished.
The dog receives the blows. The cat steals a sausage from the table but the dog receives the blows from the mistress.

Rats cause cats to be killed. The rats unite and all go to houses together, increasing or decreasing their ravages with the increase or decrease in the number of cats. Thus the cats are suspected of the damage and are killed.
Grandmother causes grandchildren to be whipped: puts dirt and hairs into cooking pot by stealth and sand in the water they draw.
Villains and traitors.

Treacherous relatives. Distinction between treacherous relatives and cruel relatives (+S0-+S99) is frequently impossible to make. Relatives whose treachery seems to be uppermost have been listed here; those usually possessing power over their charges and exercising their power in a cruel fashion have been listed under cruel relatives.
Treacherous brother. Usually elder brother.
Treacherous elder brother(s).
Treacherous younger brother(s).
Treacherous brother-in-law.
Treacherous foster brother. False accusation of theft.
Treacherous stepbrother.
Treacherous sister. Usually elder sister.
Treacherous sister attempts to poison brother.
Treacherous sister as mistress of robber (giant) plots against brother.
Treacherous queen has her brother killed.
Treacherous stepsisters.
Treacherous sister-in-law.
Treacherous wife.

Matron of Ephesus. (Vidua.) A woman mourns night and day by her husband's grave. A knight guarding a hanged man is about to lose his life because of the corpse he has stolen from the gallows. The matron offers him her love and substitutes her husband's corpse on the gallows so that the knight can escape.
Faithless wife and paramour throw hero overboard.
Love-mad queen pushes her husband into well, as fakir lover directs.
Faithless wife plots with paramour against husband's life.
Faithless wife has husband and children killed so that she can be with paramour.
Faithless wife poisons husband to be with paramour. Paramour fearing a like fate refuses to go to her.
Paramour demands that wife bring him her husband's head.
Wife plots to kill her husband, but her paramour answers that he could never touch murderess.
Faithless wife deceives husband while she searches for lover.
Queen in love with own brother kills her husband.
Betrayal of husband's secret by his wife.
Secret of vulnerability disclosed by hero's wife.
Noah's secret betrayed by his wife. The devil persuades his wife to intoxicate him and then find out what he is doing (building the ark).
The faithless resuscitated wife. Husband at great sacrifice has brought his wife back to life. She immediately deserts him and plots with a paramour against his life.
Faithless wife transforms husband.
Faithless wife betrays husband to her father.
Faithless queen aids lover to dispossess king.
Faithless wife incites sons to make war upon father.
Faithless wife tricks husband into setting lover free.
Treacherous queen tricks king into bestowing kingdom upon her son.
Young queen murders her old husband in order to get a new one.
Queen kills her husband as revenge of his killing of her father and brother.
Queen deceives her husband as revenge for his killing of her lover and brother (Helgi. )

Treacherous queen lures her husband into chest and betrays him to hostile king. He is hung up between two fires, but his second wife cuts the strings so that he falls down and kills his enemy and takes his kingdom back.
Wife betrays husband in revenge for his once having taken a second wife.
Treacherous children.
Treacherous daughter.
Daughter has aged father cremated with dead husband to honor the latter.
Treacherous daughter-in-law.
Treacherous daughter-in-law plots against husband's mother.
Treacherous son: leads revolt against his father to whom he owes all.
Treacherous foster son.
Treacherous uncle.
Treacherous nephew kills good uncle for his money.
Treacherous relatives-in-law.
Treacherous mother-in-law accuses innocent wife.
Treacherous father-in-law.
Treacherous rivals.
Jealous rivals prevail on person to break tabu (prohibition).
Treacherous rival lover. Wife's paramour or rival in love.
Woman poisons her successful rival.
Treacherous co-wife (concubine).
Treacherous lovers.
Treacherous mistress.
Adulteress has lover killed.
Treacherous lover (man).
Treacherous lover betrays woman's love and deserts her.
Treacherous officers and tradesmen.
Treacherous inn-keeper.
Treacherous steward.
Treacherous seneschal.
Treacherous porter.
Treacherous marshall.
Treacherous prince.
Treacherous princess (queen).
Treacherous king.
Treacherous king spies so that he may levy fines.
Treacherous lord.
Treacherous minister.
Treacherous minister's son.
Other treacherous officers and tradesmen.
Treacherous potter.
Treacherous treasurer.
Treacherous goldsmith.
Treacherous merchant.
Treacherous butcher.
Treacherous servants and workmen.
Treacherous servant.
Treacherous slave.
Treacherous slave-girl.
Treacherous maidservant.
Treacherous barber.
Treacherous cook.
Treacherous herdsman.
Treacherous swineherd.
Treacherous ox-herd.
Treacherous stable-groom.
Treacherous gardener.
Treacherous peasant.
Other treacherous servants and workmen.
Treacherous woodsman.
Treacherous lamplighter.
Treacherous potter.
Treacherous sailor.
Dark traitors. Persons darks by race, habitual occupation, or complexion, or even marvelously colored, are frequently traitors in folk-tales.
Treacherous dark man.
Treacherous dark woman.
Treacherous negro (Moor).
Treacherous gypsy.
Treacherous charcoal-burner.
Treacherous red knight.
Deformed villains.
Hunchback villain.
Crippled villain.
One-eyed villain.
Blind villain.
Beardless villain.
Leper as villain.
Treacherous dwarf.
Treacherous churchmen.
Treacherous bishop.
Treacherous cardinal.
Boniface VIII, when cardinal, impersonates angel and dupes Clement V into abdicating.
Treacherous priest.
Treacherous chaplain.
Treacherous brahmin.
Villain disguised as ascetic or nun.
Ascetic as villain.
Treacherous anchorite.
Sage as villain.
Other villains and traitors.
Treacherous beggar.
Treacherous physician.
Treacherous old woman.
Treacherous host.
Treacherous animals.
Treacherous partridge.
Treacherous eagle.
Treacherous cock.
Treacherous lizard.
Treacherous camel.
Treacherous partner.
Treacherous robber-partner.
Treacherous friend.
Man leaves his sweetheart in charge of friend. He tries to force his attentions upon her and then claims it was a test of fidelity.
Man takes his friend's mistress when the friend is away.
Treacherous counselor.
Other villains and traitors miscellaneous.
Treacherous astrologer.
Treacherous peoples (tribes).
Other deceptions.
Deception by equivocation.
The single cake. Restricted to a single cake during Lent, the peasants make one as large as a cart wheel.
Oath literally obeyed.
Oath literally obeyed: to tell no Christian. Woman thus sworn to secrecy talks to her unchristened child.
Saint, when forced to return to his monastery after swearing not to "come with his face before him," comes walking backwards.
Death message softened by equivocations. Various false explanations are given to prepare the hearer.
One day and one night. Saint has tribute remitted for a day and a night, i.e. forever, because there is but one day and one night in time.
One day and one night: object borrowed for a day and a night retained.
King induced by saint to remit tribute till Luan.  ". Luan" means both "Monday" and "Doomsday.
Water-monster allows saint to place cauldron over its head until Luan.
Peasant betrays fox by pointing. The peasant has hidden the fox in a basket and promised not to tell. When the hunters come, he says, "The fox just went over the hill," but points to the basket.
Thieves dig field and drain tank when miser says gold is hidden there.
Deception by equivocation miscellaneous.
One foot in Ireland, one in Scotland. Man carries sods of two countries with him that his whereabouts will be so defined.
Warrior proposes to fight in single combat. Fights with aid of sons and grandsons. They belong to him.

Saint hides fugitive from king underground. When king demand fugitive, saint (who never lies) replies, "Verily, I know not where he is, if he is not under thee even where thou art. " The king is satisfied and departs. Later suspects trick and arrests fugitive.
Deception by frightening.
Corpse set up to frighten people.
Man who killed mother uses her corpse to get presents.
Dummy set up as corpse to frighten people.

The three hunchback brothers drowned. A drunken man is employed, by the woman who has accidently slain three hunchback brothers, to throw one into the river. He does so. Then she puts another out and finally the third. The man thinks they keep coming to life. Finally he sees the woman's hunchback husband and drowns him.
The cowardly duelers. In the war between the wild and the domestic animals, the cat raises her tail; the wild animals think that it is a gun and flee.

Fox's tail drops and frightens animals. In war between birds and quadrupeds the fox's lifted tail is to be the signal for the attack. Gnats sting the fox under the tail. He drops it and the quadrupeds flee.
He-goat bleats and frightens animals assembled for fight.
Old woman and tiger flee in terror from each other.
Hiding from the strange animal. A cat shrieks and the frightened bear falls out of the tree and hurts himself.
Ferocious animal frightened by ass braying.
Devil frightened by threatening to bring mother-in-law.
Wolf-captor scared by fiddle-playing of captive ram, who escapes.
Parson is tricked into giving up his room. Is told there is a snake in it.
Tiger frightened away from man's tree refuge by man's stick and rope.
Wife, to drive away parasite priest, tells him husband has gone to get drunk and will kill him with rice mortar on his return. He leaves in haste.
Ogre frightened at rustling. Man sets juniper afire.
Tiger frightened at sound of clashing knives: thinks it is leak in house of which he is afraid.
Bear frightened by wife's sneezing.
Wooden image frightens away invaders.
Military strategy.
Animals help in military victory.
Sparrows of Cirencester. Fire is attached to birds who fly in and set fire to a besieged city.
Fire tied to foxes' tails: destroys enemy's cities and fields.
Bees thrown into redoubt drive out enemies.
Bees carried in drum attack and defeat attacking army.
Ashes transformed into bees, wasps, scorpions and snakes drive invading army away for hero.
Mice and hogs let loose put elephant cavalry to flight.
Elephant drunk with toddy sent to attack enemy.
Horses frightened by instruments of war are backed into enemy's ranks.
Birds frighten enemy's horses so that they throw their riders down.
Wild horses with bags containing stones tied to their tails, driven into enemy's camp to cause stampede.
Horse with basket of powdered peppers sent into hostile camp: enemy overcome.
Hot pepper mixed with flour supplying enemy camp. Thinking they have been poisoned, they beat a retreat.
Wild fawn sent by saint into hostile army, so that all follow it and leader (enemy of saint) is slain.
Strategy to get into enemy city: huge rat makes a burrow.
Women spread shawls on enemy's path and entangle them. They are easily defeated.
Fresh hides spread so that enemy slips and falls.
Treasure cast down crushes besiegers.
Treacherous priests prolong mass to let enemy destroy city.
Women throw ashes in eyes of attacking soldiers, so that they are defeated.
Man blinded by throwing dust in his eyes: he is robbed.
Disguise to enter enemy's camp (castle).
Disguise to spy on enemy.
Owner admitted into his own castle, captured in his absence, in guise of a monk. He has given news to conqueror of his purported death.
Disguise as musician to enter enemy's camp.
Disguise as pilgrim to enter enemy's camp (castle).
Disguise as old man to enter enemies' camp.
Rabbi feigns death to be carried out of the besieged city and to approach enemy.
Weapons disguised permit entry to enemies' camp.
Woman disguises as man to enter enemy's camp. Slays enemy king.
Disguise in killed enemy's clothes to enter enemy's castle.
Disguise as woman to enter enemy's camp (castle).
Disguise as beggar (pauper) to enter enemy's camp (castle) or to spy.
Disguise as merchant to enter enemy's castle.
Disguise as leper to enter enemy's camp.
Disguise as carpenter (tradesman) to enter enemy's camp.
Disguise as juggler to enter enemy's camp.
Disguise as churl (bachlach) to enter enemy's hall.
Capture by hiding warriors in baskets on back of oxen driven into enemy's camp on pretence that food is being brought.
Man disguised as animal sent among enemy that first blood be spilled by other side.
Woman saves herself from soldiers by receiving them joyfully rather than fearfully.
Capture of castle by feigning death.
Spies' false report of enemies' weakness brings on premature attack.
Enemy's ships fired by use of fireship.
Enemies defeated by setting forest afire.
Enemy induced to give up siege.
Enemy induced to give up siege by pretending to have plenty of food.
Enemy induced to surrender city by show of wealth on part of besiegers, who shoot golden apples over walls.
Enemy soldiers persuaded by show of great wealth and generosity of king to desert to his side.
City is falsely promised to enemy. When they enter they are attacked and defeated.
Trickster admits defeat: enemy and friends invited to fort for ceremony and then attacked.
Besieger scatters beads in protecting hedge: besieged destroy hedge to find beads.
Enemy deceived into overestimating opponents: retreat.
Sound of artillery is simulated to overawe enemy.
Persons run wagon back and forth over a corduroy bridge to simulate sound of artillery.
Sounds of mock battle scare away attacking force.
Sounds of battle in playhouse scare away attacking soldiers.
Sham doctor prescribes medicine for king's army;  they fall ill; invading army, seeing multitudes being carried away in litters, flee, thinking there is a plague.
Enemy induced to give up siege by making it look as if the besieged have got reinforcement.
Military strategy miscellaneous.
Marauder pretends beggary that king will underestimate his power.
Division of warriors hidden in pit on battlefield. Emerge during battle.
Largest part of fleet does not emerge until late in battle.
Treacherous king participates in battle only when he sees who is likely to win.
Treacherous ruler of city under siege sends sons to deliver city to enemy.
Postponing of payment asked in order to get time to gather reinforcements.
Besiegers drowned by diversion of river.
Military strategy: city won by turning river from its course through city. Enemy soldiers march through empty bed into city.
Shammed discussing of peace while getting reinforcements.
Cauldron containing lighted torch brought into enemy's camp ostensibly to be used for serving food: torch uncovered as signal for attack.
Fairy mist mistaken for smoke of enemy's burning ships.
Hero causes confusion in enemy camp in dead of night: army men fall upon one another, convinced the enemy has infiltrated their camp.
Poisoned food sent to enemy camp.
Enemy leaders invited to banquet and poisoned.
Brambles heaped in ford to halt enemies.
Miscellaneous deceptions.
Deceiving the higher powers (God, the saints, the gods, fate).
Heaven entered by a trick.
Heaven entered by trick: permission to pick up cap. Trickster throws a cap or leather apron inside the gate.
Heaven entered by trick: demanding back the charity gift. The trickster demands of Peter an article which he has given in charity. He then sits on it as his own property within the gates.
Heaven entered by trick: "wishing sack" thrown in. Trickster wishes himself in the sack.
Heaven entered by trick: sitting on Peter's chair.
Heaven entered by trick: slipping in along with holy person.
Heaven entered by trick: angel tricked by drink into telling woman how to enter.
Gods tricked into help in escaping one's fate.

Ingeniously worded boon asked of God combines riches, issue, and restoration of eyesight: "Oh God!. I want to see from above the seventh story of my mansion my great-grandsons playing in the streets and eating their cakes from golden vessels.
Dog sent ahead so as to avoid seeing husband transformed.
Enemies reconciled by gifts which the one's son tells are sent from the other.
The returned box on the ears. At table each gives his neighbor a box on the ears. The soldier is to give it to the king, but he returns it to the courtier from whom he has received it.
Entering a garden by swimming down a stream that flows into it.
Temporary advantage gained by pretending to yield in a combat.
Person allowed to win first game so that he will play for higher stakes.
Warrior consents to flee for the sake of future victory.
Enemies deceived through shammed flight.
Ammunition saved till enemy has used his.
Hero sleeps during the first part of battle and emerges only later.
Ruler diverts attention from misgovernment by beginning a war.
One animal injures another by deception.
Bird plucks another bird's feathers out.
Dwarf-deer pastes other animal's eyes shut and pretends that hunters are coming.
Tying cat to balky horse's tail to make him move.
Man tricked to be one's sworn brother in order to secure his help against his mother.
Demon enters person and refuses to leave until wishes have been fulfilled.
Attempt to kill by throwing knife.
Victorious youngest child.
Victorious youngest son.
Name of victorious youngest son.
Thirteen" as name of victorious youngest son. (Youngest of thirteen brothers.)
Abused son of younger co-wife becomes hero.
Fortunate youngest son. Always has good luck.
Seal of humiliation put by youngest brother-in-law on the back of his rivals.
Favorite youngest son.
Compassionate youngest son. Kind to people or animals: rewarded.
Youngest wife's son restores eyesight to blinded six wives of raja and reinstates his mother.
Stupid youngest son becomes clever.
Youngest brother helps elder.
Only the youngest brother helps his sister perform dangerous task.
Younger brother given birthright of elder.
Victorious youngest daughter.
Favorite youngest daughter.
Abused youngest daughter.
Compassionate youngest daughter.
Churlish person disregards requests of old person (animal) and is punished. Courteous person (often youngest brother or sister) complies and is rewarded.
Youngest daughter agrees to marry a monster; later the sisters are jealous.
Stepdaughter heroine.
Abused stepdaughter.
Clever youngest daughter.
Youngest daughter suspects impostor. Elder have been deceived.
Youngest daughter avoids seducer. Elder sisters have been deceived.
Youngest of group victorious.
Only the youngest of group of imprisoned women refuses to eat her newborn child.
Youngest animal in group overcomes adversary.
Unpromising hero (heroine).
Unpromising hero (male Cinderella). Usually, but not always, the unpromising hero is also the youngest son.
Unpromising hero: aged man.
Unpromising heroine. Usually, but not always, the youngest daughter.
Unpromising hero given great powers by deity.
Types of unpromising heroes (heroines).
Hero (heroine) of unpromising origin.
Exile returns and succeeds.
Banished youth becomes mighty king.
Fugitive bull-calf returns when grown and defeats his father.
Foundling hero.
Future hero found in boat (basket, bushes). Legends of Moses, Cyrus, Beowulf and others.
Future heroine found in hollow tree (calfshed, house "without door but only window and skylight").
Future hero found on shore.
Future hero found on top of a tree.
Future hero found in wolf den.
Heroine found in harp.
Widow's son as hero.
Orphan hero.
Orphan hero lives with grandmother. Avenges slaughtered kin.
Orphan heroine.
Orphan brothers as heroes.
Mistreated orphan hero.
Bastard hero.
Anchorite's son as hero.
Future hero (heroine) raised by animal.
Heroes sons of wife not favorite of king.
Heroine daughter of wife not favorite of king.
Hero of story neglected grandson of raja.
Unpromising fourth son succeeds.
Hero (heroine) of unpromising appearance.
Monster as hero.
Loathly man father of supernaturally born boy.
Very small hero.
Deformed child as hero.
Hero with deformed head.
Dirty boy as hero.
Burnt-belly" as hero.
Scar-face" as hero.
Skin-sore as hero.
Leper hero.
Lame child as hero.
Ugly child becomes great poet.
One-armed hero.
Heroine born with pigeon's head.
Hero (heroine) of unpromising occupation.
Menial hero.
Heroine endures hardships with menial husband. Rewarded by his success.
Swineherd as hero.
Stable-boy as hero.
Mad fisherman as hero.
Shepherd as hero.
Goatherd as hero.
Cowherd hero.
Cowherd's daughter (foster child) as heroine.
Slave as hero.
Menial heroine.
Heroine has been goatherd.
Poor weaver as hero.
Peasant as hero.
Woodcutter hero.
Smith as hero.
Quack-doctor as hero.
Barber becomes king.
Tailor as hero.
Flute player as hero.
Hero (heroine) of unpromising habits.
Lazy hero.
Spendthrift hero.
Unruly hero.
Cheater as hero.
Hero with disgusting habits.
Successful foolish son.
Insane hero (heroine).
Stupid hero.
Half-wit successful.
Unsophisticated hero.
Pauper hero.
Penniless hero. Loved by a courtesan, he proves later to be a great man.
Dumb hero.
Child silent till seventh year.
Famous poet does not speak until he is fourteen (four, seven) years old.
Silent hero.
Abode of unpromising hero (heroine).
Hearth abode of unpromising hero (heroine).
Ashes abode of unpromising hero.
Pig-sty abode for unpromising hero (heroine).
Unpromising son leaves his home and goes into the world.
Unpromising hero must live in hut.
The unpromising surpasses the promising.
Stupid person surpasses clever.

The stupid monk recovers the stolen flocks. A nobleman steals the abbot's flocks, saying that the monks have no use for them since they eat no meat. The most learned of the monks tries to recover them, but without success. The most stupid is then sent. Asked to dinner, he eats till he can hold no more. He tells the nobleman that he ate as much as possible since he could take back with him only what he had in his stomach. The nobleman pleased with the reply returns the flocks.
Simpleton's naive answer to robbers makes them think he knows their secret. They share their loot with him.
Hero stupid at games but fleet of foot.
Inept child eventually surpasses others.
Pupil surpasses master.
Pupil surpasses thieves in stealing.
Pupil surpasses magician.
Son surpasses father in skill.
Poor man surpasses rich.
Poor girl chosen as wife in preference to rich.
Poor suitor makes good husband; rich suitor cruel.
Ignorant surpasses learned man.
Ignorant steward straightens his master's accounts. The educated stewards have always cheated. The ignorant puts his belongings in one box, his master's in another. Both master and steward gain.
Farmer surpasses astronomer and doctor in predicting weather and choosing food.
Ugly preferred to pretty sister.
Ugly sister helps pretty one.
Neglected surpasses favorite child.
Ape tries to flee with favorite child; neglected child saves himself. The favorite child is killed through the mother's overanxiety.
Tardy surpasses punctual.
Tardy bird alone succeeds at bird convocation.
Slowness surpasses haste.
If you hasten you will not get there. In spite of the saint's advice the teamster hastens and breaks his wagon.
Peasant girl outwits prince.
Daughter succeeds on quest where son fails.
Scorning stops when it turns out that the scorned has saved the king by fighting alone against four.
Disagreeable and disliked child surpasses the likeable one.
Unpromising hero kills those who scorn him.
Lowly hero overcomes proud rivals.
Success of the unpromising hero (heroine).
Lowly hero marries princess.
Marriage of poor boy and rich girl.
Fool wins beautiful woman as wife.
Mercenary soldier (exile) accepted lover of princess.
Lowly heroine marries prince (king).
Lowly boy becomes king. (Most references to +L161 apply here).
Lowly successful hero invites king and humbles him.
Lowly successful soldier invites general and humbles him.
Despised boy wins race.
Despised boy wins gambling game.
Modesty brings reward.
Modest choice best.
Modest choice: three caskets type. Objects from which choice is to be made are hidden in caskets (or the like). The worst looking casket proves to be the best choice.
Choice among several gifts. The worst horse, armor, or the like proves best.
Saint, offered any gift from God, chooses (virginity and) wisdom.
Solomon, offered any gift from God, chooses wisdom. Granted wisdom and wealth.
Hero prefers fame to long life.
Fame (honor) is more enduring than life.

Modest choice proves good (simple unique privilege). Girl offered reward of five villages chooses rather to be only one on certain night to be allowed to have light in her house and to keep all animals who enter as hers. All kinds of livestock come.
Poor girl chosen rather than the rich. Treasure follows.
Modest choice best: wife chosen from crowd of women only one poorly dressed.
Choice of ugliest girl as bride.
Old chosen rather than new. Fortunate choice.
Unpromising magic object chosen. Hero refuses to take one that cries out "take me!
Poor game proves rich.

Accustomed rags preferred to new garments. A Brahmin returns home to find a palace instead of a cottage; he recognizes his wife only after she throws off her jewels and ornaments to stand before him in her old rags.
Former poverty chosen over new riches. Weaver laments loss of water vessel. Offered many new, but prefers old and modest life.
Modest request best.

Modest request: present from the journey. Asked what her father shall bring her as a present, the heroine chooses a modest gift. It is usually a flower but sometimes does not turn out to be such a simple gift after all (golden cloak, golden apple).
Present from the journey: what you first see.
Modest choice: parting gift. Small gift with blessing preferred to large gift with parent's curse.
Modest choice for parting gift money or counsels. Counsels chosen.
Modest parting gift best meat or bones. Bones thrown to pursuing dogs delay them and allow escape; not so with meat.
Modest choice for parting gift: when offered money man takes magic stick.
Modest choice of parting gift: magic iron measure chosen.
Hero refuses reward. Rides away without it.
Modest business plans best.
Beggar with small bag surpasses the one with the large. Latter refuses all but large donations; gets none.
Modesty brings reward miscellaneous.

Prosperity forever or for a day?. King asks prince whether he has secret of prosperity forever or a day. Prince says "forever" and is captured. Later his wife, asked same question, says "for a day" and is honored.
Triumph of the weak.
Hermes distributes wit. Gives everyone the same measure of wit, so that the smaller are more clever than the large.
Weak overcomes strong in conflict.
Weak (small) hero overcomes large fighter.
Sick hero overcomes antagonist.
Poorly-armed hero overcomes well-armed by strategy.
Poor prince overcomes king.
Little innocent girl is able to drive giant out of land.
Small boy overcomes enraged gorilla.
Little strong man defeats giant in race.
Small animal overcomes large.
Bird flies into large animal's ear and kills him.
Mouse runs into buffalo's ear and overcomes him.
Mouse torments bull who cannot catch him.
Fox burns tree in which eagle has nest. Revenges theft of cub.
Mother ape burns bear. Revenges theft of her young.
Lark causes elephant to fall over precipice.
Elephant killed by mouse who runs up open end of trunk to head and there smears poison over his brain.
Insects worry large animal to despair or death.
Dungbeetle keeps destroying eagle's eggs. Eagle at last goes to the sky and lays eggs in Zeus's lap. The dungbeetle causes Zeus to shake his apron and break the eggs.
Fish pricks monster with fins and defeats him.
Falcon attacks eagle repeatedly and defeats him.
Mice overcome camel.
Lizard defeats leopard.
Rabbit slays rhinoceros.
Hedgehog defeats tiger by jumping into tiger's mouth and tormenting him.
Ants overcome serpent.
Small animals dupe larger into trap.
Offended rats gnaw saddle girths of king's horses so that he is defeated in battle.
Mice win war with woodcutters.
Easy escape of weak (small).
Little fishes escape from the net. The large are caught.
Mice escape into their holes; weasels cannot follow them.
Hummingbird can see fowler's net; eagle is caught in spite of his boasts of good eyesight.
Mildness triumphs over violence.
Mildness triumphs over violence: queen advises husband to use kindness to enemies. This wins them over where war failed.
Saint uses kind words to pagan priest who has just smitten a Christian. This causes pagan to repent. Conversion follows.
Contest of wind and sun. Sun by warmth causes traveler to remove coat, while wind by violent blowing causes him to pull it closer around him.
Contest between wind (rain) and sun. Rain also tries unsuccessfully like wind.
Sun cursed by man for its burning rays, wind for its hot breath, but moon is blessed for its soft, cool, and beautiful light.
Mild brother triumphs over warlike. Survives him and inherits property.
Priest who gives mild penances succeeds where others fail.
Goldsmith gives money to one who addressed him as friend (the goldsmith had no friends because he has cheated everybody.)
Triumph of the weak-miscellaneous.
Needle kills an elk. Slips into his stomach.
Reed pricks and drives away dog that urinates on it.
Mouse stronger than wall, wind, mountain.
Mosquitoes sting King Pharaoh and show they are stronger than the man who cannot escape them.
Only love to offer. Bride asks suitors what they have to offer her. Poor youth who has nothing but love to offer gets her.
Slow flying swan lasts longer than speedy crow in flying.
Frog, tortoise, fish each tell of how long they expect to live. Frog alone does not expect to live to a hundred and ten years and alone escapes fisherman's net.
Pride brought low.
Proud ruler (deity) humbled.
Proud king humbled: realizes that pomp, possessions, power are all of short duration.
King, defeated in battle, obliged to flee without money.
Boasting king insulted by crow dropping filth on him.
Defeated king must be peddler or beggar.
King overthrown and made servant.
Ruler enslaved.
Queen forced to become a courtesan.

Proud king displaced by angel. (King in the bath.) While the king is in the bath (or hunting) an angel in his form takes his place. The king is repulsed on all sides until he repents of his haughtiness.
Rich man made poor to punish pride. He boasts that God has no power to make him poor. While he is at church, his property burns and he returns home poor.
Woman casts ring into sea boasting that it is as impossible for her to become poor as for the ring to be found. Ring is found in fish: she becomes poor.
Proud inscriptions sole remains of powerful king.
King vainly forbids tide to rise. (Canute.)
King vainly attempts to measure the height of the sky and the depth of the sea.
God punishes David for his pride in the number of his subjects. An angel is sent to kill his people. Desists only when David repents.
King commanded to wear enemy's shoes on his shoulders as sign of submission.
Proud king humbled when imprisoned by enemies.
God finds that his statue sells at low price. He prices it in a statue shop and finds that his price is lower than other gods.
King shown he is less powerful than God. In spite of all his plans, his servant recovers the lost (exchanged) treasure.
Proud ruler (deity) humbled miscellaneous.
Goose boasts superiority to mushroom. Both served up at same meal.
King (prince) becomes beggar.
Overweening ambition punished.
Overweening ambition punished. Man sets self up as a god.
Attempt to fly to heaven punished. Car supported by eagles.
Attempt to climb to heaven punished.
Peter acts as God for a day: tires of bargain. A girl takes her goat to pasture and leaves him: "My God care for you! " Peter must run everywhere after the goat.
Man who has never known unhappiness or want is swallowed up by earth with all his household.
Dream (prophecy) of future greatness causes banishment (imprisonment).
Poor man aspires to high office: made a cook.
Arrogance repaid.
Arrogant mistress repaid in kind by her lover.
Haughty mistress makes extravagant demands of lover: repaid. (Glove and the Lion.)
Scorned lover poses as rich man and cheats his scornful mistress.
Sneering princess is impregnated by magic.
Impoverished husband begs from wife's new husband. He has formerly refused this man charity.
Cruel brothers brought to beg charity from abused sister.
Impoverished father begs from daughter he has banished: recognized.
Impoverished father begs from his prosperous daughter whom he has made to marry a poor man.
Impoverished husband begs from wife he has formerly expelled.
Impoverished youngest brother comes to elders in search of work.
Arrogant farmer allows none to ride his precious horse without permission. He kills the man who does it, but is in revenge deprived of most of his goods.
Self-righteousness punished.
Self-righteous hermit must do penance. He has said of a condemned man that he deserves his punishment.
Self-righteous monk rebuked by abbot. Abbot tells him to search his own heart to see if he is free of sin before attacking others.
Self-righteous woman punished. She has passed judgment on a girl who has a bastard.
Woman with three hundred sixty-five children. Punished for self-righteous condemnation of unchaste girl.
Self-righteous tailor in heaven expelled. Throws God's footstool at an old woman thief on earth.
The beggar on the cross in place of Christ. Is made to leave the cross for his impatience concerning the sinners.
Proud animal less fortunate than humble.
Wild animal finds his liberty better than tame animal's ease.
Tame bird and wild bird. The tame bird tells the wild one to look about him. He is shot.
Wild ass envies tame ass until he sees his burdens.
Wolf prefers liberty and hunger to dog's servitude and plenty.
Parrot prefers cold wet nest in freedom to luxury in royal palace.
Ass is jealous of the horse until he learns better.
Ass jealous of horse, but sees horse later working in a mill.
Ass jealous of war-horse until he sees him wounded.
Mule carrying corn escapes while one carrying gold is robbed.
Lean dogs envy arena-dog his fatness. Later see their error.
Calf pities draft ox: is taken to slaughter, ox spared.
Pride brought low miscellaneous.
Stag scorns his legs but is proud of his horns. Caught by his horns in trees.
Fox destroys nest of bird who boasts of nest's warmth.
The mule's double ancestry. When well fed says, "My mother was a thoroughbred horse. " Later, hard worked, says, "My father was a miserable ass.
The man scorns the storm: killed by it.
Zeus smites Capaneus while he is climbing a ladder.
Pride or wealth of man brought low by actions of gods.
Oil lamp blown out: had thought that it outshone stars.
Jackal singing about his deeds falls down from tree and is eaten by alligator.
Gnats having overcome lion are in turn killed by spider.
Men too prosperous (happy): things are made more difficult.
Men are too rich: greedy gods created to impoverish them.
Men are too rich: gold sent below ground.
Men are too rich: weeds created to spoil their harvests.
Men are too proud: snakes created.
Men are fearless: tiger made to frighten them.
Men enjoy themselves too much: disease created.
Judgments and decrees.
Senseless judicial decisions.
Inhuman decisions of king.
Inhuman decision of king: sends man's sons to certain death and then murders man.
Deity settles disputes between races.
Irrevocable judgments.
Irrevocable judgment causes judge to suffer first. Has decreed that no one enter a meeting armed. He forgets to remove his sword. Kills himself.

Irrevocable sentence carried out even when innocence is proved. A knight condemned for murdering his comrade is met by the latter on the way to the gallows. A centurion leads them to the emperor, who condemns all three to death: first because he has been sentenced; second for causing by his absence the conviction of his comrade; third for delay in the execution.

Sentence applied to king's own son. Those caught in adultery are to have eyes put out. When king's son is found guilty he insists on the punishment. He finally compromises by having one of his own and one of his son's eyes put out.
Ruler has son beheaded for rape.
Captain hangs own son for violating order not to enter enemy city.
Gardener made king by minister decides against him in law case and returns lands to plaintiff.
Irrevocable judgment of king upheld. King leaves laws that must be kept until his death. Years later he has his bones sent back to that land to let people know that he is dead and they are free.
Short-sighted judgments.
King Lear judgment. A king flattered by his elder daughters and angered by the seeming indifference, though real love, of the youngest, banishes the youngest and favors the elder daughters.
Other judgments and decrees.
Decree that hero must wed only a virgin.
Judgment: pardon given if hero produces the lady about whom he has boasted.
Judgment: thief to be pardoned if he can steal king's treasure without being caught.
Judgments and decrees miscellaneous motifs.
Virgin Mary reverses judgments of church.
Decision left to first person to arrive.
Deity grants woman two sons, one to be wise and ugly and the other a fool and handsome.
Vows and oaths.
Punishment for broken oaths.
False swearer not allowed to approach altar.
Broken oaths cause of maimed people.
Death as punishment for broken oath.
Death caused by elements (exposure, drowning, etc.) as punishment for broken oath.
Man offers to sacrifice bangles if he is given a son; when he takes bangles back, son dies.
Broken oath causes girl's hand to wither.
Punishment for broken oath: loss of the inheritance of earth or heaven.
Equivocal oaths.
Escape from vengeance caused by broken oaths.
Vow fulfilled in next existence.
Violators of oaths.
Babylonians do not keep their oaths.
Taking of vows and oaths.
Swearing while one knows that his oath is rendered valueless.
Oath is valid only when decreed in presence of ten.
Oath uttered by pious when in danger of succumbing to temptation.
Oaths taken over severed pieces of horse. Pieces are then buried.
Oath taken on ring.
Oath taken on arms.
Oath taken on sword.
Oath taken on sacred object.
Oath on sacred book.
Oath by Tora.
Oath taken on holy stone.
Vows taken on holy swine.
Swearing on sacred relics.
Taking oath on cowdung.
Oath by touching sacred thread.
Only one oath binding. It must be by so and so or else it is worthless.
Three-fold oath.
Oath so heavy it dries up stream; oath so great it splits the rock in twain; oath so violent it makes the tree wither.
Oath taken on hand of saint.
Swearing on hand of king.
Swearing by saint's bachall.
Swearing by saint's bell.
Vow to perform certain act unless cataclysm occurs.
Swearing on a skull.
Taking of vows and oaths miscellaneous.
Swearing by the elements: sun, moon, stars, wind.
Oath by River Styx.
Swearing by (clan) gods.
Vows taken as an old Norse custom at the festival of Yule.
Vows taken by placing one's foot on a certain post in the hall.
Swearing on a stone.
Swearing by "the Seven Things which they serve.
Oath by placing hand on genitals.
Oath taken by the life of a person.
Swearing by one's father and mother.
Swearing by life of father.
Vows concerning personal appearance.
Vow not to shave or cut hair until a certain time.
Vow: woman not to bind hair till enemy is conquered.
Vow not to change clothes till a certain time.
Vow not to wash till a certain time.
Vows concerning sex.
Vow of chastity.
Vow of virginity.
Vow: man will love only a virgin.
Prince vows to marry no woman unless he can beat her daily.
Vow never to remarry.
Vow not to marry till iron shoes wear out.
Vow never to be jealous of one's wife.
Woman requires husband free from jealousy.
Vow to marry first person performing certain act.
Vow to marry off two daughters to first two men father looks at on the following morning.
Vow never to strive against a woman.
Vow never to carry a woman.
Vow to wed no man who cannot perform certain feat.
Vow to wed no man who fears to saddle and mount a lion.
Vow to marry a certain woman.
Vow to marry queen of fairies and not to eat or drink inside kingdom until this is done.
Boy vows to marry none but girl born under the same circumstances as he.
Vow that magically conceived children shall marry (or be friends).
Brother and sister arrange marriage of their unborn children to each other.
Vow to marry none but daughter of certain man.
Vow of enemy chief to marry princess of besieged city.
Vows concerning sex miscellaneous.
Lovers vow to marry only each other.
Vow to die rather than marry unwelcome suitor.
Vow to kill more successful rival.
Quarreling prince and princess vow that if they are married he will desert her on the wedding day and she will make him eat boiled rice and thin broth for six months. It so happens.
Oath to marry daughters only into family with bridegroom for each daughter.
Vow to get stubborn girl half-married only.
Vow only to marry daughter to the man who kills snake by her house.
Other vows and oaths.
Vow not to eat before hearing of adventure. Sir Gawayne and the Green Knight SS 5; Irish myth:
Vow not to eat before learning secret.
Vow not to marry until quest is concluded.
Vow not to reign and to starve to death unless picture's original is found.
Vow not to take food or drink until manner of father's death is learned.
Vow not to take food or drink until enemy is killed.
Vow not to eat or sleep until certain event is brought to pass.
Vow not to eat, drink, or move from position until dead anchorite comes himself to accept necklace.
Vow not to eat or drink before knowing if king is alive.
Heroine will not laugh till arrival of destined hero.
Vow not to eat until lost son is found.
Vow not to see friends until quest is completed.
Vow not to go to bed with wife till enemy is killed.
Vow not to kiss anybody until father is revenged.
Vow not to sit on father's high-seat until he is revenged.
Vow to perform act of prowess.
Vow to kill wild boar alone at night.
Vow to find vanished sister.
Vow never to flee from fire or weapon.
Vow to watch at frightful place all night.
Vow to ride the forest all night and slay all comers.
Vow never to refuse food to any man.
Vow never to flee in fear of death.
Vow to attack (kill) the enemy or die.
Vow to revenge (king, friends, father) or die.
Vow to live and die with the king.
Vow rather to die (on a spear) than to accept grace.
Rather die than go in the enemy's service.
Rather die in battle than in bed.
Vow not to be killed by a single opponent.
Vow never to make a nocturnal assault.
Bard vows that none of his profession will make a request of any man.
Vow to ask nobody for peace, grace.
Other vows about fighting.
Vow never to give more than one blow in a fight and never to beat a fallen enemy nor take his weapons.
Vow rather to be cut in pieces than permit oneself to be bound.
Vow to kill anyone who touches his beard.
Vow: never to fight with brother.
Oath not to fight relatives of king.
Vow to serve only the most generous of all kings.
Vow not to devastate country or take revenge after release.
Vow not to deceive the man who spared one's life.
Vow never to accept a man who does not know any sport.
Vow not to touch certain thing.
Vow never to touch money and to give what anyone begs for.
Vow not to touch certain tree. Later cannot cross bridge made of this wood.
Pledge to say but a single phrase. In carrying out this agreement the men innocently confess a crime.
Vow to change religion.
Vow to become a Christian.
King swears to become Christian if he wins battle.
Oath not to be christened until he has fought in seven battles for Jesus.
Prince vows that he will always be servant of a goddess (Kali).
Vow not to enter any house before reaching one's own.
Religious vows.
Vow to build shrine.
Vow to bathe in the Ganges.
Vow to find Holy Grail before returning to Round Table.
Vow to become monk should he escape execution.
Vow if queen bears another girl she and child will both be killed.
Vow that no daughter born to chief's wife will be allowed to live until she bears a son.
Vow to abide by laws.
Vow never to pass over demarcation line into other's property.
Oath to abide by results of lot drawing.
Oath not to mention what has been seen.
Vow to put to death every king that comes his way unless engaged in marrying a lady at the time he sees them.
Vow to destroy kingdom by austerities.
Bargains and promises.
Making of bargains and promises.
Bargain with God (by holy man).
Covenant between Israel and God.
Covenant between heathen and Israelites.
Blood covenant. Contract written (or signed) with blood.
Blood of contractors mixed to seal bargain.
Pact with devil signed in blood. (Theophilus.)
Covenant confirmed by eating together.
Spitting of all parties into vessel to seal bargain.
Covenant between saints confirmed by cutting off their thumbs.
Covenant confirmed by marriage.
Covenant confirmed by hostages.
Fulfilling of bargain or promise.
Bargain or promise to be fulfilled at all hazards.
Promise to be fulfilled when iron shoes wear out.
Prisoner would be set free only after he has used up a pair of harmed shoes.
Man keeps word to return to enemy if his mission to his people fails.
King's promise irrevocable.
King punishes one of his men who robs someone to whom the king has given safe conduct.
King kills self to carry out own promise.
King sells self and family into slavery to keep promise.
Demanding of promised boon postponed.
Demanding of promised boon postponed until an auspicious moment. Granted anything he may ask, the recipient waits to announce his choice.
Breaking of bargains or promises.
Promise kept in deed but not in spirit.
Animal punishes broken promise.
Turtle carrying man through water upsets him because of a broken promise.
Fish (whale) carrying man through water shakes him off when man strikes him with coconut.
Cat witness to betrothal punishes violator. Kills the man's son when he has married a different woman.
Curse as punishment for broken promise.
A man who breaks his oath to a woman cannot be king with right.
King breaks promise to care for man's family. Is caught trying to steal his money.
Promise made merely as a matter of form not binding.
Host offers to send his guest a cask of the wine he has praised. Later refuses to send it as it was merely a "verba honoris".
Land grants (bargains).
Price set on one's head.
Bargain with devil.
Man sells soul to devil. (Faust, Theophilus.)
Man unwittingly sells soul to devil. He jestingly offers to sell his soul. Devil in disguise buys it.
Man goes to well at midnight on Old Christmas to see water turned into wine. Just as it turns into wine the devil takes him, or injures him.
Man sells soul to devil in return for devil's building house (barn, etc.).
Man bequeaths soul to devil.
Jews must repay devil's help by giving tribute of persons each year.
Formulas for selling one's soul to  devil.
Man sells soul to devil for visit home in boat that sails through sky.
Man sells soul to devil for magic power to escape capture.
Man sells soul to devil for devil's doing one specific job.
Person sells soul to devil in return for the granting of wishes.
Devil agrees to help man with robberies.
Devil as helper of robber refuses to let women's ornaments be stolen. They are his own weapons.

Devil at gallows repudiates his bargain with robber. Ring turns to rope. The judge cannot find a rope and is about to release the thief because of the miracle. But the ring in the box presented by the devil as a bribe turns out to be a rope. The man is hanged.
Devil as substitute for day laborer at mowing. He mows with a magic sickle. The evil overseer tries to keep up with him and dies of overexhaustion.
Devil to help gambler in exchange for one task yearly.

With his whole heart: devil carries off judge. The devil refuses to take anything not offered him with the whole heart. He hears the judge (advocate) cursed for fraud with such sincerity that he carries him off.
Devil bargains to help man become priest. He must not later exorcise him from people.
The devil helps man study for priesthood. For this, he must promise the devil his soul. Having become a great priest, the man finds means to save himself.

The devil makes the herdsman's son a priest in return for a whistle. After quarreling with the devil, who asked to repair the whistle during Mass, the priest forgets all he learned and does not know how to hold Mass. Is beaten.
Devil bargains to help man win woman.
Servant makes pact with devil denying Christ to secure nobleman's daughter.
Contract with the devil destroyed.
Pacts with the devil, sealed in blood, made ineffective by a saint.
Other devil contract motifs.
Bargain with the devil for an heir.
Devil fetches man contracted to him.
Devil appears in great storm, takes away soul of person contracted to him.
Devil flays corpse of person contracted to him.
Man contracted to the devil responds to call by voice: "The hour has come but not the man.
Devil carries off hunt-loving priest.
Body of devil's disciple is removed from coffin by devil.
Devil puts body of convert on a sea monster which takes it away.
Familiars guard and protect those who have pact with the devil.
Familiar devours whoever does not keep pact with devil.
Other bargains.
Beheading bargain. Giant allows hero to cut off his head; he will cut off hero's later.
Hag offers to run race with men on condition that the one left behind shall be beheaded. Marvelous runner beheads hag.
Man umpires dispute in exchange for guarantee of safety. Disputants, bear and tiger, agree not to eat him.
Blind promise (rash boon). Person grants wish before hearing it.
Person who never refuses a request.
Eyes exchanged for food. A starving man lets himself be blinded in return for food.
Horse, clothes, and members of rider's body exchanged for food.
In return for magic shirt from girl hero is to stay in Ireland for three years. In return he claims her as wife.
Free keep in inn exchanged for good story.
Prince to give up life in exchange for learning a secret.
Three deformed witches invited to wedding in exchange for help.
Life spared in return for life-long service.
Life spared in return for poetic mead.
Life spared for bringing a dreaded enemy without weapon.
Life bought for gold.
Life bought with promise of reparations and healing of enemy.
Bargain: woman rides naked through streets to obtain freedom for citizens. Godiva.
Peace bought for husband.
Bargain to save face.
Opponents agree not to fight and are thus undefeated.
Bargain: to divide all winnings.
Dividing the winnings: half of the bride demanded. When the hero shows that he is willing to carry out the bargain, his helper relents.

Dividing the winnings: presents (favors) from man's own wife. After the agreement to divide all winnings the first man receives favors (presents, kisses) from the second's wife. He faithfully delivers them.
Bargains and promises between mortals and supernatural beings.
Mortal fosters fairy child to prevent destruction of crops.
Contract between hungry god and untouchable: to give gods food it they will eat from his hands.
Ogre released in return for his magic girdle.
Bargains between men and animals.
Bargain with king of mice.
Captured bird promises to deliver fifteen birds in exchange for freedom.
Covenant of friendship.
Covenant of friendship between animals.
Covenant of friendship between elephant and jackal.
Covenant of friendship between louse and crow.
Covenant of friendship: no matter how poor son of one is, daughter of other will accept him as groom.
Covenant of friendship: to secure brides for each other.
Promises connected with death.
Dying man's promise will be kept.
Promise of dying man to bring news of other world. (Or two friends agree that the first to die shall bring news.)
Friends in life and death. In pursuance of the pledge, the living follows the other to the world of the dead.
Promise to be buried with wife if she dies first.
Deathbed promise concerning the second wife. Promises his dying wife that he will not marry unless the bride meets the specifications the dying wife imposes.
Promise to dying man broken.
Sons break promise to have masses for father's soul.  ". If he is in Hell it will do him no good; if he is in Heaven he won't need it; and if he is in Purgatory he can purge himself.

Dying monster's request and promise. Hero is to drink his blood, suck his eyes and brains, and give his heart to his loved one to eat. He will become marvelously strong and his wife will have three sons and four daughters with great powers.
Dying hero's request and promise to disciples.
Murdered person's request and promise.
Promise to dying man sacred.
Promise to dying father leads to adventures.
Promise to dying father not to wed woman of certain tribe.
Promise to dying father to bury him in his homeland.
Other promises.
Chaste woman promises herself to her lover when the rocks leave the coast. (They are moved by magic.)
Chaste woman promises herself to her lover when he can make a garden bloom in winter.
Raja to marry girl when cut mango branch blooms.
Princess promises to embrace her teacher on her wedding day. Teacher has only been testing her promise.
Person promises to have but one consort if he is cured.
Retreat in return for cessation of attack. Host agrees to march back a day's journey if warrior will cease his feats of arms upon them until a certain battle in the future.
Man promises to build church if he is saved at sea.
Promise to give another one's wife for a day.
Marriage promised to save life.
Sons agree to meet at father's grave after they have been out in world for one year to learn trade.
Supernatural woman promises to return if she gives birth to a boy.
Bargains and promises miscellaneous.
Trickster undertakes impossible bargains and collects his part. Trusts that in the year he is given either he or the other will die.
Wife undertakes man's penances for him:  also to go to heaven for him?. He has a dream and when he sees that she also goes to heaven for him he decides against the bargain.
Covenant: one nation not to wrest city from inhabitants without their consent.
Divine promise not to destroy sinful city if righteous live there.
Bargain to keep secret.
Tiger lets man go on condition he does not tell what he has overheard.
Two men in love agree to have nothing to do with the girl without the other's consent.

Prophecy by Jesus that certain people shall live "till coming of Patrick. "  So it was.

Prophetic gift received from another prophet.
Suppression of prophecy.

Prophet speaks six nights each year.
Wild man as prophet.
Old woman as prophet.

Druids as prophets.
Prophecies from old man who writes in a book.
Saints (holy men) as prophets.
Anchorite prophesies at childbirth.
Cuchulinn prophesies birth of 50 women. Shall be loyal folk to God.
Fairies as prophets.
Banshees as portents of misfortune.
Biblical worthy as prophet.
Moses as prophet.
David as prophet.
Abraham as prophet.
Personification prophesies.
Half-wit as prophet.
Fool (entertainer) as prophet.
Angels as prophets.
Spirit as prophet.
Three fates, "norns", prophesy at child's birth.
Icelandic guardian spirits, " spbdnsar", prophesy victory.
Summoned dead prophesies.
Mountain in human shape prophesies whole family's death.
Gods prophesy both good and evil about hero's fate.
King as prophet.
King in will foretells that daughters of his son shall be fruitful.
Poet as prophet.
Smith as prophet.
Child as prophet.
Sibyl as prophet. Writes on leaves blown about by winds.

Prophesying through knowledge of animal languages.
Man's fate written on his skull.
Fate written on the head.
Man's destiny read in his face.
Descent into hell to learn future.
Horoscope taken by means of stars.
Astrology forbidden.
Tasks assigned so as to learn future.

Enigmatical prophecy: what thou sowest thou shalt not reap, etc. (Thou shalt have children and they shall not die, etc.) Jewish: Neuman, Gaster Exempla 217 No. 144, Gaster Oldest Stories 205.
Two sons: one a purse cutter and the other a killer. Wife tells husband that they will make a purse designer of one, and a butcher of the other.
Enigmatical prophecy: princess will wed physician, fisherman and prince all in one. Man puts on the guise of all three, one on top of another.
Enigmatical prophecy: "He that is to kill you shall grow up in Braja (a place).
Enigmatical prophecy: "He who will kill your child is not here, but in the village."

Prophecy: future greatness and fame.
Prophecy: preeminence of man's descendants.
Prophecy of preeminence to descendants of man provided they do the will of saint to be born.
Prophecy: future greatness of unborn child.
Heroic career prophesied for (new-born) child.
Prophecy: birth of hero at certain time (in certain place).
Prophecy: conception of hero at certain time.
Prophecy: child to be born.
Prophecy: child to be born to childless couple.

Prophecy: man will eat magic salmon and gain knowledge.

Prophecy: sinners to be burnt by fire on Doomsday.

Prophecy: death from hands of man with one sandal.

Prophecy: death by tiger. Tiger-shaped cake becomes tiger and kills man in spite of all precautions.
Prophecy: death from tiger. Tiger picture comes to life and kills man.
Prophecy: death by lightning.
Prophecy: death through future husband.
Prophecy: death through spindle wound.
Prophecy: death by means of bone.
Prophecy: death at hands of man bearing a certain name.
Prophecy: death from thorns in rice.
Prophecy: king to be slain by certain spear unless it is given when demanded.
Prophecy: death in battle.
Hero kept from going to battle lest he be slain.
Prophecy: death at hands of certain person.
Prophecy: wholesale slaughter to be inflicted by colossal wheel rolling over Europe.
Prophecy: death from snakebite.
Prophecy (through dream): death from cobra.
Prophecy: death by calf.
Prophecy: death by hanging.
Prophecy: death by alligator (crocodile).
Prophecy: man to be swallowed up by earth at the foot of his stairs.
Prophecy: king's son to die for lack of water.

Prophecy: death in Jerusalem. Man dies in Jerusalem Chamber.

Prophecy: death on seashore.
Prophecy: criminal going to death predicts that his judge (king, prince) shall soon meet him.
Prophecy: either youth or mother will die.
Prophecy: person foretells own death.
Prophecy of downfall of kingdom.
Prophecy of downfall of king (prince).
Prophecy: son-to-be to destroy lineage.
Parricide prophecy. In spite of all attempts to thwart the fates, the child kills his father.
Parricide prophecy: king's successors will be parricides.

Prophecy: torture "with varied tortures."

Prophecy of famine.

Prophecy: certain hero to achieve Holy Grail.
Prophecy: death of ruler to insure victory.

Prophecy: woman to be ancestress of David and the Messiah.

Immunity from wet or dry, steel or wood, sword or javelin, by day or by night. Man killed at edge of sea, at twilight, with force of sea and thunderbolt.

Prophecies that person will tell three (two) falsehoods before death.
