Curse: god to live life of a cat for twelve full years in house of huntsman on earth.
Irrevocable curse.

Curse given to negate good wish. Odin gives man life three times the normal; Thor ordains that in each he is to commit crime. Odin gives him the choicest weapons; Thor denies him landed property, etc.
Curse: appetite of twelve men. Given with the gift of twelve men's strength.
Curse: eternal life without eternal youth.
Method of cursing.
Curse by "building a fire of stones" in fireplace. The person who removes the stones is cursed.
Enduring and overcoming curses.
Release from curse with birth of child.
Curse transferred to another person or thing.
Curse removed when victims reform.
Curse changed by God into blessing.
Curse on everybody on earth who listens to the fatal mentioning of trolls' names, is evaded by person in cave, because he is in the earth.
Curse mitigated by deity when superhuman task is performed.
Miscellaneous ways to overcome curses.
Release from curse by burning vomit.
Release from curse by putting pins around horse's heart and then boiling it.
Release from curse by burning animal in straw pile.
Release from curse by heating the colter of the plow in the stove.
Release from curse by pricking louse and hanging it on wall.
Release from curse by putting a five cent piece in the churn.
Release from curse by putting a piece of silver in the gun.
Curses on persons.
Curse: bodily injury.
Curse: loss of eye.
Curse: toads from mouth.
Curse: fire to burn hands and feet.
Curse: arm to fall off.
Curse: hand of person cursed to drop off.
Curse: wound not to heal.
Wicked stepmother cursed to have fire lit under her.
Curse: leprosy.
Curse of sterility on wife of enemy.
Curse: head to split in seven pieces.
Curse: to be plagued by nightmares.
Curse: to be carried off by evil spirit.
Endless sleep given Endymion.
Curse: to be swallowed by a siren.
Curse: not to taste food from own table. Food always seized by harpies.
Curse: prince to fall in love with witch's daughter.
Curse: monstrous birth.
Curse: "What I carry may you carry; what you carry may I carry.". Cat thus causes ungrateful pregnant woman to bear cats and herself to bear twin girls.
Jealous sisters curse the child one of them may have by the god Thor, so that it never will grow nor thrive.
Curse: humiliation.
Curse: man (poet) to kiss a leper.
Curse: hero not to be able to stand the sight of blood.
Girl bewitched so that no man will remain faithful to her.
Curse: hero to remain as dead till the curser dies.
Dying father condemns weak son to be servant of his brothers.
Curse: failure in all undertakings.
Curse: man's sword will fail in danger.
Curse: when brothers' swords bite the very best, they will all be killed by a single man.
Curse: deformity.
Curse: descendants to be unshapely.
Curse: she-wolf to carry off man's genitals.
Curse: privation.
Curse: lack of food, shelter, good company.
Curse of childlessness.
Curse laid on unborn child; it is stillborn.
Giant cursed: may neither heaven nor earth receive him.
Curse: undertaking dangerous quest.
Curse: undertaking dangerous revenge of father.
Curse: to sink into the earth.
Curse: ground shall swallow children.
Curse: death.
Death by suicide.
Death by drowning.
Curse: insanity.
Curse: corpse to be put in three different places after person's death.
Curse: change of sex.
Curse: restlessness.
Hero cursed to restlessness (except on boat or in tent), till he sees girl.
Curse: not to be able to love the same woman more than twelve months.
Thrall cursed to sit on chest and yell and never have rest.
Curse: couple to wander until new seat of race is pointed out.
Curse of petrifaction.
Miscellaneous curses on persons.
Curse: woman will not travel far.
Curses on families.
Curse: children will be sick.
Curse: descendants of nine robbers never to exceed nine.
Curse on village: descendants never to exceed certain number.
Curse: race to lose sovereignty.
Curse on tribe (district).
Curse of a woman against her caste: they should remain unclothed and untaught.
Curses on objects or animals.
Curses on animals.
Curse: cow will give red milk.
Curse: milk will not turn to butter.
Cursing to make pigs lean.
Curse: horses will die.
Curse: horse will be lame.
Curse on land.
Curse on a city.
Curse on a city: never to grow.
Curse on river.
Curse on river or sea: no fish in it from that day.
Curse on lake.
Curse on lake: fire from lake will burn the forest around it.
Curses miscellaneous.
Presence of cursed person brings disaster to land.
Whomsoever demons curse is blessed, and vice versa.
Wagers and gambling.
Gamblers.
Gambling caused by possession of men by evil demons.
Hero makes fortune through gambling.
Conquering gambler. Bankrupt gambler gets supernatural power and wins back his fortune.
The miracle of broken die at gambling saves man.
Dice made from bones from graveyard.
Betting contest between two kings.
Extraordinary stakes at gambling.
Play for unnamed stakes.
Stakes not claimed by winner, who insists on another game.
Own body as stake: to be taken as slave.
Lives wagered.
Bodily members wagered.
Head wagered.
Hand wagered. To be cut off.
Hands and feet wagered.
Eyes wagered.
Nose wagered.
Intestines wagered.
Helpful animals lost in wager.
Whole kingdom (all property) as wager.
Right of succession to the throne lost in gambling.
Half kingdom as wager.
Wife as wager.
Sister as wager.
Daughter as wager.
Damsel as wager.
Love wagered in game.
Supernatural adversary in gambling (witch or giant).
Gambling with a god.
Devil as gambler.
Devil cheated at card playing.
Devil makes wager with builder of Cologne Cathedral.
Playing game of chance (or skill) with uncanny being.
Card-playing parson. The parson plays cards all Saturday night, goes to sleep at church, and calls out the names of the cards.
Luck in gambling.
Luck in gambling from compact with devil.
Cuckold loses luck. A man's wife is deceived in order that he may lose in gambling.
Saint helps gambler.
Trained rat upsets pieces in gambling game: trained (or transformed) cat chases it away.
Gambler's attention distracted by women.
Wagers and gambling miscellaneous.
Gambler loses everything.
Wagers on wives, husbands, or servants.
Wager on wife's complacency. Though the man has foolishly bargained everything away, she praises him and he wins the wager.
Wager on the most obedient wife. The husband tames his shrewish wife so that he wins the wager.
Wager: raja's daughter will bring servant dinner in field. Merchant ignorant that she is his wife.
Husbands wager that they will be able to do what wives tell them to do. One is told to drown himself: loses wager.
Chastity wager. A man makes a wager on his wife's chastity. In spite of unsuccessful attempts to seduce her and of false proofs presented, he wins the wager.
Chastity wager: woman succumbs.
Wager on nun's chastity.
Wagers on unborn children.
Wager on sex of unborn child.
Fathers whose unborn children are affianced wager as to mastery in the house.
Wager on truthfulness of servant. The servant is sent to a neighbor's where he is made drunk and is seduced by the neighbor's wife. He tells the master all.
Other wagers.
Wager: who can call three tree names first. The bear names different varieties of the same tree, so that the fox wins the wager.
Wager about tree names: learned and common names. Brahmin gives learned names but servant's common names are confirmed by illiterate peasants.
Wager: it is an auspicious day. In spite of all misfortunes wagerer insists that he is right.
Shooting contest on wager.
Loser of shooting wager to go naked into thorns for bird.
Wager: woman to turn somersault in middle of public square. It is performed not exactly in the center of the square; hence she loses.
Wager that falsehood is better than truth. Left to unjust umpire, so that falsehood wins.
Wager: more doctors than men of other professions. The trickster feigns toothache. Everyone suggests remedies. He takes down their names as doctors and wins the wager.

Wager: fortune made from capital or from working at vocation. Test: money given to workman is stolen or lost; lead for his work given him is lent to fisherman who rewards him with a fish in which is a diamond.
Wager: woman can be forced to give alms. Trickster announces that only those who have deceived their husbands are exempt.
Wager: to begin sermon with illustration from card-playing. Card-playing parson wins the wager.
Wager on second marvelous object. First object has proved to be ordinary. King induced to make large wager that second is ordinary. He loses.
Wager: whose hunger is it more difficult to appease that of man or that of beast?. When nuts are strewn before master's well-fed guests, they snatch and eat them. Herdsman wins wager.
Wager: to swallow egg with one gulp. Tricksters give numskull egg with chick in it. Fool hears chick peep as he starts to swallow his egg, but he says that the chick peeped too late.
Wager: bullock to defeat elephant. Elephant is frightened and flees.
Ghoulish wager won.
Wagers and gambling miscellaneous.
Purchase of box without knowledge of its contents.
Wager to win or lose according to whether jackal howls or ass brays before game is finished.
Father hides wealth to keep son from gambling it away.
Nature of luck and fate.
Inexorable fate.
Inexorable fate: no day without sorrow. A king, who has made decree against sorrow on a certain day is blinded by a swallow in his sleep.
Inexorable fate: death from violating tabus.
Man cannot die: snake will not bite him though it is provoked by him.
Man fated to become king becomes so despite fact he breaks his tooth in which his luck resides.
Fortune comes to deserving and undeserving.
Luck and fate personified.
Fortuna. Luck (fate) thought of as a goddess.
Dwelling place of Fortuna.
Home of Fortuna in other world.
Home of Fortuna on island (in otherworld).
Appearance of Fortuna.
Fortuna blind.
Fortune has one eye, watches over everybody.
Fortuna with two faces.
Fortuna half white, half black.
Fortune's wheel.
Fortune's wheel turned by dead king in mountain.
Fortune with pair of scales in his hands weighs man's balance.
Fortune's dealings with men.
Man thanks earth for saving his life; had he fallen into well he would have blamed Fortune.
Giant is clerk to God of Destiny and measures out mortals' spans of existence.
Bad luck personified.
Bad luck put into a sack.
Good luck personified.
Good fortune resides in an object.
Casket with Good Luck in it given to men by Zeus.
Personification of Good Luck lives in man's forehead.
Lucky right hand.
Man's luck resides in his tooth.
Personification of Good Luck leaves palace since king is destined to die that night.
Luck can be found in certain place.
Fortune as an old woman.
Book of fate.
Issues left to fate (luck).
Ship's course left to the winds that it might be carried where fate wills it.
Luck and fate personified miscellaneous.
Dog tries to catch its fate in its own tail.
Buffalo's fate in bamboo growing from head.
Ill-omened face of king; harbinger of evil.
Determination of luck or fate.
Fate decided before birth.
Child born with objects that indicate fate.
Spirit of new-born child in uniform. God has determined fates of everyone.
New-born child with a weapon and a game animal: fated to be hunter.
Death forestalls evil fates. Mother shown what would have been the evil fates of her children if they had not died.
Newborn girl fated to be a courtesan.
Seventh daughter predestined to be magician.
Lucky or unlucky places.
The choice of roads. At parting of three roads are equivocal inscriptions telling what will happen if each is chosen. Brothers each choose a different road.
Unlucky places.
Choices by chance.
He upon whom feather (wisp) falls to be king's fool.
Luck determined by whether a crooked-necked demigod is looking at one.
King to be victorious as long as he rides muzzled gelding.
Districts named from first person met in each.
Lots cast to determine luck or fate.
Lots cast to determine who shall undertake adventure.
Lots cast to determine father of illegitimate child.
The auspicious (lucky) day (days).
Different kinds of luck attending persons born on the several days of the week.
Tuesday as auspicious day.
Wednesday as auspicious (inauspicious) day.
Thursday as lucky day.
Friday as auspicious day.
Unlucky days ("cross-days").
Days of the week on which certain tragic deaths occurred.
National disasters occur always at the same date.
Monday and Wednesday as unlucky days.
Changing of luck or fate.
Acts performed for changing luck.
Luck changing after cohabitation.
Turning right-handwise in certain place brings luck.
Spilling salt brings bad luck.
Judas Iscariot spills salt at the Last Supper.
Luck changing after change of name.
Luck changing after change of place.
Persons effect change of luck.
Persons bring bad luck.
Unlucky to have man in house while cloth is being dyed.
Wife brings bad luck to the husband's family.
Persons lose luck as punishment.
Spirit of adversity brings bad luck to house.
Passenger brings bad luck to ship. Cast overboard.
Objects effect change of luck.
Thirteen as unlucky number.
Possession of money brings luck. Nothing escapes a mouse as long as she has in her hole a purse of money Chauvin II 94 No. 45; Bshdker Exempler 291 No. 49.
Discovery of treasure brings luck.
The luck-bringing shirt. The king is to become lucky when he puts on the shirt of a lucky man. The only man who says that he is lucky has no shirt.
Feast for those who have not known sorrow. Dying Alexander's letter to his mother orders such a feast. No one comes.
Lucky marks on body.
The judge's bad-luck bringing boots. The wealthy merchant becomes a beggar, due to the judge's boots he acquired through exchange (theft).
Philosopher conquers evil fate.
Nature of luck and fate miscellaneous motifs.
Luck or intelligence?. Dispute as to which is the more powerful. Man with intelligence remains poor (is brought into court). Saved by mere luck.
Which is more important, learning or wit?
Which is more powerful, wealth or wisdom?
Which is more beautiful, nymph of Luck or of Ill-Luck (Luck when coming, Ill-Luck when going).
Weaver married by Wealth to a princess to show Wisdom that he is the more powerful.

Destiny better than work, show, or speculation. A peasant makes a little by his work; a nobleman more by his outward show; a merchant still more by speculation; but a prince most of all by his destiny.
Luck only with money that is earned honestly.
Cast-out princess prospers because of Good Luck.
Man not fated to die cannot be killed.
The capriciousness of luck.
Unprotected son makes fortune; protected son has bad luck.
Prodigal as favorite of fortune.
Prodigal son favored over faithful son.
Disagreeable and disliked youth as favorite of Fortune.
Careful builder outside when storm comes is killed; careless builder saved.
Beggar escapes from fire. Refused hospitality, he must sleep outdoors. The house burns down.
Loss of eye saves man from execution. Man to be buried with king. Gets off because he lacks an eye.
Broken leg saves man from fatal fight. King has ordered that he be killed in a fight. He breaks his leg and cannot take part. Meantime the king learns of his innocence.
Man chosen for execution because he is fat.
King's counselor expelled from a court thereby escapes accompanying the king, who is killed by robbers.
Only crippled cow not driven away by robbers.

Fortunes of the rich man and of the poor man. The Fortune of the rich brother tells the poor brother to seek his luck under a bush. The poor man goes there and Fortune tells him to become a merchant. He becomes rich.
Snake turns to gold in answer to dream. Woman tells dream of pot of gold. Robbers overhear but finding only snake in pot turn it loose on woman's bed. It turns to gold.
Money lost twice: recovered third time.
Fugitive woman burdened with child saved; childless woman killed.
Man who derided another's faith in the stars becomes respected astrologer.
Hero fails to meet the man he seeks, though they are close to one another.
The good gifts of fortune.
Wish for exalted husband realized. Girls make wish that they may marry king (prince, etc.). It so happens.
Wishes for good fortune realized.
Wish realized that all women should fall in love with man at sight.
Lucky person.
Lost object returns to its owner.
Lost ring found in fish. (Polycrates.)
Lost articles found in interior of fish through virtue of saint.
Lost pin found in fish.
Key (to fetters) found in fish.
Lost sword found in fish.
Lost trinket found in fish.
Brooch lost by saint found in fish.
Unavailing attempt to get rid of slippers; they always return.
Angel helps to find lost pin.

Money cannot be kept from where it is destined to go. Miser told that his hoard is to go to poor man. He hides it in a trunk and throws it into the sea but it drifts to the house of the poor man who tries in vain to restore it to its owner.
Husband's magic gift returns to him. Wife gives husband's magic gift (fruit) to lover, who presents it to a dancing girl, who sells it back to the husband.
Man fated to be rich.
Child borne off by tiger, which is caught by griffin, which is killed by lioness, which rears child with her whelps.
Man granted power of winning at cards.
First objects picked up bring fortune.
Man must have drinking horn; stumble reveals one as he departs on search.
Man finds treasure he refused as gift.
Man robbed and penniless entertained by wealthy widow and enriched.
Wrecked man saved on coffer of jewels; becomes rich.
Man who is impoverished is given high post by princess in disguise. Marries her.
Leopard tied in bag in water floats to shore and finds a mate. Grateful to trickster who has tied him up.

The fourteen lucky daughters. The husband leaves his wife, who has given birth to fourteen girls, thinking he is persecuted by bad luck because of failure to have a son. On the seashore, the girls find precious stones. The wife, now prosperous, finds her husband among beggars.
Boast of poor boy made good by fate:  he boasts to elder brothers he will build a palace on a certain spot; accidentally comes on treasure trove and makes good his boast.
Persistent bad luck.
Bad luck follows man who shoots stork.

Persecution by bad luck. Wishing to escape it, the luckless couple build themselves a new home. Scarcely do they establish themselves in the new home, when bad luck addresses them from the hearth: "I have already waited for you here three days."
Persecution by a god so that will of deity can be followed.
Bad luck banished and freed. The poor man in some way banishes his bad luck and becomes prosperous. Out of envy his rich brother sets it free; it then follows him.
Person pursued by misfortune. (Placidas, Eustacius.) His goods are destroyed, his wife carried off by a ship captain and his children by animals.
Man captured by pirates is maimed, crippled, blinded. He is patient through it all. Finally he is elected ruler by his dead master's subjects.
Man who aspires to greater wealth loses all. When he is about to be rewarded by king the latter dies.
Man who loses fortune marries widow of his rich master.
Travelers pursued by misfortune.
Fortune of the lucky wife. A luckless man becomes successful in all his undertakings when he marries a lucky woman and lives by her luck.
The luckless son and his envious father.
Misfortune pursues farmer.
Messengers announce successive misfortunes.
Messengers announce successive misfortunes to warrior as he sets out for war. Tells of death of father, mother, brother, and sister, but he refuses to turn back.
Safety in shadow of wall. After many misfortunes the man is apparently safe. The wall falls on him.
Escape from one misfortune into worse.
Stag escapes from hunters to be eaten by lion.
Ass gets progressively worse masters. Finally the farmer beats him living and will not spare his hide when he is dead.
Halcyon builds nest on sea-cliff to escape land hazards. Tempest blows nest away.
Fugitive slave takes refuge in mill house, where he must work harder than ever.
Daw fleeing from captivity caught in trees by thread around foot. Starves.
Old man burns self with gunpowder, and then burns himself worse when he pours hot water over his body.
Unlucky classes.
Goldsmith unlucky.
Train of troubles from lost horseshoe nail. Master tries to go on in spite of the loss.
Train of troubles from sparrow's vengeance. A man runs over the dog, friend of the sparrow. Through the sparrow's vengeance the man loses his horse, his property, and finally his life.
Train of troubles for seven brothers for having destroyed bird's nest.
Whether man begs all day or for an hour he gets only a small basket of grain.
Person brings bad luck to others.
Girl brings ill luck and death to everyone she comes in contact with.
Crime inevitably comes to light.
Murder will out.
The sun brings all to light. The murderer repeats as he sees the rays of the sun, the last words of the dying man, thus betraying the crime.
Moon brings murder to light.
Murder revealed by unusual names of boys. The dying man leaves message to name his sons "O God" and "O king" (or the like). This arouses the king's curiosity and brings the murder to light.
The Cranes of Ibycus. Murdered man calls on cranes, the only witnesses of the murder, to avenge him. The cranes follow the murderer and point him out.
Ravens pursue murderer who has killed two children.
Murder discovered through knowledge of bird languages. Birds point out the murder.
Murderer through miracle suspected of theft; murder thus discovered.
Murder revealed by child.
Child's song reveals murder.
Murder discovered on digging foundations of house. House burns. Diggers discover body.
Murderer traced through victim's ring.
Tree follows murderer.
Ship will sink if murderer is aboard.
Murder will out: murderers quarrel under influence of drink and reveal crime.
Criminal confesses because he thinks himself accused.
Criminal confesses because of misunderstood animal cries.
Criminal confesses because of misunderstanding of a dialect.
Detection by accidental remark. Wife misunderstands husband's remark and confesses.
Thief imagines that group of people in street are talking and laughing at him; he confesses.
Criminal in church mistakes words of service as accusation.
Sheep thief confesses when preacher says, "All we like sheep have gone astray."
Oxen bear dead usurer to gallows to be buried. They are allowed to go where they will.
Supernatural voice points out criminal.
Unlucky accidents.
Accidental separations.
Separation of persons caused by looking for water.
Separation of twins through being carried off by beast.
Child follows bird and loses its mother.
Persons fall asleep on rock, which magically shoots upward.
Separation by being on different banks of stream.
Separation in jungle (forest).
Separation of family by shipwreck.
Accidental separation of lovers.
Man, thinking it an enemy, flees as sweetheart comes after him in pursuit.
Princess accidentally elopes with wrong man.
Person unwittingly killed.
Man unwittingly causes death of daughter.
Son returning home after long absence unwittingly killed by parents.
Eavesdropping person unwittingly killed.
Eavesdropping man in disguise as devil killed unwittingly by daughter's lover.
Eavesdropping wife hidden in bushes killed unwittingly by husband.
Parricide prophecy unwittingly fulfilled.
Man unwittingly kills prince. Exiled.
Transformed prince unwittingly killed.
Unwitting murder because of insane illusion.
Man kills son thinking that he is cutting a branch.
Women, driven mad, devour their infants' flesh.
Mother kills son thinking him a wild beast.
Accidental killing or death.
Things accidentally fall and kill person.
Dagger in wall above bed falls and kills girl. Has been placed there by her lover.
Knife accidentally strikes girl's throat and kills her.
Prince's arrow accidentally grazes breast of merchant's wife.
Bride lets dagger fall and kill husband.
Bread accidentally dropped from tree on bear's nose kills bear.
Man hidden in tree so frightened of lioness he drops his sword and kills her.
Accidental poisoning.
Man accidentally fed bread which his father has poisoned. The wicked man puts poison in the bread he gives a beggar. The beggar gives his loaf to the son.
Poisoned bath prepared for another accidentally used by hero.

Horse accidentally poisoned instead of master. An attempt is made to give the hero a poisoned cup. He is on horseback and spurs his horse away to avoid the cup. The poison is spilled and enters the horse's ear and kills him.
Elephant on rampage accidentally poisoned instead of man. Man claims having killed elephant.
Serpent carried by bird lets poison drop into milk and poisons drinkers.
Head of killed snake bites and kills king.
Snake in jug bites would-be thief.
Boy accidentally drinks "poison" intended for his stepbrother. Doctor had substituted sleeping potion for the requested poison.
Youth accidentally takes the poison he intended for his father.
Woman unwittingly poisons her son. Mistakes poison for medicine.
Man eats food which is mysteriously poisoned.
Hidden fruit accidentally poisoned by snake.
Aiming at fly has fatal results.
Person killed by hitting fly on his face.
To give child a slap to stop its crying, numskull kills it.
Man accidentally killed by bear trying to chase away flies.
Accidental fatal ending of game or joke.
Children play hog-killing: one killed.
Hanging in game or jest accidentally proves fatal.
Practical joker asks doctor to castrate him. Doctor insists on the operation.
Unexpected death at hands of an animal.
Bird hunter killed by adder just as he is shooting bird.
Blood bath causes woman to be carried off by bird. A pregnant woman demands a bath of blood: husband substitutes a bath of red dye. A Garuda bird attracted by the dye carries her off.
Sick queen lying under red satin carried off by bird who thinks it is red meat.
Death by rebounding bow. Ants gnaw a bowstring, so that the bow rebounds and cuts off head of man who is leaning on it.
Accidental death from flying splinter of bone. Bone being gnawed by animal lets splinter fly and kills young animals.
Hound strikes unique vulnerable spot.
Series of accidental animal killings.
Attacking animal is killed by another in ambush.
Tortoise lands on elephant's back so that elephant's back is broken.
Accidental death through dream. Man dodging blow in dream hits his head against wall and kills himself.
Accidental death through misdirected weapon.
Blind poet unintentionally kills friend.
Hero, while measuring wild boar, accidentally wounded mortally by bristle.
Axe thrown at one animal misses but kills another.
Death as result of mistaken identity: wrong person killed.
Saint changes places with charioteer; latter is killed.
Fool (person) disguised as (supposed) king killed.
Son killed because mistaken for someone else.
Father orders unrecognized son thrown into sea.
Accidental death miscellaneous.
Man falls into jar of honey and is drowned. Chases a mouse.
Flies caught in honey. Death from greed.
Foxes crowd into house and are suffocated.
Groom killed by lightning on wedding night.
Uxorious king is burned to death while taking an alcohol bath.
Man forgets to wear magic gown and is killed.
Army drowned by unnoticed incoming tide.
Accidental death from fall on own weapon (shield).
Accidental death of father from fall into the fire when taking down weapons for his son.
Girl abducted by fairy left on shore, where she is accidentally drowned.
Youth gazing at own image reflected in water falls and drowns.
Girl lets down her sari for hero to climb up by but, when he is halfway up, sari breaks and he is killed.
Prefect, cursed by bishop, dies of fish-bone stuck in his throat.
Accidental death by striking head against lintel of door.
Wife throwing husband's corpse into river (according to custom) is caught by corpse's arm and drowned.
Thief crushed to death by fallen fragments of wall he has bored.
King mortally wounded on killed enemy's tooth.
Bottle wherein jinn is imprisoned inadvertently opened and jinn escapes to kill his captor.
Hasty killing or condemnation (mistake).
Suicide in remorse over hasty condemnation.
King hastily has 7,000 people put to death for stoning his judges to death.
Woman wrongly condemned for drunkenness when seen to take one drink.
Misunderstood message causes messenger to be killed (accused).
Hasty condemnation of man who accidentally becomes suspected of crime.
Faithful servant guarding master's wife from danger falsely condemned for betraying his master.
Faithful son guarding his father from monster falsely accused by stepmother.
Stumbling over bloody corpse brings accusation of murder. Man gets blood on himself.
Jealous and overhasty man kills his rescuing twin brother.
False accusation overheard causes hasty killing.
Angry brother kills husband, thinking latter had killed wife (sister) and baby.
Woman mistakenly accused of cannibalism. She is seen biting off finger of corpse to get its ring.
Lover kills self believing his mistress dead. She has been frightened away by a lion. (Pyramus and Thisbe.)
Mistress kills self, believing her lover dead.
Wife dies, believing husband dead.
Woman feigns death to meet exiled lover. It leads to his death. Lover hears of her supposed death, returns and submits to execution.
Lover commits suicide on finding beloved dead.
Father kills self believing that son is dead. The son forgets to spread white sails, the prearranged signal of his safety. (Told also of lovers.)
Wrong sign put out leads to boys' leaving home. They are to be informed by a sign if a sister is born.
Father causes death of innocent son, believing him guilty of adultery with father's wife.

The falcon of Sir Federigo. An impoverished suitor has only a falcon to catch birds with. His lady's sick son wants the falcon and she goes to ask for it. The suitor serves dinner for her his falcon. When she makes her request it is too late.
Pigeon hastily kills his mate for stealing wheat. It has merely dried out and no longer fills the nest. When the dampness later swells the wheat, he sees his mistake and kills himself in remorse.
Innocent man accidentally suspected of crime.
Clerk who enters tavern arrested with others for murder.
Saint who entered house of ill fame to reform inmates accused of going with evil intent.
Boy is hanged for cattle theft; the strayed cattle are discovered later.
Man having purchased stolen ornament unwittingly presents it to owner as gift; is thrown into jail as thief.
Poor man presented rich robe by emperor is locked up as a thief.
Man falsely accused commits suicide.
Greedy disciple decides to remain in city despite learned teacher's warning and is condemned to take the place of a thief.
Jealous husband kills innocent wife. Suspicions aroused when villain leaves his handkerchief in her room. (Othello.)
Hasty killing or condemnation miscellaneous.
Warriors erroneously slay allies in night battle.
Father kills his son in battle rage.
King, seeing eldest son leaving room, decides that he is a rakshasa.
Accidental loss of property.
Money (treasure) unwittingly given away. Unlucky man given a loaf which is filled with gold exchanges it for another loaf.
Boy's servant takes pearl to his wife instead of to merchant; she throws it away.
Beggar accidentally overlooks money put into his way.
Bird carries off ring which lover has taken from sleeping mistress's finger. He searches for the ring and becomes separated from her.
Bird carries off jeweled veil with which girl had covered sleeping lover's face. Lover pursues bird and becomes separated from the girl.
Jewel (garment) carried off by bird from bather. Clothes have been left on bank of stream.
Serpent steals jewels: person falsely accused of theft.
Man unwittingly commits crime.
Sacred animal unwittingly killed.
Brahmin unwittingly kills calf.
King (prince) unwittingly killed.
Incest unwittingly committed.
Boy unwittingly commits incest with his mother.
Man unwittingly falls in love with his own mother.
Unwitting father-daughter incest.
Father unwittingly falls in love with daughter.
Unwitting brother-sister incest.
Brother and sister unwittingly in love with each other.
Boy says, "Whoever eats this mushroom is my wife.". His own sister eats it and he runs away.
Man unwittingly lies with mother-in-law.
Daughter unwittingly turns her own parents out of doors.
Other unlucky accidents.
Drop of honey causes chain of accidents. Hunter drops honey in a grocery; weasel eats honey; cat chases weasel; dog chases cat; grocer kills dog: all the cause of a bloody feud between villages.
Ant pinching frog causes chain of accidents.
Fugitive slave takes wrong road and is caught.
Man falls dead from sudden realization.
Man falls dead when he realizes that he has been riding over frozen sea.
Man falls dead when he realizes that he has eaten bread from flour used for abscess plaster.
Mother dies of fright when she learns that she was about to commit incest with her son. He has disguised himself to test her chastity.
Death from fright.
Madness from fright.

The cadaver arm. Medical students (or student nurses or hospital employees) play trick on one of their number by suspending a cadaver arm or leg from the light cord in the person's room (sometimes the object is placed in the person's bed). Some circumstance keeps them from being on hand to observe the person's reaction; the next day they remember the joke and go to the victim's room to investigate. They have to break down the door. They find the victim sitting on the bed her hair is snow white and she is gnawing on the cadaver arm.
Mouse frightens man to death.
Death in the graveyard; person's clothing is caught; the person thinks something awful is holding him; he dies of fright.
Wicked stepmother falls into the fire because of fright.
Fraternity initiate dies of fright.
Queen dies from fright because of evil prophecy.
Sham magician causes simpleton's death. Is frightened to death by the impersonation of demons.
Sham execution proves fatal. Jester condemned to die on block. Pail of water used instead of axe. He dies.
Priest frightens boy by tying girl's corpse to bell-rope. In revenge the boy puts the body in the priest's bed. Priest flees. Dies from injuries.
Lover frightens mistress as a joke. She dies from the shock.
Man playing ghost killed. Meaning to frighten son, father plays devil or a ghost. Son kills him.
Joker playing dead killed.
Woman playing dead to spy on husband killed.
Brothers fall dead at sight of long lost brother whom they sold into captivity.
Unintentional injuries bring unfortunate consequences.
Person has successive misfortunes while making plans because he forgets to say, "If God wills."
Lover's wound breaks while he is in bed with mistress. He bleeds to death (or is discovered because of the blood).
Lover's spur catches in sheet when he tries to escape. Uncovers mistress.
Man pinned in bed by weapon caught in quilt.
Feud starts over trifle.
Quarrel over dog starts the Guelph-Ghibelline feud.
Blind men accidentally hurt each other. (Trying to kill pig, or the like.)
Lover who is detained away beyond stipulated time returns to find fiancie married.
Hospitality enforced on hero keeps him overlong from home; meantime wife abducted.
Mistress expecting lover accidentally exchanges places with her maidservant.
Robber attempting to steal cow at night seizes thieving tiger. Great fight in stable.
Escaping prisoner falls by accident onto tiger's back and is carried away.
Woman errs on to the road-of-the-tiger: carried off.
Delay in bringing pardon allows deserved execution. Messenger, ignorant of contents of message, stops to view culprit's execution.
Sign of prisoner's reprieve changed by wind. A flag to be flown in certain way, but wind catches it just at the wrong moment so that prisoner is executed.
Man blinded trying to heal girl. Powders blow into his one good eye.
The sleeping guard. Watchman falls asleep as enemy approaches.
Accidental self-injury.
Mistake in interpreting prophecy (oracle) brings misfortune.
Additional unlucky accidents.
Shipwrecked man lands on deadly enemy's territory and is attacked.
Man's inordinate laughter brings unfortunate results.
Man discovers he is married to wer-tiger.
Lucky accident.
Lucky business venture.
Object unknown in a country sold for a fortune.
Whittington's cat. A cat in a mouse-infested land without cats sold for a fortune.
Cat as sole inheritance.
Sickle sold for fortune in land without sickles.
Sickle as only inheritance.
Fortune from informing foreign king of use of saddle, bridle, and stirrups.
Salt in saltless land sold for fortune.
Sandalwood merchant sells his product at high price in land lacking sandalwood.
Fortune from trifling sum sent abroad with merchant.
King's example makes merchant wealthy. The king buys shoes for a high price and then has all his dinner guests buy them.
Lucky bargain.
Progressive lucky bargains.
Abducted princess wishes that she were with rejected suitor; discovers that she is.
Poor man carries unwittingly in his water jar a large scorpion which brings him fortune.
Valuable secrets learned.
Secrets overheard.
Secrets overheard from animal (demon) conversation.
Secrets of animals (demons) accidentally overheard from tree (bridge) hiding place.
Secret remedy overheard in conversation of animals (witches).
Remedy for lack of water in certain place overheard in conversation of animals (demons).
Reason for withering of tree overheard in conversation of animals (demons).
Secret remedy revealed by departing animal. House spirit (or bird) leaves saying, "If you knew what valerian is good for, the people would not die so fast."
Man transformed as ant, learns secret of freeing princess.
Conversation of objects overheard.
Speaking bed-legs overheard.
King overhears conversation of lamps.
Overheard (human) conversation.
Overheard boast about hidden money brings about robbery.
Robbers' plans overheard: owner warned.
Robbers' secret overheard and later used in court against them.
Secret formula for opening treasure mountain overheard from robbers (Open Sesame).
King overhears girl's boast as to what she should do as queen. Marries her.
Secret remedies learned from green-clad woman.
Husband learns of wife's fidelity through conversation overheard.
Secret about prince's father learned by eavesdropper from his mother's talking to him.
Friend lingering in the kitchen learns of friend's distress and helps him.
Location of sought object learned from overheard conversation.
By hiding, stupid son overhears conversation and claims magic power for bamboo cup.
Servant overhearing conversation realizes the misery of his employment.
Men hear father threaten to marry daughters to first comers.
Enigmatical smile (laugh) reveals secret knowledge.
Secret physical peculiarity discovered by barber. (Midas.)
Secret physical blemish revealed by beaten handmaid.
Secret of person's sleeplessness discovered by trickery.
Daughter lousing mother weeps and reveals secret.
King in disguise to learn secrets of his subjects.
Newborn babe reveals secret; then becomes silent.
Foolish attempt of second man to overhear secrets (from animals, demons etc.). He is punished.
Secret name overheard by eavesdropper.
Secret age overheard by eavesdropper. Man masking as cuckoo in tree causes the surprised ogre to disclose secret.
Secret reason why hero does not want to eat the food of the foreign king overheard by eavesdropper.
Secret of unique vulnerability disclosed.
Secret of vulnerability voluntarily disclosed.
Man vulnerable only in armpits shot as he stretches his arms.
Secret unique means of killing ogre overheard from children.
Secret wealth betrayed by money left in borrowed money-scales.
Secret meat-eating betrayed by grease on mouth.
Secret escapes with man's blood.
Secret learned by torture.
Secret learned by burning hand.
Giant unwittingly reveals span of life to dwarf, who is thus emboldened to attack him.
Treasure trove.
Where treasure is found.
Treasure in ground.
Treasure buried by men.
Treasure buried by dying man.
Sword hidden by old man.
Treasure buried in graves.
Treasure buried in ancient settlements.
Treasure buried in extraordinary topographical formations.
Buried treasure wanders from place to place. Indicated by a light.
Treasure buried in woodshed.
Treasure in cellar of ruined house.
Treasure found in ruined wall.
Treasure hidden by retreating army.
Treasure buried in chest, cask, kettle, or cannon barrel.
Treasure buried under tree.
Treasure buried under flower.
Treasure buried on top of mountain.
Treasure buried on island.
Treasure buried under stump.
Natural underground treasure.
Treasure placed in ground by supernatural beings.
Treasure of mountain spirit.
Treasure placed in old fortifications by supernatural beings.
Treasure found in snake hole.
Treasure under stone.
Treasure in underground chamber (cavern).
Treasure hidden under the water.
Man jumps into the sea, river or waterfall with his treasure.
Sword hidden under water.
Treasure hidden in spring.
Treasure hidden in river.
Treasure buried in sunken ship.
Queen's jewel-box thrown into tank floats to top during first week of new moon;  light or large jewel on top reveals it to passersby. It disappears when someone tries to get it.
Treasure hidden in religious shrine.
Treasure hidden in sanctuary.
Treasure in temple.
Treasure at end of rainbow.
Treasure hidden in building.
Treasure hidden in secret room in house.
Treasure hidden within wall (under floor) of house.
Gold found, concealed in bricks and successfully secured.
Treasure left in stick. It accidentally falls apart.
Treasure hidden in pillow under dead man's head.
Treasure hidden in a stone.
Treasure found in beggar's hat.
Money found in the dead beggar's coat.
Treasure found in chest (kettle, cask).
Treasure found in bundle of rags.
Treasure (money) carried by bird to nest.
Diamond in meat carried to eagle's nest.
Talisman found in bird's stomach.
Treasure found in hollow of tree.
Where treasure is found miscellaneous.
Lump of gold appears in Arabia at Christ's birth.
Pearl found in fish.
Discovery of treasure.
Treasure discovered through dream.

Dream of treasure on the bridge. A man dreams that if he goes to a distant city he will find treasure on a certain bridge. Finding no treasure, he tells his dream to a man who says that he too has dreamed of treasure at a certain place. He describes the place, which is the first man's home. When the latter returns home he finds the treasure.
Dream brings treasure: trade vineyards with neighbor. A treasure is found in the new vineyard.
Dream of treasure bought. Treasure has been seen by man's soul absent in sleep in form of a fly. The purchaser of the dream finds the treasure.
Grateful king advises merchant in dream to take treasure from his grave mound.
Man dreams of large jars full of wealth, which he can get if he will sacrifice his wife for the getting.
Light indicates hidden treasure.
Half-moon close to the earth indicates hidden treasure.
Treasure discovered by magic object.
Treasure discovered by clairvoyant vase.
Treasure found by clairvoyant mirror.
Treasure discovered by hand of unborn child.
Consecrated wine used to discover treasure.
Men find mines of copper, silver, gold and iron where balls fall.
Treasure discovered by accident.
Stumble reveals depository of treasure.
Gold hoard found by cow stepping into hole.
Saint sticks crozier into sod and finds pound of gold.
Information about treasure received from overheard conversation.
Poor boy accidentally finds deserted city with treasure.
Treasure found by man when he obeys call of nature.
Man digging stones in the pavement finds a chest of treasure.
Men digging hole to plant rose-tree find treasure.
Jewel found accidentally on a bought donkey's neck.
Treasure indicated by statue (stone) with inscription, "Dig here".
Treasure indicated by stone cross on the ground.
Treasure pointed out by angels.
Speaking bird tells where treasure is buried.
Treasure pointed out by supernatural creature (fairy, etc.).
Treasure pointed out by soul which has left body for this purpose.
Treasure from defeated giant.
Treasure reveals itself only at certain times.
Treasure reveals itself only on Christmas at midnight (or Christmas Eve).
Treasure reveals itself once a century.
Treasure found on Hallowe'en.
Treasure discovered at the Nativity of Christ.
Special conditions for finding treasure.
Treasure found if one goes with one-night old colt on to one-night old ice.
Treasure to be found when three-legged cat shrieks over the burial place.
Certain person to find treasure.
Only particular persons see hidden treasure in its true form;  others see it as coal, serpents, scorpions, etc.
Treasure to be found by hand that hid it.
Treasure to be found by man who plows with cock and harrows with hen.
Treasure to be found by man who marries original owner's daughter.
Man in despair digging own grave finds treasure.
Man in despair preparing to hang himself finds treasure in the tree (beam).
Man ready to kill self hears voice directing him to buried fortune.
Understanding of animal languages leads to discovery of a treasure.
Discovery of treasure miscellaneous.
Four pots of rupees magically appear on horns of buffaloes stuck in pond, and poor owner becomes rich.
Unearthing hidden treasure.
Continual failure to find or unearth hidden treasure.
Who may unearth a treasure.
Only weak-minded person may unearth a treasure.
Treasure may be unearthed only by man who on the spot has sexual relations with a woman in the manner of dogs.
Treasure opens itself.
Treasure opens itself for destined hero.
Tabus in effect while treasure is being unearthed.
Tabu: incontinence while treasure is being raised.
Unlucky encounter causes treasure-seekers to talk and thus lose treasure.
Treasure finders must not take all of money.
Tabu: looking around while raising treasure.
Tabu: fear of threatening animals while treasure is being raised.
Ceremonies and prayers used at unearthing of treasure.
Sacrifices at unearthing of treasure.
Time favorable for unearthing treasure.
Between midnight and cockcrow best time for unearthing treasure.
Treasure nearest to surface at full of moon.
Treasure-finders always frightened away.
Treasure disappears after being uncovered.
Raised treasure turns into charcoal (shavings). If one takes it along it will turn back into gold.
Electric shock scares away treasure diggers.
Treasure removes itself from time to time.
Treasure having removed itself eventually returns.
Treasure seekers find hole from which treasure has recently been removed. (Often they have delayed searching for one reason or another, arrive too late.)
Magic illusion prevents men from raising treasure.
Guardian of treasure.
Devil (demon) as guardian of treasure.
Ogre's son guardian of treasure trove.
Woman as guardian of treasure.
"White woman" as guardian of treasure.
Swan maidens as guardians of treasure.
Girl with ghostly treasure in boat.
Sleeping king in mountain as guardian of treasure.
Dwarf as guardian of treasure.
Griffin as guardian of treasure.
Ghosts prevent men from raising treasure.
Voice of ghost scares away treasure seekers.
Ghostly lights frighten treasure seekers.
Ghost of treasure's human owner as guardian.
Blind man carrying lame man as guardians of treasure.
Treasure guarded by magic object.
Treasure guarded by magic millstone.
Serpent guards treasure.
Angel as guardian of treasure.
Treasure trove miscellaneous motifs.
Curse on treasure. Finder or owner to have bad luck.
Treasure from striking animal or person and disenchanting him.
Helper in hiding treasure killed in order that nobody may ever find it.
Discovery of rich mine.
Rich mine discovered through dream.
Rich mine discovered by accidental breaking off of rock.
Discovery of underground oil pools.
Pools of underground oil discovered through dreams.
Accidental discovery of crime.
Criminal accidentally detected: "that is the first."

Criminal accidentally detected: "that is the first" sham wise man. The sham wise man employed to detect theft is feasted. As the servants enter with food he remarks to his wife, "That is the first" (course). (Or allowed to feast for three days remarks at end of first day "That is the first.") The servants, thinking they are detected, confess.
Name of criminal accidentally spoken out (identical with ordinary word in speech).
Criminal accidentally detected: "That is the first"   sleepy woman counting her yawns. Robber hearing her flees.
Numskull bridegroom unwittingly sings out phrases that thieves mistake to mean he has detected them.
Thief hears owner of house singing "Bore and throw out the earth" and thinks himself detected. Offers owner money to purchase his silence.
Numskull talks to himself and frightens robbers away.

Man scolds his ass and frightens robber away. While the man is absent from his ass the robber steals the man's coat. The ass brays and the man scolds him. The robber thinking he is discovered flees and leaves the coat.
Numskull bribed to keep silent in elephant sale when he manifests interest, though utterly ignorant.
Cane as evidence of robbery. A man believing that he has killed a robber forgets his cane. Later finds it in robber's house.
Murder revealed to thieves climbing into bank.
Impostor accidentally gives king talking bed which reveals his identity.
Officer comes accidentally to the same building where the fugitive sleeps.
Accidental success in hunting or fishing.
Lucky shot with arrow foot and ear of deer. Deer is scratching ear.
Arrow accidentally makes shot for which prize is given.
Game killed by jumping on it from above.
Tortoise jumps from tree and breaks rhinoceros's back.
Lucky cast of spear (weapon).
Lucky cast of spear animal's mouth pinned shut.
Lucky cast of ball: boy throws ball into mouth of hostile hound. Ball carries out entrails.
Lucky cast of ball made of human brains   ball sticks in head of enemy.
Lucky cast from sling slays hostile queen.
Man falls into well and accidentally kills cobra: rewarded.
Fish jumps into boat of disheartened fisherman.
Ass falls into water and catches fish in his ear.
Destructive elephant eats poison man has prepared for himself. Man rewarded.
Accidental acquisition of treasure or money.
The early pupil finds the gold. An innkeeper hears that education makes one rich and enters school. He is scolded for coming late. He comes very early and in twilight finds a purse of gold.

The triple tax. A poet is given by the king the right to demand a coin of the first hunchback he meets, from the first man of a certain name, and from the first man of a certain city. He sees a hunchback and demands the coin. A quarrel arises in which it appears that the hunchback also has the required name and residence. With each revelation the poet demands a new coin.
Accidental healing.

Patient laughs so at foolish diagnosis of sham physician that his abscess breaks and he gets well. She has been told to examine the floor around the patient's bed for signs of what he has been eating. She finds the patient surrounded with pillows: he has eaten too many pillows.
Patient laughs at monkey and cures himself. Monkey takes medicine and cuts capers as result.
Frog removed from queen's nose by telling such interesting story that she gives quick breath and dislodges him.
Insane man accidentally cured by blow on head.
Blind and deaf cure each other by blow on head.
Stinging of buttocks as cure for cough. Patient applies stinging medicine and makes himself sore. He represses his cough to keep from hurting his hindquarters and is finally cured.
Cure by fall which causes bleeding.
Lost memory recovered in battle.
Man thinks to end life by drinking poisonous water, but it cures him.
Thorn accidentally removed from cobra's throat by woman's finger. Grateful cobra.
King accidentally cured by doctor's ruse and excuses pretended inability to cure him.
Life saved by accident.
Pet swan saves self by singing death song. Master about to mistake the swan in the dark for the goose that is to be slaughtered.
Nut falls and wakes man about to be bitten by snake.
Child falls from cliff; uninjured.
Hero catches spear hurled at him and kills serpent with it.
Waves break caul of abandoned child. He is rescued.
Angry man strikes king just in time to save his life.
Warriors discover in the last moment that it is their own chief they are about to murder by burning.
Husband arrives home just in time to save wife and her father from being burned to death in their home.
Life saved by accident miscellaneous.
Poisoned cakes intended for man by his wife eaten by thieves: booty left to man.
Youth accidentally absent when entire family is wiped out.
Accidental escapes.
Sleeping king abducted by fairies wakes when his foot touches water. They free him.
Storm blows down tree and frees marooned tortoise.
Lucky accidents miscellaneous.
Lucky fool.
Series of lucky successes.
Husband (lover) arrives home just as wife (mistress) is to marry another.
Return home to one's own funeral.
Wife finds lost husband just as he is to marry another.
Ruler makes ready to abandon barren wife and marry another. He remains with her when he learns that she is with child.
Incest accidentally averted.
Man about to consummate marriage with own mother; accidentally prevented.
Man in love with his own sister accidentally learns her identity.
Son returns on day his mother is to be married to another (though her husband still lives).
Prophecy of future greatness fulfilled when hero returns home unknown. Parents serve him.
Stranger accidentally chosen king. Picked up by sacred elephant.

Naked soldier becomes general. Stripped for bathing he takes his place as guard when the king unexpectedly arrives. King invites him to come naked to the castle, where he is chosen as husband by a general's daughter.
Fool passes as wise man by remaining silent.
Hero's (heroine's) identity established as he (she) is on the point of being executed.
Hero unwittingly helps fee's sons: rewarded.

What is in the dish: "Poor Crab". A sham wise man named Crab is put to a test of his powers of divination. He is to tell what is in a covered dish (crabs). In despair he says, "Poor Crab!" and is given credit for knowing.
Doctor know-all accidentally saves raja. Roof caves in after he has dragged raja out with the intention of killing him and putting an end to all of his questions.
Objects accidentally picked up used to overawe ogress.
Numskull's outcry overawes tiger who is carrying him on his back. Tiger thinks that words are the name of the "demon" riding him.
Hero attempting to escape from tiger plays music and tiger follows. People marvel and give him money and he is rewarded with princess's hand.
Stupid man grabs tiger in the dark, ties it up, and saddles it, believing it to be a horse. It happens to be the tiger for whose capture a reward has been offered.
Person reported lost joins unwittingly in search for himself.
Missing girl reveals identity and saves man condemned for kidnapping her.
Man sent away from battlefield to deliver message the only survivor of battle.
Apparently dead woman revives as she is being prepared for burial.
Apparently dead woman revives when dropped. Had swallowed a bone. Lover exhumes her. Stumbles as he carries her. She revives and later marries him.
Passengers on a boat are terrorized by a cutthroat. He turns courteous and leaves them unharmed.
Fugitive in tree urinates from fright: pursuers think it rain and leave.
Man falls out of tree and frightens tiger away.
Grinding stones carried by men seeking refuge in tree-top fall, killing their enemies below.
Hawk carries off necklace from bathing queen and drops it by lucky girl, who gets reward.
Other lucky accidents.
Father and brother accidentally return home just as they are most needed in fight.
King's son comes home just at his father's funeral, when the heritage has to be divided.
Companions arrive as hero is about to be killed.
Orphan gets wife because swollen creek prevents marriage to someone else.
Boy while cutting trees comes to one which happens to be bound up with the life of an ogre. Ogre bribes him with large fortune not to cut tree.
Overheard wish is realized.
Accidental encounters.
Accidental meeting of hero and heroine.
King (prince) accidentally finds maiden and marries her.
King (prince) finds maiden in woods (tree) and marries her.
Hero finds maiden in (magic) castle.
Hero finds maiden in (magic) garden.
Prince sees maiden at church and is enamored.
Lovers meet at temple.
Prince (king) finds girl floating on water in basket: marries her.
Prince sees heroine at ball and is enamored.
Prince first sees heroine as she comes forth from her hiding-box. She has concealed herself until the favorable moment.
Princess concealed in trunk and sent to beggar, who marries her.
King marries girl who finds lost object of his.
Princess catches raja's golden bird; he trails it to her palace.
King marries girl who finds his lost ring.
Lovers first see each other on shores of lake.
Hero finds maiden at fountain (well, river).
Lover sees beloved first while she is bathing.
Man stumbles on bathing maiden.
Accidental meeting with the son of the only person who can overcome curse on hero.
Runaway horse carries bride to her lover. Bridegroom unwittingly hires a horse belonging to his rival for his bride to ride to the wedding. A storm arises and the horse carries her to his master.
Girl sees man as he lies sleeping by wayside.
Hunter accidentally discovers beautiful girl being secretly reared in a cave.
Accidental reunion of families.
Unexpected meeting of father and son.
Unknown son returns to father's court.
King unknowingly adopts his own lost son.
Father-son combat. Neither knows who the other is. (Sohrab and Rustem.)
Hero fights with friend of father and then reveals himself.
Undesired combat between sworn (blood) brothers (foster brothers).
Father unexpectedly meets abandoned son and reinstates him.
At execution block condemned man discovered to be king's unknown son.
Accidental meeting of father and daughter.
Father unwittingly buys daughter who has been sold into slavery.
Deserted daughter's good fortune discovered by accident.
Daughter's good fortune accidentally discovered by father who has become a beggar.
Parents accidentally meet daughter who has survived their attempts to drown her.
Accidental meeting of brothers.
Brothers unwittingly fight each other.
Brother unwittingly kills half brother in fight.
Joseph and his brethren. Elder brothers unwittingly come to maltreated youngest in great need. Eventual recognition.
Two returning brothers unwittingly purchase bird, which is transformed youngest brother, as present intended for him.
Brothers accidentally reunited when wedding of one to a king's daughter is celebrated and neighboring rulers are invited.
Accidental meeting of brother and sister.
Slaves ordered married discover they are brother and sister.
Saint prays with woman; learns she is his sister.
Accidental meeting of mother and son.
Begging ascetics beg alms of their own mother.
Accidental meeting of mother and daughter.
Accidental reunion of lovers.
Accidental meeting of nephew and uncle. Hero takes refuge unwittingly at his uncle's court.
Uncle and nephew unwittingly about to kill one another.
Unexpected meeting of husband and wife.
Concealed wife. Unknown wife supernaturally conceals herself until the favorable moment to come forward.
Husband and wife become separated in shipwreck. Wife unexpectedly meets husband on street. They are reunited.
Slandered queen chances to be in Rome at the same time as her estranged husband. Reconciled by the Pope.
Calumniated wife is forced to flee.
Husband and wife reunited after long separation and tedious quest.
Maiden found in magic garden; prince's wife in former life.
Accidental meeting of sisters.
Accidental meeting of seeker of exiled prince with prince at meal. Messenger in pilgrim garb invites unknown prince to eat with him. Recognition.
Accidental meeting of cousins.
Other accidental encounters.
Unexpected encounter in oasis.
Person accidentally met unexpectedly knows the other's name.
Hero captured by man he has formerly rescued: rewarded.
Unexpected meeting with wild man.
Meeting with robber band.
Unwitting adultery with blood-brother's wife.
Unwitting combat between sons of friends. Recognition and reconciliation.
Abandoned children accidentally discovered by villainess.
Experiences leading to adventures.
Feast as occasion for the beginning of adventures or the arrival of questers.
King (prince) lost on hunt has adventures.
King on hunt is taken prisoner.
Girls going in the wood for nuts have adventures.
Parting at crossroads to go on adventures.
Adventure from following animal to cave (lower world).
Adventure from following ogre to cave.
Adventure from returning for forgotten comb.
Adventures from pursuing enchanted animal (hind, boar, bird). (Guiding Beast.)
Adventure from pursuing thieving birds.
Adventures from seeking (lost) domestic beast (bull).
Adventures from pursuing animal (not magic).
Runaway ox leads pursuer to burial place of Adam and Eve.
Race with fairies leads to adventures.
Light seen from tree lodging place at night leads to adventures.
Climbing tree to look around leads to adventures.
Adventures from trying to strangle oneself in tree.
Adventures from having slept beneath tree.
Dropped ball (basket) leads to adventures when recovery is attempted.
Adventures encountered in running after cotton being blown away by wind.
Bucket dropped into well leads to adventures.
Flax dropped into well leads to adventures.
Spindle dropped into well leads to adventures.
Taking refuge in a grave leads to adventure.
Hero embarks in rudderless boat.
Mother's parting gift to adventuring son: the two loaves of bread. One for hunger, one for overeating.
Broken vessel (calabash, etc.) to be mended leads to adventure.
Shouting after bathing: adventures follow.
Adventures from seeking water.
Man hunting honey encounters lost maiden, returns her to her parents.
Anchor catching in oratory of submarine monastery leads to adventures.
Incidents when wife takes food to husband in field or forest.
Adventures from pursuing object carried off by river.
Adventures from pursuing objects carried off by bird.
Helpers.
Helper grateful for being bought from slavery.
Supernatural helpers.
Invisible guardians.
Helper's beard and eyebrows cut. Only after hero has performed this service is help forthcoming.
Hero's divine father as helper.
Supernatural helper comes from sky.
Supernatural person disguised as servant as helper.
Saint disguised (as poor man) as helper.
Supernatural godfather. A king chooses as the godfather of his son the first man he meets. The godfather proves to be supernatural.
Giant or ogre as helper.
Giant's help secured by feeding him.
Wise giant as foster father of hero.
Giantess as foster mother and helper of hero.
Grateful giantess as helper.
Giantess helps the man she loves.

Competition in friendship: prisoner and jailor. Officer in charge of prison offers to let his friend escape, though his own life will be forfeited. The friend refuses; tells officer to let king think he has escaped and if the king demands his life the officer can produce the prisoner. King hears of the generosity and forgives the prisoner.

Harper.

Usurer stops lending money. He does so, not because it is wrong, but because he is losing money.

Tailor.
Tailor occupies God's throne for a day.
Tailoring only trade devil cannot learn. He fails to knot thread because it would make sign of the cross.

Busy tailor asks soldier to mount watch in his place.

Baker and devil walking together.
Miller.
Water-miller.
Why millers are thieves.

Brave soldier and timid cabinet-maker as companions.

Smith from Lochlann  (Scandinavia, otherworld [?])

Spinner.
Dressmaker (milliner, etc.).
Shoemaker.

Why shoemakers are indolent. A shoemaker spits at Christ on way to be crucified. Christ tells him, "A poor slobbering fellow thou shalt be, and all shoemakers after thee, for what thou has done to me."

Mason (bricklayer).
Carpenter.
House-painter.
Woodsman.

Printer.

Actors banished along with vagabonds.

Robbers defeated and killed.

Man condemned to lose his eye is allowed to choose the instrument.
Condemned woman may be freed by marrying a rogue.
Release from execution at a woman's request (by marriage to her).
Criminal may fight against odds rather than be judicially executed.
Pardoning of criminal comes too late.
Youngest of judges first to give decision.
Crime less serious if committed at request of a lady.

Complacent judge disregards the confession. He has put the criminal to torture without success. When he releases him, the criminal says, "In a moment I should have confessed all." The judge lets him go nevertheless.
Laws.
Lex talionis. One life for one life. Equal number must be given up by each feuding side.
A nose for a nose.
Bringing suit in law courts.
Foreigner may not bring suit.
Madman may not bring suit.
Fool not to be punished for his crime.

He nearest to blood of slain man must avenge his death.

"To every cow belongs its calf,"  a legal principle applied to question of ownership of copy of manuscript.
"To every son belongs his mother" : in case of suspected illegitimacy, child is not guilty.

Tribe failing to attend yearly feast to send gift as sign of submission.
Tribute required of conquered foreigners.
Tax on treasure trove.
Payment of tax (tribute).

Army.
Band of professional warriors.

Soldiers chained (tied) together to prevent flight from battle.

Conflicts with the recruiting officers.
Retainers not required to go to battle under overlord except for pay.

Battle-pen. Warriors fight in circle around leader.
Superior troops distributed throughout army to prevent their soldierly qualities from being too obvious.
Phalanx.
Roof of shields. Testudo.
War-machines.
Haircut as preparation for war.
Weapons.
Poisoned weapons.
Battle-cairn. Losses reckoned by number of stones remaining in pile after each survivor has removed one.
Defeat in battle.
Submission indicated by defeated lying with conqueror's sword between teeth.
Corpses of dead foes dismembered.
Heads of fallen enemies piled up after battle.

Jawbone cut from slain opponent.
Gate of captured town (castle) to be widened until overlord's spear can pass through crosswise.

Challenge by turning left side of shield toward enemy.
Challenge to battle by hurling javelin skyward.
Military customs.
Warrior not entitled to ransom if captured without arms.
Pledge with enemy to be kept.
Stones erected where enemy falls.

First to reach field of combat has choice of weapons.
Warrior who begins combat has right to desist.
Choice of weapons alternates each succeeding day.
"Men's truth" (fir fer). Challenger to single combat must submit to same conditions as person challenged.
Warrior engaged in combat with one-armed opponent allows one hand to be bound to his side.
Warrior disgraced by slaying of those under his protection.
Warrior dies with face toward foe.
Divorce given to wives before leaving for battle.

King is persuaded to rescind ban on tournaments.
Tournament: to avenge death of king.
Customs.
Women meet when bathing.
Trumpet blown before house of one sentenced to death.
Charon's fee: putting coin in dead person's mouth to pay for ferry across Styx.
Newcomers forced to pass the night with ruling princess. Given sleeping potion. Goods confiscated for failure to consummate marriage.
People weep when child is born. They sing and laugh at burials.
Bridle goes with horse when horse is bought.
Servant must keep horns and hide of his cattle that are slain.

Fasting against God.
Clerics fast against God for revelation.
Fasting against the Devil.
Fasting against fairies.
Fasting against saints.
Fasting by saints causes tree worshipped by pagans to fall.
Fasting to enforce saint's dues.
Calves not let to cows during fast.
Strangers to be given precedence over man at home. Duke permits visiting duke to go through narrow path first. This sets custom.

Couches provided for men of high rank.
Cuts of meat distributed according to rank.
"The champion's portion.". The choicest portion assigned to the bravest at feasts.
Rank among children recognized by quality of appointments and food.
Color worn signifies rank.
Precedence shown by position of shield (flag).
Long hair prized by Irish heroes.
Young not to precede old.
Feasts.
Customs connected with eating and food.
Feast (hospitality) endures for three days and three nights.
Feast (hospitality) endures for seven days and seven nights.
Injured husband will not kill a naked man.
Only the brave to wear beards.
With only opponent's arms. Hero goes to encounter unarmed except for the arms he wrests from his opponent.
Hero unwilling to answer questions before he is dressed.

Bells hung at every corner of ship.
Bells on horse's mane.
Bells rung backward as alarm.
Hut for invalid to prevent noxious odor.
Custom: boasting of sexual prowess.
Woman veils self as expression of surprise.
Pulling a man's beard as an insult.
Fur made of beards of conquered kings.
Cutting off a man's (woman's) hair as an insult.
Rubbing shaved head of hero with cow dung as insult.
Insult: lighting lamp with king's moustache.

Touching head as sign of acceptance of bargain.
Feet (legs) seized in supplication.

Duel: shooting and catching arrows in turn.
Pulling out hair as sign of grief.
Tearing garments as sign of grief.
Mourning customs.
Greeting customs.
Greeting in God's name.
Voyagers have right to ask landsman first question.
Nations.
Patriotism.
Wolves of his own country dearer than dogs of another.
Mother of invalided soldier says of his limping: "Every step will remind you of your virtue."
Common citizen saves the honor of his country. Gives his own funds.
Scipio plunges into burning pit to save Rome from destruction.
Roman undertakes to kill Hannibal. Kills another by mistake. Burns off his hand for having failed.
National unity preserved by expulsion of all foreign elements.
Aristotle rises from sick bed to rush into battle for his country.
Aversion to burial in foreign soil.
