Marriage of girl to a dagger.
Marriage of girl to a sword.
Marriage of girl to a drum.
Marriage of girl to an idol.
Marriage with a tree.
Marriage to tree by day, man by night.
Marriage to a flower.
Marriage to a gourd.
Marriage to doll.
Marriage to river.
Plant wife (in form of a woman).
Marriage to a statue.
Girl (man) married to (enamored of) a monster.
Monster husband invisible.
Marriage of dragon girl to orphan boy.
Unequal marriage.
Knight weds peasant girl.
Noblewoman weds shepherd.
Princess marries courtier.
Princess marries lowly man.
Ruler marries fugitive noblewoman.
Wealthy girl marries deformed and penniless philosopher.
Princess marries saint.
Rich girl marries fakir.
Man weds his bondmaid.
Rich girl marries servant.
King (rich man) weds common girl.
Infertile raja marries beggar woman in hope of having a son.
Marriage by royal order. Widow hesitates to marry. Queen sends her a letter ordering her to marry the bearer (a suitor).
Lazy boy and industrious girl matched. Jesus (incognito) as matchmaker.
Fool given intelligent wife; lame man hardworking wife.
Blind girl marries lame man.
Fantastic marriage.
Marriage of Mother Earth and ogre.
Marriage of mountain and cockle-shell.
Marriage of earth and sky.
Marriage customs.
Marriage restrictions.
Princess has unrestricted choice of husband.
Father promises that girl may wed only man of her choice.
Relative's consent to marriage necessary.
Brother's consent for sister's marriage needed.
Father's consent to son's (daughter's) marriage necessary.
Girl must marry father's choice.
King chooses bridegroom for daughter from boys' pictures.
Father demands that son break all relations with his beloved.
Son refuses to marry father's choice.
Marriage against will of parents.
Younger child may not marry before elder.
Eldest daughter will marry man only if he will marry all her sisters too.
Widow may not remarry.
Exogamy. Marriage only outside the group.
Marriage within clans sanctioned because of incest-origin of tribe.
Girl will marry on condition she is to be only wife.
King may not marry girl who has been wife of another.
Different religion as obstacle for marriage.
Brahmin may marry from all four castes.
Preparation for wedding.
Girl fattened before wedding.
Parents become servants to secure funds for wedding.
Travel to wedding.
Faithful servant accompanies bride to new home.
Royal bride conducted by embassy to husband's kingdom.
Drummer beats drums before bride on way to wedding.
Bridegroom and his men come for the bride.
Mounting upon horse to fetch bride.
Groom's mother visits bride-to-be and puts the betrothal ring on her finger.
Conduct of bridal couple before ceremony.
Bridal couple must never see each other before wedding.
Betrothed parties do not see each other until night of the wedding.
Man who has once been married helps groom to dress for wedding.
Wedding ceremony.
Marriage formula: "You are mine and I am yours".
Touching of privates considered a marriage pact.
Wedding by proxy.
Sword and shield as proxy at wedding ceremony.
Groom's sword makes vermillion mark on bride's forehead as wedding ceremony.
Marriage by exchange of garlands.
Marriage by drinking festival.
The bride must have someone to give her away, usually her father or brother.
Two or more weddings at one time as the end of a tale.
Wedding ceremony in church.
Marriage custom: going round and round fire (pillar, etc.).
Bride and groom drink from same cup as part of ceremony.
Bodies of would-be bride and groom besmeared with turmeric and mustard-oil.
Bride and groom look into a big mirror while old member of family knocks both their heads together.
Wedding-canopy over bride and groom.
Breaking a glass during wedding ceremony.
Accompaniments of wedding.
Wedding feast.
Rice thrown at weddings.
Amusements at wedding.
Dancing at wedding.
Marriage odes sung at wedding feast.
Gifts at wedding.
Gifts for bridal couple by a special ceremony with the bride on a bridebench.
Parting gifts after wedding.
Bride scatters presents among groom's relations.
Customs following wedding.
Advice to a parting bride.
Bride and bridegroom conducted to bridal bed.
Bride and groom simultaneously touch hearthstones and put one foot down inside threshold as they enter groom's house.
Groom invited after marriage ceremony into female apartments to eat wedding breakfast with the bride.
Groom becomes a member of bride's family.
Bride (and party) fetched by groom and party after wedding.
Journey to husband's home accompanied by attendants.
Assignment of bride to another.
Dying man assigns bride to his brother.
Wives exchanged.
Hero assigns the bride he has won to another.
Infant marriages.
Polygamous marriages.
Polygyny.
Marriage to five women, each with separate duties.
Man requires seven women.
Seven wives each to have the husband one day a week.
Man married to several sisters.
Second wife taken because first is barren.
Competition in ale-brewing between king's two wives.
Man's two wives each claim part of his body: they torment him.
Man pulled down stairs by his two wives.
Polygamist must love all his wives.
Man's senior wife ugly but diligent; his second, beautiful but lazy.
Polygamy so that head wife may be quickly replaced for wrongdoing.
Polyandry. Woman with two husbands.
Several men marry one woman.
Woman requires thirty men.
Marriages made at annual festival.
Matriarchy.
Son named for mother.
Happenings at weddings.
Year's respite from unwelcome marriage.
Respite ruse. Captive maiden assigns quest, agreeing to marry when it is accomplished.
Father giving away daughter makes condition: son-in-law not to see daughter as his wife during one year.
Six months' respite from unwelcome marriage.
Thirty days' respite from unwelcome marriage.
Other respites from unwelcome marriage (three months, two years, etc.).
Bride wounded accidentally on way home. Fatal wound from bridegroom's sword.
Bridegroom slain on way to bride.
Cruel stepmother enchants stepdaughter on eve of wedding.
Old beggar transforms wedding party into wolves.

Marriage for a night to evade law. In order to have girl escape unwelcome marriage, the hero agrees to marry her and give her up the next day. He puts up a large bond as pledge to give her up. But he gets hold of the money by trickery and keeps her.
Marriage for a night to insure heir of warrior destined to be slain (next day) in battle.
Affianced wife of chieftain falls in love with another man at betrothal feast, drugs the company with sleeping potion, and forces man of her choice to elope with her.
Consummation of marriage.
Jus primae noctis. Overlord claims right of sleeping the first night with subject's wife.
King deflowers all twelve year old girls.
Lover allowed to sleep with woman first few nights after her marriage to another.
Feast of "bedding and handspreading" before consummation of marriage.
Girl may remain virgin for three days after marriage.
Consummation of marriage postponed until revelation by dream of future of family has been secured.
One year to elapse between ceremony and consummation of marriage.
Twenty-four hours to elapse before consummation of marriage.
Bride and groom separated on wedding night.
Three years asked before consummation of marriage as trick.
Consummation of marriage postponed till couple return home.
For first six months bride of prince is only to sit an hour or two in his house.
Bride afraid of intercourse refuses consummation until judge orders it in court.
Bride refuses to sleep with ugly groom.
Bridegroom must be taught sexual intercourse.
Bridegroom driven from bridal chamber by magic. Usually by hornets or wasps.
Dangers to husband in bridal chamber.
All husbands have perished on bridal night.
Bridal chamber filled with coiled snakes.
Bridal chamber invaded by magic dragon (serpent).
Grateful dead man kills princess's monster husband. (Or otherwise renders her innocuous to the bridegroom.)
Bride's monster-father tries to kill husband, but is defeated.
Murderous bride.
Strong bride tries to stifle husband in bed.
Hostile brides kill husbands in the bridal bed.
Magic perils threaten bridal couple. The perils are various magic horse, poison, enchanted clothes, etc.
Falling furniture threatens bridal couple. Furniture etc. arranged by jealous rival so that it will fall.
Bridegroom magically impelled to leave his bride.
Dangerous husband.
Death from intercourse.
Marriage miscellaneous motifs.
Marriage by force.
Married life.
Marriage destroys friendship. Lover and mistress live together and are happy; become unhappy as soon as they marry.
The happy couple: wife blind, husband deaf.
Peace in marriage more important than truth.
Faithfulness in marriage.
Faithful wife.
Faithful husband.
Faithfulness to marriage in death.
Wife dies so that husband's death may be postponed.
Woman drowns herself as sacrifice to water-gods to save husband's boat from capsizing.
Husband learning from augurs that his wife will die if he saves self from serpent, lets self be bitten to death.
Wife offers to sacrifice her right arm for husband's safe return.
Female deer offers herself instead of her mate, who has been captured. Hunter, struck by her sacrifice, lets both go.
Wife's suicide at husband's death.
Wife throws herself on husband's funeral pyre.
Wife prefers to be burned together with husband even though she was forced to marry him and she has helped to prepare the revenge.
Wife promises to die with husband.
Husband and wife kill themselves so as not to be separated.
Husband falls on sword when his wife dies.
Wife hangs self because her husband has been killed.
Spouse's corpse kept after death.
Wife's corpse kept after death.
Husband's corpse kept after death.
Wife will not give up dead body of husband to God of Death.
Man becomes a hermit after his wife's death.
Widowed she-fox rejects suitors who do not resemble her deceased husband.
Girl forced to marry before sweetheart's return is faithful to her husband. When she refuses to give her former fianci a kiss, he falls dead. She goes to his funeral and falls dead over his body.
Wife unwilling to deceive her husband for the man she loves.
Excessive grief at husband's or wife's death.
Wife dies of grief for death of husband.
Wife swoons realizing her husband is dead.
Man kills self in grief for wife.
Grieving man goes to die where his wife's corpse lies.
Loving couple die of separation.
Constancy of wife brings husband back to life.
Husband (wife) sickens as result of separation from spouse.
Faithfulness of married couple in misfortune.
Wife carries mutilated husband on her back so that he may beg.
Wife offers starving husband (father) milk from her breasts.
Husband nourishes starving wife with his own flesh and blood.
Wife puts out one of her eyes to show sympathy with her husband. He has lost an eye in a tournament and is ashamed to return to her. She shows that it makes no difference in her love.
Fugitive returns to his family so that they may collect reward from his capture.
Woman swims nightly to husband's prison and arranges his escape. Spurns the attentions of treacherous suitor.
Wife travels for years with sick husband in order to have him cured.
Wife alone does not desert leprous husband.
Woman sells her hair to feed starving husband.
Loathly bridegroom carried on back in basket by wife.
Wife refuses to become unfaithful although she knows her husband to be so.

Woman' s naiviti proves her fidelity. Man is rebuked for having bad breath. He reproves his wife for never having told him. "I thought that men liked it as I did." He realizes that his wife has not known any other man.
Wife hides husband's unfaithfulness from emperor and even shelters his mistress.
Husband tempted by own wife disguised in fine clothes: says he will touch no woman save his wife. She puts on her old clothes.
Faithlessness in marriage.
Wife and husband believe each unfaithful at the slightest provocation.
Faithless wife causes her husband to go insane.
The faithless widow.
Faithless widow betrothed anew at husband's funeral.
Faithless widow fans husband's grave. She does not want to remarry until the body is cold (or the earth on the grave is dry).
Faithless widow ready to marry messenger who brings news of husband's death. The husband, however, has only feigned death to test her.
Faithless widow offers city to killer of her husband if he will marry her.
Faithless widow's heartlessness repels the new suitor. She obeys him when he tells her to knock out the teeth of her dead husband. Fearing like treatment, he leaves.
Faithless widow marries slayer of husband.
Woman deserts husband for unworthy lover. (Deformed, mutilated, monstrous, or of different race.)
Woman consorts with leper.
Adulteress chooses loathly paramour.
Adulteress poisons husband in order to be with swineherd.
Woman enamored of repulsive and abusive lover.
Faithless wife pays her paramour for enjoying herself with him.
Wronged wife goes to wronged husband.
Husband transforms himself to test his wife's faithfulness.
Woman enamored of an unknown knight in a tournament loses interest when she finds that it is her husband.
Old man married to young, unfaithful wife.
Adulteress on her death-bed reveals the illegitimacy of her children. Did not want her husband to be burdened with their bringing up.
Series of husbands try in vain to control adulteress.
Fight between husband and lover for kingdom and wife.
Woman reveals whereabouts of husband to enemy in revenge for desertion.
Woman reveals whereabouts of husband to hungry bear in revenge for desertion.
Man unfaithful even on wedding night.
Object stolen (left) as token that infidelity has been discovered.
Substituted sword. Husband leaves wooden sword in scabbard of wife's paramour upon discovering their infidelity.
Faithlessness in marriage miscellaneous.
Adulterous wife convicted commits suicide.
Husband and wife (king and queen) each unfaithful to other.
Characteristics of wives and husbands.
The shrewish wife.
Man ejected from heaven for folly of marrying twice.
Christ, not having married, knew nothing about suffering. So thinks the man after hearing all about Christ's torments.
Man reprimanded by judge for marrying several times. The man replies that he was always looking for a good wife.
Avoiding the shrewish wife.

Belfagor. The devil frightened by the shrewish wife. A man persuades his shrewish wife to let herself be lowered into a well. When he comes to pull her out he raises a genie (devil) who is glad to escape from the woman. Later he frightens the devil by telling him that his wife has escaped.
Devil flees shrewish wife and enters body of a duke. Exorcised by telling him that they are sending for his wife.
Late husband chooses to remain in Purgatory rather than to return to his shrewish wife.
Husband chooses to go to hell rather than join shrewish wife in heaven.

Man in hell declares that life there is much better than on earth with his wife. Bargain with the devil: should the latter not be able to endure life with his wife for three years, the man would be released from hell. The devil is the loser.
Man had rather remain transformed to mule than to live with his shrewish wife.
Man forces devil to take back the shrewish wife.
Minstrel throws wife into sea: her tongue the heaviest thing on board. Ordered to throw all heavy articles overboard.
Thief overhears and oversees quarrel of two jealous wives. Arraigned before judge, he asks any punishment be given him rather than that of having two wives.
Taming the shrew. By outdoing his wife in shrewishness the husband renders her obedient.
Shrew tamed by setting another shrew against her.
Husband dons armor and forces the household to shout: "Long live the Master!". Takes off his breeches and dares his wife to put them on. Establishes his mastery in the home.
Wife becomes obedient on seeing husband slay a recalcitrant horse.
Husband tries to reform wife by killing a recalcitrant horse in her presence. She thinks he has lost his mind and continues in her ways.
The wicked queen reformed. While asleep she is made to exchange places with the cobbler's wife. She thinks she is in hell. The cobbler teaches her to obey and fear her husband.
Shrewish wife driven from home but when in danger, runs to husband and receives protection. She is a good wife thereafter.
St. Peter's wife meets him with a broom handle. She is waiting for him at the rear door of the house.
Socrates and Zanthippe: "After thunder rain". He thus remarks as she empties slops on his head.
Strength in words, in herbs, and in stones. When first two do not cure shrewish wife, the last does.
The browbeaten husband from under the table: "The man always has a man's heart."
Husband will not search for shrewish wife who has run away from him.
Shrewish wife gives husband heating every morning.
Husband consoled by seeing woman even more shrewish than his wife.
Wife beats her husband and eats up everything he earns.
Fakir thankful for shrewish wife: she is a thorn in his flesh and warns him from neglecting the ways of righteousness.
The overbearing wife.
Unsuccessful search for man who can rule his wife.
Cock shows browbeaten husband how to rule his wife.
King sees how male stork kills his unfaithful wife. Follows its example.
Monkey (jackal, etc.) shows husband how to rule his wife.
King tells jackal his statistics are wrong since there are more men than women. Jackal: husbands ruled by their wives counted as women.
Wife threatens husband with death if he will not tell secrets.
Prize for husband who rules his wife. (Ham, egg.)
Man claims prize (boots) as ruler of his house, but is afraid to carry the boots lest he soil his clean shirt and anger his wife.
Men rulers in their house asked to sing. No man in congregation does so. Priest alone sings. Next year he cannot, for then he has a maid.
Wife threatens suicide if she does not have her own way.
Vexed woman brings pot down on husband's head in presence of guest.
The nagging wife.
Nagging wife drives husband to prepare for suicide.
Woman advised that nagging will never make a husband virtuous.
Saint composes hymn to free himself from the mala vita in which he lives with his wife.
The disobedient wife.
The husband shows his wife poison to avoid: she takes it and dies.
Husband forbids wife to ride on the dog: she immediately does so and is bitten.
Man with obedient wife looks young; with disobedient, old.
Man forbids wife to open chest. Loaded crossbow placed in it. She opens it and is killed.
Husband warns wife not to enter empty furnace. She does so and it falls in upon her.
Disobedient wife punished.
Wife refuses to bring husband warm water: is beaten.
The obstinate wife or husband.
The obstinate wife: cutting with knife or scissors. At the end of the argument the man throws his wife into the water. As she sinks she makes with her finger the motion of shearing with the scissors.
The obstinate wife sought for up-stream. When she falls into the stream, the husband concludes that she would be too obstinate to go with the current.
The obstinate wife: sign of the louse. She calls her husband a lousy head. He throws her into the stream. As she sinks she makes a sign of cracking a louse.

The obstinate wife: the third egg. The husband and the wife dispute as to who shall eat the third egg. She pretends to die. At the grave she asks him, "Do I eat two of the three eggs?" and he gives his consent. She jumps up and cries out "I eat two!" and everyone flees except a lame man who exclaims, "Poor me and the other one!"
The obstinate wife: insists on eating three of the five eggs.
The dish which the husband detests and the wife keeps serving him. He affects to like it and thus gets rid of it.
Obstinate wife refuses to take cover off boiling kettle. Is beaten by husband.
Man warns his wife that he has dreamed that she is attacked by a wolf. She pays no heed to him and the dream comes true.
The quarrelsome wife or husband.
Quarrel between husband and wife explained by their having been previously a tiger and a dog.
Quarrelsome wife conquered by silent husband.
Medicine against quarrelling: the wife must take one dose and keep it in her mouth for ten minutes as soon as her husband is angry.
Quarrelsome wife reproved by a good whipping.
Jealous wife or husband.
Heavenly maidens are not jealous.
Woman jealous of a fair maid in her house. Fears her attraction for her husband.
King's wives jealous of his attention to pet animal.
Jealousy of rival wives.
Wife exposes bald head of second wife to disgrace her. Hair marvelously regrows.
Jealous wife (mistress) transforms rival to hound.
Decision not to punish a jealous husband: he already suffers enough.

Husband jealous of wife who goes to confession is punished by the priest. When the husband sees the priest take her behind the altar to punish her he volunteers to take the punishment. The wife says, "Pound him well. I am a terrible sinner."
Jealous husband kills nightingale which his wife gets up to hear.
Woman's scented hair attracts deer: husband jealous.
Jealous king causes massacre of handsome young captives.
Husband's unjust jealousy forces wife to commit adultery.
Wife repays husband's supposed adultery by doing likewise.
Jealous husband objects to wife's enjoyment of intercourse: thinks she has had previous experience.
Jealous husband spends all his earnings as skillful smith bribing courtiers not to talk to his wife, and at last locks her up in hut in the forest.
Trickster sends jealous wife after husband: steals food.
Jealous wife ties husband to her so that he cannot get away to meet another woman.
The curious wife.

The curious wife: wait and see. A man and his wife overhear thieves planning to rob the house, put the man out of the way, and have their will of the wife. The man wants to raise an alarm. She says, "Wait and see."
Husband insists on knowing wife's secret.
Wife insists upon knowing husband's secret.
The ungrateful wife.
Husband takes wife's place and receives punishment for her adultery. She is ungrateful.
The hypocritical wife. Shows what she has done for her husband, but not what she has done for herself.
Jewels of Cornelia. She shows her children as her jewels.
Beautiful woman married to hideous man: he is thankful, she patient. She says that they have thus both gained paradise.
The neglected wife.
Woman gets rid of impotent husband and remarries.
Mistress of impotent husband sends her maid to find a man for her.
The silent wife.
Silent wife brought to speech by dangers to her husband.
Wife cannot keep secret.
The spendthrift wife.
Other aspects of married life.
Sex hospitality. Host gives his wife (daughter) to his guest as bed companion.
Sex hospitality given to druid.
Sex hospitality given to king (prince).
Handmaid given as wife unto husband by barren wife.
First (barren) wife insists her husband should take second wife.
Wife withholds intercourse from husband to enforce demand.
Frightened wife shows marks of affection for husband. This is so rare that he pardons the robber who has caused the fright.
Mistress has always said her "Aves": Virgin Mary refuses to help wife against her rival. The wife tells this to the mistress, who repents.
Sight of mistress's ring causes husband to withhold himself from his wife.
Why separation of a good woman from a bad man is a benefit.
Wife refuses to sleep with detested husband.
Wife curses unbeloved husband who attempts to force her.

Why widow does not remarry. (1) Only her property is wanted; (2) her husband is still in her heart; (3) if new husband is bad it will not be well, if he is good there will be the fear that he will die.
Wife keeps vow never to wed after her husband's death.
Wife sold unwillingly by husband.
Wives traded.
Husband (wife) of supernatural being longs for old home and visits relatives.

Husband's indiscreet boast about wife brings about his death. King regards his wife as so beautiful that he has a friend view her naked through a crack in the wall. Wife learns of his act, goes over to the man who has viewed her, and with the latter brings about the king's death.
Wife buys (sells) privilege of sleeping one night with husband.
Reconciliation of separated couple.
Other aspects of married life miscellaneous.
Sleeping with head laid in wife's lap as sign of tenderness.
Wife gives wise warning to husband.
Man warned by wife against stepping on red cloth.
Wife warns departing hero against seductions of women.
Chastity and celibacy.
Sacrifice of virginity.
Methods of ascetics.
Celibacy and continence.
Ceremonial continence.
"Night of Sabbath" (Friday night) only devoted to conjugal pleasures.
Woman averse to marriage.
Woman's aversion to marriage motivated through a dream.
Flight of maiden (bridegroom) to escape marriage.
Woman prefers to remain chaste rather than keep an impotent husband.
Girl commits suicide rather than marry man she does not love.
Girl remains a virgin after both her suitors are killed in battle.
Maiden queen prefers to fight instead of marrying, but is at last conquered and married.
Saint's daughter dies when wooed.
Woman dies when spoiled of her sanctity.
Ravished girl's virginity restored by Virgin Mary.
Ravished girl's virginity restored by saint.
Pregnant nun's virginity restored through power of saint.
Father kills daughter lest she become prostitute.
Father kills daughter lest she become the property of a tyrant.
Continence in marriage.
Marital continence by mutual agreement.
The continent husband.

The audacious water and the continent husband. A woman with a continent husband (lover) splashes water on her thighs as she crosses a stream and then reproves it for being bolder than her husband. She thus calls attention to her situation.
Wife reproves continent husband by showing conduct of cock and hens.
Wife reforms continent husband by having walls of bedroom painted with erotic scenes.
Woman continent in two marriages to become a nun.
The repression of lust.
Repression of lust through sitting in water.
Repression of lust through prayer.
Repression of lust through preaching.
Repression of lust through fasting.
Man and woman in chaste love for twenty-five years.
Monk finds that only abuse and cruel treatment from his fellow monks can conquer his lust.
Wife proves her faithfulness. Had substituted for husband's mistress. Proves legitimacy of her child by producing tokens and by child's missing toe (like her husband's four-toed foot).
Escape from undesired lover.
Oft-proved fidelity. Repeated attempts to seduce innocent woman. She escapes them all.
Virginity saved in spite of torture. Undesired suitors give up task.
Girl kills man who threatens her virtue.
Woman escaping from slavery kills man who would ravish her.
Bride puts to flight man who attempts to ravish her.
Widow dons late husband's armor to put would-be ravisher to flight.
Wife escapes lust of king by shaming him.
Woman escapes king's lust by inducing bad breath.
Girl gives up wealth and flees to escape lecherous emperor.
Wife sets fire to house to escape undesired lover.
Escape from undesired lover by miracle.
Maid pledged to celibacy is given, at her prayer, a beard.
Girl named Mary has virginity spared by knight who has bought her. The Virgin appears to her.
Girl's virginity spared by knight when he sees her surrounded by the Virgin and her train. In her straits the girl has prayed for help.
Girl prays to Virgin to spare her virginity. Two soldiers quarrel over possessing her. Captain slays her, thus "saving" her.
Magic sickness (discomfort) prevents lover from raping woman.
In answer to maiden's prayer saint changes boat's course and guides it to another place.
Girl strikes man who tries to kiss her.
Woman kicks lecherous monk down the stairs.
Princess threatens to kill amorous king.
Undesired lover drugged and carried out.
Girl pleads vow of chastity to repel lover.
Escape from undesired lover by strategy.
Princess escapes from undesired lover by fleeing disguised as a bishop.
Princess evades unwelcome lover by putting on foul-smelling skin-coat.
Girl's virginity saved by the kindness of an emissary. Makes the lord believe she is a relative.
Chaste woman resists advances of a conqueror.
Chaste woman promises conqueror drug of invulnerability. Has him try it on her. Cuts her head off.
Suicide to save virginity.
Girls drown selves to save their virginity.
Man is killed defending sweetheart's honor. She kills herself.
Martyrdom to preserve virginity.
Mutilation to repel lover.
Maiden sends to her lecherous lover (brother) her eyes (hands, breasts) which he has admired.
Woman successfully prays for disease to repel lover.
Saint plucks out her eye when urged to marry.
Maidens befoul selves with blood to escape rape.
Woman raises sores on her body to preserve chastity.
Princess takes on loathsome disguise to avoid unwelcome demon-lover.
Girl escapes from undesired lover by cutting off her plaits of hair.
Girl lives in sepulchre to preserve chastity.
Anchorites under temptation.
Man unsuccessfully tempted by woman. (St. Anthony.)
Monk unsuccessfully tempted in nunnery.
Knight unsuccessfully tempted by host's wife.
Woman masks as man to deceive anchorite.
No place secret enough for fornication. Monk thus repels temptress.
Anchorite saved by a miracle. When he is about to give in to temptation a dove flies out of his mouth. On repenting the dove re-enters his mouth.
Saint flogs woman who tempts him.
Saint sleeps with maidens without sinning. Another saint, who doubts fact, undergoes same test and perceives its efficacy.
Monk unsuccessfully tempted by woman he formerly loved.
Monk yells "thief" to repel temptress. When she seeks him in his bed he screams. He says she steals his most valuable possession, virtue.
Man tempted by fiend in woman's shape. (Or woman by fiend in man's shape.)
Woman sent by deity to tempt self-righteous anchorite.
Man mutilates himself to remove temptation.
Tempted man bites out his tongue and spits it in temptress's face.
Tempted man burns off his fingers. Frightens his temptress.
Man disfigures his face to remove temptation.
Tempted rabbi tears out his eyes to escape temptation.
Tempted holy man mutilates genitals.
Hero cuts off head and wraps it in napkin so he will not be tempted by sight of virgins.
Monk cures himself of desire for dead sweetheart. He digs up her remains.
Monk goes into desert to avoid temptation of women, the prime source of sin.
Saint exposes self to temptation but preserves chastity. Thus insures self greater reward in Heaven.
Sight or touch of woman as source of sin.
Woman's girdle as source of sin.
Woman's voice as source of sin.
Woman wagers that she can seduce anchorite.
Saint's enemy, wishing to cause saint to violate his oath never to "commit folly and utter lie," induces his daughter to tempt saint. Saint perceives trick and avoids sin.
Virtuous man seduced by woman.
Ascetic successfully tempted: kills son born in consequence.
Chaste sleeping together.
Sword of chastity. A two-edged sword is laid between the couple sleeping together.
Bed-cover of chastity. Similar to sword of chastity.
Boy sleeps between couple to safeguard their virtue.
Object set between beds of couple sleeping in same room.
Chaste sleeping together to torment woman. Man remains utterly impassive.
Chaste sleeping together with six sisters-in-law one by one.
Young man sleeps on girl's mat without touching her to signify his desire.
Chastity and celibacy miscellaneous.
Nun refuses to look at man.
Nun so opposed to seeing men that she refuses to see St. Martin.
The boy who had never seen a woman: the Satans. When he sees a girl and asks his father what it is, the father tells him it is Satan. Asked what he most likes he says, "The Satans."
Boy is denied sight of all women except his mother and his nurse until he is eighteen. He falls in love with the first woman who is more attractive than his mother.
Adulterous love changed into a chaste one.
Heavy chastity belt imposed on wife.
Young man betrothed to statue. Man puts marriage ring on finger of statue of Venus (Virgin Mary). She afterwards forbids him the embraces of an earthly bride.
Man leaves earthly bride for service of Virgin.
Imprisoned virgin to prevent knowledge of men (marriage, impregnation). Usually kept in a tower. (Danal.)
Girl intended for marriage with king cloistered.
Wife imprisoned in tower (house) to preserve chastity.
Guarded maiden first seen by hero in church.
Guarded maiden first seen by hero in otherworld.
Attempt to keep wife chaste by carrying her in box. In spite of all precautions she meets men.
Other futile attempts to keep wife chaste.
Message of chastity: uncooked meat left behind. Man conducting a woman leaves uncooked meat behind each night of the journey as a sign to the husband following that she has not been touched.
Illicit sexual relations.
Virgin Mary as protectress of illicit lovers.
Pregnant abbess secretly delivered of her child by Virgin Mary.
Incest.
Master discovers that slave girl he wants to marry is a near relative.
Father-daughter incest.
Lecherous father. Unnatural father wants to marry his daughter. (Manekine.)
Father by trickery secures priest's advice to marry his own daughter. If a man raise a lamb, shall he eat it himself or let another eat it?
Father feigning death returns in disguise and seduces daughter.
Girl got with child by intoxicated father.
Daughters seduce drunken father.
Mother-son incest.
Mother guilty of incest with son forgiven by Pope (Virgin Mary).
Incognito son tempts mother to see whether all women are wicked.
Mother guilty of incest with son whose honor she is testing.
Boy courts his mother, is driven off by father.
Brother-sister incest.
Lecherous brother. Wants to seduce (marry) his sister.
Brother repels incestuous sister.
Lovers reared as brother and sister learn to their joy that they are not related.
Two lovers give each other up when they learn that they are brother and sister.
Brother-sister marriage.
Suicide to prevent brother-sister marriage.
When boy cannot have his sister for a wife he asks for one of her eyes and ears instead.
Son-in-law seduces mother-in-law.
Mother-in-law seduces son-in-law.
Lustful stepmother.
Lustful stepfather.
Man marries his aunt (mother's sister).
Youth attempts to seduce his grandmother.
Brother-in-law seduces (seeks to seduce) sister-in-law.
Prostitution and concubinage.
Wife born to be prostitute. Husband unable to change her ways, submits to them.
Woman disappointed in love threatens to become prostitute.
Prostitution to avoid starvation.
Prostitute has favorite lover.
Devil causes girl to become prostitute. Destroys the girl's family and begets on her a boy.
Bawds. Professional go-betweens.
Mother acts as procuress of bedmate for her son.
Getting advice from a woman in bed.
Hero learns feats of arms through gratifying woman's lust.
Prostitute gets advice from customer.
Woman sells favors for particular purpose.
Woman sells favors to obtain a jewel.
Woman sells favors to obtain many jewels.
Woman sacrifices her honor to free her husband (brother) from prison.
Woman commits adultery to obtain aid for husband in battle.
Woman sells favors for beautiful clothes.
Women sells favors for new shoes.
Parents urge girl to trade her favors for truce with hostile warrior.
Woman gives favors to pay for help across river.
Woman sells favors for large sum of money (property).
Princess gives herself to Turks of her own accord in order to save her people.
Bed-partner to receive payment from first man she meets in the morning. It so happens: she marries the man and he makes her wealthy.
Girl dares not receive gift from a man as it may be supposed to be payment for her favors.
Sacred prostitution.
Woman enjoys the ravishings of the enemy.
Sexual perversions.
Person enamored of an object.
Woman enamored of a river.
Women cohabit with magic house pillars.
Tree as wife.
Lesbian love.
Lesbian love: women give birth to monsters as result.
Homosexual love (male).
Bestiality. Intercourse of a human being and an animal.
Sheep born with human head as a result of bestiality.
Foal born of Loki after dealing with mythical stallion.
Homocentaurus born as a result of bestiality.
Children are spotted like leopards as result of bestiality.
Pig born with head like that of man as a result of bestiality.
Necrophilism: sexual intercourse with dead human body.
The amorous bite.
Illicit sexual relations miscellaneous motifs.
Rape.
Fines imposed for rape.
Man unwittingly ravishes his own sister.
Wild man as ravisher of women.
Husband sends wife poison to avoid having her ravished by the enemy.
Unknown (clandestine) paramour.
Unknown paramour discovered by string clue.
Hero lies by princess in magic sleep and begets child.
Intercourse with sleeping girl.
Incognito mistress. King's mistress secretly becomes hero's without revealing identity.
Adultery.
Adulteress roughly treated by her lover.
Queen's illicit passion for diseased man.
Queen commits adultery with low-born man.
Adulteress sells self to devil for money.
Wife seduces husband's servant (pupil).
King takes subject's wife while her husband is sent away.
Queen begets son with duke while the king is in war.
Woman advises husband to kill guest else, she will make him chase husband and marry her instead.
Day husband: night husband. Woman has two husbands: juggler at home only at night, robber only in day. They do not know about each other. (Similarly, day wife: night wife.)
Maidservant given to lover's companion as bed-partner.
Fruit-picking time used for sexual promiscuity.
Man has a son not his wife's; wife has a daughter not her husband's. Children become lovers.
Queen makes all men who come to serve her copulate with her.
Black nipples of girl's breasts reveal her loss of virginity.

Each likes his own children best. Snipe asks sportsman to spare its small ones, easily recognized as being the prettiest in the forest. To be on the safe side he shoots only the ugliest he can find. They are the young snipes. (Often told of the ape.)
Animals ridicule foolish pride of owl in the beauty of his son's really hideous feet.

Children sleep in village dormitory.
Life's inequalities.
Justice and injustice.
Small trespasses punished; large crimes condoned.
Ass punished for stealing mouthful of grass; lion and wolf forgiven for eating sheep.
Animals confess sins to one another: fox and wolf forgive each other; punish ass.
Animals confess sins to lion holding court. All the powerful animals forgiven. Ass and lamb are punished.
Penitent in confession worries about little sins and belittles the big ones.
He who steals much called king; he who steals little called robber.
Wolf punished for theft; kings honored.
Largest burdens laid on smallest asses: best offices to most ignorant men.
Unworthy rewarded instead of the worthy.

Fool laughs at the absurdities he sees about him. (1) Sees a man who is to die that day buy shoes. (2) Sees sheriff leading a man to the gallows: a big thief leading a little one. (3) Sees farmer weeping at funeral of his child, while priest (the real father) sings.
Dwarf king (fairy) laughs at the absurdities he sees about him. (1) Sees man who is to die that day complain that his shoes are too thin.
Philosopher laughs at the vanities and sins of the world. His companion weeps.
The fathers have eaten sour grapes and the children's teeth are set on edge.
Justice depends on the point of view.
Hen complains that man eats her, but she eats ant.
A gift of property silences criticism. A priest who has preached against lucrative places given the clergy is silent when he receives one.
Man complains of injustice of gods' wrecking ship because of one man's sin. He then kills whole swarm of ants because one has stung him.
Wolf objects to lion stealing sheep from him although he has himself stolen it.
Judge reduces penalty when accused is his own son.
Theft to avoid starvation forgiven.
Swallow killed in court house by snake laments injustice in house of justice.
Rights of the strong.
Wolf unjustly accuses lamb and eats him. When all the lamb's defenses are good the wolf asserts the right of the strong over the weak. (Usually accused of stirring up water from lower in stream.)
Cat unjustly accuses cock and eats him. Although all the cock's defenses are good the cat tells him that she can no longer go hungry and eats him.
Crow exercises rights of strong over dove who cannot defend self. Dove at crow's request sings to save her brood which crow kills after song.
Smallness of offense no excuse when hunter prepares to kill lark. She has stolen but a single grain of wheat.
Cock killed by his captors in spite of his plea of usefulness to man.
Nobleman murders one of the people. Goes unpunished.
Nobleman who kills one of the people is brought to justice only after long delay.
Rich man (king) seizes poor widow's (nun's) cow.
King seizes old woman's cow.
King seizes poor man's lamb.
Nobles ruin peasant's (widow's) crops with impunity.
Lion cub killed by bull gives lioness no right to complain.
Wolf as commander orders all booty divided, but keeps his own.
Ruler exiles subject for trivial remark.
Ruler forces bishop to ordain ignorant priest.
Praise what your master likes and scorn what he dislikes.
Wealth and poverty.
Dividing after God's fashion: little to poor, much to rich.
Priest has no friends until he becomes bishop: then they flock to him.
Wealth is relative: beggar with horse, wife, or dog considered rich by poorer beggar.
Grass serves as pleasant couch for poor.
Every man has his price.
Every woman has her price.
Bid raised for queen's favors until she hesitates. Jester replies, "If a man have goods enough, he might have a sovereign lady."
Jester takes cow and tells king people have plenty of milk, for "he who is warm thinks everyone else is."
Optimist becomes pessimist when his money is stolen.
Man so constantly enriched by God that he cannot give all his goods to the poor.
Great possessions bring great risks.
Dove's pride in her large brood linked with fear for their loss.
King in exile neglected, but courted when he regains throne.
Price of object depends on where it is on sale.
Appearances deceive.
Many books do not make a scholar.
Many books do not make a scholar: youth tricks mother by carrying many books.
Beard on she-goats do not make a male.
Big voice: little creature. (Frogs, crickets.)
Mountain in labor brings forth a mouse.
The skeleton in the closet. An apparently happy man lets another see the actual misery of his existence.
Apparently happy woman discloses the skeleton of her slain paramour.
Hypocrite is acclaimed as saint after his death.
Man rejects bride because she seems immature. Her father reassures him that she has had several children already.
Other ways in which appearances deceive.
Revelations of a satyr.
At a funeral of a child a satyr reveals that the real father (officiating priest) sings while the cuckold weeps.
At a hanging the witnesses are bigger thieves than the culprit.
Peasant wishes to exchange places with monks. Thinks they lead a very easy life. One night's experience in the monastery makes him change his mind.
Handsome exterior does not indicate beautiful soul. Angel holds nose when handsome sinner passes.
An ugly face does not mean an ugly soul. A noble and holy man who is very ugly is proved to be a saintly soul.
Stories to show that one's name does not alter his condition.
Nature will show itself.
Like parent, like child.
Crab walks backward: learned from his parents.
Hind, like his mother, flees before the hounds. Useless for her to urge him to stand up against them.
Farmer's son and noble's reared in country. The former takes to toil on farm, the latter to riding and hunting.
Alleged son of king proved to be bastard when he displays habits of his true father.
Father, like son, acts foolishly at king's court.
Butcher's son becomes cruel and atrocious ruler.
Dungbeetle prefers his dunghill to all other smells.
Beetles treated with as much honor as oxen will not learn to act as oxen.
Hog goes to bath but wallows in the mud.
Scorpion, in spite of himself, stings the turtle carrying him across the stream. Is drowned.
Wolf loses interest in the sermon when he sees a flock of sheep. A dervish preaches to him.
Heron (crane) loses interest in heaven if there are no snails.
Dog allowed to warm self in house begins to bark. Is chased off.
Fawn, in spite of his fine horns, runs from the dog.
Tiger son of human mother scratches her and licks her blood.
Tiger father of human child licks its blood.
Nature will show itself miscellaneous.
Thieving nature of the fox will show itself.
Prostitute will deceive new lover as always.
Washerman as minister thinks of washing and fails the king.
The power of habit.
Newly rich cannot resist call for distribution of food to beggars.
Familiarity takes away fear.
Fox finally converses with lion whom he had feared at first.
Men at first frightened at camel take him into their service.
Man soon learns to stand the smells of the tannery.
Farmer prefers stable smells to flowers. Latter make him ill.
Knight doesn't want to go to heaven if there are no hunting dogs there.
Longing for accustomed food and living.
At feast cat chooses rat meat; other animals cannot eat it.
Shepherd in king's palace sickens for country air.
Former slave sickens for accustomed food.
Peasant girl married to king longs for peasant ways of eating.
Peasants fed white bread demand the rye bread to which they are accustomed.
Fisher and hunter exchange catches for variety: soon return to original food.
Dissatisfied workmen exchange work: still more dissatisfied.
Beasts and fishes exchange places: fatal to both.
Mill horse when taken to war keeps going in a circle, as he has learned in the mill.
Habit of dishonesty (thievery) cannot be broken.
Dishonest silversmith restless until silver ornament is mixed with alloy.
Thieves cannot quit plundering.
Power of habit miscellaneous.
Habitual food and drink continued even when it is harmful.
Conservatism defies reason.
Conservative but absurd way of slaughtering hog stubbornly kept.
One man's food is another man's poison.
Enmity between fisherman and dweller on the river. Fishing stirs up the water and makes it unfit for drinking.
Ox likes loving strokes of man; flea fears them.
Collier and fuller cannot live together: one makes things clean, the other soils them.
Nightingale cannot lodge with birds whose nest is made of manure.
Royalty unable to endure coarse entertainment.
Coarse food, etc., sends adulterous king back to his wife.
Animals try unsuccessfully to exchange food.
Good weather for one is foul for another.
Bird wants sunshine, worm clouds.
What is one man's food is another man's poison miscellaneous.
Lions despise what asses admire (braying).
Indifference of the miserable.
Ass indifferent to enemy's approach: he could be no more miserable than now.
Misfortune with oneself to blame the hardest.
Eagle killed with arrow made with his own feather.
Tree cut down with axe for which it has furnished a handle.
Behavior of the blind.
Blind man crosses a narrow bridge which his guide is afraid to attempt.
Two blind men succeed in fooling each other about their blindness.
Futile attempt to explain to a blind man meaning of "white".
In vino veritas.
Man unable to persuade wife to confess misdeed to priest succeeds when he makes her drunk.
Bad ruler, bad subject.
No great knights now because no great kings.
To have good servants a lord must be good.
Forced peace valueless.
Monk under pressure from abbot forgives the crucifix which has fallen and hurt him. He says that nevertheless there will always be hatred between them.
The nature of sin.
Monk leaves monastery when he sees a devil there tempting brethren. Returns when in the world he sees scores of devils tempting the people.
Hermit having rebuked youth falls himself when exposed to the same sin.
Monk rebukes brethren who succumb to temptation. When he is exposed to it he understands what temptation is.
No place secret enough for sin.
Lying is incurable. A father asks about his son. When he hears that he lies, he gives the son up as hopeless. Other sins may be outgrown.
Liar cannot be healed even when taking bath in the Ganges.
False repentance of the sick. Wolf having eaten too much meat promises God to eat no more meat. When he becomes well he eats as before.
False repentance of the sick, rich man. After his death it was discovered that he had intended to retrieve his money from church if he recovered.
Power of mind over body.
King grows lean from fear of death.
Hares fearing death outrun pursuing dogs.
The hare's last will. Surrounded by hunters and hounds, the hare considers to whom each of his members will be allotted. Succeeds in escaping.
Courage conquers all and impossible is made possible.
Shortness of life.
The bad custom in the world: the young die as well as the old. Hence youth enters monastery.
Passage of time.
Time seems short to those who play, long for those who wait. So says servant girl whose mistress upbraids her for late hours.
Suffering healed by time.
Security breeds indifference.
Cat ceases catching rats as soon as he is given a home in a monastery. Thus with lazy priests.

Saint cures palsy.
Saint restores dumb man's speech.
Saint cures leprosy.
Leper cured by the kiss of a saint.
Saint subdues madman.
Saint cures frenzied animal.
Saint's blessing sufficient to control a mad dog.
Saint purifies monk with sign of the cross.
Saint sustains man on gallows.
Woman relieved of incurable malady by kissing letter from saint.
Wounds cured by saint leave no scars.
Cut off parts of body attached again by saint.
Men with enormous and unnatural appetite cured by saint.
Saint cures dumb person.
Saint cures blindness.
Miraculous manifestation acclaims saint.
Birth of saint predicted by visions of miracles.
Pillar of fire rises over woman pregnant with future saint.
Saint identified by pillar of fire above her head.
Dazzling heavenly light by day and night marks place of saint's birth.
Angels appear above place where saint is born.
Marvelous light accompanying saint.
Supernaturally bright light marks sleeping infant saint.
"Fair Drop" from. Heaven falls upon infant saint.
Radiance fills church when saint dies.
Hand of saint made bright by Lord's touch. Too splendid for man's sight thereafter.
Column of light descends from heaven upon chosen man.
Lights show where the body of saint is buried.
Brake in which saint loses tooth bursts into flame.
Choral singing accompanies saint.
House of saint filled with fragrance.
Aromatic smell of a saint's body.
Oil bursts from ground as saint is made bishop.
Bell sounds at approach of saint.
Church bells ring without aid of human hands at death of holy person.
Dead holy man stretches hand from tomb to honor saint.
Holy man passes through fire for his faith. Only his clothing burns.
Earthquake accompanies entrance of holy man into palace of heathen emperor.
Saint falling into an abyss found perched in the branches of a tree which projected from the cliff. As soon as the man is drawn up, the tree vanishes.
Flowers fall from saint's mouth while he speaks.
Holy man restores a garden to bloom.
Sun sends shaft of heat to cook meat given persecuted saint.
Roses lose thorns when saint walks on them.
Saint changes maggots in the sores of a nun into precious stones.
Robbers who enter saint's garden to steal are caused to spade it up for him. This proves him to be saint.
Saints have miraculous knowledge.
Saint gives advice.
Saint warns against poisoned well.
Saint can perceive the thoughts of another man and reveal hidden sins.
Saint helps with learning.
Truant boy learns long lesson while asleep with head in saint's lap.
Saints blessed with ability to discourse in the native idioms of the people whom they visit.
Saint understands language of wren, fly, cat.
Saint as prognosticator.
Saint can foretell the weather.
Miraculous replacement of objects (animals) for saint.
Objects used as firewood for saint miraculously replaced.
Food (animals) eaten by saint miraculously replaced.
Animals stolen from saint miraculously replaced.
Performing fox accidentally killed miraculously replaced for saint.
Supply of lime for building church miraculously renewed for saint.
Saints in several places at once.
Saints as hermits.
Saints have divine visitors.
God gives staff of Jesus to saint.
Immunities of saints (holy men).
Saint immune to poisoning.
Saint drinks poison without being injured.
Anchorite immune to magician's powers.
Saints miscellaneous.
Saint commands return from dead with supernatural information.
Sanctity of saints.
Saintly babe repeatedly found with arms extended in form of cross.
Saintly babe disgorges unclean food.
Saint will drink only milk of cow milked by faithful woman.
Saint as baby refuses to take mother's breast on Wednesdays and Fridays.
Baptism of a wonder child is accompanied by a variety of phenomena.
Place of saint's martyrdom perpetually green.
Martyrs emit milk instead of blood from their wounds.
Saint sheds tears of blood.
Flowers grow on graves from the mouths or hearts of holy persons.
Saint's body remains unspoiled in the earth for a long time.
Tombs of saints distill oil.
Stones answer "Amen" after saint's preaching.
Miracle saves saint from unjust censure.
Saint causes gluttonous reptile to leap from saint's body into bishop's throat and then return as proof of bishop's injustice.
Extraordinary longevity of saints.
Seven Irish saints who never died.
Saint lives for 300 (100?). years without eating food or uttering evil.
Saint promises to return from heaven.
Saint banishes snakes.
Saint overcomes (destroys) monsters (dragons).
Saint banishes demons.
Saint confines monster (dragon) in lake.
Saint in conflict with druid.
Saint limits powers of satirist (druid).
Ale poisoned by druid miraculously purified by saint.
Druid raised in air, cast down, and brains scattered on stone by power of saint.
Druid by spells seeks to drive saint from island.
Invaders miraculously defeated by saints.
Saint drives away an army by bringing upon it a dense and smoky cloud.
Saints create magic concealing mist.
Unusual fuel used by saints: burning stone, snow and icicles, marble pillar, and green timber.
Broken objects restored to their original forms by saint.
Burned clothes restored to their previous form.
Holy man restores cut-off hands and feet.
Saint causes grey hair to grow in black.
Saint with tongue of fire (literally).
Sinful beauty is converted and spends the end of her life doing penance (Mary Magdalene, Mary of Egypt, and Thais).
Ground elevates itself to give protection or comfort to saint.
Saint in anger shows strength: wall broken by his kick.
Saint disguised as poor man saves almsgiving king from punishment in hell.
Lake of milk made through merit of saint.
Saint's blessing causes a river to be best place for fishing.
Dispute between two saints settled by angel.
Objects mourn death of saint (holy man).
Downfall of ascetic (saint).
After birth of son holy person loses miraculous power.
House and family appear overnight to afford hospitality to benighted priests.
Severed head of saint speaks so that searchers can find it.
Stone turns red when saint's picture is removed.
Saint turns snakes to stones.
Conversation of animals reveals to man how to become saint.
Angels.
Man beholds angels.
Angels powerful.
Angel and mortal struggle.
Appearance of angel.
Angel in bird shape.
Shooting star as angel.
Angel with four wings.
Angel is form of cleric.
Angel appears to woman to warn her not to force girl into marriage.
Angel in the form of an old man.
Angel as helper.
Angel as helper in battle.
Angels appear and help boy prince slay treacherous uncle.
Angel carries mortal.
Angel carries boat to water.
Angel transports saint's staff.
Angels supply food to mortal.
Angel shows saint where to dig for water.
Angel looses man's fetters.
Angel as guide.
Angel guides chariot.
Angel reveals location of lost (buried) object.
Gifts from angels.
Angel brings cross as gift to saint.
Angel helps Peter to escape from prison.
Angel cleans hearth.
Angels build church.
Angel of death.
Angel of death spares mother who is suckling children. As punishment angel must serve as sexton.
Songs of the angels.
Angels sing in honor of saint.
Angels sing to welcome saint.
Angels sing over saint's body.
Angel choir responds when saint receives orders.
Angels sing on night of Christ's Nativity.
Mortal visited by angel.
Mortals visited by angel in vision.
Angel invoked by fasting.
Angel announces birth of Christ to shepherds.
Angel comforts repentant sinner.
Angel bars abbot from his cell because abbot has cast out a sinning monk.
Fallen angels.
Fallen angels become fairies (dwarfs, trolls).
Angel bars the way to Baalam's ass.
Guardian angel.
Angels hover over mortal (saint).
Angels melt snow around saintly babe.
Service of angels marks saint's destination.
Air above grave of converted druid full of angels.
Angels honor mortal.
Angels attend saint's funeral.
Angel directs saint's burial.
Angels hold service over (saint's) tomb.
Angels shed light upon saint's tomb.
Angels run races before saint.
Angel baptizes saint.
Angel names child.
Angels set heavenly veil upon head of pious woman.
Holy place (object) glorified by angel's presence.
Train of angels rises from graveyard.
Angel abides in church.
Angels attend church service.
Angel passes daily over blessed stone.
Angel answers mortal's prayer.
Angels appear above grave of fallen girl through virtue of prayers said by her lover (young monk).
Angel beseeches at unholy grave of redeemed sinner until body is moved to sanctified ground.
Angel punishes mortal.
Angel scourges mortal for disobedience to God.
Angel counsels mortal.
Angel leaves letter (book) with instructions for saint.
Angel dictates (gives) book.
Angel tells saint where to build his church.
Angel as saint's teacher.
Angel informs saint of coming of guests.
Daily life of angels.
Angels and God.
Angels miscellaneous motifs.
Angel makes proclamation.
Language of angels.
Hebrew the language of the angels.
The Virgin Mary.
Irish saint as "Mary of the Gael".
Virgin Mary has golden hair.
Virgin Mary prevents (retards) death so as to save sinner's soul. Permits time for repentance and absolution.
Virgin Mary brings man back to life after he has seen hell's torments.
Virgin Mary defends innocent accused.

Virgin Mary returns borrowed money and reveals cheat. A man borrows money from a Jew with the Virgin as security. Unable to return the money in time, he commits the money to the sea with a prayer to the Virgin. The Jew receives it but claims that the money is not paid. The Virgin reveals the cheat.
Virgin Mary saves criminal from fire at stake.
Faithfulness to Virgin Mary, even if not to Christ, rewarded.
Efficacy of saying "Aves".
Saying of "Aves" obliterates sin.
Virgin Mary supports robber on gallows because he once said "Ave Maria".
Ship in storm saved because of sailors' "Ave Maria".
"Ave" on the tongue. Because of faithfulness in saying "Aves" the words are found imprinted on the dead man's tongue.
Blasphemer paralyzed in all members except tongue which had once said "Ave Maria".
Devil exorcised by "Ave".
Nun forgets to hail Mary and goes into the world to sin.
Joseph and Mary threaten to leave heaven when the man who has always prayed to them is refused admittance.
Murdered boy still sings "Ave" after his death. (Chaucer's Prioress's Tale.)
Criminal who said "Ave" beheaded. His head calls repeatedly, "Ave Maria".
Virgin Mary will not let devil (authorities) take robber noble who daily says "Ave".
Virgin forbids devil to take robber as long as he continues to say two "Aves" daily.
Virgin Mary has dissolute monk buried in consecrated ground: his only mass is that of the Virgin.
Devotee of Virgin not buried in consecrated ground has lily issue from mouth so that his grave is made known.
Virgin gives private mass to devout lady unable to attend.
Miraculous healing by Virgin Mary.
Healing spittle of Virgin Mary.
Miracles of healing performed before image of Virgin Mary.
Virgin Mary restores severed hand to Saint John Damascene. He had cut it off to repress lust.
Virgin Mary saves life of man who at devil's instigation has castrated himself. She will not, however, restore his severed members.
Virgin Mary restores life to drowned man who always had saluted her.
Virgin Mary designates favorite for election for office.
Virgin restores office to an ignorant man because of his faith.
Virgin pardons man who repented for cheating in election.
Virgin Mary supplies mead for unprepared hostess of the king.
Portrait of the Virgin appears to devotee.
Virgin Mary rescues man attacked by the devil.
Virgin Mary brings man a pact he signed with the devil and frees the man from devil's power.
Virgin miraculously prevents nun (monk) from deserting cloister.
Image of Virgin tries in vain to keep nun from leaving convent.
Virgin Mary converts a Jew.
Devotee of Virgin is comforted in the hour of death.
Miracles performed under protection of Virgin Mary.
Boy under protection of Virgin Mary pulled from well alive after a week.
Virgin Mary saves devotee from death in waves.
Virgin Mary destroys Moorish army besieging Constantinople.
Virgin Mary saves devotee's son from shipwreck.
Image of Virgin Mary works miracles.
Virgin Mary as foster mother.
Virgin Mary comforts repentant criminals.
Virgin Mary appears to erring man.
Virgin Mary appears to erring monk and exalts him to prayer. His prayers weave her a garment.
Virgin Mary appears and pardons monk who has been too overworked to pray to her.
Virgin Mary aids repentant slayer of priest. Priest is resurrected in order to forgive murderer and then is returned to tomb.
Virgin Mary appears to devotee.
Virgin Mary appears to devout nun with infant Jesus. The nun devoutly prayed to see Him.
Devotee of Virgin Mary given present by her.
Stella Maris: Virgin Mary as protectress of sailors.
Testament of Virgin Mary.
During a flood the Virgin descends into the streets to save her image from the flood waters.
Other sacred persons.
Master poets (ollamhs) as sacred persons.
The Apostles of Christ.
Appearance of the Apostles.
The Twelve Apostles of Ireland.
Lepers as sacred persons.
The Pope.
Religious beliefs.
Particular dogmas.
Belief in the life to come.
Doctrine of immortality taught by druids.
Man converted to belief in future life on deathbed. Feels sure nevertheless that nothing will come of it.
Dying man refuses to believe in life to come.
Given choice between life and heaven, person chooses latter.
Belief in Immaculate Conception.
Proclamation of dogma of Immaculate Conception stops plague.
Man miraculously dies for opposing dogma of Immaculate Conception. Attempt to disprove the dogma by false miracle. Sham dead man is to rise if the dogma is not true. He is found to be actually dead.
Last judgment.
Belief in the Atonement.
Power of repentance.
Efficacy of prayer.
"He that asks shall receive.". Hermit wants to prove truth of these words of the Gospel and asks for the hand of the princess. Performs the difficult task imposed upon him.
The chosen people.
Holy land.
Heretics.
Insane man burns heretic in his bed: restored to his senses as reward.
Heretical baptism. Heathen baptized into devil's possession.
Atheists.
Epicureans regarded as atheists.
Baptismal water vanishes before Aryan bishop.
Hero renounces heaven because dead companions (heathen) are not there.
Author of book against heretic honored by Virgin Mary and angels.
Man sets fire to his house and perishes in it rather than accept Christianity.
Conversion from one religion to another.
Conversion to Christianity.
Druid converted to Christianity.
Three (two) Irishmen who believed in Christianity before the coming of St. Patrick.
Conversion to Christianity through miracle.
Conversion to Christianity by miracle of seeing blood flow from Jesus' image.
Conversion to Christianity through appearance of the cross and angels.
Conversion to Christianity because the heathen gods prove to be less powerful.
Conversion because saint's staff miraculously goes through neophytes' foot.
Conversion to Christianity on pain of death.
Miraculous beautification upon conversion to Christianity.
Conversion to Christianity through repentance.
Conversion to Christianity through love.
Conversion to Christianity out of gratitude. Ruler has captive baptize his sister and then marry her. Grateful for past kindnesses.
Saladin asks to be made a Christian knight.
Fairies converted to Christianity.
Swans (transformed children) do not suffer in harsh weather after conversion to Christianity.
Conversion to Christianity because of admiration for Christian virtue.
Conversion to Christianity through show of forgiveness and gentleness.
Baptism of heathen.
Conversion to Judaism.
Miracle manifested to non-believers.
Pagan sybil draws picture of Madonna and Child in sand. Result of vision.
Sign of cross intimidates Jews.
Jews protesting against marriage of Jewess and Christian are struck dumb.
Temple about to be taken over by pagans saved by appearance of a Sign of the Cross (image of the Virgin).
Dove flies out of man's mouth. Impious anchorite has agreed to forsake his religion in return for the possession of a maid. When he repents the dove reenters his mouth.
Skeptic kicked by sacrificial animal.
Idols found on their faces after saint's arrival.
Conflicts between religions.
Duel (debate) to prove which religion is better.
Wise heretic is vanquished in debate with a Christian.
Brahmin wins a discussion on religion.
Unbeliever loses argument with hermit.
Magician overpowered in contest with a saint.
Contest of St. Peter with Simon Magus, a magician.
Prayer-contest to prove which religion is better.
Contest of miraculous powers between a Yogi and a Musselman.
Pagan disputant with Christian stricken dumb.
Pagan disputant with Christian bested by the words put in his mouth by God.
Life of heroic age preferable to Christian living.
Buddhists become slaves of Taoists because they cannot produce rain.
Christian hero (saint) overthrows heathen idols.
Saint dispels pagan devils from ancient shrines.
Pagan shrines and idols, or magic books destroyed by fire from heaven.
Heathen idols sink into earth up to their necks through power of saint.
Saint's bachall pointed at idol defaces it.
Christian and Jewish traditions about each other.
Christian child killed to furnish blood for Jewish rite. (Hugh of Lincoln.)
Plague from Jews' poisoning wells.
Jewish child thrown into oven by father for taking eucharist. Preserved by Virgin Mary.
Jewish child resurrected (saved by power of Virgin Mary) after being burned to ashes for eating consecrated bread in Christian church.

A Christianized Jew becomes a priest. During Mass, he stabs the consecrated host, blood flows (cf. +C55, +J1261.2, +V30). He kills the other priest who saw him commit the sacrilege, and before killing, forces him to renounce his faith. A miracle exposes the murderer.
Jewish traditions concerning non-Jews.
Religious beliefs miscellaneous.
Heathen beats his god because of misfortune.
Doctor ridicules belief in Devil, Heaven, and Hell.
Religious fanaticism.
Prolonged prostration in worship causes death.
Hindu drinks water by mistake from Mohammedan's vessel: his fortune turns to evil.
Romans won't include Jesus in their pantheon because of his poverty which they hate.
Charity.
Charity rewarded.
Charity rewarded above prayer or hearing of masses.
Prince's motto: charity conquers.
Miraculous reward for charities.
Queen gives away a sleeve of her dress: miraculously restored.
Saint exchanges coat with beggar: gold sleeves miraculously appear.
Man who has given all in charity has foot amputated: restored miraculously.
Stones turn to gold for charitable money-lender. Hence money borrowed for wedding is never refused by lenders.
Treasure given away by saint miraculously restored.
Man earns as much as he gave away for charity in his former life.
Food given away by saint miraculously restored.
Charitable king blows nose after having given to beggar. Huge ruby appears in his kerchief.
Jesus appears to St. Martin when he gives his cloak to beggar.
Charity miraculously repaid: flame settles on forehead.
Miraculous manifestations during act of charity.
Bread stolen by St. Nicholas for purpose of feeding poor is miraculously restored.
The more bread (flour) the monks give to the poor the more God places in their bins.
Son's acts of charity save his father's soul.
Saint shares punishment of sinful man whose cloak he shared in life.
Children envious of money given by deceased father to bishop. In vision they take their father's body up and find a quittance saying that he has received more than a hundredfold reward.
Act of charity obliterates sin.
Man convicted of cheating at his bookkeeping is excused when it is learned that he has given the money to the poor.
Reward of the uncharitable.
Shipman refuses alms: ship turned to stone.
Uncharitable knight drives bargain even in giving alms: devoured by serpents. His alms of corn turn to serpents.
Uncharitable pope wanders after death.
Charity miscellaneous motifs.
Charity of usurers ineffective.
Man beggars self by charity.
Charity of saints.
Conqueror restores kingship to king for charity.
Pious man charitable to man who has formerly refused him charity.
Mendicant refuses to accept alms from barren woman.
Saint repeatedly bestows father's goods upon the poor.
Merit for charity lost by asking work in return.
Other religious virtues.
Forgiveness.
Saint heals enemy.
Religious orders.
First-born son and one of every ten born thereafter given to Church.
Levites as religious order.
Clerical virtues and vices.
Clerical virtue.
Obedient and industrious nun the worthiest in the convent.
Truthful monk refuses to cheat even for his order.
Chastity as clerical virtue.
Submission as clerical virtue.
Truthfulness as clerical virtue.
Extended meditation as clerical virtue.
Monk lives where people speak ill of him to avoid danger of flattery.
Clerical virtue of absolute faith. Man captured by robbers is so confident that God will protect him that he is saved.
Poverty as saintly virtue.
Asceticism.
Kingship renounced to become an ascetic.
Since salvation is predestined, asceticism deemed useless.
Husband abandons wife to become ascetic.
Murderer becomes ascetic.
Maintaining silence as ascetic practice.
Ascetic fasting.
Ascetic faster increases his sufferings by placing food and drink before himself.
Person refuses to eat dainties.
Saint refuses pearls as alms and asks for food.
Death from ascetic devotions.
Ascetic weeping.
Asceticism: allowing self no repose.
Asceticism: cleric practices continual genuflexion.
Cross vigil. Cleric stands with hands extended in shape of cross.
Saint always extends one hand toward heaven while performing such acts as eating or reaping.
Ascetic cleric tortures his flesh.
Ascetic cleric prays to become diseased.
Ascetic cleric wears hair garment.
Saint never wears woolen clothing, but skins of wolves and other beasts.
Ascetic cleric sleeps (prays) with wet sheet (mantle) about him.
Ascetic cleric sleeps on stone.
Saint takes but little sleep.
Saint stands for seven years without sleep.
Ascetic cleric avoids listening to music.
Ascetic cleric never smiles.
Ascetic immersion.
Saint confines himself in narrow pen during Lent.
Saint stands (asleep) while bird builds nest and hatches brood in his hand.
Ascetic cleric leads mendicant life.
Ascetic cleric lives for seven years on whale's back.
Ascetic cleric renounces world (to become a herder).
Monk refuses chance of having temptation removed since he considers it strengthening to have it ever present to test him.
Evil ascetic misuses magic powers obtained through religious meditation.
Boy takes twelve years to wash off ascetic's dirt.
Religious martyrdom.
Cleric surrenders life that body may consecrate land.
First martyr: John the Baptist.
Self-torture to secure holiness.
Clerical vices.
Incontinence of clergy.
Incontinent monk (priest).
Monk seduces girl; then kills her; becomes infidel.
Marriage of clerics.
Incontinent nun.
Nun hidden by abbess from pursuing knight betrays her own hiding place to him. Is afterwards abandoned.
Nun tempted into sinning with man who tells her God can't see things that happen in the dark.
Simony.
Pope guilty of simony.
Priest uses cook-book instead of breviary.
Priest is bribed into betraying the confessional.
Clerical vows.
Taking clerical vows heals disease.
Clerical vows because of disappointment in love.
Man becomes hermit when he realizes selfishness of his beloved's love.
Former monk refuses to take pay for his work, considering it as a religious act.
Renunciation of clerical vows.
Monk who has left order punished (dies in torment).
Monk who has left his order forgiven and miraculously reinstated.
Man who is disappointed with his religious order renounces his vow.
Saint leaves his order because he is fond of music.
Anchorite tempted by money to return to worldly life.
Religious visions.
God speaks in vision to devotee.
Only man without sin can see God.
Visions of the other world.
Visions of heaven.
Saints have visions of heaven.
Vision of angels defending road to heaven against devils.
Visions of hell.
Vision of fires of hell.
Vision of gate of hell.
Girl sees vision of her mother in hell. She chooses to live the poor life of her father which leads to heaven.
Visions of purgatory.
Visions of Land of the Saints.
Vision of judgment. Man sees his own soul being judged.
His faith into the balance. A clerk sees his good and evil deeds being weighed. He asks them to throw his faith in Christ (the Virgin) into the scale. He is saved.
Man whose only good deed was unintentional sees this deed outweigh all his evil in the scales of judgment.
Saints have miraculous visions.
Saint incited (instructed) through vision.
Vision of the earth in the devil's snares. Saint sees earth in snares.
Non-religious visions.
Allegorical visions.
Allegorical visions religious.
Vision of chairs (thrones) in heaven. Chairs of gold, silver, crystal (glass) assigned to saints according to merit.
Wife sees moon enter mouth of husband; husband sees star enter mouth of wife: famous child (saint) will be born.

Saint sees vision of flames covering Ireland quenched except for sparks; then great light appears, dispelling darkness. Flames are those of the faith brought by St. Patrick; they become less until restored by St. Columkill.
When shower falls, small stone becomes larger, large stone wastes away. Vision of present and future state of Irish church.

Vision in which swineherd sees yew tree upon a rock, with an oratory in front of it and angels ascending from it. Vision interpreted by druid as symbolizing founding of Cashel and the royal line of Munster.
Constantine's vision of the Cross.
Vision of dry bones.
Allegorical visions political.
Vision in which chieftain sees pair of gray seals that sucked at his two breasts. They are two of his allies who are being overpowered by invaders.
Vision in which king sees whelp reared by him gather dogs of Ireland and Britain against him but suffer death in battle at last. The whelp is one of king's two foster sons.
Vision in which saint foresees allegorically the ramifications of king's family Irish myth: Cross.
Vision in which king sees his four sons changed into lion, greyhound, beagle, cur, which fight with alternating success, until lion subdues the other three.
Vision of future.
Salvation.
Sinner reformed after visit to heaven and hell.
The only king ever saved in spite of himself.
Sinner who thinks of God saved; devotee who thinks of worldly things goes to hell.
Worship of particular deity brings reward of birth in Brahma-world.
Pilgrimages.
Pilgrimage to Holy Land.
Pilgrimage to follow roads Christ walked.
Pilgrimage to Mecca.
Pilgrimage to Benares.
Pilgrimage to Jerusalem.
Intervention of Providence saves person's life.
Man is prevented from taking passage on ship which later sinks.
Man hears voice telling him to leave danger spot in mine.
d. Mdrchens I 359b s.v. "Charakter-motive".
Favorable traits of character.
Good inclinations enter body at puberty.
Kindness.
Saint never drives fly or gnat from his face.
Saint gives calf to wolf.
Generosity.
Philanthropist will give his spurs if someone will drive his horse for him. He has given away his coat, etc. to beggars. One finally asks for his spurs.
Munificent monarch.
Emperor thinks day lost when he gives no gifts.
King will not eat breakfast till gifts are given.
Man divides money into three parts: (1) for the poor, (2) for pilgrims, (3) for himself and family.
Man lets himself be sold as slave so as to practice generosity.
Brahmin steals to feed guests (deities).
Generosity toward enemy.
Ruler pardons his enemies.
Man pardons his assailants. They attack again and are killed.
Ruler pardons emissary who has come to murder him.
Wronged knight conquers enemy and then pardons him.
Conqueror returns defeated man's wife and family to him.
Conqueror spares city.
Ruler reproaches son for bringing him the head of his fallen enemy. Latter given honorable burial.
Man saved through intercession of enemy.
Man pays fine for enemy who is falsely accused.
Captor contributes to captive's ransom.
Warrior gives steed to his enemy.
Calumniated woman intercedes for accusers.
Man's life spared through the intercession of the daughter he has wronged. He has ordered her killed.
Champion grants requested boon of safe convoy to his enemies.
Chieftain spares enemies whom he takes unawares (unarmed).
Chieftain who takes king unawares, spares him on condition that chieftain be called "lover" by women of king's tribe.
Hero in battle refuses to slay charioteers, women, or physicians.
Ruler generously settles quarrel between loser and finder of money.
Nobleman's generosity enables impoverished lover to entertain his lady.
Impoverished nobleman offers wife to ruler. Latter spares her honor and aids the couple.
General sends for king so that the latter may get credit for victory.

Prince donates all including a tooth. When he has nothing left he is asked for a gift. He allows man to extract a tooth from his mouth. (Father had offered reward to anyone persuading his son to have it extracted.)
Ruler protects thief. Asks for the stolen plate and hides it so that it will not be found on the culprit.
Ruler rewards man who would curb him.

The generous correction. Ruler asks treasurer to give man 200 crowns. Treasurer makes error and puts down 300. Ruler raises sum to 400. "I can't allow your pen to be more liberal than I." Italian Novella:
King rewards knight with large sum of money. Chancellor: "If you saw such a sum it would seem large to you." King answers that it looks small and doubles it.
Novel sign of death. It is the first time that what he has given away seems too much.
Youngest brother shares wealth with older brothers who foolishly lost theirs.
Generous person refuses no man anything.
Generous king gives away his only eye.
Hospitality as a virtue.
Man (king) prefers death to loss of reputation for hospitality.
Man looks for strangers so as to bestow hospitality on them.
Woman shelters son's murderer out of charity.
Murderer goes to victim's son and asks to be killed. The son aids him to escape.
Bishop exchanges places with prisoner so as to have him return to his mother.
Envious man sets out to kill one who is noted for his generosity. He is won over by the generosity of his intended victim.
Other favorable traits of character.
Emperor friendly to everyone. Would act as he should like an emperor to act toward him if he were a common man.
Man never listens to scandal.
Man speaks no evil.
Equanimity of the comedian. When he sees his house carried off by a flood, he fiddles the whole time.
Equanimity of the enslaved unfortunate. Does not complain when beset by a series of misfortunes.
Minister always says, "It is for the best," when anything happens.
Patience.
