Gratitude.
Man weeps with gratitude to God because He did not make him hideous as toad.
Self-sacrifice.
Woman drinks poison that son may be king.
Woman sacrifices life for son's honor.
Man leaps from vessel into jaws of sea-beast so as to save remaining passengers.
Saint threatens to take place of homicide in hell unless soul is released.
Obedience.
Bravery.
King Richard leads host to victory by leaping his horse overboard.
Heroism.
Badly wounded warrior continues fighting.
Warrior refuses to delay battle in return for promise of long, happy life.
Loyalty.
Man constrained to flee with leader' s fiancie resists her blandishments.
Loyal friends refuse to fight against disgraced comrade.
Cowardly to leave battle while lord is alive.
Fakir rewarded by prince with a life of luxury in city chooses to return to his monkey friends in jungle.
Justice.
Man picked to judge bull-fight because he is "no fairer to his friend than to his foe."
Upright judge refuses a bribe: he is responsible to a higher tribunal called Conscience.
Conscientiousness.
Man never breaks his word.
Oil well digger runs out of money, leaves the country, forgetting to tell his driller. He returns fifty years later, finds the driller still drilling away.
Man keeps promise to return to be eaten by tiger: let go without harm.
Rabbi returns jewel found with bought ass. He had not paid for it.
Peacefulness.
Honor.
Prostrate soldier asks his enemy to stab him in the chest instead of the back in order to save his honor. The captor frees him and the two become friends.
Unfavorable traits of character.
Unfavorable traits of character personal.
Laziness.
Contest in laziness. Each cites instances of his laziness.
Man lets legs burn in fire rather than move them.
Man is burned to death because he is too lazy to put out spark.
Lazy man's belongings burn. He is too lazy to stop rats from playing with lighted candle.
Man too lazy to open eyes to see where fire is burning.
Three lazy beggars burn alive rather than run away from burning castle.
Mother calls to daughter to tell her that she (daughter) is standing on a live coal. The daughter asks which foot the coal is under.
Man will not lift knife to cut rope about to hang him.
Man will not move in bed when water drops in his eyes.
Man so lazy that he will not wipe his running nose. This causes him to lose prospective bride.
Man floating in river too lazy to drink. His voice is damaged.
Man too lazy to pick up berries (dates).
The lazy servant.
Lazy servant gets others to perform his duties.
Servant to call his master at daybreak:  looks into dark closet to see if it is yet light. They sleep till noon.
Servant to close door at night: leaves it open so that he will not have to open it next morning.
"If it is day, give me food; if it is night, let me sleep.". The master has told the servant to go to work.
Boy to see whether it is raining: calls dog (cat) in and feels of his paws.
Boy to see whether there is fire in the house: feels of cat to see if she is warm.
The boy eats breakfast, dinner, and supper one immediately after the other; then lies down to sleep.
Lazy boy always says that it is raining. The peasant and the boy sleep during the rain in the hay barn. When the peasant asks, the boy always says that it is still raining.
Lazy boy says he cannot walk.
Servant tells master to cover his face: no need to put out lamp.
The lazy wife.
Lazy wife in soiled dress thinks husband is bringing her a new dress from market. He is bringing a goose.
Cat beaten for not working. Lazy wife must hold cat and is scratched.
Lazy wife throws bread out of window instead of putting it back into oven.
Why he beats her. Lazy wife beaten by husband maintains that she has done nothing. That is why he is beating her.
Wife too lazy to spin. Supposed dead husband comes back to life and gives his wife a beating, because there was no shirt even in the event of death.
"Who will not work, shall not eat.". Idle daughter-in-law learns work.
Lazy husband.
Other lazy persons.
Lazy mother given shoes of cotton; son knows that she will not wear them out.
Lazy girl does not know where the spring is.
Lazy man asked direction only points with his foot.
Lazy dog wakes only for his meals.
Man in mud too lazy to take hand extended to help him up.
Lazy son-in-law: afraid of a dog.
Ruler is too lazy to stop quarrels. They lead to his death.
Man with stolen fig in his mouth submits to having cheek lanced rather than open his mouth.
Man is so lazy that he starves rather than open his mouth for food to fall in when it falls from trees.

Learning a trade in bed. Working independently, the lazy fellow spoils the materials received starts making something big, which at the end turns to nothing. For example, begins with forging a plough: this becomes an axe, the axe a knife, and knife a needle, the needle nothing.
Lazy man asks if wood is split before he accepts it as a gift.

Lazy man is being taken to poorhouse or out of town or to cemetery to be buried alive. The group take pity on him, offer him various articles to help him get started again. One offers a bushel of corn. The lazy one rises up from the bottom of the wagon or coffin where he has been lying: "Is the corn shelled?"
Lazy man misses seeing the sheriff's funeral; he is facing the wrong way as the procession passes.
Man digs three potatoes in one day: one dug, one being dug, one about to be dug.
Man weeds garden from cushioned rocking chair, using fire tongs to reach weeds.
Slovenliness.
The slovenly fiancie.
Woman becomes clean only after three washings and the use of three pounds of soap.
Rancher is not recognized by his wife and family after he has cleaned up in town at hotel.
Vanity.
Old woman reaches town before vain fop who stops to adjust clothes.
Expenditure of money for vanity.
Plain people made rulers have vain display.
Peacock admires self in mirror.
Wasp seeking fame stings courtiers: killed.
Wealthy man pretends enjoyment of good music. Told when to applaud.
Use of strange language to show one's high education.
Jackal forces all animals who come to drink to praise him like a king.
Boastfulness.
Neglected wife given trifle boasts of it.
Cowardice.
Hunter wants to be shown lion tracks, not lion himself.
Coward boasts when there is no danger.
Ass insults dying lion.
Fox insults caged lion.
Crow sits on sheep's back; afraid to sit on dog's.  Wienert FFC LVI 55 (ET 154), 106 (ST 188).
Dogs tear up lion skin: fear living lion.
Coward gloats over robber slain by another person.
Monkey safe in tree insults gorilla as "broken face".
Cowardly soldier turns back when he hears raven's croak.

Queen mother shames cowardly son and companions. "In truth, gentlemen, you do well in weeping; for since you didn't fight like men to defend your land, it is suitable that now you weep like women on leaving it."
Cowardly spider rushes at fly but hides when wasp appears.
Coward gives his purse to thief with lame excuse.
Cowardly bridegroom flees elephant and loses bride.
Illness from fear.
Swooning from cowardice.
Indecision.
The man who only tasted wine. Will not drink but gets drunk nevertheless by frequent tasting.
Gluttony.
Greedy animal eats poisoned fruit in spite of warning.
Gluttonous wife eats all the meal while cooking it.
New son-in-law given choice of meals eats all.
Pupil eats cakes given as alms for his master.
Husband eats wife's share of food as well as his own.
Disobedience.
Monk obedient only as long as work is agreeable. Always says that unpleasant work is beneath his dignity.
Petulance.
Dissatisfaction.
Hog tired of his daily food. Goes to the judge and gets better food assigned to him, but the fox cheats him out of it.
Dissatisfied fox. In kingdom of lions laments that he always gets the worst bits of food.
Dissatisfied rivers complain against sea. Say that it makes their water unusable.
Peacock dissatisfied with his voice.
Monk dissatisfied with things as he has them is admonished to take what he receives from God.
Sparrow dissatisfied with pond water wants to go to sea.
Profligacy.
Profligate wastes entire fortune before beginning his own adventures.
Inconsistency.
Prince penalizes cursing, although he himself curses.
Woman admires marvelous shot of hero which kills deer, but angers him when she begs mercy for the deer.
False modesty.

Look!. look! she cries from the barrel. A nobleman has arranged for a peasant girl to become his mistress. When he comes to take her away he cannot find her. Disappointed, he is about to depart when the girl, who has hidden in a barrel, calls out "Look!" She really wants to be found.
Curiosity.
Talkativeness.
Unfavorable traits of character social.
Greed.
Cauldron of greed.
Harlot weeps when her impoverished lover leaves her to think that she has left him his coat.
Visiting friends take everything from house of dying man.
Visitors of sick stag eat up all his provisions so that he starves.
Hospitable man impoverished by greedy guests.
Wolves devour an ox without leaving a share for the rightful owner.
Snake and weasel stop fighting in order to catch mouse.
Father-in-law sued for breach of contract because he does not die in two years as he has predicted.
Hog with broken leg refuses to tell another where peas are to be found. "I intend to go there myself as soon as I get well again."

Eats up the money. Old man before dying eats his money. In church, son wants to cut corpse open and get the money. The devil: "Don't spoil the skin." Shakes money out of the corpse's throat and takes the skin.
Thieves quarrel over booty: owner comes.
Greedy person (animal) gets hand (head) stuck in food jar.
Greedy man tries to stuff food into his nostrils as well as into his mouth.
Stinginess.
Fox spoils his food rather than divide with ape.
Man had rather be burned alive than to share food with a guest.
Stingy dead woman raises her head to correct account of laundress, who is overcharging her daughter.
Stingy man forced to share his money when he lies and says he has none.
Stingy woman will not give soup to man until she spills it. Then she says he may have the soup.
Stingy king will not hire soldiers: defeated.
Spider in stingy woman's house grows thin.
Stingy horse refuses ass little feed, though he promises much for later time.
Stingy man cancels invitations to his guests. "It is better that they speak ill of me on an empty stomach than on a full one."
Drummer drums for own wedding so as to save expense.
Stingy men love possessions so much that they wear out their feet to save shoes.
Stingy man and his servants.
Farmer gets help up early in morning for a light breakfast: a glass of water and a lantern.
Stingy farmer encourages help by promise of hot lunch. The servant discovers that the hot lunch is a mustard sandwich.
Master insists that maid whistle when she brings in the dessert. He is afraid she will eat the raisins out of the cakes.
Master insists that servants whistle as they pick strawberries so that they cannot eat any.
The stingy man and his animals.
A stranger notices that man's cows need feed, feeds them. They die of the shock of being fed.
Man who insists on using everything that is useful.
Man finds a bunghole lying around loose, has cooper build a barrel around it.
Man saves sausage skins, sends them back for refilling.
Stingy man does not eat butter; only looks at it and enjoys the thought.
Wife of stingy man prays that her husband become sick so that she can get better food.
Wife keeps half of the money she plans to give for a shrine.
Miserliness.
Miser's heart found in his strong-box.
Miserly husband spies on wife to see that she does not eat too much. Gets burned in the chimney and beaten in the bed where he hides.
Miserly husband spies on wife, lest she cook too much.
Miserly wife exposed to guests by her husband.
Man is so miserly that he never drinks wine until it becomes strong. Gets full benefit from it.
Friar so miserly that he stays in ditch three days before "lending" a hand to his rescuers.
Miser dreams that he spends some money. Strangles himself in his sleep.
Miser decides not to commit suicide. Does not want the expense of a rope.
Miser is given rope to hang himself. Miser annoys merchant so much over the price of a rope that the latter gives it to him provided he will hang himself as he plans to do.
Miser appoints himself as the sole heir of his own estate.
Miser decides to kill his pigs himself. Refuses to pay fee. Chain of circumstances make it infinitely more expensive.
Miser is rebuked by friend. "You get no benefit from your wealth." Proves his folly.
Miser dies because he will not buy a candle.
Dying miser tells son to extinguish candle just as soon as he dies.
Miser runs back home to put out lamp left burning.
Miser is kidnapped and held for ransom.
Wood dealer prays for raja's death so that he can sell sandal wood for funeral pyre.
Miser tries to reduce sacrifice promised to god.
Miser prays to enter heaven with his clothes on: gold coins sewn into undergarments.
Ingratitude.
Man dismissed after years of service with a pittance.
Usurer's ingratitude toward servant. Dismisses him and charges him for a rope which he had cut while saving the usurer from hanging.
Monster ungrateful for rescue.
Rescued animal threatens rescuer.
Man ungrateful for rescue by animal.
Crane pulls bone from wolf's throat: wolf refuses payment. "That you were allowed to take your beak from my throat is payment enough."
Lion rescued from net by rat: eats rat.
Tiger has thorn pulled by man: attacks man.
Hunter beats dog which has grown old in his service.
Dog tries to bite man rescuing him from well.
Ungrateful fox hits with tail the man who carries him across stream.
Man kills whale which carried him home across sea.
Man who has been rescued from pit tries to kill his monkey rescuer for food.
Ungrateful ape plucks feathers from heron who has carried him across water.
Ungrateful wanderer pulls nut tree to pieces to get the nuts.
Wanderers in shade of plane tree blame it for not bearing fruit.

Grateful animals; ungrateful man. A traveler saves a monkey, a snake, a tiger, and a jeweler from a pit. The monkey gives him fruit; the tiger a necklace of a princess he has killed. The jeweler accuses the rescuer before the king. The serpent saves him by biting the prince and then showing the man the proper remedy.
Man rescued from drowning kills rescuer.
Whales rescue drowning king who planned to kill them.
Snake kills ungrateful tamer.
Tiger returns rope to former captor: rewarded by having tail cut off.
Man kills his rescuer in order to collect reward.
Knight is ungrateful for rescue in battle.
Ungrateful Brahmin brings his wild goose rescuer to king as remedy against leprosy.
Ungrateful brothers plot against rescuer.
Benefactor falsely accused of theft by ungrateful youth.
Woman who saves suitor from death is later condemned to die by the ingrate.
Kind magistrate is victim of ingratitude. Gives lawbreaker a light sentence. The latter seduces the magistrate's wife.
Ruler persecutes his friends and is kind to his enemies. Is killed.
Man beheads rescuer for leaving him so long in pain.
Man ungrateful for life saved because rescuer helped others also.
Ungrateful Jew steals horse of Christian who has lent it to him.
Man beats people bearing him gifts.
Workers (builder) killed when secret building or grave is finished.
Person compared to nettle, which stings the hand that protects it.
Ingratitude from ignorance.
Man fails to feed his animal rescuer.
Man sets dogs onto bear after bear has carried him home to safety.
Man demands ever larger gifts.

Man trades an egg for a needle, demands treat of a gill of rum, the traditional reward for traders. The storekeeper gives him the rum; he asks for an egg in it. The storekeeper breaks an egg (the one he has just traded the needle for) into the rum. It has two yolks; the trader asks for two needles.
Man works his horses to death, then complains that borrowed horse overeats.
Wizard makes pupil think himself Emperor and exposes pupil's ingratitude.
Hardness of heart.
Hardhearted horse allows ass to be overburdened until it is crushed. Horse must then assume the load.
Old bullock deserted and left to die.
Man overloads and starves camel.
Man helping another across stream drops him when he learns that he has lost his high position.
Man unable to weep for hardness of heart.
Hardhearted person refuses reprieve for father's murderers.
Permission refused to drink from water tank.
The dog in the manger. Has no use for the manger but refuses to give it up to the horse.
Dishonesty.
Priest uses fortune dishonestly made to erect monuments to himself.
Inhospitality.
Love of publicity.
Three envoys debate as to which of them should be received with the greatest honor.
False pride. Son ashamed of his peasant father who brings him money. Father disinherits him.
Humble man after speaking to king disdains his own family.
Ass after associating with lion disdains his own family.
Stubbornness.
Two stubborn goats meet each other on a bridge. Neither will step aside; both fall into water.
Woman's stubbornness causes loss of chance to go on pilgrimage.
Two-facedness.
Man winks both at buyer and seller. He tries to appear friendly to both.
Changeableness.
Sister gives due honor and regard to brother only in times of his prosperity.
Jealousy.
Sheep jealous of dog because he does nothing. Do not consider that he guards the flock.
King kills architect after completion of great building, so that he may never again build one so great.
Architect kills pupil who has surpassed him in skill.
Architect commits suicide when he discovers that his pupil has surpassed him in skill.
Raven wants to be as white as a swan.
Jealous fox betrays wolf to peasant and then appropriates wolf's cave and food. Peasant kills him in a few days.
Raven jealous of partridge's way of flying.
Jealousy of Venus in the love of Psyche and Cupid.
Ruler who is jealous of his subjects' happiness prohibits their games.
The crying child. He stops crying so that after a rest he can cry louder than ever.
Violence of temper.
Man demonstrates his violence of temper. He overhears a man tell of his temper. In anger he enters and demands to know when he has ever lost his temper.
Prayer that overbearing knight's illness be increased. A little sickness has made him kind; more may make him kinder.
Temper lost from reading history. Man so angered that he refuses to pay his workmen.
Monk loses temper at cup and breaks it.
Violence of judge's temper leads him to have men given death sentence unjustly.
Insult worse than wound. The lion to the man: "The wound has healed, but the pain of harsh words still remains."
Insolence.
Contentiousness.
Extortion.
Man extorts large price for betel leaf from addict.
Envy.
Goose and turkey envious of peacock point out its ugly legs and voice.
Lack of patience.
Traits of character miscellaneous.
Active imagination.
The boy: "If I had one and then got two more, I should have three."
"I surely saw a hundred wolves (snakes).". "There weren't so many as that." "Well, what made the noise in the bushes?"
"I am not alone!". Man travelling alone through the forest at night, is afraid of robbers. He hangs his cap on a stick and keeps repeating: "I am not travelling alone, there are two of us."
Eagerness for combat.
Eager warriors go through tent wall. Warriors so eager for battle they do not take time to go out of tent door but go through the tent wall.
Warriors contend with each other until battle starts. When they agree to engage in battle, they cannot endure to be without combat.
Man will not allow food served to strangers until a man of them wrestles with him.
Host requires deed of bravery before feast is eaten.
Man will not do a woman's bidding.
Extreme prudence.
Magic help sent to enemy. Hero sends fairy healing charms to his enemy so that when they resume fighting it cannot be said he wins because of superior care.
Refusal to fight wounded enemy. Hero feels it dishonorable to fight with sorely wounded enemy, because it would be said he died of previous wounds rather than the ones hero might inflict.
Long life sacrificed that descendants may be kings as prophesied.
Thrift.
Thrifty merchant tells son that even a snake laid by will be useful.
Taciturn man.
Man is rebuked for loquaciousness when he speaks after thirty-seven days.
Moving home simple for poor man. Man is so poor that when he moves all he has to do is to put out the fire and whistle for the dog to follow him.
Humor of discomfiture.

Red pepper for the slow ass: man tries it on himself. When, on the advice of a friend, he gives the ass red pepper, the ass runs away. Then he tries it on himself. He runs so fast that he passes the ass. Arriving at home, he says to his wife, "Unload the ass when he comes. I must run through the village a couple of times more."
Man interrupted each time he tries to eat something.
Man continually interrupted from eating answers in rhymed monosyllables.
Accidental cannibalism. A man eats up the dried meat of a Jew on shipboard. It happens that the Jew is carrying his dead father back home for burial in this form.
The dream of marking the treasure. A man dreams that he finds treasure and that he marks the spot with his excrements. Only the latter part of the dream is true.
Man dreams that he is rich. Finds cat's excrements.
Pig licks sleeping man's lips: man thinks he is being kissed.
Wager with overdressed youths that servant can carry a large bucket of water upstairs. They follow and are soaked when the servant purposely spills the dirty water.
Use of itch-producing ointment.
Ridiculous nakedness or exposure.
Woman exposed to ridicule when her wig is snatched off by a monkey.
Man given ride on a hemp-dresser.
Humor of disability. Besides the motifs which follow, the entire series of motifs concerning fools (+J1700 +J2799) properly belongs here as well as where it is given.
Humor of deafness.
Deaf men and their answers.

Deaf persons: search for the lost animal. A inquires for his lost animal. B talks about his work and makes a gesture. A follows the direction of the gesture and happens to find the animals. He returns and offers an injured animal to B in thanks. B thinks that he is blamed for injuring the animals. Dispute. Taken to deaf judge.

Deaf peasant: travelers ask the way. Travelers ask their direction. Peasant thinks they want to buy oxen. Peasant's wife arrives; thinks they say her food is too salty. Daughter-in-law and father-in-law misunderstand each other.

Two persons believe each other deaf. A trickster tells each of two persons before they meet that the other is hard of hearing and must be shouted at. A great shouting takes place, and each thinks the other out of his wits.

Deaf peasant: the wedding invitation. Lord: Good morning, Peter. Peasant: I come from Bingen. L. What is the hog worth? P. Two weeks from next Sunday (the wedding). L. Shall I come to the wedding? P. Three and a half gulden.
Deaf man on the bridge. Lord: Good day, Caspar. Caspar: I am making a reel. L. Good day, Caspar. C. It is worth four pence. L. Good day, Caspar. C. Yes, my lord, whenever you wish.

The deaf man and the proud nobleman. A nobleman amuses himself at the expense of the deaf man. Finally Nobleman: I wish you a thousand gallows and ropes around your neck. Peasant: My lord, I wish you twice as many.
Misunderstood words lead to comic results. In some the people are not really deaf but fail to catch a word; in some they are deaf.
The deaf man with the bird in the tree. A traveller asks the way and the man keeps telling him about the bird he has caught. (The questions and answers often rhyme.)

Deaf man visits the sick. He plans the conversation with the expected answers. The answers turn out otherwise. A. How are you? B. I am dead. Thank God! What have you eaten? Poison, I think. I hope it agrees with you.
"Good day.". "A woodchopper." The workman answers the traveler's courtesies with remarks about his work.
Buyer and deaf seller.
The deaf parson. The youth answers unintelligibly but is praised nevertheless.
The deaf bishop. The drunken priest says, "In the morning I take a drink of rum and afterwards four or five little drinks."
Deaf litigants and deaf judge misunderstand one another.
Travelers pass through Wesley. One asks name of town; another replies, "This is Wesley." Another says, "I thought it was Thursday." Third says, "So am I; let's have a drink."
Deaf husband orders deaf wife to prepare a certain dish: misunderstanding.
Misunderstanding and quarrels in family of deaf.
Humor of bad eyesight.
The wife who saw double.
The squint-eyed son and the bottle. Sent by his father to get the only bottle of rare wine, he sees two. Not wishing to show his father to be a liar, he breaks one really the only one.
One-eyed man as appraiser of horse. Has appraised it at half a mark. "He saw only half a horse; otherwise he would have valued it at a mark."
Blind man and the bull. Man asks bull if he is on the right road. Bull butts him and knocks him down. The man says that all that was not necessary, simply to say yes or no.
Blind man reaches his home hanging on ox's tail (or in other ridiculous situation).
Nearsighted knight mistakes own servant for one of the enemy. Runs lance into his posterior.
Blind man strikes woman thinking she is buffalo.
Blind son-in-law visits his wife's family: gets into difficulties.
Blind men trying to kill pigs with clubs strike one another.
Blind man in awkward position pretends to see.
Other physical disabilities.
The wry-mouthed family. Each member has mouth turned in a different way. Unavailing attempts to blow out the light.
Man calls convention of all long noses.
The humor of stuttering.
Each of four stutterers thinks the others are ridiculing him.
Stutterer tries to give alarm. Amusing results.
Humor of ugliness.
Blind, lame, and deaf as witnesses in court.
The humor of small stature.
Dwarf king falls into porridge-pot at court of human king.
Dwarf poet forced to swim in drinking-horn of human being.
Tiny ambassador put on horse with long stirrups. Cannot say anything as he is too busy trying to keep his seat.
Short magistrate wears a high helmet.
Humor of lameness.
Lame man taken on hunt in wheel chair beats the dogs home when they tree a spook or when a bear gets after them.
Humor of bad singing.
Audience of one hired to listen to egoistic dismal-voiced singer.
Humor of fatness.
Six short, fat husbands married to six tall, fat wives try absurdly to kiss them at the threshold on their wedding day.
Fat man so unwieldly he fishes from his window in the street.
Humor dealing with tradesmen.
Jokes about millers.
Millers as thieves.
The honest miller. Baker cannot understand how a man who has been a miller can be a beggar. It is a wonder that the farmers are not beggars instead.
Priest commends the poor miller. If he had been like the rest of the congregation he would have become rich.
Why no millers in hell. A mad dog in place of a miller in a sack.
Monks get revenge on millers. Drunken millers force monks to dance. Millers are enticed to monastery and beaten.
Jokes about tailors.
Oversight of the thievish tailor. Sews the stolen piece of cloth on the outside of his coat, thinking that it is on the inside.
Thievish tailor cuts a piece of his own coat.
Thieving tailor can hide stolen cloth even in needle-and-thread tube.
Tailor always associated with goat.
Tailors cowards as warriors: go home to their needles.
Jokes about butchers.
Butcher wonders that man who has been buying his meat for seven years can still be alive.
Jokes about cobblers (shoemakers).
Ugly cobbler continually threatens to throw his last at people. The object of jokes.
Shoemaker drinks more than his portion of "drink of lies", which has been prepared for all to partake of equally.
Jokes about other artisans and tradesmen.
Jokes on weavers.
Why no weavers in hell. Devils annoyed at their noisy trade.
Jokes about barbers.
Client flees when cobwebs are brought in to medicate cuts.
Barber uses cut hair to staunch cuts.
Jokes on fishermen.
Talkativeness of the fishwives of Paris. Anecdotes of their invective.
Humor dealing with professions.
Jokes on lawyers.
What will happen when there are so many lawyers. Woman sees the crowds of students in the law school. She knows that the one lawyer in her village has ruined nearly everyone.
Beggar frightens lawyer into giving by telling him of all the lawyers in hell.
Dying like Christ between two thieves. The dying man has the lawyer and the notary stand on either side of him.
Lawyer who tries to practice without lying fails. He enters religious order and tries to conduct the legal business without lying.
Dying lawyer says, "I appeal".
Dying lawyer asks delay.
Nero has reserved place in hell for lawyers.
Lawyer thrown back into mud when rescuers learn that he is a lawyer.
Lawyer loses tongue in death because he sold it in life.
Miscellaneous jokes about lawyers.
Eloquent lawyer makes obviously guilty client doubt his own guilt.
Jokes on magistrates.
Guilty of everything connected with the seven senses. When the priest to whom he is confessing says there are but five senses, the magistrate says that he needs two more senses than other people.
Foreigner wonders why city with so many judges has not been destroyed.
Jokes on teachers.
Music teacher charges double for those who have taken music before. One fee for teaching and one for making them forget the old teaching.
Jokes on scholars.
Master of seven liberal arts begs from wagoner. With his one art latter supports his family.
Jokes on doctors.
Doctor cures palpitation of heart: patient stops breathing.
Head cut off to cure snakebite.
Eyedrops prescribed for stomach ache so that patient can see what he eats.
Foolish doctor performs useless operation.
Man with cheeks stuffed with food operated on to remove swellings.
Doctor called to attend sick man immediately gives orders for the funeral.
Jokes on parsons.
Parson put to flight during his sermon.
Sexton's dog steals sausage from parson's pocket: parson flees.
Sexton puts needle in sacramental bread: parson sticks his hand.
Sexton arranges wasp-nest so that parson sits on it. Wasps chase him.
Tame bear tied to church bells. Rings alarm.
One-eyed parson in dimly lighted church joins the wrong couples. Marries the old man to the girl and the old woman to the boy.
Parson rides ox into church. He wants to show how Christ rode into Jerusalem. Sexton sticks ox with needle.
The hog in church. Locked in church all week by mistake. When the congregation comes, the hog runs between the parson's legs and carries him out.
Parson preaches so that half the congregation weeps and half laughs. Has clothes torn in the back. Those that see this laugh. He wins the wager.
Parson smears his hand with butter. Rascals have spread butter on the altarbread. The parson preaches, "What is the life of man?" and therewith brings his hand down on the altar-bread: "Pure butter!"
Parson is to let a dove fly in the church. It dies in his pocket.
At the blessing of the grave the parson's ox breaks loose: "Now the devil has him."
The corpse with his feet cut off. The coffin-maker has fitted him to the coffin. The parson: "On the last day he will arise." One of the coffin-makers: "Did I say that?"

The devil in the cemetery. A sexton hears thieves in the cemetery cracking nuts and thinks it is the devil cracking bones. With the gouty parson on his back he comes upon the thieves who, thinking it is their companion with the sheep, call out, "Is he fat?" The sexton: "Fat or lean, here he is!"
Robbers mistake man for devil (the "sheep" speaks, "Gently, gently!")
The parson who said there is no devil. The bear-showman lets the bear climb up the pulpit. The parson thinks the bear is the devil.
If his son were only a fool he would let him study to be a priest. So says the innkeeper.
A bad year for priests: few funerals. All but the priest rejoice over the good health of the community. He bemoans his loss of income from burials.
Enmity between priests and monks: chickens and eggs. Monks eat eggs and make chickens expensive; priests eat hens and make eggs high.
The hungry parson and the porridge-pot. Overnight at the peasant's house. The hungry parson hunts the porridge in the dark, guided by a rope the sexton has given him. Series of accidents.
Stupid man tries to take honey from jug at night while visiting. Series of accidents.
The parson put out of countenance.
The large loaves need a large oven. Parson says that the loaves with which Jesus fed the people in the wilderness were as large as the mountains. The mason asks what kind of oven they were baked in.
Grace before meat. The parson asks the boy: "What does your father say when you begin to eat?" Boy: "You young devil, etc."
The boy applies the sermon. Makes a present application of the words of the parson.
"What says David?". Boy: "Pay your old debts." Variants: (a) What evil did Adam do? He (shoemaker) made my shoes too small. (b) What kind of man was Moses? He was a day laborer.
Parson "Where did the father stay?". "He stayed to hold the oxen."
Parson: Where was Christ when he was neither in heaven nor on earth?. He was in the willow-grove looking for a stick to beat those who ask foolish questions.
Names of persons in the Trinity. The priest's example: the three cows. The boy: "The Holy Ghost has just had a calf."

Sermon about the rich man. A boy rides with a rich man. Goes into church and leaves his coat lying on the sled. When the parson preaches about the rich man who went to hell, the boy calls out, "Then he took my coat along!"

The parson sings like a goat. The parson sees an old woman weeping and believes that she is touched by his singing. When spoken to she says that she has been reminded of her old goat which she has lost.

The dream: all parsons in hell. The smith tells the parson whom he has summoned that he has dreamed of going to heaven where St. Peter would not admit him before he saw a parson. There were no parsons in heaven, but all in hell.
All devout women in hell. Devout woman and a priest retell their dreams. The priest has dreamed that all the devout women are to be found in hell.
Parson and sexton at mass. Parson intones instructions to the sexton (cook) as a part of the mass.

"I can't hear you.". Rector confesses his sacristan: "Have you drunk the wine designated for the mass?" "I can't hear you." Exchange of places. Sacristan asks rector: "Have you kissed my wife?" "Really, I can't hear you."
Whistling at mass. Bell breaks and priest's patron whistles in place of ringing the bell at mass.
Parson's poor horsemanship.
Chaplain on bucking mule.
Parson refreshes himself during the sermon.
Parson takes a drink of liquor during the sermon.
Parson takes a chew of tobacco during the sermon.
Cock crows at church and the sexton awakes and begins to sing.
The parson has no need to preach. Those who know may teach those who don't know.
No need to give sermon about saint again. "Last year I told you all about his life and works. He has performed no new miracles."
The woman whose name was "Worthy.". Refuses to say, "I'm not worthy" at communion.
Chapel endowed with fifty blows for the friar.
Jokes on monks.
Bishop willing to admit castrated man as monk: wishes all were in the same condition.
Jokes on parsons miscellaneous.
Man heeds what he thinks to be call to the ministry.

Young man plowing corn sees letters "P.  C." formed by clouds. He explains situation to minister, asks to be ordained. The minister explains that the letters mean "plow corn" instead of "preach Christ".
Humor concerning other professions.
Jokes on fortune-tellers.
Fortune-teller shows others how to get rich but remains poor himself.
Humor concerning other social classes.
Jokes concerning usurers.
Barber alone praises usurer. Custom not to bury dead until someone has something good to say about him. No one will praise a dead usurer until a barber is willing to say that he had a good beard.
Usurers do not reply. The parson asks the various trades and professions to rise one by one for a special blessing. When he calls for the usurers none reply.
Devil will not carry usurers to hell but will drag them by the legs. So declares a youth paid by a usurer to protest against the priest's remarks that the devil would carry all usurers off.
Only usurers can carry the corpse of the usurer. It refuses to be moved by anyone else.
Usurer encourages sermons against usury, so that his competitors will cease activity.
Jokes concerning prostitutes.
Only prostitutes can carry the corpse of a prostitute.
Jokes concerning beggars.
Begging cripples hurry away from shrine lest they be healed and lose their livelihood.
Jokes on madmen.
Cohabitation between lunatics brought about for sport.
Jokes on secret societies.
Jokes on freemasons.
Jokes about travelers.
Jokes about hunters.
Man chased by bear to camp claims that he brought it in thus since he did not want to carry it.
Humor concerning races or nations.
Jokes concerning Jews.
How the Jews were drawn from heaven. Someone cries, "Clothes are being auctioned off in hell."
Trickster breaks up Jewish marriage ceremony and seduces the bride.
Jokes concerning other races or nations.
Battle between lice of Strassburg and of Hungary.
Learning the Bavarian language. A caretaker of an estate recently sold to a Bavarian sits among the swine so as to learn Bavarian.
Why Arabians are liars. Hermes and his wagon of lies break down in Arabia.
Jokes concerning various cities.
Blason populaire. Despiteful names used by one city for another.
Humor concerning sex.
Jokes on old maids.
Marriage forbidden outside the parish. An order is read in church forbidding the young people to marry girls from other parishes.
The old maid in bed. On one side is a bundle of straw (her husband) and on the other a dog (her child). She gives the straw bundle a push and thereupon falls on the floor herself.
A youth promises to marry an old maid if she will sit all night on the roof. She falls down.
The meal of beans. One of the old maid's three teeth breaks off.
The wolf steals the old maid. She keeps him for a husband.
The mother trains the old maid to speak properly. Absurd results.
Jokes on courtship.
Humor based on drunkenness.
Drunk man lying under his bed thinks he is lying in his shroud. Is cured of drunkenness.
Drunk man goes to the king and wants to buy an island.
Drunk man at the wedding. Goes to sleep and never reaches it, though at home he praises the wedding.
Drunk men try to see one another home. Absurd results.
Drunk man sees everything revolving and waits for his house to come to him.
Drunk woman thinks she is in heaven. Hears someone play the lyre.
Drunk recruits make war on a haystack.
Drunken volunteer firemen bungle their work.
Humor of lies and exaggeration.
One lie a year. A man who tells but one lie a year is believed because of his general truthfulness. Amusing results.
Liar comes to believe his own lie. He tells a lie so often that he believes it himself.
Lie used as catch tale.
The teller reduces the size of his lie.
The liar reduces the size of his lie when his brother steps on his toes to remind him of his lying habits.
Liar reduces the size of his yarn when challenged.
Lying contests.
Master brought to say, "You lie!"
Greatest liar made king of Schlaraffenland.
Claim of property based on unusual lie.
The liar: "I have no time to lie today"; lies nevertheless.
Boy to deceive his uncle: induces uncle to climb tree before deception begins: this is the deception.

Would not lie for a trifle. Liar tells of shooting large number of animals with one shot (an odd number, usually 99). When asked why he did not make it a round number (or an even hundred), he replies indignantly that he would not lie for one pigeon (rabbit).
Man has servant corroborate his lies. Rewards him poorly. Servant exposes him.
The second liar corroborates the lie of the first.
Lie: sea has burned up. (Often with answer: "Many fried fish.")
Other stories about liars.
The incorrigible liar.
Church member who has been called to task about his lying habits tells another lie in expressing his concern for his weakness. He says he has shed barrels of tears because of his weakness.
The liar outdoes the tricksters who try to catch him in a lie. He continues the lie the tricksters have made up to catch him.
Lie: the remarkable man.
Lie concerning birth of hero.
Lie concerning babyhood and boyhood of hero.
Lie: death of extraordinary man.
Lie: persons with remarkable bodily parts.
Lie: the large man.
Lie: remarkably tall person.
Lie: great weight of large person.
Lie: great girth of large person.
Lie: remarkably thin persons.
Lie: remarkable person's physical powers and habits.
Lie: remarkable eater.
Lie: remarkable drinker.
Lie: remarkable chewer.
Lie: remarkable spitter.
Lie: remarkable blower.
Lie: person with remarkable hearing.
Lie: person with remarkable voice.
Lie: person of remarkable sight.
Lie: other motifs pertaining to extraordinary senses or bodily powers.
Lie: remarkably strong man.
Remarkable lifter.
Whole village lifted.
Fight on old woman's hand.
Elephant (camel) put in pocket as a curiosity to show friends.
Wind blows group of persons into woman's eye.
Lie: remarkable carrier.
Lie: man ties up 700 camels in a corner of his sheet.
Lie: remarkable thrower.
Beautiful girl seated on large lotus flower holding big elephant in each hand which she devours and throws off alternately.
Lie: child throws out elephant's carcass.
Lie: remarkable catcher.
Lie: remarkable hitter or striker.
Lie: remarkable breaker.
Lie: remarkable bender.
Lie: remarkable twister.
Lie: remarkable squeezer.
Lie: remarkable pincher. Hero marks logs by pinching a piece out of end of each one.
Lie: strong puller.
Man draws sixty (300) carts of wood.
Lie: remarkable pusher.
Lie: remarkable killer.
Lie: hero responsible for topographical features (lakes, rivers, etc.).
Lie: other strong physical reactions.
Lie: hero breaking wen causes wall to fall down.
Lie: remarkable person's skills.
Lie: extraordinary bodily skills.
Lie: remarkable swimmer.
Lie: remarkable diver.
Lie: remarkable jumper.
Lie: remarkable kicker.
Lie: remarkable oarsman.
Lie: remarkable fighter.
Lie: remarkable wrestler.
Lie: occupational or professional skill.
Lie: remarkable smith.
Lie: skillful flayer. Man skins buffalo alive, turns them loose to grow new skins.
Lie: skillful axe-man.
Axe of wax cuts jungle.
Lie: remarkable logger.
Lie: remarkable rock driller. (John Henry.) Engages in contest with steam drill; he wins the contest but dies in the attempt.
Lie: remarkable carpenter.
Lie: remarkable thresher.
Lie: remarkable user of whip.
Lie: remarkable roper.
Lie: remarkable rider.
Lie: man rides unusual riding animal (lion, deer, etc.).
Lie: man rides cyclone.
Lie: remarkable cook.
Lie: remarkable mental skills.
Lie: the great inventor.
Lie: person displays remarkable ingenuity or resourcefulness.
Lie: axes ground on boulders rolling down hill.
Lie: remarkable possessions of remarkable man.
Lie: remarkable clothing of remarkable man.
Lie: remarkable bouncing rubber boots (or the like).
Lie: other extraordinary personal effects of remarkable person.
Lie: extraordinary equipment of remarkable man.
Lie: extraordinary tools of remarkable man.
Lie: extraordinary machinery of remarkable man.
Lie: remarkable buildings.
The great building.
Lie: the great kitchen.
Lie: remarkable equipment in big kitchen.
Lie: The great kettle.
Lie: help in big kitchen.
Lie: remarkable cooking in big kitchen.
Lie: remarkable baking in big kitchen.
Lie: skating with bacon to grease griddle in big kitchen.
Lie: other extraordinary foods from great kitchen.
Lie: remarkable food preferences.
Lie: extraordinary piles of garbage from great kitchen.
Lie: the great dining quarters (Paul Bunyan tales).
Lie: the great bunkhouse.
Lie: the great hotel.
Lie: the great stable.
Lie: the great stable: distance to stall. Cow has calf and the calf grows up and has calf before it can reach its stall.
Lie: other possessions of remarkable man.
Lie: great boat or ship of remarkable man.
Remarkable size of great ship.
Extraordinary man's family.
The big wedding. Giant with sixty daughters.
Lie: occupations of remarkable man.
Lie: remarkable logging operations.
Lie: remarkable manufacturer.
Lie: remarkable sawmill operator.
Lie: remarkable dairyman.
Lie: remarkable steel worker.
Lie: remarkable oil drilling operator.
Lie: the remarkable hunter.
The wonderful hunt.
The unlucky hunt.
Hunter shoots ram-rod full of ducks.
Hunter catches fish in boots while wading.
Man lays bag by fencehole and all the hares run into it.
Two hares run into each other and are caught.
Tiger lies in water with mouth open: cat drives fish in.
Large bag of frozen raccoons taken by hunter.
The rabbit-catch: rabbits freeze feet fast to ice at night.
The breathing tree. Hunter cuts down tree packed full of animals. The tree is so full of animals that a crack in tree opens as animals inhale, closes when they exhale.
Miscellaneous stories of plentiful game.
Lie: thick flock of birds.
Lie: remarkable bag of deer.
Lie: the great marksman.
Lie: the great marksman's remarkable gun.
Lie: hunter with remarkable marksmanship.
Lie: hunter shoots projectile great distance.
Lie: person shoots many animals with one shot.
Lie: ingenious person bends gun barrel to make spectacular shot.
Lie: the hunter catches or kills game by ingenious or unorthodox method.
Shooting off the leader's tail.
Hunter turns animal inside out. He reaches down animal's throat, grasps his tail, and turns him inside out.
Accidental discharge of gun kills much game. Gun kills a bird which falls on loose limb of tree, which falls on bear, etc., etc. (First ed.
Gunshot splits limb and catches feet of birds.
Hunting wolves with rod and line.
Lie: hunter's unusual experiences.
Game rolls down hill in snow; snowball builds up around game, keeps it fresh and protected until used.
Fruit tree grows from head of deer shot with fruit pits.
Tree grows out of horse and gives rider shade.
Water of stream or lake freezes just as frogs jump into lake. The frogs are caught in the ice.
Ingenious skinning of animal.
The nailed wolf's tail. Wolf's tail nailed to tree. Wolf runs away and leaves his skin hanging.
Lie: the hunter in danger.
Lie: man uses remarkable means of getting out of tree stump.
Man escapes from bear by running for a long time, from summer to winter. Bear chases man in July; he finally crosses a river on the ice. The bear falls in or stops following (in December).
Man in barrel grabs wolf by the tail and is drawn out of danger.
Animal unwittingly puts tail into man's hands and is caught.

If the wolf's tail breaks. Trickster and companion are wolf hunting. The companion goes into the wolf hole. The wolf comes. The other catches the wolf by the tail and the wolf scratches dust into the companion's eyes. "What a dust." "If the wolf's tail breaks, you will see another kind of dust!"
Man escapes from bee's nest on bear's tail.
Tigers stand on each other's heads trying to reach man in tree. His tears form a stream.
Lies about fishing.
The great catch of fish.
Lie: large number of fishermen in one spot.
Lie: fish caught by remarkable trick.
Lie: unusual catch by fisherman.
Fisherman catches fish with amazing contents.
Man catches fish with larger fish inside.
Lie: other unusual methods of catching fish.
Lie: fish caught with another's cries.
Lie: remarkable animals.
Lie: the great animal.
Lie: animals inherit acquired characteristics or conditions.
Small cart serves as back legs for crippled sow. Pigs also have these carts.
Lie: animal's food affects him in unusual way. (E.g. Pine tops: milk good for cough syrup.)
Lie: animals eat one another up.
Two wolves eat each other up so that only tails are left.
Lie: two birds swallow each other.
Lie: venom of animal (snake, hornet, bee) causes object to swell.
Snake strikes object, causing it to swell.
Lies: animals trained to respond to certain sounds: absurd result.
Animals already cooked for eating.
Roast pigs run around with knife and fork in back ready for eating.
Lie: roast hens fly, heads to sky, tails to ground.
Lies about mammals.
Lies about cats.
Lie: cat scratches out bear's tongue.
Lie: crippled cat uses wooden leg to kill mice.
Lies about wildcats.
Lies about panthers.
Lies about dogs.
Dog and other animal chase each other in hot weather.
Lie: large dog.
Lie: small dog.
Lie: weak dog.
Lie: tough dog.
Lie: ferocious dog.
Lie: fast dog.
Lie: intelligent dog.
Lie: obedient or dutiful dog.
Lie: dog with remarkable scent.
Lie: the split dog. Put back together but back legs point upwards.
Lie: greyhounds drag mill out of water.
Lies about wolves.
The wolf harnessed. Eats the horses, is harnessed and runs in the harness.
Lies about bears.
Lies about chipmunks.
Lie: the big chipmunk.
Lies about mice.
Lie: mice consecrate bishop.
Lies about rats.
Lie: extraordinary hog.
Lie: large hog.
Lie: large boar has bristles as long as pitchfork tines.
The great wild-boar. Tusks go through tree and come out on other side.
Lie: tough hog.
Hog finds dynamite supply, eats it, walks behind mule; the mule kicks the hog. The explosion kills the mule, blows down the barn, breaks windows out of house. The hog is ill for several days.
Lies about thin hogs.
Miscellaneous lies about hogs.
Lie: salesman guarantees sow to bear male, then female, then kid.
Lie: remarkable cow.
Large cow.
Cow wears church bell for cowbell.
Lie about cow's rich milk.
Cow gives so much cream that several men do nothing but skim cream.
Owner provides cow with green goggles, feeds her sawdust or snow.
Lie: cow climbs to roof.
Lie: cow puts bread in oven.
Lie: remarkable ox or steer.
Lies about strong oxen.
Man plows through stump which catches the back of his pants in cleft. His oxen continue to pull; he holds onto the plow, pulls the stump out of the ground.
Lie: the remarkable blue ox.
Lies about horses.
The great horse.
Well-trained horse.
Horse takes cattle out to pasture; brings them in by himself.
Trained horse as harvester and hunter. He rolls in the field. Oats in his flanks; club in his tail kills birds.
Lie: horses knead dough.
Lies about mules.
Lies about asses.
Lie: ass with silver nose hunts hares.
Lies about sheep.
Lie: the great Darby ram.
Lies about goats.
Lie: goat carries one hundred cartloads of grease.
Lie: goats heat oven.
The great he-goat.
Lies about birds.
Lies about crows.
Lie: crows mow meadow.
Lies about doves.
Lie: doves tear up wolf.
Lies about geese.
Lie: man carried through air by geese.
Lie: the tough goose.
Remarkable ducks.
Remarkable hawk.
Hawk flies away with geese on a line. They have been tied together as a protection.
Lie: hawk swims.
Lies about insects.
Lies about crossbreeding of insects.
Bumblebees imported to rout mosquitoes; the two insects crossbreed and have stingers on both ends.
Lies about ferocious insects.
Insects eat team of horses or mules, pitch horseshoes to see who gets what is left.
Lies about bees.
Lie: the great bee. Liar says that in a certain place bees are as big as sheep. And the bee-hives? The same as ours. How do the bees get in? (Various answers.)
Lies about fleas.
Remarkable mosquitoes.
Lie: the large mosquito.
Lie: wingspread of large mosquito.
Lie: weight of large mosquito.
Lie: mosquito's long bill.
Large mosquitoes fly off with kettle. They have drilled through kettle. Their bills are clinched inside like nails.
Large mosquitoes carry off prey.
Big mosquito with golden palace in his mouth.
Large mosquitoes miscellaneous.
Lies about ferocious mosquitoes.
Lie: extraordinary fireflies.
Lies about grasshoppers.
Lies about bedbugs.
Lies about flies.
Lie: flies build bridge.
Lies about gnats.
The tragic death of the three gnats. One of them meets his death between the horns of two struggling oxen, another because of two restless stallions, the third during a tussle between two giants.
Lies about lice.
Rag so full of lice it can move.
Lies about fish.
Lie: the great fish.
Lie: remarkable actions of big fish.
Big fish pulls man or boat.
Lie: tamed fish lives on dry land.
Dogfish act like dogs.
Crowded fish.
Lies about reptiles.
Lies about snakes.
Lie: the great snake.
Lie: remarkably long snake.
Lie: great snake is thought to be a log.
Lie: large number of snakes.
Lies about remarkable kinds of snakes.
Lie: hoop snake. Snake takes its tail in its mouth and rolls like a hoop toward its victim.
Lie: extraordinary amphibia and other animals.
Lies about frogs.
Lie: the big frog.
The great frog. Eaten by one larger and this in turn by crow.
Ferocious frog.
Lie: frog eats plowshare.
Lies about crabs.
Lie: crab hunts hare.
Lies about snails.
Lie: snail kills lion.
Lies about worms.
Lies about imaginary animals.
Lie: the side-hill beast. Animal with two short legs on one side for convenience in living on hillsides. It can walk around the hill in only one direction.
Lie: imaginary snakes.
Lie: seaserpent.
Lies about plants, fruits, vegetables, and trees.
Lie: the great vegetable.
Lie: animals live inside great vegetable, usually feeding from it.
Lie: harvesting great vegetable.
Lie: hole from which great vegetable is removed.
Lie about the fast-growing plants.
Lie: plants produce fruit in remarkably short time after planting.
Lies about fruits.
Lie: the large fruit.
Lie: the great melon.
Lie: large watermelon.
Lies about large pumpkins.
Lie: large pumpkin vine.
Lie: the great pear.
Lies about vegetables.
Lies about cabbages.
Lie: the great cabbage. (Usually matched by tale of great pot to put cabbage in.)
The great mushroom.
Lies about turnips.
Lies about big turnips.
Lies about potatoes.
Lie: large potatoes.
Lies about field crops.
Lies about corn (maise).
Lie: remarkable cornstalks.
Lie: remarkable yield of corn.
Lies about trees.
Lies about large trees.
Lie: tree bears unusual fruit.
Lie: pancakes growing on lime-tree.
Lies about flowers.
Lie: remarkable lilies.
Lie: miscellaneous plant motifs.
Lie: man raises eggs from eggplant.
Lies about geography and topography.
Schlaraffenland. (Land of Cockaygne.) Land in which impossible things happen.
Land in which highest praise parents can earn is that they marry their children when they are babies.
Blind town, its king fourfold blind.
Lie: land where all things are sold for the same price.
Mountain of grain to be eaten through on way to Schlaraffenland.
Topsy-turvy land. Land where all is opposite from the usual.
House where omens go by contraries.
The extraordinary names. A place where animals and things are designated by senseless names.
Lies about land features.
Lies about mountains and hills.
Remarkably narrow valleys.
Lies about steep slopes of mountains.
Lie: country so steep that people look up chimney to see when the cows come home.
Lies about farming on steep mountain.
Lies about mountain roads.
Crooked railroads in mountains or hills.
Mountain of unusual material.
Lie: mountain of cheese.
Lies about remarkable soil.
Rich soil produces remarkable crop.
Rich land: corn grows so fast that it pulls up its own roots.
Lies about water features.
Lies about hot springs.
Lies about remarkable underground channels.
Water passage through the earth.
Remarkable pond.
Lie: fish pond supplies both fresh fish and cooked.
Lie: remarkable river.
Lie: round river: runs in circle without outlet.
Lie: river of honey.
Lie: honey flows up high mountain.
Geography and topography miscellaneous motifs.
Remarkable road.
Roads go over roofs of houses.
Lies about cities.
Lie: Rome hanging by thread.
City into which only married and mothers may enter.
Village where rubies sell for four pice apiece.
Lies about weather and climate.
Lie: year with two summers and no winter.
Lie: year with two winters and no summer. It is winter all summer and in fall it gets colder.
Lie: mixed weather: summer in one spot and winter in another nearby.
Lies about changes in weather.
Lies about quick change from cold to warm.
Lies about quick change in weather from warm to cold.
Man freezes to saddle. Must be thawed out by the stove.
Lies about winds and storms.
Lies about the wind.
Lies about big wind (cyclone, tornado).
Lies about cold weather.
Lies about freezing.
Lie: shadow freezes.
Lie: words freeze.
Lie: frozen words thaw out in the spring.
Lie: flame freezes: startling results.
Lies about hot weather.
Lie: effect of heat on animals.
Lie: weather so hot that corn pops in fields, animals freeze to death thinking it has snowed.
Lies about dry weather.
Lie: clouds beaten by man until they promise to water his crops thrice daily.
Lie: how dry weather affects animals.
Lie: bullfrogs several years old cannot swim   have never had water to learn in.
Lies about precipitation and dampness.
Lies about fog.
Lie: shingling the fog. Man shingling building during thick fog shingles several feet of fog when he gets beyond the roof line.
Ship sails on thick fog.
Lies about snow.
Lie: fast-melting snow leaves horse dangling in air.
Lie: blue snow.
The man who sold dried snow for salt.
Lies about rain.
Lie: dry rain.
Lie: extraordinary floods produced by heavy rain.
Lie: heavy rain of boiling water melts palace.
Lies about extraordinary mud.
Lie: the man under the hat, which is the only thing seen above the mud.
Lies about climate.
Lies about healthy atmosphere.
Lie: air from healthy climate revives dying person.
Lie: place so healthful that residents shoot man to start cemetery.
Lies: logical absurdities.
Lies about numbers.
Schlaraffenland lies three miles beyond Christmas.
Absurd disregard of anatomy.
Lies about surgical operations.
New backbone for the horse made from a stick.
Lie: man's organs replaced with animal's.  (Cf. +E782.). He acts like animal.
Lies about swallowing.
Swallowed person is discovered in animal's stomach still alive.
Fish swallows a gourd fruit where people have taken refuge during rain; hawk swallows fish.
Lie: man swallowed by fish and later rescued alive.
Falcon and heron eaten by wild boar recovered alive from his body.
Person enters animal's body.
Man crawls into body of animal (after killing it) to escape cold. The animal freezes back together; man must eat his way out.
Seeing without eyes.
Digging without hands.
Man cuts off own head.
Lie: man cuts off own head and eats it.
Man cuts off own head, picks it up and replaces it.
Absurd stories about beards.
Lie: barber shaves wife's beard.
Lies about falling.
Person falls from great height without injury.
Man falls from height, goes into solid rock up to knees.
Man falls and is buried in earth: goes for spade and digs self out.
Lies about sinking.
Lie: man lifts heavy load, sinks into solid rock.
Man stays under water for long time.
Man falls through ice, has to swim two miles to come out at an air hole.
Man under the ice. Falls through ice with his horse, wanders around on the river bottom, pushes his spear through ice from below and rises to the surface.
Absurd disregard of anatomy miscellaneous.
Person swallows pin or needle; it later emerges through skin of relative.
Lie: man makes drinking water from his own skull.
Absurd disregard of natural laws.
Lies about gravitation.
Person or animal rises into the air in defiance of gravity.
Person or animal jumps back to starting place (from midair).
Law of gravity is petrified in petrified forest.
Lie: anvil swims river.
Lies about occupying space.
Giants go through small hole where plant has been torn from earth.
Lie: two bullocks go where one cannot.
Lie: 900,000 roofs on point of needle.
Absurd disregard of the nature of objects.
Lies about watches.
Watch continues to run indefinitely when lost (swallowed).
Disregard of nature of basketry.
Lie: people carry wine in baskets.
Rope of sand (chaff).
Rope of dry dust.
Absurd disregard of the nature of non-material things.
Absurd disregard of the nature of holes.
Person pulls up old oil wells and sells them for post holes after sawing them up into short lengths.
Lie: people eat the bungholes from barrels.
Absurdity based on the nature of the object.
Lies about boats with light draft.
Boat sailing over dry river bed (rice water).
Lies about stretching or shrinking.

Lie: the stretching and shrinking harness. Man driving team with wagon uphill in rain finds on arrival at the top of the hill that the tugs of rawhide or buckskin have stretched and that the loaded wagon is still at the bottom of the hill. He unhitches the horses and throws the harness across a stump. Sometime later, or the next morning, the sun comes out and shrinks the tugs, drawing the load to the top of the hill.
Man cures rheumatism: puts mosquito milk in a cat's horn, stirs it with duck's crotch.
Lie: the realistic painting.
Other logical absurdities.
Lie: deaf, dumb, blind, and lame men catch hare.
Lies concerning speed.
Lie: footless man outruns swift horse.
Miscellaneous lies and exaggerations.
Tall tales about miscellaneous objects.
Lies about loaves of bread.
Lie: the great loaf of bread.
Lie: the great egg.
Lie: remarkable railroad.
Lie about rough railroad.
Lies about slow trains.
Lies about bridges.
Lie: razor-sharp sword as footbridge.
Other tall tales.
Man in moon lets himself down.
Boy shot from a cannon.
Boy with hat of butter, clothes of paper, etc.
Man in hollow tree defends himself successfully from leopard and bear.
The boy in the hollow tree. He frightens the woodchopper who leaves behind his horse.
Lie: plow without horse or wheels.
Lie: suckling children rock mother in cradle.
Lie: child throws down a kid.
Lie: child throws down mill-wheels from one town to another.
Lie: man drowned on mountain.
Lie: man cuts ice with own head.
Lie: the hunt for the lost bee.
The over-hasty toad (beetle). Is years ascending steps. On last step falls and curses haste.
Why gypsies have no churches. They ate up their churches made of cheese and bacon.
Lie: warrior whose horse is cut in two continues to ride on the half horse.
Lie: the great noise from the bass-viol.
Formulas.
Formulistic framework for tales.
Beginning formulas.
End formulas.
Transition formulas.
Endless tales. Hundreds of sheep to be carried over stream one at a time, etc. The wording of the tale so arranged as to continue indefinitely.
Endless tale: corn carried away grain at a time.
Endless tale: hundreds of birds in snare fly away one at a time.
Unfinished tales. Just as the interest is aroused the narrator quits. "If the bowl had been stronger my tale had been longer."
Catch tales. The manner of the telling forces the hearer to ask a particular question, to which the teller returns a ridiculous answer.
Tale-teller frightens listener: yells "Boo" at exciting point.
Catch tale: teller is killed in his own story.
"Runs.". Conventional passages of set form within a tale, usually recited in a different voice from the rest.
Tale avoiding all pronouns.
Tales ending with a question.
Four brothers construct a woman. Whose is she?
Rounds. Stories which begin over and over again and repeat.
Formulistic conversations.
What makes your ears so big?. To hear the better, my child, etc.
Formulistic frameworks miscellaneous.
Game-tales. (Used as game.)
Tales filled with contradictions.
Cumulative tales.
Cumulative nonsense tales.
Chains based on numbers.
Origin of chess. Inventor asks one wheat-grain for first square, two for the second, four for the third, eight for the fourth, etc. The king cannot pay.
Wages: successive harvests from one grain of rice. Master has no fields left.

Ehod mi yodea (One; who knows?). ; Le dodici parole della verita, Las doce palabras retorneadas. The numbers from one to twelve are brought into relation with various objects, often of religious significance.
The Twelve Days (Gifts) of Christmas: 1 partridge, 2 turtle-doves, 3 French hens, 4 colly birds, 5 gold rings, 6 geese, 7 swans, 8 maids, 9 drummers, 10 pipers, 11 ladies, 12 lords.
The Twelve kinds of Food: 1 partridge, 2 turtledoves, 3 woodpigeons, 4 ducks, 5 rabbits, 6 hares, 7 hounds, 8 sheep, 9 oxen, 10 turkeys, 11 hams, 12 cheeses.
How the Rich Man paid his Servant (Ltsnen hos den rike man). A farmer pays his servant in the first year a hen, in the second a cock, goose, goat, cow, horse, .... girl. farmstead.
The forgetful man counts the days of the week. On Monday they go to mill, etc. (First ed.
Widower tells of his courtship, his marriage, and the death of his wife, all in a week.
Life story in ten hours:  "At one I was born .... at ten my child's soul was crowned in heaven."
Bird advises man to treat his lazy children as she does her young:  "In March I make my nest .... in August I have nothing more to do with my young."
"Solomon Grundy, born on Monday .... buried on Sunday."
Fly forgets her name; asks woodcutter, axe, tree, etc., in vain. Finally foal in mare's belly says her name is "fly".
Chains involving a single scene or event without interdependence among the individual actors.
Chains involving a wedding.
Pif Paf Poltrie. The suitor sent from one relation to the other for consent to the wedding.
Louse and flea wish to marry. Mosquito, toad, ant, etc. volunteer to supply the wedding feast.
Chains involving a death: animal actors.
The funeral procession of the hen. Animals one by one join the procession. The funeral carriage breaks down or the procession drowns.
The death of the cock. (Der Tod des H'hnchens.) The cock chokes and the hen seeks aid of objects and persons (stream, tree, pig, miller, baker, etc.).
The death of the little hen. She is characteristically mourned by objects and animals; e.g., flea, door, broom, cart, ashes, tree, girl.
The death of the little hen described with unusual words. Each act of mourning described by a neologism: the table untables itself.

Little ant finds a penny, buys new clothes with it, and sits in her doorway. Various animals pass by and propose marriage. She asks what they do at night. Each one replies with its characteristic sound, and none pleases her but the quiet little mouse, whom she marries. She leaves him to tend the stew, and he falls in and drowns. She weeps and, on learning the reason, bird cuts off its beak, dove cuts off its tail, etc. (First ed.
Cumulative: master to kill hen. She begs off; he goes to kill rooster .... goose, rabbit, toad, tiger.
Mourning about the dead ass (Tulsi Das): from washerman to the queen. "But who is Tulsi Das?" The report is traced back to the washerman, who says: "He was my ass."
Chains involving the eating of an object. (Members of the chain not interrelated.)
The fleeing pancake. A woman makes a pancake, which flees. Various animals try in vain to stop it. Finally the fox eats it up.

The fat cat. While the mistress is away, the cat eats the porridge, the bowl, and the ladle. When the mistress returns she says, "How fat you are!" The cat: "I ate the porridge, the bowl, and the ladle, and I will eat you." The cat meets other animals and eats them after the same conversation. Finally eats too many.
Woman meets a pig. "Good morning." "Why are you up so early?" "I am not up so early. I have drunk seven vats of milk and eaten seven plates of porridge and I shall eat you." She ate the pig.

The fat troll (wolf). A troll eats the watcher's five horses and finally the watcher himself. The master goes to investigate. The troll: "I ate the five horses, I ate the watcher, and I will eat you." Does so. Likewise the wife, servant, daughter, son, and dog. The cat scratches the troll open and rescues all.

Louse and crow make covenant of friendship:  louse eats crow despite crow saying, "If I strike you once with my beak you will disappear; how then can you talk of eating me?". Likewise louse eats loaf of bread, she-goat, cow, buffalo, five sepoys, wedding procession with one lakh of people, elephant, tank of water. A sepoy cuts louse in two with his sword and rescues all.

The singing wolf. By his singing the wolf compels the old man to surrender his cattle, his children and grandchildren, and finally his wife. The old woman goes in the wolf's service. She returns home bringing butter, etc.
Chains involving other events without interrelation of members.
The goat who would not go home. One animal after another tries in vain to persuade the goat to go home. Finally a wolf (bee) bites him and drives him home.

The goat who would not leave the hazel bush. Final formula: The devil goes to strangle the Jew, the Jew to kill the ox, the ox to drink the water, the water to quench the fire, the fire to burn the stone, the stone to blunt the axe, the axe to cut the rope, the rope to tie the hunter, the hunter to shoot the goat the goat leaves the hazel bush, the wee goat leaves the hazel bush.
There was a wee wee woman who had a wee wee cow, etc.
The crow on the tarred bridge. His beak and tail alternately stick. (Endless.)
Where have you been, goose?. In the fields. What have you in your beak? A knife. etc. (Tile, water, ox, firewood, old woman, friars, mass, shirt.)
Titmouse, what are you eating?. A large turnip etc.
Sparrow, where are you going?. To eat seed. The owner will scold you. I'll sit on a pine tree, etc.

The hen lays an egg, the mouse breaks it. Sorrowing over this mishap, all show extraordinary behavior; the master puts an end to it. Final formula: hen strips off feathers, rubbish heap catches fire, oak falls to ground, hare drowns self, magpie twists leg, ox breaks horns, river flows blood, maid breaks pails, housewife scatters dough. Master locks up wife and maid, goes to seek people more foolish.
Mother ties bell on child; cat cuts it off. "Why did you cut off the bell?" "Why did you lay the block here, etc." Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges.
Girl left in tree by sisters: asks monkey, ape, bear, and tiger to put her down or else bite her. All refuse. Panther comes and devours her.
Small grain-measure runs away when her husband beats her: succession of suitors.
Series of things acquired by mouse  "You cannot have this but you may have that instead," etc. Clod fish cakes kid goat drum girl. Girl kills mouse accidentally.
Chains with interdependent members.

The old woman and her pig. Her pig will not jump over the stile so that she can go home. She appeals in vain for help until the cow gives her milk. The final formula is: cow give milk for cat; cat kill rat; rat gnaw rope; rope hang butcher; butcher kill ox; ox drink water; water quench fire; fire burn stick; stick beat dog; dog bite pig; pig jump over stile. (Various introductions.)
Woman has meat (liver) stolen by bird. Recovery chain (similar to +Z41).
Crow must wash his bill in order to eat with other birds. Asks water; water must first have horn from stag, who must first have milk from cow, etc.
Conflict between fowl and thistle. Wind obeys and breaks the chain.

The mouse regains its tail. The cat bites off the mouse's tail and will return it in exchange for milk. The mouse goes to the cow for milk, the farmer for hay, the butcher for meat, the baker for bread. Other persons mentioned are the locksmith and the miner.
Mouse bursts open when crossing a stream. Series of helpers similar to +Z41.4.

My dog picked up a string, but did not wish to give it to me unless I gave her bread. Cupboard did not wish to give bread unless I gave it a key; smith, charcoal; charcoal-burner, calf's legbone; butcher, milk; cow, grass; meadow, water; clouds, dove's feather. Dove gave me a feather which I gave to clouds, etc.
Lending and repaying: progressively worse (or better) bargain.

Bird's pea gets stuck in socket of mill-handle. She goes to carpenter, king, queen, who refuse to help. She asks snake to bite queen, stick to beat snake, fire to burn stick, etc. Final formula: cat eats mouse, mouse cuts plant creeper, creeper snares elephant, elephant drinks up sea, sea quenches fire, fire burns stick, stick beats snake, snake bites queen, queen speaks to king, king chides carpenter, carpenter cuts mill handle, and pea is extracted. Questions in rhyme.

Gram (parched grain) sticks in post ; parrot goes to raja, etc., for help. Final formula: at last creeper took pity on birds, and elephant feared creeper, and ocean feared elephant, and fire feared ocean, and stick feared fire, and snake feared stick, and carpenter feared snake; and carpenter split post which gave up the grain to the birds, who went away.

The wormwood does not want to rock the sparrow. Final formula: the worms begin to gnaw the rods, the rods to beat the oxen, the oxen to drink the water, the water to quench the fire, the fire to burn the hunters, the hunters to shoot the wolves, the wolves to kill the goats, the goats to gnaw the wormwood, the wormwood to rock me   it rocked and rocked me to sleep.
Boy dirties his shoe and asks the hay stack to wipe it clean.

Pulling the needle out of the seamstress's hand. Final formula: That was just what the cat was waiting for it sprang to devour the mouse, the mouse to tear the spider's web, the spider to entangle the dog, the dog to eat the goat, the goat to gnaw the rushes, the rushes to grow in the stream, the stream to quench the fire, the fire to burn the stone, the stone to beat the axe, the axe soon pulled out the needle that was stuck in the seamstress's hand.

The lazy servant and the grain. "Lentils, lentils, get into my sack!" Final formula: the hungry hawk attacks the hens, the hens the worms, the worms the stick, the stick the ox, the ox runs to the water, the water attacks the fire, the fire the hunters, the hunters the wolf, the wolf the goat, the goat the willow, the willow the cat, the cat the mice, the mice the lentils, the lentils go whoosh whoosh into the sack.
Stronger and Strongest. The frost-bitten foot. Mouse perforates wall, wall resists wind, wind dissolves cloud, cloud covers sun, sun thaws frost, frost breaks foot.
The Esdras chain: stronger and strongest, wine, king, woman, truth.
Abraham learns to worship God. At nightfall Abraham worships a star, then the moon, then the sun, and finally gives up idolatry.

Brahmin worships idol and sets sacrifices before it daily. Rat devours offerings and he sets it up as his idol as a being more powerful than his idol. When cat devours rat, he worships it instead. His wife accidentally kills the cat, so he sets her up to worship. He happens to slap her and she loses consciousness. Thereafter he worships himself as most powerful after all.

The cock's whiskers. A mouse throws a nut down and hits the cock on the head. He also steals the cock's whiskers. The cock goes to get an old woman to cure him. The final formula is: Fountain give up water for forest, forest give up wood for baker, baker give up bread for dog, dog give up hairs to cure the cock. (Variant: mouse loses tail.)

Toad asks magpie in tree to throw down a chestnut. Magpie refuses, saying it might break its beak. Toad promises, if that happens, to get a horsehair to tie it up again. Magpie throws chestnut and breaks beak. Toad asks ass for hair, but ass first demands grass; mower demands sheep; shepherd, pup; mother dog, bread; baker, stumps. Toad cuts the stumps and gets the hair.

The cock strikes out the hen's eye with a nut. The cock blames the hazel bush for tearing its knickers, the hazel bush the goat for gnawing at it, the goat the shepherd-boy for not tending it, the boy his mistress for not baking him a bun, the mistress the pig for eating up the dough, the pig the wolf for killing its young.
Nut hits cock in head: he thinks world is coming to an end. He sends the hen to tell the duck, the duck to tell the goose, etc. Final formula: Fox, who told you? Hare. Hare, who told you? Goose, etc.
Fly frightens snake; snake frightens rats; rats frighten monkey, etc.
Boy changes self to nut; fowl eats nut; bush cat eats fowl; dog eats cat; dog swallowed by python.

Man invites animals to come and work in his field. Rooster kills beetle; cat kills rooster; dog kills cat; leopard kills dog; hyena kills leopard; buffalo kills hyena; elephant kills buffalo, and lion chases elephant so that both fall into trap. Man calls wives to see meat he has killed.

The house that Jack built. Final formula: This is the farmer that sowed the corn that fed the cock that crowed in the morn, that waked the priest all shaven and shorn, that married the man all tattered and torn, that kissed the maiden all forlorn, that milked the cow with a crumpled horn, that tossed the dog, that worried the cat, that caught the rat, that ate the malt that lay in the house that Jack built.

The house the old man was to build. The woman for whom he is to build the house has some beans for him. The goat eats these up. Cumulative search. Final formula: Smith give me my iron, iron which belongs to the man, man who ate up my fish, fish which belongs to the sea .... sea shirt washerwoman soap woman wood   press   grease   herder   cheese-frame   fig-tree  horn goat beans.
The Horseshoe Nail. For want of a nail the shoe was lost, for want of a shoe the horse was lost, for the want of a horse the rider was lost .... and all for the want of a horseshoe nail.
The climax of horrors. The magpie is dead. Overate on horseflesh. Horses dead? Overworked at fire. House burned down? etc. (First ed.
Series of trick exchanges.
Series of trick exchanges: razor pot bride drum by tricky fox. Fox sings formula of exchanges.
Miscellaneous interdependent chains.
"I killed my grandmother because she refused to cook a hare. I killed a priest because he said my crime was bad. A friar absolved me to avoid being killed."
Cumulative pursuit. Boys get help. One of them injures the helper. Pursued. Hidden by kind hen. One injures the hen. Hen pursues, etc. (First ed.
Fat mouse cannot get into hole. "Carpenter, please pare off a little flesh from my ribs." Refused. Final formula: the scythe cuts the creeper loose.

The bird indifferent to pain. A man catches a mango-bird eating mangoes and strikes it against the roots of a mango-tree. The bird cannot be made to say it suffers from the blow. In turn, he puts it in water, strikes it on the ground, a stile, a door-frame, singes its feathers, cuts it up, cooks it, and eats it. The bird always expresses indifference in a cumulative rhyme. At last the bird asks him to look out of the window, whereupon it flies out of his nose and the man dies.
There was once a woman; the woman had a son; the son had red breeches; etc. At last: "Shall I tell it again?"
Where is the warehouse?. The fire burned it down. Where is the fire? The water quenched it.

"Where is that grain?". "The cock snatched it." "Where is that cock?" "He drowned in the sea." "Where is that sea?" "It is grown over with reeds." "Where are those reeds?" "The maids have cut them down", etc.
The wolf who wanted to make bread. The farmer explained to him how bread is made. He keeps on asking: "Shall I then be able to eat?" Decides he will not have enough patience to make bread.

Trial among the animals. Deer steps on kitten: cat investigates. Deer has been frightened by bird, this bird by another bird .... by crab's pointed claw, crab by mouse in his hole. Cat eats mouse. (Frog croaks because turtle carries his house on his head; turtle carries house because firefly is bringing fire; firefly brings fire because mosquito tries to bite him, etc.) (First ed.
Birds fight and cause series of accidents to other animals and people.
Bite (prick) causes series of accidents.

Man sharpening his dao is bitten by a prawn. He cuts down a big bamboo; a fruit falls from bamboo and strikes a bird on the nape of the neck; the bird scratches up an ant's nest with his feet; the ant bites a wild boar in the eye; and the boar bears down upon a plantain tree where a bat dwells under a leaf; the bat seeks refuge in the ear of an elephant, and the elephant kicks down the house on an old woman. She rushes out and falls into a well.
