Cumulative tale: bird who seeks carpenter to release young caught in closed tree. Beetle bites calf, calf bites cow, cow hoofs carpenter, carpenter beats wife, hunters save carpenter's cow, carpenter releases birds.
Biting a grain in half. Final formula: Forester attacks bear, the bear the wolf, the wolf the dog, the dog the cat, the cat the mouse, the mouse the grain the grain is bitten in two.

Pulling up the turnip. Final formula: The mouse holds onto the cat, the cat holds onto Mary, Mary holds onto Annie, Annie holds onto grandmother, grandmother holds onto grandfather, grandfather holds onto the turnip they all pull and pull it out.
Lizard eats cricket, frog eats lizard, snake eats frog, eagle eats snake, man shoots eagle; animals escape except lizard. Man takes eagle home.
Who is guilty of the accident. (One person blames another who blames another, etc.) India:
Wall in construction collapses. Finally the king finds out that the sea is guilty. (The chain: mason cement mixer beautifully singing woman pearl necklace jeweller diver sea.)
Thief breaks foot climbing wall to rob. Suit against owner for dangerous wall.
Hermit must get cat to kill rats in hunt, cow to give cat milk, etc.
Chain of killings: bulbul destroys flower and is killed by cat; cat shaken by dog; dog killed by boy; boy sentenced to death by king.

The little old lady who swallowed a fly. She swallows a spider to eat up the fly, a bird to eat up the spider, a dog to eat the bird, a cow to eat the dog. "The little old lady swallowed a horse she died, of course."
Cumulative tales miscellaneous.
Chains involving contradictions or extremes.
The house is burned down. That is too bad. That is not bad at all, my wife burned it down. That is good. That is not good, etc. (First ed.

Bird avenges caged mate. Builds cart, yokes frogs to it, arms himself with piece of reed, and proclaims war with king. Collects cat, ants, rope, club, and river. He is put by king into fowl house; cat eats up fowls. In stable rope and club beat up horses. In elephant-house ants get into their brains and kill them all. Tied to king's bed, river floods king in his bed. King gives bird back his mate.
The animals with queer names: as hen (henny-penny), cock (cocky-locky), goose (goosey-poosey).
Other formulistic motifs.
Never. Various ways of expressing this idea. When black sheep turn white, when a dry branch sprouts, etc.
Never. "Till Ogham and pillar be blent together, till heaven and earth, till sun and moon be blent together."
Forever. "A day and a night."
Butterby Church no church at all. If person says he has gone to Butterby Church, he has not gone to church.
"He struck him such a blow that he remembered the milk he drank on the sixth day after he was born."
Proverbial simile.
The old and the new keys. Hero marries his first sweetheart according to the proverb that the old key is better than the new.
"Bridegroom like the sun and bride like the moon."
Formulas signifying fruitlessness,  e.g. like putting a withe about sand, like mocking a beggar.
Three explanations. When explanation of phenomenon is asked, three explanations are offered of which the last is always the true one.
Proverbs.
Proverb: one man for worship, two men for cultivation of a field, three men for a journey.
Color formulas.
Red as blood, white as snow. Often from blood on snow as a suggestion, a wish is made for a child (wife) with skin like snow and cheeks like blood, etc. (Sometimes black as a raven.)
Red as blood, white as snow, (and black as a raven). Usually applied to the cheeks, skin, and hair of a girl's lover.
Series: white cock, red cock, black cock. These crow at dawn and scatter ghosts.
Formulistic numbers.
Odd numbers  formulistic.
Formulistic numbers: a number plus one  (101, 1001, etc.).
Formulistic number: three.
Triads.
Formulistic numbers: threefold (e. g. three times thirty).
Formula: three days and three nights.
Three chairs in heaven for three saints.
Three strains of (fairy) music.
Three things that lead to hell (heaven).
Three innocent children: Ananias, Zacharias, Misael.
Three Lents.
Three Maries.
Three orders of Irish saints.
Three seas surrounding the earth.
Three sods that none may escape: "The sod of his birth, the sod of his death, the sod of his burying."
Three whom Christ raised from the dead.
Three spiritual gifts of God.
Three persons who spoke immediately after birth.
Three weak things that are the strongest.
Three worst things in Ireland.
Three reasons why men should condemn wealth.
Three cries of the world.
Three bad stories of the saints of Ireland.
Formulistic number: four.
Formulistic number: fourfold  (e.g. 400, 4000).
Formula: north, south, east, west. (The cardinal directions.)
The four elements.
The four humors.
Four places that cleanse the soul.
Four categories of souls at Judgment.
Four things that prevent the holy life.
Four things to which the glory of the world is compared.
Sending four messengers with four winds.
Formulistic number: five.
Formulistic numbers: fivefold (e. g. 50, 500).
Five sighs we should vent over our sins.
Five wounds of Christ.
Formulistic number: six.
Formulistic number: sixfold.
Formulistic number: seven.
Formulistic numbers: sevenfold (e. g. 49, 70, 70,000, 7,777).
Seven brothers and one sister.
Journey beyond seven seas.
Seven year's peace with no killing of men.
King for seven years.
Exile for seven years.
Seven as a number in religious and social records.
Seven causes of poverty.
Seven Deadly Sins.
Seven ecclesiastical orders.
Seven grades of wisdom.
Seven joys of the Virgin Mary.
Seven masses necessary to free soul from hell.
Seven orders of poets.
Seven gifts of God (Holy Spirit).
Seven penitential psalms.
Seven prayers of saint.
Seven to whom alms should be given.
Seven fair rivers in Inis Eidheand (Eden) in the East of Africa.
Seven daughters of Humility.
King with seven wives and seven mares. The seven wives pregnant for seven years, the seven mares seven years in foal.
Seven brothers marry seven sisters.
Formulistic number: nine  (99, 900, 999, 99,999, etc.).
Three times nine.
Nine whirlpools of the world.
(Nine) wonders of Ireland.
Nine materials used in building Tower of Babel.
Formulistic number: eleven.
Formulistic number: twelve.
Twelve articles of faith.
Twelve abuses of the world.
Formulistic number: "twice twelve years".
Formulistic number: twelve plus thirteen.
Formulistic number: twelve score.
Formulistic number: twenty-four.
Formulistic number: thirty-six.
Formulistic number: thirteen.
Formulistic number: sixteen.
Formulistic number: thirty.
Formulistic number: forty.
Formulistic number: sixty.
Formulistic number: seventy-two.
Formulistic number: seventy-seven.
Formulistic numbers miscellaneous.
Formulistic number: eight.
Eight deadly sins.
Eight virtues.
Eight miracles of Christ's body in the sacrament.
Eight unprofitable types of fasting.
Formulistic number: ten.
Ten plagues.
Formulistic number: twenty-five.
Formulistic number: twenty-six.
Formulistic number: thirty-two.
Formulistic number: eighty.
Formulistic number: sixteen hundred.
Formulistic number: eighty thousand.
Formulistic number: fifty-two lakhs.
Formulistic number: fourteen.
Formulistic number: fifteen.
Fifteen characteristics of a good (bad) woman.
The fifteen Oes.
Fifteen signs before Doomsday.
Formulistic number: seventeen.
Formulistic number: twenty-one.
Formulistic number: twenty-two.
Twenty-two rooms and twenty-two doors built by skillful carpenter.
Formulistic number: fifty-three.
Formulistic number: fifty-six.
Formulas based on the year.
A year and a day.
Seven years, seven months, seven days.
Seven (three) years between feasts.
Seven years as length of course in school.
Every third year as period of tribute.
Three hundred and sixty-five.
Twelve years and thirteen days.
A day and a night.
After four days another two days another day.
Formula: as many children as holes in a sieve.
Formulistic exaggerations.
Three-fourths of men of Ireland die in one night.
Testament willing rewards and punishments. Conventional ending of a story.
Formulistic rimes.
Blowing the house in. I'll huff and I'll puff till I blow your house in.
Miscellaneous formulas.
Formula for other world: "Where no man goes and no crow flies."
Formulas of distance.
"A tree on island beyond the seven seas and the sixteen rivers."
Symbolism.
Names of giants (Fomorians) with sinister significance.
Personifications.
Death personified.
Death enclosed in a bottle.
Death imprisoned by a soldier in a magic knapsack, bottle or nutshell.
Death magically bound to tree. While he is bound no one can die.
Death stuck to tree.
Death (demons) glued to chair.
Death as eight-headed monster.
Death allegorically personified as an animal made up of several different animals.
Death excluded from sacred grove.
Death (fate) assumes various forms to destroy men.
Death's messengers.
Death's messengers bribed with food.
Salt in food given Death's messengers renders them harmless.
Sickness personified.
Fever personified.
Life personified: old woman carrying healing potions and salves.
Old age personified.
Wind personified.
Man takes case against wind for damages. Wanting to have nothing to do with a court, the wind generously makes good the damages, and punishes the judge guilty of bribery.
Sovereignty personified.
Empire personified.
Poetry personified.
Sea personified.
Waves as tresses of sea-god's wife.
Waves as sea-god's horses.
River personified (Mother Ganges).
Truth personified.
Truth leaves city because there is no place left for her.
Time personified.
"Time" overpowered when weight is taken from his clock.
Mother of Time personified.
Twelve months as youths seated about fire.
The four seasons personified.
Fury personified.
Fury personified as demon which enters man's heart and counsels evil.
Valor personified.
Valor personified as bird which flutters over champion's head.
Virtue personified.
Energy (strength) personified.
Sin personified.
Sin personified as the goddess Venus with her train of nymphs.
Lust personified.
Wisdom personified.
Intelligence personified.
Falsehood personified.
War personified.
Battle carnage personified.
Victory personified.
Defeat personified.
Poverty personified.
Poverty personified as diseased beggar woman.
Fortune personified.
Fortune personified as a matron in fine clothing.
Adversity personified.
Civilization personified.
Personifications miscellaneous.
Sloth personified.
Crime personified.
Wine personified.
Wine personified in person of the god Bacchus.
Cold personified.
Cold depreciated and praised. Depreciated, takes revenge by becoming colder; praised, makes reward, gives clothing.
Worry personified.
Modesty personified.
Ladder as symbol of upward progress.
Ladder to heaven as symbol of saint.
Virginity, Wisdom, and Prophecy personified as three beautiful maidens.
Color symbolism.
Color of flag (sails) on ship as message of good or bad news.
Colors corresponding to the four world quarters.
Color symbolism of the cardinal points.
Symbolism of colors in mass vestments.
Bridegroom inadvertently buys for bride cloth suitable only for widows. She supposes he has died.
Symbolic color: red.
Red garment to show anger of king.
Red as symbolic of martyrdom.
Martyrs called "red wheat"; saints, "Dei triticum" (God's wheat).
Mill in which two men are slain said to grind "red wheat".
Red as symbol of falsity.
Symbolic color: white.
White rose the symbol of death.
White as symbolic of martyrdom.
Symbolic color: black.
Black as symbol of grief.
Symbolic color: blue.
Blue as symbolic of martyrdom.
Symbolic color: green.
Green as symbolic of martyrdom.
Symbolic color: brown.
Brown hair as sign child is descended from goddess.
Symbolic color: purple.
Purple is symbol of royalty.
Yellow a lucky color.
Other symbols.
Ring broken as token of broken engagement.
Princess crushes lotus-flower to show that she will be submissive.
Gray hair the symbol of departed usefulness.
Cloud (mist) as symbol of misfortune.
Olive branch symbol of peace.
Symbolism: not to fight alone. Various figures employed to show it is not good for one warrior alone to fight the battles of a host.
Arthur's Round Table symbolic of round earth.
Message or orders given symbolic action.
Inverted shoes at doors to indicate banishment.
Black dummy to indicate banishment.
Sign language. Message delivered by means of the fingers, etc.
Language of flowers.
Lovers' assignation by symbolic messages.
Symbolism of the mass.
Lamb as symbol of Christ.
Allegorical game. Witch, aided by dragon (lion) is vanquished by maiden, aided by lamb (ram). Witch is devil; maiden, church of Christ.
Nudity as sign of anger.
Nudity as sign of madness.
Symbolic wounding of king.
Symbolic names.
Three trees called "Grief," "Dark," and "Dumb-Mouthless Oak."
Symbols of divinity.
Mill turned by the water of the grace of God as symbol of saint.
Symbolism: needle and thread sexual intercourse.
Heroes.
Brothers as heroes.
Warriors identically equipped (brothers).
Lodge-Boy and Thrown-Away as joint adventurers. Of brothers (sometimes twins taken from body of slain mother) one is abandoned and becomes wild. Later he joins his brother.
Dreadnaughts. Brothers deliberately seek dangers they have been warned against. Triumph.
Hero "son of seven mothers". Seven mothers each with a child imprisoned. Six eat their children to keep from starving. Seventh does not. He rescues all the mothers and becomes hero.
Supernatural origin of hero: magic conception.
Eldest brother as hero.
Extraordinary exploits of hero.
Boyish exploits of hero.
Hero with extraordinary animal companions (cock, goat, cow, horse).
Boy hero.
Hero at first nameless.
Fool as hero.
Destined hero.
Hero born out of wedlock.
Beardless hero.
Giant heroes.
Death of hero.
Return of the hero.
Unique exceptions.
Unique vulnerability.
Achilles heel. Invulnerability except in one spot.
Left eye only vulnerable spot.
Spot below right ear only vulnerable one.
Leprosy cured by holy water except on thumb.
Man can be injured only in armpits.
Unique deadly weapon. Only one thing will kill a certain man.
Person can be killed only by red-hot spits being thrust through soles of his feet.
Giant ogre can be killed only with iron club he carries (with own sword).
Unique source of weakness.
Unique bait for fish.
Vulnerability only by one person.
Only one person can overtake hero.
Sword which will break in only one peril: this known only to the maker of the sword.
Ogre vulnerable only when his face is turned away when he is struck.
Only one way to besiege certain city.
Object will fit only one thing (or person).
Ring fits only one person.
Only one ferule fits certain staff.
Vessel from which nothing can be drunk save through certain tube.
Other unique exceptions.
Only one person refuses to weep at hero's death.
All trees except aspen refuse to make Christ's cross.
All snakes but one placated by music. In snake den prisoner fails to placate one snake and loses his life.
Unique survivor. Only one person left from destruction of his community.
